text: Fairly malty. Lovely deep amber color. Noticeable Belgian yeast funk going on. Not unpleasant, though. Complex and some subtle spice.
Complex and tasty. Spices, dark fruits, dark fruits, and brown sugar. Smooth with a full body.

Bottle at a share. An excellent example of a really under-brewed style. This nails the sweet, raisin malt and Belgian yeast interplay of some of the best dubbels. Complex and heavy, but worth sipping slowly on a cold night.

Bottled 1/14/13, consumed 9/11/16.

Cloudy light mahogany, minimal tan head. Nose of deep molasses, raisin, allspice. Dark fruitiness. Lightly bitter, spicy. Muted, mellow sweetness. Medium to heavy body, creamy, smooth mouthfeel. Long finish. Everything blends together beautifully. Undertone of alcoholic sharpness. This aged remarkably well. Excellent.

UPDATED: AUG 12, 2016 Smells like apples...very nice, taste is very malty and heavy medium sweet...smooth and low hops...some complexity but not crazy amount...finishes like apple cider for a second...but aftertaste isn?t great...kinda bitter...lip smacking...hard to place...Had at Noras for D&D
2011 bottle. Pours a hazy brown color. Aroma and taste are bready malts, toffee, and brown sugar.
Clear light brown with orange tints. Sweet aroma of candies and raisins. Body is light and sweeter than I would expect. Light spice with a lingering finish.
Aroma of prunes, raisins and malt, pours a cloudy reddish brown color. Heavily carbonated. A full bodied feel a boozy malt taste with notes of plums and prunes.

Plenty of plums, figs and raisins. Delicious.
Cerveja muito saborosa, com notas de frutas vermelhas maduras, ameixas, figos e passas.

Sidder og hygger med denne øl, efter at have fået en almindelig dåseøl. Den giver nok lidt til øllen i den positive retning.
Let spritet, lidt brændt smag. Eftersmagen er efter min mening lidt for brændt. 
Har ikke helt fylden til at smage af "rigtig Belgien".
The aroma is caddy sugar, fruit, spice. The color is light brown. The taste is like the aroma. The palate is smooth. Overall enjoyable.

Solid malt, full palate, candy sugar, dark fruits, dates, figs. Low on hops but the malts is the superior flavor. It's perfect for a winter drinker

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

I didn't take any extra notes when I tried this beer for the first time but I'm gonna try it again and update my comments.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: NOV 3, 2015 Bottled: 13 Nov 2013, Alc. 8.7% by Vol. Pours a clear light brown with a small khaki head. Head retention is poor. AROMA: malty, caramel, roasty, bread, alcohol, earthy funk, raisin, candied sugar, honey, brown sugar, floral, dark stone fruit, spices, herbal hops, soda, light coffee, woody, herbs and Belgian yeast strains. TASTE: caramel, candied sugar, roasty, malt, soda fiz, alcohol, light coffee, herbs, spices, herbal hops, raisins, earthy funk, bread, Belgian yeast strains, spices, dark stone fruit, honey, woody, molasses and slight hay. AFTER TASTE: malty, caramel, molasses, soda, honey and light spices with a smooth light body finish.                     Bottled: 02/25/2011. Alc. 8% by Vol. Similar to 2013 release but everything is more balanced and smoother. Some aromas and flavors have mellowed but are still present. Not as much spice as 2013 however it has good caramel sweetness and pleasant earthy funk. There is a slight tartness but nothing to harsh. I do prefer the flavor profile found in 2013 but this 2011 is easy to drink and enjoy.

구스아일랜드 브루잉 - 페어 쟈크 2013 8.7% ABV 쉽게 마실수 있지만 매우 복잡한 것들을 한데 담고 있는 좋은 맥주. 점액질의 뭉클한 액체가 꽃꿀의 달콤한 내음을 풍기며 잔바닥으로 떨어진다. 

홍차잎의 향기, 복잡한 풍취의 꽃내음, 케러멜, 토스티 함, 약간의 넛맥류의 향신료의 스파이시함, 이것저것 솟아오르는 기운에 어느새 젖어드는 달콤한 알코올 기운. 벨기에산 이스트를 사용한 벨지안 스타일 에비 에일. 사진으로는 잔이 약간 에러.

최대 5년까지 보관하여 마실수 있으며 물론 보관 기일에 따라 디테일이 변화한다. 아무래도 오래될 수록 복잡도 보다는 조화로움에 더 기울어지지않 벨기에의 그것에 비하면 가볍지만 상당히 고급스런 맛과 외관의 맥주. 다시 마실 기회가 생기면 좋겠다.

https://twitter.com/M
From the bottle. Delicious, smooth, very malty and fruity with a slight rose aroma. Very easy to drink, hard to notice the alcohol. I'd enjoy this any time.

Bottle.
Aroma: prune, dough, caramel, 
Appearance: Hazy dark apricot color. minimal head, 
Taste: medium sweetness,   not syrupy, prune/raisin, heath bar, lightly bitter, lightly sour, good balance.
Palate: average carbonation, medium body, mild hop finish
Very nice Ale, will be my go-to for this style

2012 vintage, 2 years aged.
Caramelized malt and maple sugar. Great roundness and no trace of alcohol. Long sweet bitterness and hint of hops. Very nice.

Hazy,Brown/reddish color with thin off-white head. Aroma of raisins, fruits , belgian yeast , malt. Moderate sweetness in rich, malty taste with notes of caramel , dark fruits , brown sugar. Semidry finish , probably because my bottle was dated by 2012.

Old rating. Bottle from Old Town. Bready malts, prune, raisin, molasses and brown bananas on the nose. Some spice present as well. Sweet and bitter on the palate. Slightly sweet and dry finish. Not great but not bad.

Tap (a rarity) at 3 Squares. Flared 10 oz pilsner glass. Cloudy deep orange, nearly red. Minor head. Aroma is definite Belgian. Sugars come through and a little dark fruit too. Taste is simply amazing. Dark fruit without the sour element. Beautiful sugars give way to a bite and hit of alcohol. Very smooth overall. Im almost at a loss for words. So good. A very close approximation of the Belgians Ive sampled in Brussels, Ghent, and Bruges.

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2015 From bottle. Label is 2012. Pours a hazy brown with a small off-white head. Rich fruity aroma and flavor of raisins and prunes and medium to dark fruits. Delicious with a gentle sweetness and very very smooth. Medium full mouthfeel, soft carbonation. One of the nicer beers. Just lovely.

Pours a dark golden caramel color with a pretty hue. Regular foam that lingers for a while, protecting a yeasty aroma.

Good feel in the mouth, complex, earthy and roasty. It is a great interpretation of an Abbey beer. 

Will definitely but several to cellar.

2013 label, enjoyed in 2015. Bottle pour into Goblet. Fruity aroma with caramel depth and alcohol is noticeable but not overbearing. Deep red-brown color. Small head disappears quickly and leaves little lacing. Sweet heavy taste is like a good barley wine, and is very pleasant. Has a fizzy but soft carbonation and a smooth lingering finish. Alcohol noticeable in the lingering finish but with the deep sweet aftertaste it is not at all unpleasant, especially to someone who knowingly buys an 8.7% beer. Overall very enjoyable and goes great with rich and savory foods.
Bottle pours a murky dark amber with off white top. Nose of fruit and candy. Tastes from malts to yeasty to fruit and candy.

Dark amber, clear, tall, tan head. 
Very full body, well flavored, well balanced and big mouthfeel, high alcohol heat, avg length, fruity but clean finish. 
Sweet, understated but sufficient bitterness, acidity in good balance with the other tastes. 
Malty, more like a tripel, grade B maple syrup followed by hoppy bitterness, barley candy, cola, caramel, touch of roast grains, very alcoholic flavor. 
Delicious, elephant of a beer. 


---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Shared 355 ml bottle, vintage 2010, from Voldby Købmandsgaard. ABV is 8%. Amber to brown colour. Oxidised malty aroma, reminds me a bit of Thomas Hardys Ale. The malty flavour is better, somewhat oxidsed but still nice, notes of oak and dark dried fruits, not very sweet though.

Flaske (årgang 2010), på rbhd-samlinga feb-15: vi nærmer oss slutten, men stemningen fortsatt preget av optimisme og entusiasme, tross mange middelmådige og noen katastrofale øl. Rødlig kobberfarge med svært kort skum. Vinøs aroma og smak - rosiner, kandis, fiken, svisker. En god og typeriktig dubbel.

Shared bottle at RBHD Bjørnøy February 2015. Vintage 2010. Hazy orange body with a tanned rim. Pungent sweet rock sugar, Belgo yeast on the nose. Heavy sweet malty with notes of dried fruits. Full bodied.

Shared bottle at RB/HD at Bjørnøy 07.02.15. 2010-vintage. Dark orange. Dark beige head. Oranges, sweet orange marmelade, orange flavoured biscuits and candy sugar in aroma. Good taste, with round mothfeel.

Shared bottle at local tasting. 2010. Pours hazy nut brown with a tiny white head. Aroma of bready malts, toffeeand sugars. Taste is moderate sweet, with some spicy malts,dried fruits, ok, but maybe a bit oxydiced.

Bottle. 2009. Pours dark red, little bit hazy, almost no head. Aroma is sweet, dark fruit, raspberries, plum, raisins, brown sugar. Taste is of more dark fruits, orange peel, plum, a sherry-like sweetness. Light carbonation, oily medium body.
это пиво очень вкусно. я бы, конечно, рекомен& его всем. пожалуй& обратит& его. очень хорошо!

Bottle from ABC. Pours a very dark brown with almost no head or lacing. Aromas are strong malts - toffee, caramel, molasses. Some dark fruits as well, with a solid yeast backbone. Really quite complex on the nose. Taste is sweet, full bodied, and long on the finish; quite boozy as well. Pretty creamy on the way down. Acquire.
way solid double....2012 vintage....really fantastic...wow.......i will buy again and again......

10 ounce sample on tap at The Davis Beer Shoppe. The aroma is fruity, sweet, and full of caramel. Plenty of yeast esters here. Mostly hazy amber body with a medium to large off-yellow head. Good lacing. Starts quite sweet and sugary with Belgian Candi Sugars. There is a bit of a dusty yeast flavor in the middle. Finishes with caramel and toffee. Very easy drinking. A little too sweet.

April 2012 bottle opened for the new year of 2015.
Pours hazy amber brown with copper highlights, thin beige head that leaves trace lacing.
Big nose: sweet malts provide raisins, cherries, blackberries, figs, caramel with a touch of earth and a hint of spice.
All that continues in the glass with slight touches of nuts, hop bitterness, brown sugar and mild alcohol heat. Big, smooth, creamy mouth with low-medium carbonation.
Under AB-InBev, Pere Jacques continues to demolish most American craft beers. This is a step below Rochefort or St. Bernardus, but it is not embarrassed by being mentioned in the same sentence.

Bottle. 2010. Hazy brown liquid with small to medium light tan head. Aroma of bread, toast, dried fruit, light booze, earth and raw sugar. Taste is light to medium sweet and light bitter with notes of raw sugar, port wine, dried fruit and toast. Medium bodied with medium to high carbonation. Pretty nice but maybe a bit old.

2011 bottle. Butterscotch appearance, sugary spice yeast aroma, love that it 
retained some carbonation,

UPDATED: DEC 24, 2014 Bottle: Dark amber-copper body, slightly hazed & topped with a thin beige film thats rounded out by a modest ring. Aroma is largely sweet, loaded with residual Candi sugar & molasses. Wow. Super gummy, yeasty, & exploding with sweet dark fruits; prunes, dates, figs. Rolling in residual sugars. Toffee. Severely under-attenuated malt. Flavor is the same. Heavy caramel, molasses, Candi sugar, brown sugar, plum, anise, dates, figs. Slight metallic notes as well as a faint metallic twinge. Slight alcohol, Belgian yeast esters, & mild phenols bust through. But goddamn I cant get past the heavy, gummy sweetness. So much residual sugar. Not my speed.
750ml bottle. Pours a hazy coppery color with a minimal tan head. Mostly fruity aroma. Somewhat sweet, fruity, malty flavor. Slight bitterness in the finish. Quite good.
Bottle in Fl. Light floral, fruity aroma. Pours a cloudy bronze. Delicious mixture of flavors. Hard to place but simply wonderful.
Pours a dark, murky brown with a thin off-white head. Aroma is sweet dark fruit, and the flavor is similar, with a bite of alcohol. This does have a bit of a thin body, but it tastes great.
Bottle tasting. Amber with small tan head. Dark fruit, sweet toffee, caramel. Can feel the alcohol a bit. Decent but not a standout.

Bottle, 2009. Reddish copper color, no head. Sweet, complex aroma with plum jam, juicy malts. Smooth flavor with some winy notes, raisins, malt and restrained hops. Full body, low carbonation. Reminiscent of Fuller's Vintage Ale, which is high praise. Aged with grace.

"like a hybrid BSA/dubble/dopplebock. i liked it all around. Big aroma, bready, doughy, sweet, and alcoholic, but not in a bad way. ditto on the flavor with a medium bodied slightly syrupy feel. nicely done."

Bottled 4/6/12. Dark amber/burnt orange. Big doughy yeast and spiced fruit aroma. The taste adds grains, rich malts, raisin, toffee, anise, and candied apple. Low carb, nice warm alcohol character, medium body, long finish. Very complex. Excellent.

12 oz 2013 bottle - 10 Sept. 2013 date stamp. 

Appearance - dark, slighty hazy red-brown body with a weak tan head. 
Ample carbonation is evident in the mouthfeel of this medium+ bodied beer. The mouthfeel is nicely creamy and would be rated higher were it not for some effects of the higher ABV. Likewise for the complex and spicy aroma. 
Given the price, this is a reasonable substitute for a better but more expensive Chimay Rouge or Westmalle Dubbel.
Tap. Dark copper pour. Raisin, floral, herb, toffee. Very nice SO aroma. Dark dried fruit, port. Full body. Sweet finish but well balanced

Transfer from BA review on 11-28-12- 
 Served on tap in a 10 oz chalice glass

 Appearance  Served a ruby-copper colored brew with a one finger white head. The head has a decent retention eventually fading to leave a decent level of retention. 

Smell  The smell is heaviest of fruit and some malt. The fruit is largely of a darker nature with cherry and plum as well as some lighter notes of apple. The malty flavors are of a bready aroma and when mixed with the fruit and a lighter boozy aroma create a pleasant nose overall.

 Taste  The taste starts out of darker fruit flavors. The fruit flavors are mainly of a cherry flavor up front with some notes of a raisin mixed within. As the taste advances the raisin grows stronger and some caramel flavors some to the tongue. These are quickly followed by a lighter yeasty flavor which when combined with the rest of the flavors produce a rather pleasant fruity and yeasty flavor with an ever so light spice flavor that is mixed within. At the end a light alcohol flavor comes to the tongue and when mixed with the rest and a sweeter sugary flavor (almost candy like) leave a rather pleasant aftertaste to linger on the tongue.

 Mouthfeel  The body of the beer was on the creamier side with a carbonation level that was just below average. Both are rather nice for the style as they are good for the dark fruit and lightly boozed flavors of the brew.

 Overall  A quite decent and rather easy drinking dubbel. Give it a go if you have the chance.

Finally ticking this one. A solid beer that would probably get a lot more love if it werent so readily available. Pretty nice to style. Chewy grain. Toffee and caramel. Nice yeast strain adds to the drink without overpowering. Lots of fruit and chewy grain. Solid.

Una Dubbel excepcional que se esconde del alcohol a través de una compleja gama de sabores. Color marrón rojizo, el sabor es algo adherido, caramelo, maltosa y se sienten el alcohol.
En general es una muy buena cerveza.

Thin head of fine bubbles that dissipates quickly. Good carbonation. Great Aroma loaded with ripe fruit, raisins, sweet malts and some toffee. Color is a hazy dark caramel brown. Sweet and malty flavor with some dough, more toffee, a hint of anise and some butterscotch. Light alcohol presence and warming. Lingering sweet malts that coat the mouth. A very good dubbel!

Superb aroma taste and color, good palate, interesting finish. Loads of dark dried fruit and dark toffee malt in the right balance. Herbal and sweet and faintly fruity-tart. Alcohol is cloaked in robes of supple richness that start rather sweet but then readily give up their fine detail and luxury. Rated by a human being chewing on shavings of Parma Reggiano..

Type: 765ml (25.9 oz.) bottle
Glass: Fullers London pint glass
From: Armada Wine & Beer Merchant in Santa Barbara, Calif.
Price: $10.99
Purchased: July 4, 2014
Consumed: July 6, 2014
Misc.: Bottled on May 7, 2013 at 8:59 a.m.

Poured a caramel amber color with 1-to-2 fingers of off-white head. Minimal lacing on the sides of the glass. Minimal retention on the top all the way down.

Smelled rather boozy up front. Also got grape, Syrah grapes, caramel, plum, slight raspberry, roasty malts, citrus notes and some bubblegum. 

Tasted much better than the nose. Got grape, plum, black raspberry, caramel and honey. Got better as it went down.

Medium body. Oily texture. Average carbonation. Smooth, fruity finish.

Really enjoyed this one. Would have it again for sure.

The pour only produces a small off white head which fades out quickly leaving a rich reddish amber liquid naked and exposed. Only a thing ring of lace remains around the edge of the glass. This lacing is slick and sides down the glass as I drink leaving nothing behind. Its aroma is very sweet, estery and malty. It is a touch phenolic and boozy as well with nice notes of caramel malt, over ripe fruit, sweet bready yeast and raw sugar. To start there is a very sweet rich malty and boozy brandy-like base full of caramel, brown sugar or Belgian candied sugar like notes. From there each sip reveals a different estery, fruity, or phenolic flavor note like sweet red apples, peach, apricot, and pear. On to the finish, and now I get leafy hop spice and mild bitterness moving in. Overall though, it remains well on the sweet boozy side in the finish. On the palate it has a medium to full body with a slick sticky texture.

UPDATED: JUN 26, 2014 Bottle thx jc A: licorice, caramel, red fruits app: clear dark copper white head. T/p: full body with moderate long sweet finish. O: splendid. Brilliantly brewed enjoyed the malt bill and overall compexity. Will need to buy some more.

How: Bottle, 2010 vintage.
Where: Monks Sveavägen, Stockholm.
Appearance: Hazy amber colour with an off-white head.
Aroma: Caramel, sweet sugar, some chocolate.
Body: Medium body and carbonation.
Flavour: Sweet, malt, alcohol, fruit, caramel, some chocolate.

Brown, not too cloudy for the style. The head disappears quickly. Very malty. Raisin and lemon sweetness. A little thin. Not great. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle 1.5 yrs old. Pours murky brown with red tinge no head or lacing. Nose is fruity, prunes. Notes of prunes, plums, brown bread. Taste med sweet light bitter. Full somewhat sticky body with medium carbonation.

765ml bottle. Hazy copper body, medium beige head with average retention. Aroma of berries liquor, raisins, yeast, lots of malts, a touch too much booze. Taste of caramel malt, raisins, prunes, a little yeast, apples and pears, again a badly hidden alcohol. Ok but overpriced.
Pours a slightly hazy amber color with off-white head. Caramel malt, sweetness, sugar, and some dark fruits on the nose; follows onto the palate. Finishes with sweetness.

12 ounce bottle into chalice, bottled on 2/21/2012. Pours moderately cloudy ruby copper color with a 1 finger fairly dense khaki head with good retention, that reduces to a thin lace cap that lingers. Slight spotty lacing clings on the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation. Aromas of big raisin, prune, fig, pear, apple, light banana, brown sugar, toffee, toast, clove, light pepper, herbal, and yeast earthiness. Very nice aromas with good balance and complexity of fruity/earthy yeast ester and dark malt notes; with great strength. Taste of raisin, prune, fig, pear, apple, light banana, caramel, toast, toffee, brown sugar, brown bread, light chocolate, clove, light pepper, herbal, and yeast earthiness. Light earthy spiciness on the finish; with lingering notes of raisin, prune, fig, pear, apple, caramel, toast, toffee, brown sugar, brown bread, light chocolate, clove, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Damn nice complexity and robustness of fruity/earthy yeast and dark/bready malt flavors; with a great malt/yeast flavor balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium carbonation and body; with a smooth and fairly slick/bready mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is well hidden with only a slight warming present after the finish. Overall this is a damn nice dubbel style. All around good balance, complexity, and robustness of fruity/earthy yeast and dark malt flavors; and very smooth to sip on for the ABV. A very enjoyable offering.
I love this style, and the pere Jacques did not disappoint. Dark in color, deep and fruity. Excellent.

2010 bottle drank in may of 2014. Belgian yeast aromas are prominent. Hazy mildy dark amber. Hazy because of an overly aggressive pour 
. Sweet Carmel with dark fruits in the background but the yeast overpowers all. Has a slight sting to it as and aftertaste but still one of the best beers personally drank

Sugars are explosives in this one. Butterscotch,barley sugar, brown sugar with a slight bitter finish showing orange zest, apricot and herbal notes. Alcohol is warm and strong. texture is thick. Close to a malt liquor.                                             
Olfactif: Du caramel saute au nez, un butterscotch très intense, de la cassonade; le tout enrobé deffluves dalcool. Du bonbon au sucre dorge, du pain grillé. Arômes maltés et sucrés surtout.
Visuel:Ambrée, floue. Mousse pétillante qui descend rapidement. Très mince. Aucune trace laissée sur le verre. 
Gustatif: Les accents de caramel priment en attaque. Le Butterscotch, le sucre dorge et la cassonade explosent en accents sucrés. La finale est légèrement houblonnée et laisse paraître des notes de zeste dorange, dabricots et dherbes aromatiques. La texture est onctueuse, sirupeuse; leffervescence moyenne. Les accents sucrés et alcoolisés sont bien équilibrés. Une bière très sucrée avec une légère amertume et un alcool enveloppant. Une bière dessert plus près dune liqueur de malt.
Pours a cloudy dark brown with very little head. Smells of raisin and grain. Taste is raisins, grain and dark fruit. Apparently, this is not my style of beer. I dont find much appealing in this one.
Bottle. Pours brown/red. Nose is raisins and caramel. Tastes like a dubbel. Sweet and strong flavor.

Deep amber color with a one finger head. Aroma is bread, malt, sweet and some citrus. Taste is malt, sweet, slight citrus and bitterness. Medium to high body with alcohol present in the end.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bloody lovely. Bridges gap between greT beer and find fine. Served as an aperitif at a dinner party. Highly unusual but well received.

Årgång 2010. 
Komplex sötma med såväl fruktartade som karamelliserade toner. Även brunt socker, honung, plommon och portvin. Mycket angenäm doft som inbjuder till lång utforskning.
Mörkt bärnstensfärgad brygd med ett något tunt och snabbt halverande skum.
Mycket fruktig smak, blandat med en kolaaktigt karamelliserad sötma. En oväntad aning metallisk ton gör sig påmind, framför allt i eftersmaken. Efterdyningarna är annars trevligt värmande.
Låg kolsyrehalt och en mjuk, halvfyllig kropp. På det hela taget en lite annorlunda och angenäm dubbel, men ändå med ett lite avslaget intryck.

Poured from a 2012 bottle into a GI snifter golden with a thin beige head.
Aroma is funky sweetness. Just like a good abbey ale.
Flavor is excellent. Fruity. Malty Belgium going on here.
A solid Dubbel from Goose Island. Have had 2007-2013. So far 2012 is my fave but not to discriminate all others. 
Balanced beauty. Always happy to consume.

Aroma is dark fruits and malt. Appearance is a honey color. 2013 pours a nice pillow like 2 finger head. 2012 and older have little to no head. Taste is dark fruits, malt and booze. Older years are more flavorful. I had back to 2007. Palate is more smooth and creamy as it ages. Overall an excellent beer that improves with age.

765 mL bottle. Pours a hazy light brown with a white head of bubbles. Amber caramel, sweet grainy malt, buttered rum, raisin, banana, spice loaf and every form of dark sugar imaginable. Delectably sweet, balanced by subtle hops, alcohol. Silky smooth and rich. Full bodied, full carbonation. Very well made.

Pours hazy chestnut brown and bubbled with a foamy yellow head. Some wet lacing. Aroma is strong fruit esters - even apple - toffee and some yeast. Taste is caramel, toffee and candied malt and raisin and fig darkfruit. Some booze backbone. Low carbonation. Highly drinkable and super tasty dupe. I really enjoyed this one.
Pretty good Abbey. Smooth and easy, not too strong. A little sugar sweet but beautiful look.

750 ml. bottle with cage and cork, 2012 vintage. Aroma of caramel, brown sugar, dark bread, dark fruits, toffee, cherry, and port (vinous qualities). Light brown/caramel colored pour with a slight tan head, no lacing. Nice rich flavor, very sweet and fruity, not much spice, minimal bitterness. Really comes through with a port-like warmness, alcohol is apparent. A good representation of a Belgian Dubbel.

2014/03/31 - Pours a cloudy, dark amber colour with a foamy, beige head. Minimal lacing. Aroma is banana, dough, figs, caramel and toffee. Taste is toasted caramel, toffee, malt, mild banana and figs and notes of sweet liquor. Mouthfeel is medium to full body, oily texture, low to average carbonation and a mildly warming, boozy finish. Flavours were a tad subdued and carbonation was a little light, but still rather enjoyable.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Brown bottle, vintage 2013, 765 ml, purchased at the LCBO, savoured on March 29 2014; eye: caramel with an auburn hue, hazy, tiny ring of beige head, no lacing; nose: toffee, malt, light burnt caramel, slight spices, light fig; mouth: toffee, malt, burnt caramel, light spices, light sourness, light fig, finale in malt with presence of toffee, medium-full body, average carbonation, mildly sweet, slick texture; overall: fine

FRANÇAIS
	
Bouteille brune, millésime 2013, 765 ml, 8,7 %, achetée à la LCBO, savourée le 29 mars 2014; il : caramel avec une teinte châtain, trouble, petit anneau de mousse beige, pas de dentelle; nez : toffee, malt, léger caramel brûlé, très léger épices, léger figue; bouche : toffee, malt, léger caramel brûlé, léger épices, légère aigreur, léger figue, finale en malt avec présence de toffee, corps moyen-corsé, carbonatation moyenne, moyennement sucrée, texture coulante; en résumé : bien

Smooth, but really mild overall. Not as spicy as the average Belgian. Very mild fruit and slight yeast, maybe a little banana and too clean going down. Just not enough there to be worthwhile. Well hidden alcohol.
complex flavors with a high alcohol content a little sweet but overall a nice ale

These are not the flavors I typically like in beers, and Dubbels are a style I have generally not even bothered rating in the past, but this is an excellent example of the style. Reminiscent of a banana nut bread or some other kind of holiday spiced loaf. Really delicious for a thing Im not usually fond of.
This is a full-bodied beer with a heaviness in the mouth. The flavors are a malty banana with undertones of orange, caramel, and and cane sugar. Long-lasting aftertaste.

(2012 vintage) pours hazy dark golden, almost copper, with a small off-white head, little retention and lacing. caramel - a tad linear, spices and cacao, soft but present earthy notes, fruitiness - fainted though, brown sugar and dark golden candi, bubblegum and bananas, slightly woodsy, few acetone and garbagy notes, lots of booze. moderate to low carbonation - lacking, light to medium body - oily, some sweetness - brandy-like sweetness and booziness, herbal-grassy-earthy finish. smooth mouthfeel. big disappointment. DP.
Bottle. Ruby gold with a beige head. Dark fruit and yeast. Rich toffee and slightly spicy.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2014 An exceptional dubble that hides it alcohol through a complex array of flavors. Over ripened and slightly caramelized fruit (bananas, fig, apricot, plum), ginger, fennel esters, and a strong Belgian spiciness play together perfectly, finishing long with a pleasant tartness.
Pours a mirky brown with light brown head. Aroma is soothing. Tastes great and packed with fruity and woody flavors. Heavy beer so probably only a pint can be drunken in one sitting. 8% ABV
From bottle. Darker yellow pour. Dark fruit. Some banana and clove. No real Belgian spices. Pretty enjoyable.

Bottle - Bottled Apr 2011; BBE Apr 2016; Drank May 2013 - Dark Reddish-Brown in colour. Very Fruity; dark fruits, plums, overripe bananas. Malty; wheat and rye, caramel, candy sugar. Yeasty; lots of floaties and some sediment. Mildly spiced. Hops: almost no bitterness; grassy hops. Very sweet fruity malty throughout. Decent, but too sweet.
Pours an amber color with virtually no head. Aroma is dried fruit and banana. Taste is the same with a pretty good alcohol kick at the end. One of the better interpretations Ive had.

Pere Jacques pours a copper brown with a sand brown head that doesnt last too long and leaves behind decent lacing. The aroma is dark fruit, raisin, bread and caramel. The flavor is dark fruit, raisin, caramel and a little bread. Overall this is a very nice beer and I would have another please.

Pour is a light amber, clear with a small tan head leaving minimal lacing. Aroma is primarily grapes, a bit biscuit malt. As expected of the style, hops are not present in the beer in any aspect. Palate is off-dry, fairly heavy body. Good mouthfeel, kind of oily. Pretty good beer. Solid dubbel would drink again

Cest rougeâtre, voilé et surmonté dune mousse dense et persistante, qui se colle au verre lorsquelle se résorbe. Un nez fruité où on réussi à sentir des épices quelconques. Est-ce quil y a du sucre dorge? Le goût est sucré au tout début et la levure se détecte longuement après que le liquide aie quitté la bouche. Des saveurs acidulées qui me font bien plaisir. Donc, fruité et épicé. Embouteillée le 12 novembre 2013. (971-120114)
Solid dubbel. I like many of Goose Island's offerings, but this is one of my favorites. Very well rounded Belgian abbey style ale.
Bottle from LCBO. Cloudy copper. Candy sweet grape aroma. Taste of caramel, grape, and spice. Very enjoyable!

765 ml bottle from LCBO. Pours a murky dark amber colour with average-size dense cream-coloured head. Aroma is candied sugar, caramelized fruit, Belgian yeast and gentle spiciness. Flavour is candied fruits - pear/apple, banana and fig - definite Belgian yeast and caramel. Fine carbonation. Average-full body. Quite a nice dubbel.

Aroma of caramel, floral, alcohol. Appearance of amber, clear, sparkling with a minimal head. The taste is medium sweet, with a medium body and creamy texture. It had average carbonation and a smooth finish. When I first tasted it, it became my favorite beer. I would recommend this to anyone.

Wow. This a gem. Thus is eminating soft fruit aromas. I can smell roasted banana from about a foot away. Sweet malty. Nice thick compact head. Viscous mouth feel. Flavour so smooth and rich. Near milkshakey. Again soft fruit notes with banana dominating. Havent been this impressed in awhile. Love it.

January 31, 2014. 765mL bottle from LCBO at Front and Jarvis. Brownish red in colour. Lovely aroma of raisins and caramel that I smelled immediately upon opening the bottle. Quite a lovely dubbel. I would say this is comparable to a Trappist dubbel. Nicely done.

Bottle @ Chrisos Pre-GBBF Shindig. 2010 bottling. The pours amber with a small head. Strong honey and Belgian yeast. Caramelised pear flavors. Nutmeg, brown bread. Earthy yeast. Medium body, soft carbonation. Solid effort.

Pours deep ruby with a fine sheet of foam atop. Aroma is promising as it pours into my glass. While its rich & sugary off the top, interesting notes of figs, dark fruit & citrus zest roll out. A tad softer than the original Belgians, and definitely over rated on this site -- really, a pure & unbiased 5 out of 5? - but it is a damn fine interpretation of the style.

Incredibly smooth and rich Belgian Dubbel. I could really think about it and find something wrong with it I'm sure, but I really enjoy almost everything about it.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottled 11/7/08 opened on 1/25/14 

I think barley wine is not my jam, but if I had rated it originally the first time I had it I wouldve hated it. Mildly sweet, kind of chunky... Idk how else to really describe it.

A 2013 750ml bottle bought at my local LCBO. Aromas of fig, booze and brown sugar. Pours with a thin minimal head, with a orange darker-brown colour. Rich sweet flavour with a strong hit of booze woith more of the dried fig flavour. Very nice beer, not blow away, but good.

2013 vintage. 765 ml bottle. Rating #900!. Hazy orange to light brown. Aroma of belgian esters and some malted caramel and syrop notes but it does sport a really nice fruity, almost berry note that i cant place but do enjoy. On the plate that certain fruityness comes through as do the estery notes and malted sweetness. A very complex beer and one that really starts to challenge my buds once it opens up! Glad I tried it!
Just wasnt feeling this beer at all! Poured out of a growler into a pint glass. Poured amber color with little head, taste was strong on the aging in wine barrels and left little to be desired.

UPDATED: NOV 19, 2014 Pere Jacques is a malty masterpiece. One of the few American-made Dubbels that tastes like it came straight from Belgium. Theres subtle fruitiness and a huge malt taste with heavy tones of caramel. Just like Goose Island suggests, this is a beer that would be an ideal pairing with an elegant meal. Rich meats are an especially good match for this brew.

Caramel, brown sugar, and alcohol in the aroma. Flavor is bready and sweet, with some caramel, raisin, and apple. Some spice, banana, and alcohol in the finish. A little weak compared to its Belgian cousins, but a fine beer nonetheless.

Ruby Orange with mild carbonation, fizzy head, and no lacing. Aroma of licorice, caramel malts, plums/dark fruits, orange peel and toffee. Flavors include caramel, plums, orange peel and caramel malts. Heavy body but lightly carbonation. Decent Beer!
Hazy amber orange, fluffy white head. Yeasty bread dough, some banana, some fruit. Nice sweet caramel, dried fruit, yeast. Nice

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2013 Bottle.

A- Dark fruits, toast.

A- Reddish brown color, cloudy liquid, white head.

T- Mildly sweet, slightly fruity, yeasty.

P- Medium body, average texture, average carbonation, sweet finish.

O- A very good Abbey Dubbel. An excellent offering fro Goose Islands specialty line. Very smooth and makes a great wine substitute.

Bottle:
Amber-orange with a minimal tan head.
Scent is cherry, honey.
Flavour is mildly sweet, fruity, light yeast.
Very smooth, easy going.
Very nicely done.

Smells almost like banana nut bread and has a hint of walnut smell. Dark copper color no head. Definitely has a malty plum taste and a bit of a burn but is very drinkable at over 8%. Sweet and yeasty on the palate. Nice double and overall balanced for all that is going on in this double.

2013 bottle, similar to the one pictured. Hard to believe Ive never rated this, but I cant remember the last time Ive actually had a bottle of it. Poured a dark brown, maybe slightly purple. Lots of yeast. Spiced but very very sweet. Heavy on the sweet fruits, lots of grape, plum. Good beer but a little unbalanced. The variants Ive had are better.

12/20/13 trade from Jamil. Yeasty, banana, fruity, malty scent and flavor with less of an alcohol presence than I expected. Beauty of a dark brown pour with a medium, cloudy feel. Overall, quite impressive. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottled 16APR10

A: pours toasted honey with little/no head production, some wisps of white here and there. No lace. Hazy. Like Ramen Beef broth.
S: Brown sugar, plums, figs and toffee. I like the way this smells. Some notes of tea and honey.
T: Taste follows suite and adds a bit of cola and subtle, nice belgian yeast additions. Too often am I turned away from Belgian style beers because they are overly yeasty in character. This was tasteful.
M: Medium bodied bordering on thin with moderate carb. The finish is semi dry.
O: Well done, pretty decent brew with some age on it. Was it worth waiting 18 months? Meh, not really.

Serving type: bottle

12-06-2011

2010 vintage. Pours deep orange with large bubbles and a short parchment head. Aromas of toffee and stale marshmallow, banana, star anise and undeniably oxidized. The flavor is caramel, Sprite, solvent, potpourri, wax; a somewhat cloying sweetness pervades throughout. Noticeable alcohol sting. Full palate and a slightly astringent finish. Even if it werent way past prime, still too perfumey-tasting and too thick and sweet (dubbel is not doppelbock!)

Bottle. Medium brown pour, small ring of carbonation and an aroma of malty brown sugar and stone fruits. Flavor is also good and malty plums, brown sugar sweetness and slightly warming on the aftertaste. Pretty solid at $12/4-pack.
765 mL bottle.it seems big, very elegant looking label. Wonderful aroma of fruit and honey. Chewy malt almost like eating a piece of fruit cake, very solid mouthfeel. Really good beer
user_location: The World of Beer, Texas, USA

text: Bottle. Poured a reddish brown with a thin white head. The aroma is yeasty malt and a little caramel. The flavor is medium bitter, malty, yeast and some weak liqourice bitterness in the palate. Not one of my Fav styles.

Pours a clear, deep ruby reddish medium amber. Small partially lasting beige head. Aroma is very yeasty, overripe fruity, caramel . Flavor has alcohol, fruity, yeasty, Carmel, fairly spiced. Medium body, a little syrupy. Good beer, but kinda standard, not too exciting.
lots of malt, a little bitter, some caramel, roastness. excellent, smooth, roasty, toasty, and sweet.sorry im watching my loves the packers play so I cant focus fully.

Very rich, with flavors of dates, figs, raisins, cherries. It is true to the style, and possibly even stronger and more complex than many Belgian Dubbels. I could have done with a little less of the brown sugar/molasses flavor, but overall a very good offering.
Bottle. Dark orange amber color. Small white head. Fruity aroma. Nice amount of carbonation with a malt fruit flavor. Oily consistency. Pretty solid.

Bottle. Pour is similar to dark apple cider. Translucent deep amber with really no head at all. Aroma similar to most Abbeys, lots of malt, sour fruit, hint of scotch. Taste is mild at first with sour fruit and light malt followed by a nice, light booze and carmel finish. Mouthfeel is a little light, the only thing that is lacking. All around a nice abbey for a Chicago brewery

22 oz. bottle. Pours a hazy orange amber color with a small off white head. The aroma and flavor have a big sweet caramel and toffee presence, nice ripe fruits, the flavor has some yeast, biscuity notes, dry almost earthy notes, but fades a bit at the finish. Ive had this many times, but not rated.

This is very fruity beer that is dark in appearance but has mild flavor and a sweet after taste. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle at the Riverside Market in Ft. Lauderdale, FL. Shared with Dan! Tulip. Pours a nice dark brown with a little oily look to it. Thick two finger head that lasted awhile. Good lacing throughout. Aroma of dark fruits, toffee, heavy malts, Belgian yeasts, and candied brown sugars. Taste was similar with the malt presence very heavy and the Belgian yeasts less than I like in an Abbey. Moderate carbonation, medium body. Finish is malty with a hint of sourness. Overall pretty good abbey.

Bottle - hazy orange amber pour with ok head. Aroma of cherries, butterscotch, and dark fruit. Flavor is like aroma, a bit sour and a touch soapy. Mouthfeel is a bit thick, ok carbonation. Good beer, not fantastic.

Bottle, shared with Mathieu87.
APPEARANCE: clear dark blond beer, small stable off white head.
NOSE: grains, malts.
TASTE: amber like, malts, little caramel.
Not that good in general...
caramel, banana, floral, raisin, butterscotch, vanilla, alcohol, brown, amber, minimal head, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, medium body, fizzy,

On tap at The Bulldog, New Orleans. Color is a beautiful reddish copper. Aroma is sweet, maybe some fig and bananas. Taste is a tad sweet for my tastes, but still enjoyable. Viscous mouth feel. Overall, a pretty good beer.
Bottle @ home. 2010 bottle. Bronze with a minimal head that quickly disappears. Aroma is sweet. Taste is loads of raisins, figs and some yeast as well. Well balanced.

Pours a brown red with an off white head. Aroma is Belgium yeast, sweet caramel, toffee, dark fruit. Smooth, sweet. Mouth feel is slightly chewy, Tastes of sweet malts, toffee and dark fruits like figs (maybe raisins). Finishes crisp, alcohol is present but not over powering.

2012 bottle poured into a glass. Mahogany body with a thin khaki head. nose is sweet toffee, dark fruits. Taste is rather low carbonation. Almost watery dark fruit, raisin, some belgian yeast. Not a great example of this style.
Pours a nice hue of brown. Very malty and fruity. A good beer but not my favorite in the series.

From Tap at Gramercy Tavern NY.
Amber brown, almost no head. Got a lot of chocolate in the nose. Taste is very alcoholic, lots of caramel, sweet. Aftertaste: pure chocolade. 
My general impression was that, for being an American beer is was a nice try, but this Belgian style would never take on at home (in Belgium). Very surprised to see now that this beer is made by AB-Inbev! Overkill due to the alcohol, out of balance.

Père Jacques sinvite pour notre anniversaire de mariage. Cette bouteille de 765 ml, née le 8 avril 2013, renferme un liquide aux rousses allures. La tête beige qui flotte se découpe comme une tonsure romaine. Le nez est agréablement doux. Ça plaît beaucoup à ma femme. De mon côté, je trouve dans ce caramel monastique quelques traces chocolatées et de bonnes vapeurs fruitées. Madame sent du raisin et assurément dautres fruits. Les deux verres se boivent très rapidement. Lalcool épicé et les malts toastés ne sont pas des obstacles. Les raisins, les pêches et les agrumes trainent une fine acidité. En bouche, nous observons une densification intéressante de la structure corporelle. Le pétillement relâché est enrobé par une texture crémeuse. La finale montre des signes plaisants dassèchement et de chaleur modérée. Une affaire honnête qui, à défaut dêtre renversante, respecte les règles de bienséance.

No real head to speak of misty deep brown pour medium carbonation the aromas alcohol toffee caramel rich fruits brown sugar honey plums the flavours caramel toffee port wine and plums brown sugar sultanas rich fruits goes down real good the finish fruit is something in this ale along with rich malts and alcohol a good dubbel

Pours dark amber with low off white head
Aromas of dried sweet fruits, loads of caramel malts, 
Taste has matured extremely well combining a very malty sweetness and a good yeast strain

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
I thoroughly enjoyed this brew! Although it is a Belgian Ale it has a flavor distinctively American. Sweet fruity flavor. Thin head. Smooth wash down. A welcome surprise! A delicious clever brew...

From 12oz bottle. 

Pours murky brown. Sweet malt aroma. Fruity malt flavor with a nice sweet touch. Sweetness stays on the tongue. Not a bad Belgian ale. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Color- medium brown with red tones. Sweet caramel, toffee, milk chocolate and pie crust malt flavors. Dried fruit raisin plum, fruit cake, pudding on the palate, a bit on the sweet sweet side from the candi sugar but paired perfectly with the caramalized onions in the dish I was eating. Warming alcohol round, rich palate. Another delicious beer from Goose Island.
Bottle at Chrissos pre-GBBF shindig. Bottle from 2010. Aroma is slight musty feet with green apple. Medium sweet malt. Some meaty yeast. Sweet finish. Nice carbonation . maybe not the best example.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown color with a small head. Nose is sweet and fruity, with an emphasis of raisins and currants. Strong esters. Taste is yeasty and fruity with some evenly balanced sweetness. Finish is malty, well balanced with a pleasant tasty ending. Quaff Score 8 / 10
Pours a muddy amber brown with a off white head and aroma of fruits and light alcohol. Taste is of malt, caramel, dried fruits, wood, and light spices with a warming, fruity, alcohol finish.

Cold bottle, 2009 vintage. Pours a very dark red, very little head. Smells of liquorice and sherry. Body is medium. Taste is more liquorice and sherry, molasses, apple, not a very potent flavour. Reminds me of Kuhnenn 4D, JW Lees Harvest Ale etc.  Nice, but not as good as those beers

A bit of a burn that can't be hid by hops. This beer is best after a year or three maybe. Other than that it's tasty

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a dark amber color with a short off white head. Smells of mostly of caramel and raisins. Surprisingly light and smooth. Drinks more like a 5%. It doesnt have the caramel I would expect with the heavy smell. Lots of fig taste but not to overwhelming. On the whole its decent but I was hoping for more.

12oz bottle, shared with our Madison hosts. Pours a mid-bodied and quite still chestnut brown with shy head. Not exploding with instant aromas, but joining an agreeable mix of nutty malts, some raisin, candied berries and milk chocolate without being too sugary. Surprisingly light mf and easy drinking for the ABV. Double, bordering on a Belgian dry stout. A bit more expressive, but considering this is marketed as GIs upscale "Belgian" range, still a bit too "clean" (macro fermentation) and lacklustre...

Pours murky amber with a small off-white head. Aroma is caramel, raisin, figs, dates, muscovado sugar, honey. Taste is bloody marvellous with caramel, raisins, dates, figs, honey, muscovado sugar, butterscotch. Fantastic!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Tallahassee, Fl - ABC Fine Wine & Spirits - 12 oz bottle. Medium amber/copper pour, soft off-white head that clings to the edge of the glass. Aroma is intoxicating with some nice port accents, a touch of dates, brief chocolate. Flavor mirrors the aroma with a fine essence of port permeating throughout, some dates and molasses and a nutty back end. Mouthfeel is warm and comforting. Excellent.

12oz bottle, bottled 2/27/13. Shared with caterwaul. Hazy dark red color. Thin khaki head. Good lace. Lots of yeast particles in the body. Cherry, dark fruit, plum in the nose. Banana, light spice. Moderate sweet taste, light bitter, light spice. Bigger body. Smooth, creamy, lightly crisp lighter carbonation. Full body, but lightly dry finish. Bigger alcohol for a dubbel, but no hint of that in the flavor. Super good dubbel. very nice, big creamy body to it.

A bottle from 2011 found at Whole Foods Bowery. Pours a dark copper or maybe brown with a red hue. The head receeds somewhat fast but persist into a tiny ring of off-white foam that leaves some lacing. Aroma of raisins and molasse, some alcohol can be perceived. Taste is sweet but not out of style. Flavors of figs and caramel. Some hot alcohol again, this isnt too well hidden. Mouthfeel is sticky and almost "barleywine grade". Not bad at all!
Poured as a taster - nose has a bit of apple and caramel, malty and sweet candy sugar. Tastes follow right along and the finish is clean.

From 22oz bottle to Trappist glass. Pour is a dark brown, thick white head. Aroma is fruity, when I first poured it a got a huge nose of banana. otherwise, heavy fruit and malt nose. Taste is bitter, medium body hint of sweet. All around good beer here.

Pours an amber orange in the glass. Thin soapy head. Slight damp cardboard aroma with a touch of the Belgian yeast notes as well. Fruity, some banana and tropical fruits. Tangy malty flavor with more banana and a slight spicy clove aftertaste. Very warming in the stomach. Overall, a solid brew...

On tap at Shamrocks. Served a hazy copper color with a small head that fades quickly with no real lacing. Aroma is quite subtle with dark fruit, bit of bread and yeast. Taste is a bit m ild with dark fruit, just a bit of malt sweetness and hops. There is no real bitterness and a very dry finish. Moderate body, smooth and well balanced. There is no hint of the 8.7% ABV. Enjoyable beer for the style. This is probably best suited to go with food or as an after dinner drink.

Pours cloudy brown with a medium beige head. Aroma and taste is of caramel malt, yeast and some sweet dark fruit notes with light bitterness. Palate is a medium body, mild carbonation with a sweet yeast and light sticky mouth feel. Sweet caramel malt, yeast with light bitterness on the end. A smooth flavorful and tasty brew.
Reddish brown pour. Decent lacing. Aroma is mild with a touch of clove. Taste is malted with an alcohol burn at the end. Smooth, complex all there. Very good.
Pours a cloudy copper amber color. With a light off white head that disipates quickly leaving little lacing. Flavors of malt, sweet fruit and a hot of a caramel aftertaste. Excellent beer.

Cloudy, tea-brown, large tan head. Standard US longneck, clean wine-style label. Candied, grassy, tea and plum aroma. Sweet, very sweet. Prunes and plums, astringent, boozy, moderately astringent. Medium-heavy body, buffered mouthfeel, frooty finish with some herbs. ABC, Bull Run.
Pours a clear golden brown with fluffy white head and good lace. Aroma is sweet caramel and dark fruity esters. Taste follows with a hint of the yeast. Not bad, but not really a fan of this style.

Bottle at Chrisos Pre-GBBF Shindig 2013, 10/08/13.
Golden amber with a thin off white head.
Nose is dark fruity tang, light soured notes, Belgian yeast esters, light spice.
Taste comprises much the same, dark malt, stoned fruits, bread dough, yeast esters, sugars, light toffee.
Medium bodied, fine carbonation, dry finish.
Ok affair but not mind blowing.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Has this on tap in Chicago and in a bottle. Pours a reddish brown. Taste of banana and malty sweetness. A bit heavy on the alcohol.

Deep amber with thin, fine, yellowish sea-foam head. Aroma is tons of soft caramel, some raisin, hint of vanilla cake. hint of sappy grass. Body is medium, carbonation sleeps then comes out a few seconds into the sip as a fine blanket of pricks on the palate. Flavor is a bit f port, dark caramel, soggy rum-raisin pudding, candy. Pretty yummy, neither cloying nor phenolic.

12 oz. bottle from 2/21/2012. Pour is a slight hazy copper, modest head and a bit of lacing. Smell is plum, raisin, caramel, and spice. Taste is plum, raisin, brown sugar, Belgian yeast, citrus and spice. Pleasant aftertaste in between sips, with the tartness and sweetness balance accompanied by a faint hop profile. A very smooth and enjoyable dubbel. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2013.08.12 - Goose Island Pere Jacques - 12oz bottle in goblet glass. 2012 Vintage. Bottled 10/18/12.

Aroma: Agree with reviewer below, a bit banana bread, a bit malt. 

Appearance: Pours around 15 on SRM scale. A rich medium caramel tan. A bit of carbonation on pour, but not much at rest. A bit of a ring.

Taste: Sweetness, basically. Raisin, candied fruit... Tastes in the ballpark of a barley wine more so than a dubbel, which is not a bad thing, just seems mischaracterized.

Palate/Mouthfeel: fairly thin. 

Overall: Mixed feelings. If I were cut off from my favorite Belgians, and Ommegang went of of business then Id certainly enjoy this, but better options exist. Could be the best thing Anheuser-Busch makes, though. Itd be nice if the impact the sale to AB had was to make this brew available in every crappy bar and restaurant in America but I doubt that.

Aroma 6/10, Appearance 4/5, Taste 7/10, Palate 4/5, Overall 16/20

Caramel brown color..all kinds of floating particles amidst the carbonation..slick off white..tan head rests as small film on top and sides..nose is dominated by butterscotch..banana..rum soaked cherry..medium bodied with a nice smooth mouthfeel..hazelnut sweetness..finish is good with a bit of the warming from the abv as things progress...
2010 bottle. Pours amber with off-white head. Smells of banana bread and malt. Taste is of booze, banana, and clove. Good beer but a bit disappointed. Thin mouthfeel.

12 oz. Bottle from Logan Twp Giant Eagle. Pours red/brown with frothy, 3 finger cream head, quickly dissipating with good lacing. Nose is band aid and burnt rubber with some raisin. Sweet. Lots of sweet. Raisin and brown sugar, some cloying molasses and other notes of cherry and dark fruit. Not bad. Not outstanding by any means.

This is a good Belgian ale but is not something I enjoy. For my preference this beer has too much malt and too much alcohol flavor. My wife loves it. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bomber. Poured ruby brown with a big off-white head and a good bit of sediment. Aroma and flavor were very fruity. Lots of cherry, dates, raisins. Quite yeasty. Slightly banana and clove. Some roasted malt. Low bitterness.

2010 Vintage
7/22/2010: Goose Island Pere Jacques 2010 Belgian Style Ale... Aroma: Caramel malts; ripe, fleshy fruits; golden raisin; refined alcohol (brandy-like). Appearance: Warm chesnut color; dark beige bubbles gather rapidly on the surface after the initial pour, but quickly burn off; subtle carbonation; slightly thick appearance with some suspended fine sediment. Flavor: Thin, mildely sweet toffee-caramel maltiness; date sweetness; golden raisin; subtle pecan; a touch sharp and metallic; strong, warming alcohol presence. Palate: Medium-bodied; tingly mouthfeel. Overall: Ive always loved Goose Island, but have never been a huge fan of this particular beer...
12 fl. oz. bottle (8% Alcohol by Volume; Bottled on: 01/13/10 2042) from The Party Source in Bellevue, KY. Rating #1175 for this beer.  Score: 7/3/7/3/13 = 3.3.
. . . . . . . . . .
11/04/2010:  Goose Island Pere Jacques 2010 Belgian Style Ale...  Aroma:  Medium Belgian candi sugar; raisin; caramelized sugar.  Appearance:  Deep orange garnet color; hazy with some fine sedimet; slowly bubbing beige crown; low carbonation.  Flavor:  Fruity (dates, rum-flambed golden raisin, caramelized maltiness; sweet yeasty bread characteristic; brown sugar; subtle booziness that is quite warming; flavors deepen and intensify as the beer warms: caramel-banana; lots of esters; sugary caramel; black cherry; touch of candied orange peel; very subtle tobacco in the finish.  Palate:  Medium-full to full body; thick, smooth, and maybe even slightly syrupy and chewy from time to time...  Overall:  Strong and rich indeed!  Yum!
12 fl. oz. bottle (8% Alcohol by Volume; Bottled on 7/14/10-1238) from The Party Source in Bellevue, KY.  Score: 8/3/8/4/15 = 3.8
Poured from a room temperature bottle into a glass. Auburn color with a white head. Slight syrup smell. Nice taste.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2014 29.06.2013, 0,35l bottle (2013) @ NY hotel room:
Nice creamy mediumlasting head. Aroma is slightly sweet fruity, caramel malts, dried fruits, toffee, nuts, almond essence, grass. Taste is sweet, slightly grassy fruity, caramel malts, grass, alcohol, toffee, dried fruits, citrus peel, dark sugar, butterscotch. Medium bitterness, slightly dry mouthfeel. Fair enough, probably way too young.

Mahogony pour, fluffy white head. Fruity aroma, cherry, fig, would have like more. The taste is nice, but timid. Fruit and yeast, slight alcohol. Palate is pretty drinkable. This is a decent attempt at a classic style, but it needs more of everything, but still very drinkable now.
Poured a clear medium brown with minimal head. Aroma of sweet berry fruit and caramel malt. Medium body, flavour of sweet yeasty fruit, fairly average.

Bottle from Stirchley Wines, Birmingham. Poured a reddish brown with a thin broken white head. The aroma is yeasty malt and a little caramel. The flavour is medium bitter, malty, yeast and some weak liqourice bitterness in the palate. A decent beer in small quantities, but I dont understand the high rating.
Bottle. Aroma is wood, red fruits and raisins. Taste is heavy sweet with definite Belgian yeast. Not my favourite.

UPDATED: JUL 30, 2013 Refrigerated 12 oz. 2012 brown bottle poured into a tulip. Pours dark amber with small beige head which dissipates quickly. Dark fruit aroma, medium body, low carbonation, and little lacing. Taste is nice long dark fruit (mostly nice raisin some dates) and dark candy sugar. Pretty easy to drink for 8.7%, good beer.  2011 brown bomber in 2013, not as sweet, but not  as much flavor as the 2012, two years old and still good.  Refrigerated 2009 12 oz. brown bottle with grey wax.  Most of the dark fruit taste from this beer have left, however dark fruit aroma is still present.  Still better fresher.  2008 over five years old, when cold aroma and taste is light milk chocolate.  2008 as it warms dark candy sugar and alcohol.

Draft at Colemans Public House. Ruby brown pour with a white head. Sweet Belgian candi sugar aroma, plums and dates, yeast, and malt. Sweet plum flavor, candi sugars, complex malts and yeast. Pretty solid beer even though not my favorite style.
Bottle at Janoinen Lohi, Helsinki. 2009 edition. Originally rated 30092011. Colour is dark brown with small head. Aromas and flavours: Belgian yeast, dark fruits, sweetness and malts.
Minimal aroma. Dark brown/amber. Apple juice flavor with a lively mouthfeel. Unique with a apple fwd presentation.

October 2012. Bottle. Copper color with a white head. Aromas of dried dark fruit, sugars and malt. Spice, fruit and sugary flavors. Very well made and balanced.

Pours dark, vibrant copper with one finger of foam that lingers. Aroma is thick and sweet smelling of fig and raisin. Medium bodied and very complex. Malty taste with great Belgian yeast notes. EtOH taste in middle but smooth and enjoyable. Finishes with a little zip from carbonation and raisin. Very good beer with red meats or Italian food. Prefer to share bottle as two glasses are a bit much.

Aroma is a sweet caramel malt, syrupy. Appearance is a dark brown red, thick syrup, almost no head, but what head there is has an off white color. Taste is sweet and syrupy, boozy, and has a nice toasted malt hint. Palate is dry, which helps the taste last as sweet and malt but not an overly sickly sweet like expected with such a syrupy appearance.

Served in a plastic dixie cup, so take this review with a grain of salt? Sickeningly sweet smell, I get molasses and whiskey. Its very boozy! It definitely gets better as it warms snd the more I drink. Still, I wouldnt buy anymore.

Deep nutty brown with a moderate head that disappeared quickly. aroma of high quality molasses and plums, moderate carbonation. Tastes of dried fruits, caramel, alcohol warmth. Another great beer from Goose Island.

-Fish!

Yum! Spicy and tasty, this ale is crisp and has no aftertaste. I'd like a stinger, thicker head, but this is one if my new favorites!

12 Fl. Oz. Bottle. Pours cloudy brown minimal off white head not much lacing. Aroma of fruit, malts, alcohol and some yeast. Nice complex and balanced taste, you fell the alcohol but not in overpowering way, its sweet and fruity. Very good beer.

Bottle, 2011 ed. Pours deep brown, massive tan head, good retention/some lace. Aroma of dark fruit, molasses, fruity ester, toffee, nuts. Taste is sweet, fig, toffee, nuts. Palate is soft, slick, sweet finish. Good.

This pours a medium brown color with a small white head. Scent is mostly that of toasted malts with some sweet, nutty tones and caramel. The taste is rather bold and complex with a lot of flavor to it.

Very impressive Belgian ale. Great toffee, nut, and malty aromas. Big brown pour with a thick beige fizzy head on top. Disappears quickly, little to no lace. Pour is dark brown, almost black in the center. Medium to full bodied, great beer.

Very attractive reddish brown appearance.  Aroma of belgian yeast and dried fruits (plums, raisin, apricot, cherry).  Flavor follows through to the taste.  A little boozy, but overall in good balance.
bottle brought back from chicago. pours brown with off white head. lots of roasted spicey malt. with some brown sugar.

Poured from a bottle into a tulip glass. Aromas of sweet berries and some dark fruit (plums?) and, oddly enough, red licorice. I expected more of an alcohol nose, but its really not there, not that Im complaining. Its a beautiful reddish-amber color with a creamy off-white head. The alcohol and dark fruit comes through in the taste, which has a lot more body than the nose would lead you to believe. Theres also a distinct and delicious rasin flavor. It coats the mouth and leaves a sweet, rasin-y flavor for just long enough to make you go back for more.

Bottle from  2012 bottled on 2/21/12.  Amber reddish pour.  Aroma of raisins and concord grapes. Flavor is sweet and includes raisins, molasses, alcohol, and some slightly bitter hops that keep beer from being cloying. High level of carbonation.

Uploading old ratings that were missing comments. Very sweet Belgian ale. Dark fruit and candi sugar.

Cloudy reddish orange, no lace. Very sweet smell with caramel, dark fruit, sweet bread. Tastes sweet and tangy with a sugary aftertaste, not a bad one, a pleasant one like you just had one bite of a danish. Ill just say, if you poured this in generic black bottle and said it came from a hermitage that only released every 6 months, people would wet themselves over this.

2012 Vintage - Aroma of Belgian yeast with hints of caramel and sulfur. (????) Pours a cherry amber with a rapidly dissipating tan head and no lacing. The taste is moderately sweet. Malts, nuts, dark dried fruit, and caramel combined with a grainy finish make this a beer of complex flavors. Medium body with soft carbonation. Smooth mouthfeel. Overall, surprisingly flavorful. SASSS (Splendid as single slow sipper.)

Deep, clear reddish-amber with an off-white head. Lots of plum on the nose with grass, cola, molasses, and caramel. Taste is semi-sweet and yeasty with a mild hop presence; balance is good. Body is medium-full, a little sticky.

Bouteille 12oz, courtoisie de Hogtownharry ou Blankboy. De couleur cuivrée-ambrée et voilée. Nez de levures fruitées (prunes, raisins, notes de petits fruits), malté de caramel toffee aux notes rôties, de sucre brun et avec des notes de mélasse, dalcool et dépices (clou de girofle). Ronde-moyenne en bouche avec pétillement bas et une texture riche, sirupeuse et légèrement crémeuse. Goût de levures fruitées sucrées (prunes, raisins, notes de cerises et de pommes) avec des notes épicées (clou de girofle) lors de lentrée en bouche auquel se rajoute un goût malté assez sucré de caramel toffee avec des notes de pain grillé ainsi que des traces de mélasse et de sucre brun. Parallèlement, lon retrouve un léger goût dalcool doux réchauffant qui se développe jusquen finale. Post-goût moyen-long aux légères notes sèches, légèrement amer dalcool doux avec un léger goût rôti et de levures fruitées (moût de raisins et de prunes).

Bottle. Pours a hazy dark brown with a slight reddish tinge and no head. Nose is somewhat strong - slightly sweet from the Belgian yeast with some malty tones to it. Taste actually isnt too sweet, but has a bite to it. Odd.

Deep nutty brown with a moderate head that disappeared quickly. aroma of high quality molasses and plums, moderate carbonation. Tastes of dried fruits, caramel, alcohol warmth. Another great beer from Goose Island.

Poured from bottle a deep amber with dark tan head. Aroma of dark fruit, caramel, candied orange rind, toffee, slight vanilla, and slight booze. Molasses, caramel, and sweet apricot. Good mouth feel.

22 oz bomber courtesy of my wife for Christmas. 2012 Vintage.  The pour is a hazed amber brown, with a one inch light tan head that falls quickly and noisily.  The aroma is soft roast malt, along with Belgian plum fruit yeast.  The taste is a sharp sweet malt, then the plum fruit, and finishing with a very Dubbel esque Belgian yeast and clove. Hint of heat, some nutmeg notes in the back.  The palate is medium bodied, the fruit yeast leads to a lingering finish. Bonus point for a beer named after the great Pere Jacques Marquette (of course I am assuming thats who its named after).  Thanks for the beer sweetheart.
bottle. deep cloudy amber with small head. aroma slightly funky. slightly dark belgian ale. moderate spice and little to no sweetness. rich belgian flavor. pretty nicely done.

pours a murky brown with a thin white head.not much in the way of lacing.aroma is malty sweet,raisins,brown sugar,musty yeast,and slightly floral from the hops.flavor is dark fruits,honey,allspice and slight pepper.full bodied,medium bodied and a creamy mouthfeel.has a slightly medicinal finish.sweet but very nice.

Aroma is quite good and complex, with tons of caramel malt, a touch of (what I think is) noble hops, some fruity esters and a touch of red wine character.  The taste is a little too malty for my liking, with a lot of caramel up front, followed by those delicious belgian yeast flavors.  It finishes a little sweet with some alcohol.

2012 bottle poured into a Duvel tulip glass. Beautiful ruby color with a small but dense bone white head that dissipates quickly. Nose of booze, bread and dark fruit. Flavor is malty, with notes of raisin and licorice in the finish. Luscious mouthfeel, the kind of beer that almost expands as you swish it around your mouth rather than simply releasing the carbonation. Leaves that familiar malty taste lingering in your mouth, urging you to take another sip.

2012 bottle pour.  Head is about one finger with larger bubble size than expected. Reddish brown with good flavor profile.
With Tim. $6 on draft at Abbey Burger Bistro. Pretty good beer but a little too sweet.
12 oz bottle. Pours a hazy brown with light head. Aromas of roasted malt and  light toffee. Subtle and smooth. Flavors of caramel, toasted malts, light marmalade, and light spice. Very nice.

22 ounce bottle, bottled on 07/30/11.  Served in a goblet, the beer pours a reddish/orange color with about a half inch off-white head that didnt stay around for very long. Medium body, alcohol well concealed, but fizzy. Nice fruity complexity, and fairly drinkable. Wanting in breadiness when cold, but develops balance when warm.
I wasnt expecting such a big beer.  Lots of sweetness and dark fruits.  Decent but these abbey beers are better left to the belgians.

bottle.  hazy amber with a small white head.  sweet malty nose with honey and caramel.  lots of caramel, some toasted malt, quite sweet, belgian yeast flavors.    a real tasty beer.

Draft - pours hazy caramel crimson, minimal white head. Slight lacing. Aromas of dried fruit, orange peel, caramel, dark bread and grain. Taste is alive and complex. More dark malts with slight bitter hop finish. Some more orange biscuit and vanilla notes. Medium bodied. Solid.
Quite a rich dark belgian style.  Syrupy on the palate with a nice soft full bodied texture - bordering on barley wine

Poured from a 2010 bottle into a belgian tulip glass. Pours a darker mahogany with a beige head of foam and good retention. Foam looks velvety. The aroma is well melded carmel, nuts, sherry, leather, wood, bananas. Smells nice.The taste is leaning more toward the sweet side with some brown sugar nuances. The two plus years this has been in the bottle have really mellowed the beer out and make it so smooth and complex. The mouthfeel is so smooth, its like velvet on the tongue. The head was indicative of the mouthfeel it turns out.

2011 vintage. 22 oz bottle, bottled 25-Feb-11, from Beers of the World in Rochester, served in a Trappist glass. Pours hazy caramel with a small tan head that fades, leaving a small amount of fine lace. On the nose, there are notes of caramel, toasted malts and raisins, along with subtle flowers and earth. The flavour is moderately sweet throughout, with raisins, toffee, plum and subtle notes of grass and flowers. The finish is long and malty, with caramel and fruity elements carried through from the aroma. The subtle grassiness becomes more prominent in the finish. On the palate, it is medium-full in body with a smooth, creamy texture and average carbonation. Overall, this is an excellent brew. It is reminiscent of a quad, but somewhat lighter in body and alcohol content. A delightful brew that would likely age well. 2012-01-29

Bottle.  Pours deep golden with an off-white head. Aroma of malt, caramel, flour, yeast and malt. Flavor is sweet and malty with some caramel, fruitiness, alcohol, yeast and biscuits. medium body, average carbonation.
355ml bottle from wegmans niagara falls. light brown with a small tan head. candied dark fruit aroma and flavour. light on carbonation. nice sipper. wish i could buy something like this locally.

Hazy unfiltered redhead of a belgian strong. Minimal head, minimal lacing. Crisp malt aroma with hints of pepper, dark fruit and light booze. This beer does not impress until it hits the lips. And once it does...your opinion changes for the better. Has an effervescence that would no doubt diminish with age and attenuation. Nice delicate balance between sweetness and robustness. Light booze throughout from start to finish. On the dry side. Im getting more of roasty notes the more I drink this, which comes to the forefront as it warms and comes closer to its optimal serving temp. Earthiness, toffee and spice (nutmeg?) also round out the  profile of this nice beer from Goose Island.
Poured from a 22 ounce bottle. A nice raisin and prune. Very malty, Belgian yeast driven. Malty, earthy, fruity. Very nice and tasty.

Poured from a large bottle into a wine-style glass to drink.  The beer had a cloudy, sediment hazy-amber color with a rusty hue and a very small foamy white head that quickly dissipated, along with minimal lacing and cling.  Its aroma featured yeast and touches of grain and wheat, along with some floral and pine components, and a light blend of caramel malt and touches of spice.  Its taste was fairly bitter and earthy, with some floral and fruit tones, along with some sour yeast and grain, and the lightest bit of caramel sweetness.  The beer had a somewhat thin and wet mouthfeel and was a bit watery with low carbonation and life.
Pours super dark brown (i think) with hardely any head at all..  aroma is prune and sour fruit...  Taste is good... Strong,  but smooth about it....

Bottle shared at Beer Temple tasting.  Pours clear amber with a tan head.  Aroma of caramel, toffee, overripe fruits, raisins, figs.  Flavor is heavy sweet and light bitter.  Full bodied with soft carbonation.
On tap at TJs. Pours dark reddish brown with a foamy tan head. Raisins, figs, licorice, earth. Moderately sweet. A tad acidic. Relatively smooth body. A decent beer.
Hazy amber hue with silky off white head. Nose and taste of toasted bread, pear, sugar, and cloves. Medium body. Yeah!!!!

Sample at the Decatur Craft Beer Fest. Dark gold, with a thin beige head. The aroma is honey, toasted malts, and coriander. The flavor is fairly bitter and sweetness. The palate is light to medium, sticky, syrupy, and smooth. Overall, this is a light, flavorful, and delicious beer.

Having dinner right now. Eating a venison beef stroganoff dish. Delicious! This beer is incredible with this meal. Pours a light caramel color, little to no head. Sweet and spicy aroma.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2013 Pours a beautiful amber. Smells of fruits. Flavor explosion of figs, pears, and some dark fruits. Mouthfeel is light-medium. No alcohol presence and very easy to drink. Excellent beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

(bottle bottled on 6/2011) Pours a clear dark red color with a very thin tan head that forms a tight ring around the glass.  Aroma is strong and expressive, with big scents of dark fruits like dried cherries, plums, and dark bread (kind of pumpernickle-like).  Theres also a bit of red vines licorice and light booze with some faint vanilla.  The cherry is really showcased here, and this is basically all I look for in a well-constructed dark Belgian beer.  The flavor is much the same as the aroma, with flavors of cherry, plum, light caramel, and a slight tang reminiscent of unripe plum or cherry skin.  Finish is faintly bready, but its far more plum jammy (like Italian plums) and I really dig that flavor and finish.  Mouthfeel is medium and carbonation is perfect and soft.  Overall this is an excellent beer and far better than I remembered it being.  Perhaps the year of age has helped this along, but I think I have now finally found an apt substitute for Alesmiths Grand Cru.  Really well done.
Strong caramel/toffee aromas. Fruity toffee candied flavors. Finishes with a little banana. Overall pretty tasty beer.

Bottle from Kris Wines, 2009 vintage drunk in 2012. Pours slightly hazy, reddish brown colour, still quite some carbonation, thin head. Deep amber color, minimal head.  Fruity aroma.  Rather sweet and malty with caramel and toffee notes.

Bomber.  Pours a deep garnet-brown, little head retention (although it could be the glass), nose is fruit, caramel and yeasty. Mouth is full, lots of caramel notes, that Belgian yeastiness and some stone fruit. Somewhat sweet, with a slight warmth to the finish,  but otherwise the 8% ABV is well hidden.

Poured from a bottle into a goblet, the aroma is very nice with a very fruity prominence, taste is sweet, malt on the back end, the carbonation is very velvety, a tart finish and nice warmth at the finish.

A really intense beer. No head to speak of and pours a dirty amber brown which is basically opaque. Aroma is of raisins and prunes, with some malty hints. The taste completely overpowers you but not really in a bad way. It has cinnamon, nutmeg, raisins, prunes, a bit of citrus...etc. Definitely a varsity beer, give it a go though.

330ml bottle from Ales by Mail. 2009 vintage consumed on day of rate. Popping the cap disturbed the sediment causing a slow gush and plenty of particles to come through on the pour. A deep, ruddy mid-brown with a large, mostly lasting beige head. Bread dough, biscuit, toffee, apple, yeast & raisin aromas. Biscuit, yeast, raisin, spice, dough, sweet toffee malts & some orange flavours finishing with a light, delicately roasty bitterness. Medium-ish body but slightly on the thin side on the palate. Soft to medium carbonation with a subtle warmth in the throat and a lingering fruitiness.

22 oz. bottle from Market Basket. 2012 Vintage. Used my Allagash chalice.  A turbid amber practically no  head or retention.  This is a Dubbel in every aspect. Carbonation seems a bit low. An aroma of malt, toffee, sweets and prunes.  Flavor is slightly sweet and heavy with toffee and sugar. Dark fruits and some ABV. It may be a nicer if aged.  Not really my thing.

2009 bottle. This beer really did it for me. Begins with a surprising color, deep pinkish burgundy, very translucent, delicate white head. Aroma was sweet hibiscus and fresh flowers. Complex but still delicate. Flavor was very sweet but also delicate, hibiscus, black cherry, peach. Really good. Bottle was a parting gift at a great beer tasting with former goose island employee, Eddie Chimichanga. Thanks!

12oz bottle - pours amber with beige head and decent lacing.  Nose is caramel and brown sugar.  Flavor adds forest fruit and earthy notes.  Sweet.  medium body with medium carbonation.  Sticky mouthfeel.  Festive and would accompany any sour desert.

Bottle. The pour was a murky dark ruby red with a strong brownish hue and a very small (less than 1/8") off white fizzy head, which diminished totally leaving behind a very small collar and poor lacing.

The aroma was of a moderate caramel malt and a sweet Belgian yeast with notes of dark fruit (raisons, figs & plums), banana, green apple and a slight alcohol tinge.

The taste was malty-sweet with notes of caramel and green apple early on and then took on a strong dark fruit presence with a touch of banana and had a slight red wine alcohol finish. The flavor lasted a decently long time proceeding the swallow with a sweet fruity taste left behind.

Mouthfeel was almost medium in body and dry in texture with a strong ticklish carbonation.

Overall very well rounded Belgian Ale with a nice caramel fruitiness which blended well with the Belgian yeast, thus containing the high alcohol content...
22oz bottled 4/12/12....Aroma: nothing to really smell...pours a root beer brown color. Sweet taste of grapes reminiscent of wine. Despite my overall score I would do this one again

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2012 On-tap at local Hardtimes Cafe.  Served in a tulip glass, copper-like amber color with tan head.  Aromas of caramel, raisins, chocolate, dark fruit, yeast and spices.  Taste adds brown sugar sweetness and some alcohol.  Light carbonation, medium body and smooth.  Great!

2009 Vintage, bottled Jun 10 
Pours a deep copper color with a decent sized beige head that quickly dissipates to a cap. Smells of brown sugar, caramel, dark cherries, raisins, and prunes with a nice melanoidin thing going on. The flavor follows the aroma quite well. Dark sugars and fruits with burnt raisin thing going on. Medium body with a light level of carbonation and a sweet slick mouthfeel. I was worried that I had sat on this one too long, but it all worked out. Nice brew that reminds me a bit of an aged barleywine or a dopplebock. Maybe now I should try a fresh one.

2012 Vintage. Pours amber with hints of orange and a tiny tan-khaki fizz. Smells mildly fruity with some sugar sweetness. Taste is fruity and strongly of caramel. Medium-bodied with a smooth texture and mild mouth-carbonation, Goose Island Pere Jacques finishes very fruity and mildly sweet.

Pours a red tinted amber, with darker beige fluffy head.  Smells of Caramel, banana and mild spices.  Taste is a velvety caramel, with hints of fruit (banana) and sweet malt, finishes strong.  Top notch

12 ounce bottle. Appearance - Dark, blood red, flat and without much carbonation.  No foam at all.  Aroma - Not much smell here. Taste - The high abv hits you over the head. Sweet, minty, lots of fruit, complex and not malty or hoppy.  Palate - Big bodied, flat. Overall - Its a rocky ride Ill decline next time.

Deep amber to brown with lace. Nice, rich, chewy nose of caramel, chocolate, raisins. Rich, fruity malt, raisin, sweet orange and plum, caramel and chocolate, light spice from the yeast. A full, tasty beer, more than a dubbel, slightly less than a quad, but tasty. smooth, full body with smooth, soft carbonation. Earthy finish, some tangy fruit and a bit of bitterness. Good stuff. Quite authentic.
This is the 2012 batch for this brew. Right on target for a Belgian Ale. Taste, color and aroma are all reminiscent of a real Belgian abbey ale. Nice job and well done. Delicious!

7/31/12:  At Maxs on tap first day they got in some GI.   Amazing mouthfeel, but I feel like the sugar or whatever is added dominates.  It's tasty for sure, but I almost feel the sugar coats my mouth like a glazed donut.  It's a little much

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Good head, reddish hue, boozy, very fruity almost reminds me of some wines.  A little too sweet for me.

Nice looking beer.  Apple juice with sweet malts and other fruits in the nose.  Cotton candy, brown sugar, and more fruits in the taste.  Bitterness in the background.  Borders on a sticky sweetness.  Good beer, too sweet for me.
