Pours dark I think it is dark red.  Very little head at all. Poured from a 12oz bottle. Fruity almost raspberry aroma.  Pleasant.  Spicy and fruity Carmel taste.  Really interesting.

On tap at Friscoe Grille & Taproom in Columbia, MD.  

Clear, very dark mahogany red with small ivory head and very good lacing. 

Aroma of dark fruit, plum, fig, dark cherry,  brown sugar, banana Belgian yeast and caramel. 

Taste of sweet dark malt, dark fruit, brown sugar, toffee, cherries and banana and sweet bourbon. 

Medium/full body and medium carbonation. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a caramel color with minor bubbles and no head.  Aroma is of sweet candy, similar to a hard candy.  Taste is clean with the high alcohol content coming through.  Slightly sweet with a clean finish that dissipates after the swallow.

The scent reminded me very much of a sour apple jolly rancher. Pretty root beer color pout, the picture above is much darker than my pour. Flavor had a little bit of the apple as well. Overall a decent beer, but nothing to get too excited over.
Amber pour with an off white head.  Aroma is spicey and some dark fruits, Taste is nice and spicey..enjoyable brew.

Pours dark purple, some head.  Reminds me a lot of a quad but not quite as thick.  Its very sweet, lots of dark fruit.  Dry finish.  Not as intense or yeasty as most quads, but similar in quality.  Note...this bottle was aged about 1 year before drinking.

Sweet, fruity aroma has a brown sugar undertone and a hint of malt. It pours a clear copper brown with a thick, pale golden-tan head. Flavor is mainly fruity, with notes of apple and pear and a hint of banana, as well as subtle tones of horehound and caramel. Texture is smooth and full-bodied, though fizz leaves a little to be desired. Finish is fruity and woody. Though a winter beer, it is quite refreshing in the murderous heat of Atlanta in July.

Bottle from the Andersons. Pours brown with a half an inch of khaki foam. Definite alcohol on the nose but also some Belgian yeast notes. Warming quality on the tongue. Solid for style. Nice digestif.

Another good goose island beer. Pours red brown, with yellowish tab head. Smells of cherries and spices. Taste is similar to Matilda, but sweeter. Almost has a cider quality. Aftertaste is not great though. Had in the bottle.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Brownish amber color with a thin off white head. The nose is layered with banana and figs. Full bodied Abbey style ale. Measured sweetness on the palate showing plenty of grape and figs. High carbonation keeps the sweetness in balance. Shows a knee buckling finish.

A: Light brown, slight haze, still somewhat clear, ok head and lacing.

S: Fruity Belgian yeast, alcohol.

T: Sweet with fruity flavors, Belgian yeast. This beer tastes slightly off. This a complex brew, with some interesting things happening, but something is just not quite right here.

M: A bit too thin, alcohol too present, which is unfortunate. The beer has a slight harsh bite I dont dig.

D: Too sweet and thin. Ive had many better examples of the style.

Pours walnut brown with a tiny head.  Aroma is dark sweet fruit.  Medium to thick in body with light carbonation makes this a bit sticky.  Flavor is very nice with a lot of traditional Belgian dubble characteristics, but much more of an alcohol bite.  Hops are in the background and offer just enough bitterness to offset the malty sweetness.  A nice ale.
on tap at Winos in Bowlling Green, KY. dark pour with a modest head. sweet toffee smell, maybe some bubble gum. very malty. some alcohol warming. a very good americanized belgian strong ale.

3rd May 2010Hazy red brown beer. Short lived light brown head. Toffee malt nose. Light palate, a little soft and semi dry. Dark toffee with some bubblegum and a little aniseed and spice. Finishes dry with surpressed bubblegum.

2012. Bottle. My second GI beer and it is as disappointing as the first. Pours a mahogany with a slight head, looks like a belgian. Smells like nothing, tastes like nothing. What is the hype about? Is this just a symptom of the buy out? Did i miss the golden days of GI? So far i feel like i would have been just as well off with bud light.

Deep brown with medium creamy head. Aroma is mostly roasted malt with hints of plum. Taste is savory, sweet and a little bitter. Body is heavy for style and texture is thick. Finishes rich and smooth. Very much like an abby quad.

Torpedo.  Poured a copper color with diminishing medium head.   Aroma is malty caramel, hops, gramcracker, belgium yeast.  Medium light sweetness.  Ave carbonation. Taste almost barley-winesque.  Has a wide balance.

pours deep amber with a big beige head nice lacing. nose is apple pie, caramel, brown sugar, rum sweet, it smells sweet. shortbread. some light citrus notes in there too like orange marmalade. taste begins nice with some bright citrus notes and brown sugar and caramel but it resides into a cloying sweet mess. this beer needs food to go with it. a dessert maybe.

Aged one year, it has a light, syrupy, slightly pale dark orange color with yeast sediment in suspension.  Its aroma is a combination off alcohol and special malts with a hint of spice and yeast - very neat.  Its very light in the mouth.  It seems to need more time to condition - theres a dominating, light, caramel malt flavor that controls the palate.  Its interesting, Ill give it that.  Either this aged too long or not enough.  Hmm... I know this beer should be better than this.

Bottle.  Poured a medium brown with minimal off-white head.  Aroma was of malt and caramel, with some dark fruit.  The flavor followed with emphasis on the dark fruit.   Surprisingly it was just a touch too sweet for my taste.  Overall a good brew.

A Belgian strong ale of the sweeter variety, though not too heavy for my liking. Its reminiscent of Abbaye des Rocs or Unibroue Trois Pistoles.  Surprisingly little sediment - I wonder if they filter these. Aftertaste has some oaky bitterness and sugarcane type sweetness. Smell has plenty of alcohol and a trace of flowers. A good beer, all things considered. Well executed - I just hope InBev doesnt start to screw with these lines. Bottle from Health food store in Lebanon, NH.

Bottle. Pours a deep, hazy copper with an off white head. Aroma is belgian spices, sweetness, and some dark fruits. Taste is very sweet and sticky. Lots of hard candi flavors mixing with a slight booze. Finishes more clean than youd expect. Pretty easy to drink for its abv.

12 oz bottle.  Dark ruby brown pour with a thin off white head.  Aroma of plums, caramel and raisins.  Thick, sticky mouthfeel that is almost like syrup, but in a good way.  Even warming alcohol finish.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2012 Pours to rapidly disappearing head; reddish color.  Terrific smell - very floral with dark fruits and yeast.  I could sniff this all night!  Taste is sweet dark fruits - plum, raisin, and a little bit of orange fruit (tangerine mostly).  Finishes malty, and then the ABV kicks in shortly after.  Very good dubbel!

Ive managed to corral enough beers to do a 3 year vertical tasting. 

2012: Poured a translucent caramel brown with a decent, but quickly dissipating head. Very effervescent. Almost soda-like. Not as many esters as I expected. Aroma overall is subdued, in fact. Tastes of sharp caramel and toffee sweetness. Some cherry tartness, too. Not that many esters. Very bubbly at first but full, overwhelming sweetness at the end. I liked this better than expected. (6, 4, 8, 4, 15: 3.7)

2011 - Appearance is exactly the same. The aroma is drastically different. All hints of caramel is gone. In its place are strong phenolics. Mostly banana and clove. Leathery, too. Some breadiness and toffee flavors, but the banana and clove flavors are much more pronounced. Carbonation and caramel sweetness are much less pronounced. Its amazing what an extra year will do to drastically change the character of a beer. (7, 4, 6, 3, 13: 3.3).
2010 - Lets face facts, Im a bit drunk now, so detailed reviews arent going to happen. Just know that the 2010 version finds a nice balance between the malty sugariness of the 2012 version and the strong phenolic character of the 2011 version. 2010 is spicier and some vanilla comes into play, too. (7, 4, 7, 4, 14: 3.6)

Bottle. Molasses, cherry, caramel malt aroma. Murky copper with a small beige head. Strong molasses, caramel malt, slight metallic, alcohol flavor with a spicy finish. Medium to full body, lively carbonation.

Dark amber almost copper with a foamy head. Aromas of light bread, banana, coriander, slight dark cherry, big caramel and toffee. Flavors of toffee, caramel, bread, slight alcohol, hints of banana, slight spice. Rich, sweet, and I like that bready thickness in this one.
A good beer but was expecting more.  Part of a beer festival tasting so likely deserves another taste. It is a decent beer just didnt pack enough flavour for dark belgian strong.

Poured from bottle. Aged 2 years. Pours amber gold with a medium thin white head...lots of lacing. Smells of cherries and ripe apple with some spice. Tastes malty sweet with chewy mouth feel and very light carbonation. You can tell the aging has tamed this down a bit. Great belgian, but I think I'll stick to it drinking a little more fresh next time. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

It pours mid-ruby brown with a strong nose of apple orchards, so much so that with your eyes closed it could be a cider. Its quite sweet with plenty of higher alcohols and a burnt sugar/ solvent finish. Im not too keen.

Pours a murky amber hue with  small white head that is mostly diminishing
Aroma of dark fruits, caramel, malt and molasses
Flavor is metallic and slightly watery with an alcoholic finish - still a good brew though
Medium mouthfeel with light carbonation
a goo brew

Tap at WF. Slightly cloudy dark amber. Strong aroma w. fruity almost fruitcake aroma. Very dark dried fruit and caramel flavor, a nice touch of hops, brown sugar finish. Overall very good dark Belgian. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft pours dark amber with sall tan head.  Aroma of dark fruits and sweet dough (like being in a bakery).  A myriad of flavors danced on my tongue;  plums, raisins, toffee, caramel, and sweet breaded malts.  One of the best Amercan-brewed Begians ales Ive tasted.

Poured into tulip, dark ruby with a finger of white head. Smell is rich plum and raisin, bit of fig and maybe a bit of booze. Taste is rich and decadent, full bodied, plum and raisin for sure, bit of cherry and some more dark fruit, and a bit more booze than I would care for. It is mildly complex but nothing mind blowing. Full bodied. Decent, but nothing spectacular.

On tap at Dubh Linns Square into a goblet.

A: Slightly hazy garnet body with a thin tan head, looks very nice.

S: Faint candied sugar and dark fruits, a bit too mellow.

T: Sweet! Candied sugar and dark fruits with a slightly spicy and medicinal cherry finish. This is one of the first Dubbels I enjoy.

M: Thick and syrupy with light carbonation.

O: This is a solid beer and I would highly consider buying this again.
330ml bottle from friend(thanks Kä!). Dark amber colour with tiny head. Aroma is spices. Flavour is malt, spicy, yeast, caramel. Great beer!
Tap. Murky light brown with thin dissipating head. Smells a little fruity and sweet. Nice flavor, sweet followed by a fruity/dry combo. Medium bodied.

(22 oz. (bottled 2/20/12, 1858) from Tullys) Pours dark red/amber/brown with a thin head. Sweet, heavy, fruity, candyish aroma. Mouthfeel smooth, a bit loose, syrupy in finish. Flavor is sweet, candyish, a little hot. Chocolate, cotton candy, fruit and yeast. A little overpowering.
Clear brown of color with a small beige head. An aroma of malt, toffee, sweets and prunes. A flavor toffee, sweets, malt, prunes and weak port. Reminds me of an oxidiced beer.

Pours a dark cloudy brown with an orange tint to it. Small tan head that quickly diminishes to a single layer of foam. Smells like dark fruits, more specifically raisins, and a little vanilla. Taste is sweet with notes of brandied cherry, fig, raisin and apple pie. Med bodied. Soft carbonation. After taste is syrupy, sweet, with a small warm alcohol finish, and then a little chalky dryness at the very end. This is a strong ale full of flavor, in true Belgian winter ale style.

22oz bomber poured into a Trappist glass. 2010 vintage. Pours a hazy brown with almost no head. Aroma of fruity malty sugar. Taste is lightly sweet. Fruity with some sugar and a good dose of caramel. Also a little spicy. Very complex with the alcohol well hidden. Full bodied with a creamy yet sticky texture. Lively carbonation and a long finish. Overall, not bad. I think I would like to try this fresh to compare the two.
Draft. Pours dark Amber with very little head. The aroma is stored fruit and fairly sweet. The taste us full of fig and raisins.. A bit of alcohol on the finish.

Draft at Eulogy. Dark amber red. Thick off-white head dissolves to a ring. Smells of light brandied cherry.  Bit sticky on the tongue.  Slight sourness. Very sweet. Strong hop bitterness runs alongside the sweetness but doesnt quite blend well enough.  May have needed more aging.

Pour dark, deep amber, with a thin white head ring of head.
Aroma is quite funky, with some dark fruits, candied tropical fruits, Belgian yeast, caramel. 
Taste is quite sweet. Medium - full bodied, with a semi-flat carb.
on tap, poured a murky copper. Thick beige head and lacing patterns. Aroma of dark fruit, belgian malt/yeast, cherry. Taste is boozey grapes, cinnamon, very sweet notes.
36cl, Vintage 2010, American brew, from The Bottle Shop Canterbury, complex brew, sweet/malty and slightly fruity/spicy, balanced, hazy, small head, good brew, yet expensive!

Hazy amber reddish pour thin ring of off white head .... aroma is of spicy dark fruits, caramel malts and lightly roasted .... taste is the same dark fruity yeast, spicy, lightly roasted, light chocolate, caramel malts .... lightly boozy with a dry malty and little bit of warming finish ... mouthfeel is rich

Aroma- dark sugar, caramel, malts, funk
Appearance- dark brown, quite murky, unappealing in nature
Taste- caramel sweetness, big malt backbone, some funk, dark fruits
Palate- medium-bodied, nice carbonation
Overall- A little bit let down by this one.  At $7 a goblet, this is overpriced and a bit pedestrian for Goose Island.

22oz bottle from Whole Foods.  Aroma of sticky sweet malts, port wine, and vanilla, with no hops evident.  Burnt orange color with minimal head.  Sweet flavors of  caramel malt and plum are just balanced by clean hop bitterness, with subdued but spicy hop flavor, and lively carbonation.  Alcohol is hidden extremely well.  Overall it starts out a bit thick, but gets better as you drink it.   Satisfying beer, will buy more to pair with a nice cut of red meat or rich dessert.

Initial lingering sweetness with bitter plums, caramel and some more sweetness. Soft carbonation, does need a little more upfront bitterness in my opinion. Alcohol is well hidden but this beer feels a little bit uninspiring.

Light brown and unclear. Has an off-white head, medium duration. Aroma is sweet, fruity, malty, sugars, faint yeasty. Heavy sweet flavor, harmonic, but too sweet, lacks some bitterness. Syrupy texture and flat carbonation.
sweet caramel, amber, hazy, off white foam, light sweetness, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, nice beer.

Amber red with frothy head; caramel and crystal malt aromas. Chalky mouthfeel with a sweet finish; no hop discernible. Reminds me more of a doppel bock and inferior version of Salvatore

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Color is hazelnutty brown. Small tan head. Aroma is fruity, caramel, yeast, sweet sugar and hint of alcohol. Taste is sweet.  Plenty of plums, brown sugar, yeast and alcohol. Decent..

Caremel, lighter body than it looks, easy drink then the fun starts. Citrusy tart entrence, smooths out to a medium full roasted but not bitter finish. tasted bigger than the IBU rating it has. Bold seasonal ale.

From notes.  First reviewed 4/28/2010.  Poured from a 12 oz. bottle into a tulip. Bottle date 6/2/09.

Out of the bottle, Pere Jacques pours a hazy brown amber color, with a medium fluffy white head. Decent retention, but the head eventually fades to a ring around the glass. No noticeable lacing. 

Sweet caramel malt, ripe plums and figs, slightly medicinal alcohol aroma, yeasty Belgian spiciness.

The flavor starts and stays sweet all the way through. Combined with the emerging alcohol, there is a boozy candy sensation. Spice from the Belgian yeast and some dark fruit flavors enter the mix. Mild hop presence at the end, still accompanied by a varied palette of spices. Too sweet for me.

The mouthfeel is a bit strange. It starts a bit crisp, but after the alcohol comes through in the taste, it develops an almost watery presence. It feels like it slides down my throat. Carbonation seems a bit low.

It is definitely a beer with a nice level of complexity, but I am not sure if the flavors all mesh together well enough for me. One is probably sufficient before moving on.

Deep red-amber-brown.  Cherry, brown sugar, and light banana.  Also some booze.  Flavor is relatively sweet with some caramel, brown sugar, light molasses, cherry, other fruit esters.  Alcohol apparent, but not detracting.  Lightly warming.  Some residual sweetness and toasted malt.

Part of gift pack with Sophie and Matilda. Big bottle into Maudite glass. Thin head with some fine lacing. Beer is murky medium brown with red-orange hues. Aroma is malty like the Matilda, but more "Belgian." Nice complexity in the flavor: candi sugar, alcohol, bitter dark fruits. Palate has a nice hop to it. Pretty bitter finish, and it lingers. Would want to find the right pairing for this one.

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2016 *(cuvée mars 2010): Couleur noisette avec une tête vivante et éphémère. Le nez est spectaculaire avec des notes de caramel, figues enrobés dans la vanille. En bouche cest aussi puissant, ça me rappelle la really old brown dog ale mais avec la touche levure belge. La texture est liquoreuse, collante avec un éventail de saveur assez bien lié.

2011 version.  Somewhat sweet aroma.  Appears a little viscous in the glass. A brownish pale color of iced tea. First taste is quite strong and provides a slight burning sensation down the hatch.  No head.  Yes, quite syrupy, almost cloying at times. Medicinal finish. Too much for this lager lover. Quite an alky punch impact.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Goose island has not let me down to date and this is no exception. The color of hazelnut with a medium head. A big beer with great caramel notes and yeast.
Pours dark with a mid off white head, small of banana, Yeast, and brown sugar. Taste of yeast and candy another great goose island I will for sure keep drinking this.

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2012 12 oz bottle shared by Jimmie. Poured a clear burnt red wih a smaller foamy light beige head. Aroma is very nice, big raisin bread, vanilla, bread. Flavor has more vanilla and alcohol with fruit notes coming in next finished by breads. Palate has some serious heat at first that settles quickly over a medium body and stronger carbonation. Good stuff.

12 oz bottle, 2011. Pours a dark burnt orange with small khaki head. The aroma has a dominant Amaretto character, along with bits of raisin, cherry, black currant, and Little Debbie cinnamon swirls. The flavor is nice and malty with raisin and cake notes. Fortunately its dry enough to cut all the richness. The finish has wood, earth, and alcohol notes. That Amaretto deal lingers into the aftertaste, which is quite nice. Tasty beer.

Bottle/22oz - Pours a dark reddish amber in color with a medium light tan head that stuck around to produce some really nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma is malty and slightly sweet with elements of caramel/toffee, some dark fruit and some of the lighter fruits also (apple?).  Flavor is slightly sweet and heavy with the caramel/toffee.  The dark fruit not as pronounced, but definitely some apple or pear or melon going on.  Better than average palate.  Lingering malty sweetness with some of the estery fruits as well.  No evidence of alcohol.  Excellent... really enjoyed this one...

9/23/11 notes: A amber brown in color, soft pearl white head. Aroma is sweet butter, ripe pear, melon, almond. Flavor is savory sweet, well balanced with spices, leading to a finish that doesnt end too drying, nor overly sweet. Very enjoyable.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2012 A - pours deep mahogany red with very small head with tight bubbles. 

S - aromas of apple juice and pineapple, earthy yeasts. 

M - medium body with tight lively carb. Lightly syrupy lingering end. 

T - honey and molasses on the nose, earthy yeasts dried fruits, apples and pineapple on the palate, lingering lightly peppery leather with amalty ending, slightly dry ending. 

O - very good strong bodies mildly sweet Belgian brew. Nice alcohol warming at end. 

7+
Very nice and raisiny abbey ale.  Similar to a quad but a bit lighter.

A cloudy, brown pour with a thin tan head.  The aroma is very fruity with just a hint of hops.  The medium body has a slick texture with average carbonation.  It has a sweet taste with some mild strawberry flavor and a warming alcohol finish.

2006 Vintage, cellared by moi. Aged this a bit more than I might otherwise have done; it was sneakily hidden in the back of the Big Stash O Beer. Opened with a gentle hiss, then poured into a snifter. Beautiful deep reddish-brown, with light carbonation and some light sediment evident. Nose is redolent of fruit; plum, raisins, maybe a hint of candy sugar. First taste confirms the fruit-up-front, with a gentle spritz of diminished carbonation. Rich mouth feel, with a lingering hint of leather and tobacco. This one has aged well.

2009 bottle. Pours a ruby reddish with a 1/8 head creamy white. Nice smell and taste caramel, bread, citrus, alcohol, darker fruits. clear, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, medium body, creamy, lively, bitter. Nice beer sweet with the booze taste in middle and a bitter hoppy type of finish. I found it be very nice warming of the stomach. May be a bit past peak but still very solid and nice.

Bomber. Pours a light copper to amber. Cloudy, unfiltered look, smallish head. aroma is semi ripe cherries and floral. Taste is belgian yeasty, farmhouse fruity, decent for the style....this was a 2010 ten bottle that should have been cellar kept, rather than under the liquor store lights!

2009 vintage.  Dead yeast suspended in cherry wood with a dissipating tan crown.  Aroma of yeast, fruit peel, toffee, honey, sugar and alcohol.  Taste is sweet with plums, dark fruit, sugar, yeast and alcohol.  Too sweet and sticky and some burn on the finish.

35cl bottle aged 3 years in my beer cellar.
decent off white head.  Slightly cloudy amber pour.  Yummy beer!

UPDATED: DEC 24, 2011 So wanted to try a "fresh" 2011 bottle. Pours Clear reddish amber with  big off-white head that leaves quickly. . Nose is semi-sweet malts with slightly dusty Belgian-type yeast. Lightly Spiced + yeasty front, earthy mild semi sweet malts  Semi-sweet throughout.  Medium body. Finish is a little boozy.

As it is,  it was decent but not that great for the style. Id obviously like to try a cellared version for comparison and see how it evolves with time.

Update: Found a 2010 bottle. 
similar to above but with a thinner head. Grape/plum notes in the nose and definitely in the taste.
definitely nicer than drinking it "fresh".

This is a review of the 2009 vintage, consumed in July 2011.

The beer pours a hazy medium brown color with an off-white head. The aroma is full of Belgian yeast, with some candy sugar and molasses notes. There is also a little bit of toffee and some biscuit malt. 

The flavor is similar. I get a lot of sweetness from the malt, molasses, candy sugar and brown sugar. There is also a nice Belgian yeast component and a little bit of dark fruit. The alcohol is also present. 

Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

(Bottle) Pours dark amber to reddish brown with an off-white head. The aroma holds nuts, almond paste, marzipan, brown sugar, sweet candy sugar, caramel/fudge, honey, bread, bread syrup, tropical fruits (melon, oranges, bananas and peach), canned pears, over ripe cherries, apples, grapes, raisins, figs, violet, coriander, wet ginger bread, metal/copper, phenols, herbal hops, flowers, wet sand and earth. Really Belgo-ish on the nose - yet too clean if you as me. The flavour is medium sweet and light bitter. Tones of nuts, sugar, caramel, honey, fudge, bread, melon, peach, banana, pears, apples, herbs, earth, light tart wood and light phenols. The mouthfeel is round, creamy, velvety and tiny sticky with a light/soft carbonation. Tart fruits, sugary malt and mild hops on the finish. Medium to full bodied.

Passed on from my brother.  Cloudy, dark brown pour with a medium sized tan head. Smell is sugary, with a caramel and malty smell sticking out. Toffee sweet and bready. Not something to drink a lot of but enjoyable overall.

12oz bottle 2010. Light mahogany, quickly fading biege head. Sweet malt, brown sugar, toffee, plum. Sweet, brown sugar, high carbonation, medium body, some yeast and malt on the finish, bit dry with some booze.

Bottle @ home. 2010 vintage. Very cloudy, brown appearance wit ha smallish tan head. Thick candy sugar, dark caramel malty, toffee, Belgian yeasty aroma. Fairly thick, rich toffee, thick candy sugar, dark caramel malty flavor thats quite sweet and somewhat bready. Kind of one dimensional, though drinkable.

UPDATED: MAY 12, 2013 Date: November 4, 2011 Mode: Bottle Source: Zipps Appearance: Translucent reddish brown with slight head. Aroma: caramel and fruit. Flavor: Consistent with aroma and sweet, thin to medium bodied and smooth. Other: Got better as it warmed.

May 11, 2013 - bottle at GI 25th anniversary party.  2005 vintage and this was really good.  Moved rating up to a 3.8 from 3.4.

#700..The 2011 version.  Pours a dark, iced tea color with no head.  Aroma had a slight whisky smell.  Definitely stronger on alcohol.  More of a brown ale smell than a belgian.  The taste was roasty malt, slight caramel, bourbon and alcohol.  Warm caramel aftertaste.  Not my favorite Goose Island specialty brew, but not the worst.

0.33l bottle @ Monks Café Sveavägen, Stockholm. Pours a murky brown body, little to no head. The aroma is sweet with a little sour tone, malty and oxidized with a hint of butter. Soft to no carbonation and a slick old oily mouthfeel. Flavors are also quite oxidized, hints of sour berries, wood, yeast, butter, caramel and floral tones. Solid and really nice stuff, but the 2007 bottle is perhaps a bit over its peak. Dont mind trying this again!

RBESG Sheffield 2009 Grand Tasting @ the Harlequin. 
Bottle 2008 vintage.
Hazy brown with  brown head. Ripe fruit aroma with a quite intense alcoholic hint The taste is very seet malty, lots of fruit. Despite the dry finish and a noticeable hops present I found it to sweet for my likings and quite unbalanced.

April 2010 bottle, consumed October 2011.
Reddish brown, beige head.
Aroma: fruity, vanilla, malty.
Taste: sweet maltiness, vanilla, licorice, fruity, vinous, some (heather?) honey, some floral notes.
Above medium-bodied, small soft bubbles.
Very well-balanced and tasty. I dont think its very interesting to talk about whether it stands up to Belgian examples of the style. American interpretations belong in their own category, and this is a good one.

Bottle from 2009. Pours a deep dark red orange with a small, but long-lasting, yellowish brown head. Aroma is dried, dark fruits, figs, date, toasted caramel, some port vinous tones. Taste is dark fruit, toasted caramel, fig, prune, raisin, some alcoholic and liquorice tone on the finish. Afteraste is rather dry with herbal and woody notes as well as strong tones of dried apricots and some port vinous notes. Palate is nicely carbonated and medium. Quite good alone, but not good with a tapas plate. Especially the Limburger cheese killed everything interesting about the beer, rendering it woodily dry.

Serving: 12 oz. bottle from State Line Liquors.  It pours a deep amber color with a very small, light tan head.  This brew seems pretty still.  The nose is a good bit of dark fruit, raisin, malt, and treacle.  The flavor is on the sweet side  with a papery bitterness.  A good bit of dried apple, pear, some date, raisin, and graham cracker.  Medium to rich body with a little bit of booze in the finish.  I think this one could have used some more time to take out the sweetness and develop more character.  Still, its a pretty taste beverage.
355 ml, bottled. Pours hazy red. Aroma: Rye, alcohol, chocolate, liqourish, malt, bread, cherry, alcohol. Taste: Quite sweet, light bitterness.. Palate: Light body, soft carbonation.
Bottle pours red/orange. Smells wonderful. Light Belgian vibe. Toffee, caramel and sour fruit. Sweet and sticky. Very high grade.

Bottle.
Pours red orange.
Taste of fruit liqoure, mainly plums. Sweet and smooth, bit brett-like tartness.
Bottle. Nice beer! Slightly sour, red berries, chocolate, quite dry, some wood in the finish.
pours a cloudy brown with an off white head. Nose and taste is of malts with a slightly tart finish. A so so ager.

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2012 190111: @DØE Århus Syd meeting. Belgian inspired American beer with a smooth, soft and pleasant taste, without much much alc. taste. The aftertaste is a little weak. little for even belgian taste..

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2016 1/16  rerate    dropped rating from 3.6.   not the type of dubbel I like.  too sweet and dry at end; not much flavor.   passé........................................9/12 rerate - dropped several spots; nice but thinking there are better out there - no parts outstanding - but solid brew  first rating was 4.0; maybe one more try to see which is right.


VERY NICE!! bomber purchased in CO.  caramel amber pour.  aroma of    

dark fruit and toffe/sugar.  Nice palate - smooth and creamy mouthfeel.  No real spice in taste.  Taste was sweet malt, toffe, dark fruits but slightest of hops and slight alcohol that balanced this really well.  Damn good brew.
no head, but a nice caramel brown colour. nose with a littl eyeast and some sugar. Medium body and some length. A bit fatnes with sweetness and orange peel, Pleasant enough but rather simple.
Very good strong ale. Pours a nice dark color with only a small white head. Lots of flavor. Quite refreshing. I liked it a lot.

Stor maltdoft. Doftar som ett sädesupplag och massor av beskt apelsinskal och pommerans. Fruktig fyllig, ganska söt, rejäl beska åt marmeladhållet, bröd, liten jästton. Medellång eftersmak. Fint öl att sippa. Saknar jästigheten som oftast finns hos belgarna.

Bottle at home. Gorgeous reddish brown colour, no head. Nose is big, sweet, rich rich caramel and a tiny bit of fruit. Palate is slick and smooth, with light carbonation. Caramel, syrup, some booze and a sticky sweet finish. Absolutely gorgeous stuff.

Shared a 22oz bottle, pre-AB 2010 vintage. Poured a ruby red color with a medium sized white head, aroma was caramel, spices, dark fruits. Flavor was molasses, spice notes, fruits. Pretty enjoyable. Alcohol either mellowed or was well masked.

This reminds me of my french like stronge ale.I think it could use more bitterness but maybe would not be to its style.Very caramley in aroma and taste smoothe slick mouthfeel a touch of dryness with raison dark candy vanilla sweetness.Maybe a bit syrupy, boozy a bit of citrus bitterness hiding in it. From my short experience with barleywines and abbeys this tastes more like a barleywine englishstyle low hopped.

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2011 Smells like a decent boozy Belgian strong ale, but it tastes very diluted.  Very little carbonation.  Almost no bitterness. Light sweetness.  It has a prominent boozy taste, but not too harsh.  This beer lacks gusto.  I wont buy again, but it isnt horrible.

I just opened a bottle dated 3/8/08, with the same labeling at the sample picture. It poured satiny smooth with no head at all and a rich, cloudy dark amber. It featured a massive amount of sediment, which didnt take away at all. The smell was subtle and of candied fruit, and slightly sweet with slight alcohol aromas. The taste was exceptional. It was both yeasty and sweet, somewhat like candied fruit. The mouthfeel was extremely smooth with little carbonation and had a medium body. The aging definitely smoothed this one out quite a bit. This was exceptional at almost 2 1/2 years old. The Pere Jacques is a top notch Belgian Dubbel.

UPDATED: OCT 5, 2013 (Oct. 5 2013 update) 2012 vintage. Brownish-red pour. Short-lived off-white head. Aroma of Belgian malts, sugars, and red grapes. Medium body.  More of an alcohol bite in the taste.  Lingering finish.

(Aug 14, 2011 rating=3.4)From the 2010 vintage.  It pours a medium to dark amber with a nice amount of foamy head.  The aroma is mainly sweet with a subtle touch of hops to balance it out.  The body is in the medium range.  It is also extremely sweet to taste with no finish to speak of.

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2013 12 oz Bottle from Party Source, Bellevue, KY.  Thin head dissapates quickly.  Color is a slightly murky light brown.  Aroma and flavor are full of caramel and dark fruit (raisin, cherry).  Alcohol is somewhat hidden - drinks fairly easy.

Bottle @ GBBF 2011. A hazy red/brown colored beer with a light beige head. The aroma of fruits like cherries and malts. The taste has sweet fruits, like cherries with some spices like coriander. A little alcohol. The aftertaste is sweet with some bitter.
12oz bottle. Pours opaque amber with beige head. Lasting foam. Aroma is slightly alcoholic, lots of caramel malts, raisin. Taste is loaded with raisin, caramel malts. Some hoppiness too.

Vintage 2011. Murky amber pour with very little head, even a hard high pour couldnt coax much out of this one. The aroma is dried fruits (raisins) and apples, with a distinct whiff of booze. Full bodied with low carbonation. The flavor is sweet caramel, apples, and sherry. Sweet throughout, very slight hops on the finish. The finish is dominated by alcohol. Not very well balanced and boozy. Kind of like an underhopped barley wine. Dissapointed.

12oz 2011 bottle, pours a a murky brown with a thin head,  aroma is of dark fruit mixed in with some caramel and malt, the flavor has a nice sweetness to it and finishes with dark fruit and spices, pretty smooth mouthfeel, not bad.

2010 bottle...pours a hazy amber with a quickly dissipating medium tan/orange head.  Aroma is fruity...rasins, apple, red licorice...sweet and a bit doughy...slight alcohol.  Flavor follows suit...definitely sweet...also some caramel...no noticeable alcohol.  Silky mouthfeel and a slightly roasted finish.  Not a huge fan of this one.

Drinking a 2009 and a 2011....I will start with 2009....its tasty but oxidized....now on to the 2011...Pours red/brown with off-white fizzy head. Aroma of red Apple and Apple peel. Flavor isnt much different with a bit of spice, vegitable and malt. Mouthfeel is medium body with medium-high carbonation. Overall, I liked the 2009 better.....

2009 bottle thanks to secret Santa. Poured  hazy amber with a white head. Aroma was brown sugar, dark fruits, and caramel. Flavor was dark fruits brown sugar, and oxidized. Body was full with soft carbonation.
strong yeast and raisin aroma. dark brown pour with little head. loads of raisin, creamy heavy mouthfeel. great beer.
Dried fruits, banana and nuts is on the nose. Flavor I get a ton of raisins and caramel followed by pear, apple cider and booze. Creamy mouthfeel, but yet more watered down, hard to explain.
UPDATED: JUL 26, 2011 From a bottle poured a brown color with a small amount of head.  Strong sweet malty flavor with a lasting finish.

Bottle from Beers of Europe. Amber colour, tan head. Nose is malty, bready, little spicy and yeasty. Flavour is malts, yeast, caramel, candy sugar and spices. Finish is sweet with a little alchol punch.
Bottle from Alko Arkadia. Originally rated on 4.5.2010. Okay, but quite generic Belgian style ale. Slightly boring.
Dark nutty brown with tan head. Arom is rich with toffee, citrus, flowery hops and some fruits. Aroma is slightly thinner with malt, toffee and alcohol warmth. Noticeable bitterness.

Very easy to drink belgian ale that has an immediate nose of brown sugar, but that doesnt mean that it is an overly sweet beer. Drinks very smooth and has a bit of vanilla in the end that makes you want to keep sipping it.

Bottle 2010 vintage ... Murky deep amber pour , thin off white head , sparse lacing . Heavy sweet malt aroma , notes of fruit , wood and spice . Medium to full bodied . Sweet and fruity , notes of alcohol, plum , caramalized sugar ,licorice and black currant . Finish is bitter and dry with a metallic twang .

Bottled 3/26/10.  Aroma reminds me of spiced apple cider, though its cooler on the nose and darker fruit than apple.  Cloudy brown pour with a touch of red, good head lingers for some time.  Good blend of spice and sweet on the flavor, following the aroma nicely, and both linger a bit on the tongue.  Very nice.

12oz bottle in a shaker.  Pours copperish brown with a thin, cream colored head.  Aroma of spicy yeast, toffee and nuts in the malts, and some light citrusy/floral hops.  Flavor finishes strong on the toffee with a little alcohol.  Average texture.  A pretty good beer.

From notes:

pours a dark ruby red color with a two finger yellowish beige head that has very good retention, slowly settling into a thick lasting cap. Soapy lacing left behind.

Spicy aroma that is countered by some bread, dark fruit, alcohol and faint hops. Hints of clove, cinnamon and pepper along with some plum, raisin and dark berry. The spice is a bit overpowering in the nose.

Full bodied and complex with a nice balance of sweet malt, zesty spice, sweet dark fruit and alcohol heat. Pretty malt forward with hints of pepper, clove and candy sugar followed by some bready yeast and dark fruit. Hints of raisin, plum, date and figs balanced by faint earthy hops. Slight alcohol heat toward the finish but overall the ABV is well masked making this beer easy to drink.

One of the better American interpretations of the style.

The label is as simple as can be.  Very fine, sweet, malty aroma.  A rich, sweet Belgian with flavors of caramel, brown sugar, and prunes.  There are some gentle hops in the closing.  It is not earth-shaking, but it is another very nicely done Belgian ale from GI.
Amber with a small white head. Sweet with fruity tones. Malt, fruit an sweet. medium to full body with nice bitteesweet finish.

Appearance: reddish brown, with a short, creamy light tan head.  Aroma: warm cinnamon raisin bread, with notes of yeast, candi sugar, booze and figs. Taste: sweet and malty, with fruity notes of plums and raisins soaked in port, over caramel and burnt sugar .   Finish: 	smooth, slightly syrupy and almost too sweet.   Notes: A fine Belgian ale, seemingly in the dubbel style.  Just a bit too much on the boozy-sweet side of balanced for my preferences, but still good.
Pours dark amber with an off white head. Aroma is malts, dark fruits and spice. Flavor is Malts, yeast and dark fruits. Medium bodied with medium carbonation. Pretty good overall.

Dark amber/cider color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of yeast, sweet malt, dark fruit, & spice; Flavor of sweet malt, yeast, dark fruit (notably plums), raisons, caramel, and spice; Nicely balanced; Pretty good overall.

Aroma:  Slightly musty, with some definite malt character.
Appearance:  Nice dirty brown color but with no head retention at all.
Taste:  Nice roastiness present initially.  Malt character, very light chocolate, and earthy herbs present at the finish.
Palate:  Nice fuller body, but with a little too much bite for me.
Overall:  Excellent beer with wonderful malt character.  Thought this could have been just dynamite with a little more exciting yeast flavor.

UPDATED: SEP 3, 2011 2010 bottle... medium clearish brown, too light, off whitehead, not a ton to look at... light aroma, caramel and dark fruits, not a ton going on... the taste is just boring, dark fruits, blah... not worth having
Bottle. Pours clear brown/orange. Aroma is floral, dark fruits, peach, syrup, nuts. Flavour is of syrup, pear, dark fruits, Dry with moderate sweetness.

Poured a lighter brown with a small head.  It was cloudy with some particles.  Nose and flavor full of brown sugar and roasted toffee.  The carbonation was soft, the finish was somewhat bitter and astringent.  The finish was very long lasting.  Very tasty!

Bomber from BOTW, served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass. Bottled JUN 10. 
App.:  Clear deep copper with a so-so tan head.
  
Aroma:  Rich malts, lots of dark dried fruits and brown sugar, cola- or root beer-like minty herbals, notes that veer into chocolate territory, so sumptuous and sweet and inviting, light playful esters, a hint of nuttiness and spiciness, really fruity, maybe a hint of yeast and citrus peel?, really nice and approachable.
  
Palate:  Medium+ body, somewhat restrained effervescence with a few prickly bubbles.
  
Flav.:  Lots and lots of rich malts, quite fruity, dark dried fruits, brown sugar, less of the minty herbals and other notes, some banana Weizenbock-like esters, thoroughly pleasant, still hints of citrus peel, a little nutty, spicy and woodsy, veering towards chocolate/vanilla, nice; lightly sweet with sufficient balancing bitterness and a long, sweet, gooey fruity malt finish with a little warming alcohol and a touch of mintiness.

Whos your Pere?  You are Jacques.  Nicely done.
nose is cola, weak sweet hops, raspberry, feel is medium, carb is mediumbroad, taste is sherry warm, red apple acid, medium malt and a weak hops finish

Pours rusty orange with a small off-white head which fades into nothingness rather quickly. Aroma is mostly of dark fruits and belgian yeast. Figs, plums, raisins, cloves. Flavor is of spicy, syrupy raisins with a dry finish. A bit overly sweet but still good.

12 oz. bottle, pours orangey-copper with an off-white head. Aroma of candied sugar, bubblegum, caramel and green apple. Flavour is quite complex with bubblegum, candied sugar, slight spiciness, apple and caramel. No characteristic outdoes the other - everything is in perfect balance. Finishes with candied sugar, some of the spiciness and green apple. Very well-crafted.
12 ounce bottle.  2010.    Pours a hazy amber with a small biege head.  Aroma of malt, fruit and yeast.  Taste is sweet malt and dark fruit.  Feels creamy.  Very, very nice.

UPDATED: AUG 19, 2013 Poured to samplers and paired with cheese morsels during this years Summertime Dock Party at the Fulton brewery. Advanced a few samples to a larger glass to review. Displayed a clear, deep gold/amber hue, with modest, off white head foam, bubbly ring, and some wavy lacing. The nose was initial alcohol presence, caramel sweetness, a touch of spice and fruit notes as apple and raisin. The flavor added only low hop bitterness, but smooth malt and warming alcohol, in a medium body. Very full flavored! Recently shared 12 oz. bottle from 07 at Chucks beer bunker for his b-day. Poured to a tulip showing a brownish amber hue, a light amount of off white/light tan head, and some leggy spotting on the glass. Syrupy sweet, esters/pear & alcohol, caramel, and some added vanilla in the flavor. Medium+ bodied, subtle notes, smooth, and still a bit warming.
Bottle 2010. Good beer. A tad sweet, sour and bitter. Kinda fruity smell to it. Not huge fan on Belgian beers. Will try  again/ =)

355ml bottle. Pours dark amber or perhaps a light chestnut colour. The nose is of toffee and nuts. The taste is rich, deep, toffee, nuts and sweet malt. The palate has a big, deep structure with a creamy texture with a tangy (if not completely clean) finish. Overall, this is a big beer with deep flavour and complex notes.

Thanks for the share at DLD 11, it had a really nice finish and a dark fruity aroma, something like a date. The taste was surprising really fruity and not much of the darker malts from what a belgian strong usually has I find, but It was a really dark brown colour, pretty good offering
Bottle at Dark Lord Day. Thanks for the share. Vintage 2009. Pours very dark with small head that retains. Medium body that isnt too strong. Very dark Belgian notes. Very good.

Bomber many thx to ekstedt cons 2011-04-01 Göteborg
AR: butter fudge, M & Ms, banan
AP: fudgy brown, oily, creamy head
F: butter fudge, bananas

Bottle, from trade with Abstractbeer, cheers bro! :-) Slightly hazy orange, vanishing small white head. Nose is lovely fruity: strawberries, raspberries, melon, sweet yeasty Belgian tones and hints of peanuts, wood and caramel. Very well toned. Taste is more of the same; highly integrated tones of caramel, raspberries, peanuts, wood and candy sugar. Full-bodied and nice mouthfeel. A sweet Belgian, but fruity and balanced enough not to go over the top. Great stuff.
Tried this beer at the Casanova Beer Cave Festival (2011), had a nice taste.
2009 bottle. Aroma with caramel and some fruits. Taste is very sweet with medium body palate. Overall very fruity and very sweet.
Bottle. Medium orange amber, off white head. Aroma of sweet caramel, banana, pear, spices. Flavours of sweet caramel, Christmas cake, maraschino cherries, spices. Smooth, full bodied, warming finish.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: 2010 vintage. Cloudy amber colour. Sweet, malty aroma with hints of dried fruit. Taste is also sweet with clear notes of raisin malt. Rich and full in the mouth. This feels better tha it tastes.

355ml bottle, 2011 vintage.  Pours a hazy dark orange with no head.  Aroma is raisin malt with a little apple.  Taste starts with some toffee and raisin malt on the finish.  Tasty but a little one sided on the taste.

9 Sept 2010, bottle - 2010 vintage. kind of hazy red colour w/ some sediment. lots of wet malt on nose. not wet bread but not a wheat smell you expect in some belgians. taste has some faint hints of rose. definitely yeasty and malty. sweet and moderately fizzy. some slight cherry malt finish. wouldnt say this is belgian but i understand "belgian style". not bad but one is enough.

2009 bottle. Pour is dark hazy amber with a creamy fizzy kahki head that dissipates to a collar. Aroma is brown sugar spice and pitted fruit. Taste is sweet mellow spice and plum and fig notes. Palate is medium feel and good subtle carbonation with a slick chaulky finish. Nice beer tasty!
Pours clear amber with a small cream head. Caramel nose, musty hop presence. Nice flavor of fruit and yeast over that caramel base.

Finally put down some $$$ for this enticing 4 Pack - In short, a good showing.  Caramel and hay backed with a pretty decent hops presence.  Yeasty dough characteristics pervade.  So...to cellar this one "up to five years" as advertised on bottle.  Nah, I dont see how this is going to develop into anything exceptional with additional ageing.  Overpriced, but good showing from reliable brewery.

Reviewed from notes.

Served in a goblet. Pours a moderate brown color with a bit of a light amber hue. Off-white head with a tad bit of lacing, though nothing substantial. Nose brings a bit of caramel and a small amount of dark fruits. A bit of light sweetness.

The taste is a bit bland, as there really arent any complexities showing through and there is just a generic dark malt and fruit combination without much more there. Mouth is a bit creamy on a medium body. Drinks okay, but this is a bit less than the type of Belgian-style ale than I expect from Goose.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-13-2010

Bomber purchased a year ago ("bottled 02/26/2010") at Holiday Wine Cellar ($7.59).  Pours a nice dark copper hue but with only a half finger of beige foam.  Aroma is rather weak but includes notes of dark caramel, bready malts, and some dark fruit.  Flavor of rich caramel, malt (dark bread), sticky fruit (raisin and cherry stand out), some spice, and some booze.  Lightly dry finish with lingering sweetness.  Low carbonation with a rather heavy mouthfeel.  (881, 517)

Bottle, mybrewerytap.com. Very red beer, heavy and fruity, with flavours of boiled sweets, yeast and ripe fruit. Very Belgian in every aspect, finish is a bit short, sugary aftertaste that coats the tongue somewhat.

Bottled from Systembolaget
Deep amber with a small, white head. Some yeast particles.
Malty aroma with sweet fruits in both aroma and flavour. Vinour with nice warming alco-feel.
Bottle. Amber beer with an offwhite head. Toffee aroma, yeast, brown sugar and some chocolate. Toffe flavor, brown sugar, raoasted, yeasty and with some chocolate.

2011 bottle.  Orangish mahogany color with a thin quick-leaving head.  Aroma is truly Belgian, with ripe dark fruits, a little bit of lavender, and a big earthy malt tone.  Taste is pretty earthy and floral malt forward, with notes of some caramel.  No real malt bitterness to speak of.  End is typical Belgian-dry, with yeasty notes and dark ripe fruit.  Not bad, just not original enough to wow me.

Bottle vintage 2010. Clear dark amber/chestnut with a yellowish head that falls fast without much much trace.
Sticky sweet nose of overripe fruit, caramell, spice, dough and booze. A bit liqueur/congnac feel to it.
Taste is sweet with butterscotch, caramell, slightly burnt, candied fruit, marmalade, syrup, dark berries. Robust maltbase, short bitterness, warming alcohol and a tobacco like dry ending.
Mouthfeel is sticky and oily and the carbonation is very low and just slightly tickeling. Keep it in the cellar a bit more.
Draft. Dark black colkor. Tastes of malt, yeast and fruittnotes of banana and apricot and plum. Awesome

Bottle, thanks to ekstedt!2010 version bottled 04/16/10, sampled on April 1, 2011Hazy copper color, nice fluffy head thats nto very lasting. Very sweet and sugary, fruity, alcohol scent. Sweet, malty, alcohol, fruity taste. Moussy mouthfeel, medium bitterness.
Bottle (bomber) from Systembolaget. Hazy copper, medium off-white head. Nutty and fudgy aroma, with some herbal hops. Medium bodied and smooth. Well balanced, semi-dry with low bitterness.

UPDATED: JUN 7, 2013 Courtesy of ekstedt. Pours clowdy dark copper with small bubbly tanned head nice lace. Aroma is sweet, hoppy, madeira, fruity, raisins. Medium sweet Mouthfeel. Flavor is thin sweet, alcohol, candy, raisins, madeira, caramel. Thin sweet Palate. Finishes tart and sweet.
130607, bottle 2010 vintage. Beautiful deep red mahogany pour nice lightly tannned lacing head. Huge aroma of grapes raisins malts fidges some dark fruits sweet fruity. Flavir balanced soucy sweet yeadty fruity raisins medium pleasant bitterness. So enjoyable.

Bottling date: 16/04/2010. Unclear redbrown with a small tanned head. Berry, oak, raisins, dried fruits and caramel flavours. Has a light sweetness. Very nice! Kind of like a non-sour Rodenbach Vintage. Great with cheese!

Sampler at the W&C in Ballwin, Mo.  It poured a reddish/brown with a tan head.  The aroma was lots of dark fruit. The taste was sweet with molasses and goes right into the dark fruits.  It finished slightly bitter from the alcohol. Nice belgian brew.

Poured into a snifter. Pere Jacques pours a rich mahogany/amber color with a short white head that has almost no retention but a ring around the inside of the glass. Light lacing. Aromas were of grapes, raisins, clove and a strong cinnamon presence. Tasting this beer after hearing about it for so long was an absolute delight. Sweet raisins were the backbone of the flavors, with a nice blend of the cinnamon and clove makes this an outstanding dubbel. Mouthfeel is nice, very smooth, not heavy at all. Very complex palate. Carbonation is low to mild. I was shocked when I saw that it was 9%, which is pretty high for a dubbel, you dont get that high alcohol taste from this, which is probably due to the aging. I would definitely love to get some more of this, since it was delightful. Based on style, this could be the best dubbel I have had yet.

Drank 3/19/11. 2010 vintage. Bomber into tumbler, shared with Brenn79. Pours a hazy orange with a quick collapsing light-beige head. Aroma is strong in carmael malt, to the point of cloying. Taste is super sweet with no bitterness. Tastes a bit like caramel corn. Carbonation is medium-high, full-bodied and oily. Way too friggin sweet for my tastes.

2010 bottle:Pours a coppery amber colour with a rich head. Sweet aroma with notes of caramel, candy and marzipan. Sweet flavour with notes of caramel, honey and marzipan. Alcohol bitter finish. Too sweet for me.

22 oz. bottle- Pours cloudy orange with a thin white head, aroma is malty, similar to a German dark lager, some caramel in the nose. The taste is extremely malty, with sweet candy like flavors, candy corn, caramel. Interesting but not anything I would want to have again.

Bottled 2009 Vintage.  A reddy brown coloured beer with a slight haze due to the yeast, and a small whitish head.  Over sweet, malty and yeasty.  A bit of wood and chocolate in the nose.  Acidity in the mouth.  Heavy carbonation.  Sour oranges and chocolate.  Not a good combination of things going on.

Deep amber, mahogany a little brown.. tan head fads quickly then came back with great retention when agitated... lightly tart aroma, sugary dark some vanilla, malty kinda sweet aroma... caramel sweetness belgian yeast dark fruits def some cherry some vanilla... semi lively medium full body... very nice beer definitely some fruits...

2010 bottle sampled at home with pineapple pork chops.  The aroma is not clearly defined... Im loathe to characterize it this way, but "typical Belgian strong ale" is the only thing I could really think of.  Sweet malts, some breadiness and some candy.  The appearance is similarly average.  A very dark orange coloration with a big-bubbled head that sits in a very thin layer on top of the beer  throughout.  The flavor is nice, but gets a bit cloying as the sweetness is not quite totally balanced by what ends up being a very modest spicy hop profile.  Enspectacular, but pretty good at what it does.

12 oz twist off bottle. 2010 edition.

It pours a reddish/brownish maroon that is delicately hazed. The head is large and off-white and the lacing doesnt stick a whole lot as it recedes slowly.

The nose is big and fruity with a ton of raisin, red grape, and some spiciness. 

The taste is similar, it is slightly twangy with the said yeast notes and a heightened amount of malt flavor in the taste. It is a bit watery though which is the main qualm I have with this beer.

Overall it is decent but nothing special really.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-09-2010 23:43:30
Bottle, 2010 vintage, 8% ABV. Pours brown, minimal head, very little carbonation. Slight aroma, thick bodies strong brown taste.

Mine was 9 % ABV and Vintage 2008. Clear dark amber with very little head and lots of yeast floating around. Aroma is sweet, malty, dried fruit and alcohol. Flavor is very sweet and only slightly bitter. Sweet finish. Too sweet. If I hadnt read the label I would say its a barley wine. 280211

Bottle, vintage 2009. Gift from Rune, thanks mate!  A finger og yellow-shaded blond foam, over a misty ruby-reddish body. Sweet malts and sweet alcohol-scented fruit-cocktail aroma. Taste is sweet chewy caramelly malts with some mild spice tones and distinct hop bitterness. Some fruit tones, and noticable alcohol presence. More than medium full. Oily, almost syrupy texture. A tad too far on the sweet side for my likings. Nothing extraordinary, a straightforward Belgian strong.

Beautiful, copperbrown beer with medium and beige head. Aroma is malty and sweet, toffee, berryjuice (Mehukatti) concentrate; strongly sweet aroma, still quite nice. Taste is also first sweet with some balancing roastiness and herbal spicyness, aftertaste is quite dry. Almost full bodied and slippery to drink, pleasant. Toffeeish and berry aromas reminds me from english ales, then taste is maybe more typical belgian ales; sweet beer that would need more trimming and more sophisticated setting.
Bottle @ Plovmand tasting. Amber body with a small white head. Aroma is sweet caramel, perfume and malt. Flavor is caramel, sweet alcohol and malt.

Poured from a 22oz. Bottle. 2010. Pours very smooth, with a thin white head, and minimal lacing. Aroma is slightly sweet and malty with a hint of hops. Also detect some dried fruit type smells. Flavour is pleasant, sweet, and still getting the taste of raisins, banana, and Carmel. Overall this is a good beer, that is very similar to Lagunitas Hairy Eyeball.

2009 12oz bottle. Pours a reddish amber color with a white head. Aromas are sweet, malty, slight spices, and banana once it warms up a bit.  Flavor is yeasty, clove, banana, caramel, and touch of cinnamon.
Smell is strong alcohol, spicy, hoppy.  Taste is alcohol, nutty, spicy.  Just not my cup of tea.  Will not be having again..
Pours a dark amber color with a small fluffy beige head. Has a sweet aroma with hints of spice, yeast, caramel and malts. Flavor is spicy with sweet malt, and alcohol with a hint of caramel.

2010 Bottle; Dark golden brown pour with an off white head that retains fairly well - light lacing in a snifter. Aromas lean towards the malty side - Graham cracker crust, vanilla, and toffee on the nose. There is a slight tropical fruit feel that appears hidden, at least initially. I think what is quite evident though, is that this is the best Belgian interpretation from Goose Island that Ive sampled. Good enough to try again, actually.

2010 bottle. Hazy amber pour with a yellow head which fades quickly to leave modest lace. Sweet, slightly metallic nose. Heavy, lightly carbonated body with flavors of dates, ripe peaches, caramel and some spices: cinnamon and cloves. Finish is, impossibly, sweet and short with some umami creeping in alongside some booziness. This is a wonderful BSA and Im going to get another two bottles tomorrow - one to share and one to cellar.
Balanced flavor and really just a great American interpretation of a Belgian style that hits the mark.

Really appealing darker amber, with a short lived, sparkly white head.  750mL bottle, drank it from a Duvel Tulip.  Nose is almost all malt - some sweet ripe, dark fruits in there, but not much, mostly roasty malts, maybe a little yeasty funk (hehe... I said yeasty funk).  Taste is dominated by dark, caramel malts, and spices... cloves and cinnamon.  Theres a smoky almost spicy bite to the finish, with a surprising alcohol presence considering its only 8% ABV.  All in all a pretty damn good beer, and an excellent example of a textbook Belgian Strong Ale.  Nothing really wows me about this beer, but its balanced, and well executed.

Bottles 2009, shared by Pinball at plovmand tasting. 
Pours a amber colour with a white head. 
The aroma is sweet and has notes of caramel malt, toffee spice and alcohol. 
Flavour is sweet with notes of caramel malt, light ripe fruits and a bitter hint.

Appearance: murky amber with some garnet highlights along the sides. Off-white head is thin but tight, slowly crawling up the sides of my glass as if to escape. Swirls with puff while maintaining a collar.

Nose: Cinnamon and brown sugars melt into maple and molasses. Homemade applesauce and cinnamon apple wedges, lightly stewed please. Whole wheat breads are soft and chewy; hint of rye seeds. Pears stewed in the aforementioned cinnamon, brown sugar, and molasses. Most of the sweetness lingers in the back; thankfully not cloying. Black cherries and plums in the front and middle.

Palate: sweet up front and in middle for the opposite of the nose. Spiced and dry in the back, lingering long into an equally dry spiced finish. Chocolate in the breath. Apple skins, plums, and pears ripe and juicy, spiced and autumnal. Cinnamon sticks and nutmeg and faint sprinkles. Plummy. Candied apple skins, just the skins please.

Final Thoughts: most intriguing indeed. Initially I was a bit unsure but it didnt take long for yet another Goose Island specialty to win this beer geeks affections. Yummy.
Bottle. Slightly hazy orange amber colour wiht a small off white head. Aroma and taste of malt, fruits and caramel with nice hoppy notes. Good beer.
22oz bottle courtesy of lance, sweet caramel aroma, some spicy  hints on first sip, nothing spectacular.

Bottle. Bottled on 07/14/10. Poured into a tulip glass a slightly hazed copper orange color with a thick, fluffy off whtie head. The aroma is a very sweet cereal type with some fruit type esters like pear and some spice, I am sort of wishing the nose had a more pronounced aroma as it is rather subtle. Medium mouthfeel. The taste is sweet and malty with an aftertaste of belgian abbey flavors along with some breadiness.  Nice lace as I drink this down. Ends rather dry with a lingering boozy flavor. Decent.
Bottle 355 ml. Poured brown in colour with beige head. Aroma is toffee, dark fruits and malty. Flavour is malty with dark fruit sweetness. A bit too sweet.

Medium amber, clear, strong small head.  Aromas are scant, bit of candi sugar, not much else.  Taste is sweet, aftertaste of medium-dark caramel malts are a bit overpowering.  Thats about it; very little fruity esters, very little complexity, an overdose of caramel malt.  Finishes with a bit of harsh hop bitterness, just a brush of spicyness.  No idea why this is rated so high, unless previous years were way better.  Mediocre.
edit:  this was the 2010 iteration.

Deep red orange in color... Very cloudy with plenty of sediment... Aroma is candi sugar... Flavor is a mix of citrus, grapes a la chardonnay or a Chateau Jiahu, and candi sugar.... Some berry notes... Finish is classic dubbel, notes of banana... Delicious
Pours a reddish brown color. Has a nice sweet candied sugar Belgium taste with orange, and floral tastes.

22 oz. bottle purchased at Woodmans in Madison, WI (2009 bottle).  Pours dark orange with a light pinkish hue with a thin off-white head.  Aroma of Belgian candi sugar, bubblegum, and light citrus.  The flavor contains sweet notes mostly but is well balanced and not too syrupy.  A very slight alcohol warming component is detected.  Overall its exactly what you would expect from a Belgian strong ale.  Very good.
Red-amber color with sweet grape and plum aroma. Raisin, caramel, and malt flavors finish sweet and sour on the tongue. Crisp and velvety on the tongue with a bit of an alcohol burn. Not bad.

Bottled. Amber coloured. Unclear. Dense off white head. Aroma of marzipan, ripe fruits, spice, sweetness. flavour of caramel. sweetness, light liqourice, ripe fruits. Medium to full bodied. Fruity end with light alc touch.

This is a very fine American rendition of a Belgian style dark ale. The aroma is reminiscent of a fine bruin, though subtler than des Rocs, for example. Sweet, elements of dark sugar. In the taste, you get more bruin deliciousness. Cherries, dark sugar, but not without some late bitterness. At a recent comparative tasting, this beer was favored by this taster strongly over Chimay blue. Considering the reasonable price, one of the best deals in the midwest market.
Sweet Aroma, excellent taste (carmel, toast & butterscotch). Very excellent brew by the Goose. Enjoyed with wife!

Bottle.  Pour is deep slightly cloudy copper with a thin tan head.  Aroma is loaded with caramel malt and dark fruit, especially figs.  Also light brown sugar, rock candy, and a light woodiness. Flavor is also deep and dark with notes of dried fruit, Belgian yeast-like spice, and a lightly sweet finish.  Big and rich. Good stuff.

Goose Island is one of those breweries I had heard quiet, low whispers about, but never saw in person.  When I saw that their circulation had extended all the way to Seattle it was sort of like spotting a moose for the first time.  You know what it is, youve seen pictures, you even know people who know people who have seen a moose and/or enjoyed a Goose Island Beer, but it doesnt quite register.  Naturally, as with a moose, I had to have it, and so I notched an arrow in my bow of currency spending and bought two bottles of their beer, one of which is the Pere Jacques 2010.  The classy French name disguises it in the forest of wines, but one knows it for a good beer the moment the liquid is in the glass.  Its a red and mahogany bodied beer, growing a thin, fuzzy light brown head as it reclines and settles into the curves of the cup.  The aroma is sweet and creamy, touching the senses with a touch of tangerine and orange, and a kiss of cinnamon and raisin to accent the sugars.  Its a dessert aroma, but fits as a high-note to the end of any kind of rich meal.  The flavor matches the aroma, approaching the sweeter side of the scale with a lot of carbonation to push the sugars around the palate.  Flavors of pineapple and orange push to the edge of cloying without tipping over the edge, restrained somewhat by the sharper edge of hops.  This is an excellent brew for anybody who likes sugar, but is afraid their beer might be more closely related to soda than a proper beer.
Quite sweet, but smooth with lots of cany and brown sugar, easy drinking for a Belgian, smooth, nice modest head, no lacing
750ml bottle. Dark  brown pour with a thin bubbly head. Fruity, malty aroma, slight brown sugar. Malty sweet flavor with a medium mouth feel. A very enjoyable beer.
Pours a nice ruby red. Flavor is plum undertones on cherry and red grape. Lots of fruit flavors are present, so I am surprised to see this is not a fruit beer.

Pours a thick clody reddish brown with a foamy tan head, with nice lace. 
Aroma is malty with traces of dried fruit and some butterscotch. Flavor is noticeably sweet; plums, figs, slight tartness and yeasty bread. Alcohol
is noticeable but very subtle. Very nice lingering finish.

June 2009 bottle, consumed 12/28/10.
Pours ruby, cloudy with some sedimentation. Medium head, full and super fine lacing.  Dark fruits dominate the nose, with some biscuit and yeast spice in the background.  First sip is really impressive.  Lively, sweet with some tart to it, yeast and spice on the finish.  Lots of brown sugar on the palate, really easy drinking.  Carbonation is significant.  A little less body than I like in what I assume they intend to be something of an abbey dubbel.  A little warming on the finish, more than Id expect for 8%.  Very good stuff though.

Purchased at the "green" Jewel in Chicago, IL as part of a mix & match six pack; enjoyed on a Wednesday night prior to the large holiday weekend.  Fantastic brew.  Appearance a vibrant amber with a thin white head, a stream of small bubbles rising to the top.  Aroma of strawberry jam, toast, slightly tart, rather sweet, more on the soft side but not faint, just a nice balance.  Taste is rather smooth with an alcohol backing, sweet, still encompassing that toast with strawberry jam flavor, a bit of Belgian candi sugar, definitely full bodied.  Its pretty good stuff.
Bottle @ home before christmas holiday. Pours a nice brown with little head.  aroma of cherries and sherry and malt.  Taste is sweet of dried fruits and malt.  its a nice belgian style ale.

Bottle @ Home. Pours orange brown with a small offwhite head. Aroma is sweet roasted malt, caramel, raisins, sweet brown bread, bit of alchohol. Taste is sweet caramel, belgian yeast, roasted malt, toffee, sweet dark dried fruit. Medium body, lively carbonation, short finish. Overall the aroma impresses more than the taste, but still a solid Belgian strong ale.201210

12 oz. bottle. 2010 edition. Bottled on 4/13/10. This is the third beer Ive imbibed over the past few months from a four-pack. Consumed on 12-19-10. Aroma features tart apple, candy sugar, bran muffin, plum, bubblegum, caramel, and toffee. Tartly dry and perfumey smell. Not the strongest aroma, but complex. The smell is almost as much barley wine as strong Belgian ale. Pours a very nice, dark red. Really cool color. Much suspended particulate makes the liquid cloudy but not opaque. Small amount of wispy beige head. If the head were more impressive, I probably would have given the appearance a 5. Sweet taste features cotton candy, dark fruit, and butterscotch pudding flavors. Tart dryness in the finish. The sweetness dominates the taste at first, but increasingly the tartness becomes a significant factor. Not much aftertaste to speak of. Full body. Fizzy and lively in the palate. Overall, Goose Island Pere Jacques is quite good, but it doesnt quite cross the line into very good, let alone great.

fruit like and alcoholish aroma similiar to a quadrupel is the only way i can characterize it pretty strong aroma though, a medium brown color full flavor starting sweet and finishing dry, pretty good beer
Bottle.  Dark brown beer with a light head.  The aroma is malty, and the flavour is vinous and port and rum like.  Overall an ok rich and vinous tasting beer.
2010 vintage pours from a bomber as a medium brown with almost no head.  Sour alcohol aroma with a caramel alcohol flavor.  YUCK!

Wonderful rummy raison aroma. Sweet toffee, notes of sherry, and dried fruit flavors. Dry finish. Rich, complex, satisfying. The flavor profile fits easily in the dubble/abbey style, maybe on the high end of the alcohol range, but not a "strong ale." Positively yummy. May I have another?
Very nice beer. aroma has a sweet smell like fruits. taste is complex yet not over powering, appearance is brownish orange with cloudiness

355 mL bottle.  (bottled 01/13/10).  Hazy, unappealing, orange-brown with a small, sticky beige head.  Sharpish, fruity (apples, grapes) aroma, with yeast, and a little thin caramel.  Nothing special.  The flavour is a little more interesting, though.  The fruit is still there (add some apricot), but there is spice, black papper, cnadi sugar, hops, and slacohol.  Solid body.

bottle poured into trappist glass.  Pours nice dark ruby red color with bubbly grey, beige head color.  Malty aroma of dark fruit and butterscotch, black cherry.  Alot more going on in flavor, which is quite straightforwardly fruity.  Notes of cherry, plum, blackberry, fig, with a long finish that hints of other berries with a subtle tartness.  Really pretty smooth, creamy mouthfeel, good to hold in the mouth.  ABV completely masked.  Notes of butter and dark, tart jam.  This is pretty good, it is complex in a focused way, highlighting all that the spectrum of dark fruit belgian tones can offer.  Surprisingly did not find much in the way of yeast or spices affecting the beer.  Overall pretty interesting, and recommended.

22 oz bottle poured into a New Belgium glass.
Murky amber, with a thin whispy head, delicate carbonation, and spotty lace.
Aroma is toffee, banana, brown sugar.
Flavor is similar to the aroma. Sweet toffee, brown sugar, ripe banana.
Finish is sweet, but not overly so, with warming alcohol.

22 oz. bottle from The Red House in Renton, WA. This beer has a fluffy head with a diaphanous brown color. Lots of yeast in the aroma. Also, there is a sharp, and pungent toasted malt aroma. This beer definitely has a fig aroma, with a subtle bit of date. A little sugar is in there [the aroma] as well. I cant say if The Red House handled this as well as they should have -- sometimes that beer room can get pretty, pretty, pretty warm. Yeast, sugar, and fig flavor. It has a nice flavor. Maybe it wasnt mishandled, maybe the aroma isnt exactly to my liking. Im digging the flavor a lot more than the aroma. Excellent slippery texture. The flavor has a bit of alcohol. This is staring to grow on me.

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2010 Bottle from Baileys Tap Room in Portland. Reviewed on the toilet in my hotel room at 2:30am. Kicked out cause it closed to god damn early so I walked out with a full glass after signing the bill with the same arm that I was holding the soon to be smuggled beer under my hoodie with. Icky brown amber with a small head. Soothing honey, light pepper, orange is mixed in somehow. Caramel, lemon and a hint of alc in the nose. Toffee, faint banana aromas. The taste is very good. Caramel , light watery pepper, toffee, toasted malts, messed up orange thingy, raisin and maybe nutmeg. Smooth mouthfeel. Finishes soft and I need more but I have epic gas that I am now going to release on the squatters in my bed

Bottle. Moderate malt aromas of cookie and caramel, light to moderate hops of cooked orange, light earth for the yeast with alcohol, honey, toffee and honey in the background. Head is small, wispy, white with fair slippery lacing and good legs and is mostly diminishing. Flavor starts moderately sweet and lightly acidic, then finishes lightly sweet, acidic and bitter. Palate is medium,watery with a lively carbonation and has a lightly alcoholic finish. The flavors finish in this Belgian Strong Ale is so fitting, it starts out prominent then fades nicely into light but complex components.

Pour was really reddish brown, lots of floating yeasties.  Sweet fruity aroma.  The flavor in this one was lots of apple/pear like fruitiness and a lot of candied and brown sugar.  Very yeasty flavor as well.  Really sweet and no earthiness that imo, a good Belgian should have.   Not worth going back to, considering its the same price as many top rate Belgians.

Dark(er) cloudy gold than Matilda, sufficient head that dissipates quickly; little lacing Smells almost cloyingly sweet (it has a resin-y, brown sugar quality) nearly dessert wine-ish; the booze is definitely in there too. Taste follows nose, but maltier.

I prefer this (just slightly) over the Matilda.

Pours the color of dark iced tea with a very small head that dissipated to a wisp of film and left little lacing. Ripe dark fruit aromas lead the way, with hints of caramel malt, barnyard yeast and alcohol. Caramel-like sweetness on the tongue, with dates and figs also prominent. Alcohol is less apparent than expected. Somewhat creamy mouthfeel, very low carbonation, and a pleasant sweetness in the finish. A little less complex than expected and hoped for.

Folds into the glass like cream. Color is a hazy copper red crowned by a thick caramel colored head, mostly lasting. Nose is caramel and malt. Very rich and creamy on the palate, the taste is full with caramel, malt and maple syrup hitting the taste buds first, followed by a slight hop dryness at the finish. Sweet and extremely satisfying. Maybe enjoyed alone as a banquet unto itself or with roast suckling pig  and applesauce with all the trimmings. Nice job, Goose Island!

Bottle from South Bay Drugs: Poured as a dark tea brown color with a thin layer of head which quickly breaks down. In the nose, there is a mild scent of spiced yeast, but the aroma in general is hard to detect. The flavor is sweet and holds a strong backbone of caramelized malts with only a slight presence of spicy yeast, and Im not even sure I would attribute the yeast as Belgian. However, the palate is smooth and balanced in carbonation which makes for a nice drink, but I dont know if I would purchase another bottle of this again.

Poured a hazy brownish-red with almost no head.  Aroma of sour grapes, brown sugar, yeast, and dark fruit.  Taste is sweet and fruity.  A good amount of caramel flavor as well with hops.  Some warming effect from the alcohol.  Overall very good.  Goose island didnt let me down!

Traded 22oz bottle probably about a year old or so. Pours a cloudy, medium brown with a short off-white head. Just a little lacing. Big aroma of caramel malt, yeast and some fruit. Flavor is pretty true to form and honestly better than expected. Some lingering burnt malt and alcohol warmth in the finish.

Bottled 02/26/2010....Colour: Deep red middle with very ripe apricot outer layer. Mezmerizing. Nose: Chocolate truffle, port, faint traces of mint, sweet wine notes. Very rich indeed. Taste: More port, plum, sour nectarine, heavy malt. Palate is syrupy but not cloying.
Pours dark amber with a beige head. Aroma is caramel, fruit and alcohol. Flavour follows the nose.

Bottle, 8%. Mild fruity aroma. Nice clear dark orange amber colour. Small tan head. The flavour is malty and caramelly. A little sweet with some brown sugar. Good bitterness to balance. Does not taste very Belgian, but good nonetheless.
Zesty brown pour.  Aroma of caramel and malts.  Flavor of malts, brown sugar, and light hops.  Mild bitter body.
Hazy orange pour. Light aroma of hops and citrus. Strong alcohol flavor. Somewht dry finish. Not bad, interesting.

Great beer.  Pours a dark brown with a small thin white head that disappears.  Aroma is yeast, malt, slightly plum and raisin.  Taste is yeast, malt backed with a sweet raisiny flavour.  Really nice finish.  Good body.

UPDATED: FEB 3, 2011 22 oz bottle. Pours dark amber with minimal head. Aroma of cedar, alcohol, and fruit: apple/grape/berries.  Very sweet with some spice. Warming alcohol is definitely present, but I really enjoyed this.
aromao- tart yeast, metal, roasted malt, cherry.  pours brown. taste is roasted malt, bread, brown sugar, bitter grass hop.  smooth, not too carbonated.
October 05 bottle. dark syrupy malt nose, dry on the back end. dark chestnut ruby. simple sweet body, Hazelnut and maple. complexity is fading, body is thinning, still a tasty dark belgian beer.
Slightly hazy orange/copper color. Sweet malt, toffee, apricot, vanilla, and honey. Medium bodied, average carbonation, slightly acidic finish.
12oz bottle. Dark amber pour with very little head. Malty caramel aroma with a sweet taste. Pretty good brew for this style.

Clear medium orange amber color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, light to moderate hoppy. Flavor is moderate sweet and light to moderate bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

Bottle. Pours a clear and dark golden beer with a weak offwhite head. The aroma is malt, sweetness, dried fruit and notes of yeast. The flavor follows the nose with some additional notes of alcohol. The palate is sweetness and alcohol. Overall a good beer.

Pours a cloudy redish brown color with a small white head.  Nose of raisins, spice, and malt.  First thing I notice is the taste of alcohol, followed by subtle hints of sweet raisins.  Very sweet and the alcohol is noticeable.  Full bodied, minimal carbonation, and a sweet finish.

22oz bottle from Brewforia 
Appearance: Pours clear brown/amber with a small white head and some lacing 
Aroma: Sweet malts and caramel 
Taste: Lively carbonated mouthfeel. Sweet malts, Belgian candi and caramel 
Very nice and enjoyable.
Looks good, in a nice slick and stylish bottle with a label like a wine bottle. Even has the year 2010 printed on it. I wonder if beer gets better with age, because fresh, this one falls a bit short.

Bottle shared by Craig. Pours a dark red/brown color with a small white head. The aroma is rich sweet candies, some fruit. The flavor is very nice; dominant caramel and sweet candy, dark fruits and dry malt. Very good. Drinkable and tasty.
A dark ruby brew with good head and carbonation. Deeply dark sweet fruit aromas and flavors. Sugars are quite prominent, but not overpowering. Smooth and drinkable. Finish of black cherry. good brew.
From a bottle,dark red/brown,brown sugar and dark fruit flavor,very sweet.i like it
