12oz bottle.   Medium brown with some larger suspended particles and a smaller beige head that doesnt last too long.   Lightly perfumey and sweet alcohol on the nose with some fruit cake and black cherry.   Hints of vanilla, but that could just be the alcohol.   Sweet flavor with a good brown sugar element and a nice prune and raisin richness.   Lightly bright and fruity from the alcohol and a nice fruit and spice from the yeast which is pretty balanced and not too apparent.   Medium bodied with a fuzzy and smooth texture, despite a decent, though not high level of carbonation.   Tasty on the whole.   A nice, sweet and fruity drink that doesnt get too big or weighted toward any one character.

2010 bottle poured a dark amber color with red highlights and a one finger off white head that had to be drawn out. aroma has sweet dark fruit, banana yeast, mild spice, and some underlying floral mustiness. mouth feel is light and has low carbonation. flavor has a lot of sugary sweetness, caramel, banana yeast, dark fruit, raisin, and some lightly done spices.

355ml bottle from Alko. Bottled: 10/05/09. Poured brown, unclear with a thin beige head. Aroma is sweet fruity, yeasty notes. Flavor is exquisite, sweet honey, plums, toffee and malt. Some alcohol burn in finish, but otherwise alco very well hidden. Very tasty.

2010 Vintage. Pours a mostly clear dark amber with small off white head that fades quickly.  Strong notes of sugary fruity esters, floral and spicy.  Starts with a shocking slight sour bitter that slowly slides into a creamy sweetness.  Medium bodied with a slight tang in the mouthfeel. Fruity creamyness reminds me of bananas. Would really like to see how it turns out after a little ageing.

The aroma is earthy horseblanket. Candi sugars with a slight funk. Grape skins and figs. Cherry liqueur.

The appearance is gorgeous rose-pink. Not a ton of head, but body for days.

The flavor is plums, raisins and dates. Dark stone fruits and sherry. Sweet sugars atop a grainy husk. The Belgian funk really comes in at the end. Hint of banana.

Fizzy and gritty texture. Coats the mouth beautifully. Slick and oily finish. An excellent Belgian-style ale. A sweetish dubbel. Really smooth, really lovely.
A good beer with a lot of different layers. Immediately you get the banana and esthery notes.  Then the next level hits you. I get licorice, hazelnut, chocolate, and caramel.
2010, 12oz bottle. Copper with a moderate head. Sweet and malty.I shared this with a couple of special friends from Houston. One said "Smooth." The the said "Melts in your mouth." I concur.
UPDATED: FEB 2, 2015 Nice abbey style beer. Caramel, dried fruits. Got the 2009 version not sure if that makes a difference. Serving: Bottle
A big fan of Matilda, Pere Jacques impressed me by outdoing Matilda.  It made me research Goose Island further and Im going to have to make room for a brewery tour the next time Im in Chicago.

Pours amber orange with little head. Aroma is bready and yeasty with a hint of citrus. Taste follows the nose but with a bit of sweetness that adds just what really makes this nice. Belgians are not my favorites but this is not to bad.

(355 ml bottle from Alko. Rated @ 17.8.2010.)
Brown colour with an average, off-white head. Caramel, malts and fruits on the taste with hops too. Apricot, hops and caramel on the taste. Medium bodied, oily texture and soft carbonation. Pretty much the same as Goose Islands Matilda.
2010 bottle. Nice reddish amber color. Woody and just a touch of funk. Good sweet belgian flavors with a clean, enjoyable finish.

Bomber with a 2010 label, poured into a tulip glass. Nice color of reddish amber, small carb head that dissipated quickly. Aroma is slightly tart but with some sweetness as well. Flavor is of the fig/raisin type but not as strong as others in this style. Good and very well made delicious beer.

Beautiful garnet color with a head that settles down quickly to a small ring around the glass. Smell is sugared plums, toasty sweetbread and caramel apples. First sip gives me alcoholic cordials and dark fruits that balance nicely. Stays clear, so theres none of the secondary fermentation I kind of expected. Reminds me most of the Three Philosophers, but a little lighter in body. A rich beer and a very good one. A steal at $7.99.
Poured out of the 22oz bottle at N9NE steakhouse, Chicago, IL.  Pours a reddish brown with little head and a lot of carbination.  Taste is plum and sugar.  Really an all around great beer.

reddish with mild white head.  carbonation low for the style.  some sweet and fruity yeast components and malt to the nose.  little bitterness.  solid fruity esters with some lingering candy like sweetness with a touch of alcohol that is somwhat distracting.  the flaw in this brew is the mouthfeel and residual sweetness, which is far to high for this style and is not benefited by the low carbonation.  i largely enjoy goose island, especially their belgian efforts, but I was disappointed in this attempt at a dubbel, with a belgian dark strong being a misnomer

Im unable to accurately describe the aroma, but it smells delicious. Pours with little head and a dark red appearance. Tastes strongly of... plum, fig and sugar. Absolutely delicious, will drink again.
UPDATED: SEP 6, 2010 2009 vintage. better than expected. not too fruity, nice and malty. alcohol well hidden. a little flat.

2010 bottle. Pours a caramel brown with hints of dark amber, and an off-white head. Nose has some holiday cake aromas that lead me to anticipate something sweet with dessert spices. On the palate theres a toffee-bready sweetness up front along with some of those holiday spices I was anticipating. Medium body and modest carbonation lead to a sweet finish that has a bit of alcohol warmth.

West USA trip 2010. Bottled 2010. The aroma has caramel and fruitiness. Clear, amber-brown coloured beer with an off-white head (observed in a dark tent). The taste is sweet, has caramel, prunes, spice, some yeast. Pretty carbonation and a good body. Quite well done.

Bottle, pours a red-amber body with a quickly disappearing, thin tan head.  Lots of sweetness on the aroma - sugar, dark fruit, plum, fig, cider.  Flavor is similar with a slight belgian spiciness near the finish.  Smooth mouthfeel and nicely carbonated - lively on the tongue.  Nice fruity finish with a slight alcohol burn on the aftertaste.  Reminds me a bit of a barleywine.
This is great stuff. The bottle is 2 years old. Very smooth. Wondeful taste. Now where do I find another?

2009 bottle shared with Frosty. Pours clear but with chunky yeasties floating around. Head is creamy but fades quick. Nose is sweet malt, fruity esters, maybe a little spit and less Belgian character than I expected. Taste is full flavored typical Belgian style sporting a broad array of spices, fruits, and some phenolics. Finishes dry with just enough hop bitterness. Medium body and smooth. Great Belgian beer from Goose.

2009 bomber from K&L Redwood City.  Pours a somewhat clear dark amber brown color with slight reddish hues.  A small light beige head sits on top, with average retention.  Very nice aroma to this one.  Sweet caramel malts and Belgian candi sugar, with a lot of dark dried fruit.  Belgian yeast is evident.  The flavor is subtle but good.  A nice sweetness level, not overly sweet as some American BSAs can be.  Candi sugar, molasses, spice, plum, fig, and Belgian yeast are the predominant flavor notes.  Decent palate, medium bodied with medium-high carbonation level.  Another nice Belgian-style ale from Goose Island this is.  Not a game-changer, but definitely one Id revisit.
Rich, very sweet caramel aroma. Flavor is light caramel and molasses. Quite sweet. Like a barleywine but smoother. Very good, could be amazing with a bit of aging to lessen the sweetness.

This is a great beer, not only in the bottle, but also on tap.  Reminds me of Tres Pistoles and is very smooth with a nice fruity aroma and slight pear taste.  The belgian yeast is very present but not overwhelming.  Very nice Belgian style.  Even better on tap sitting next to Wrigley Field and enjoying a nice Chicago summer day.

12 fl oz (355 ml) bottle. 2009 vintage, drunk summer 2010. Pours dark ruby/orange, with loads of floating yeast. Amazing funky, yeasty, heady, off-ish, sharp sour aroma with what I though was a hop edge. Sour taste but no real hop finish. Must be lots of fresh yeast knocking around. Written "Belgian Style" on the bottle but Ive never tasted anything like this before. Pity there is little substance to back up the massive sour ale nose. Maybe I should leave one to lay for up to 5 years as the bottle suggests.

Dark amber orange pour with a pillowy, off-white cap of foam.  Mild brown sugar aroma with spice behind it, dried fruit/date notes.  Plenty of sweet brown sugar and dates to the flavor, leather, mild pumpkin pie spice notes.  Aluminum metallic flavor on the finish.  Very little alcohol detectable, moderate body.  Found this one to be a touch too sweet for my tastes without any traits to mitigate it.

Location: 12 oz bottle from New Beer, Vintage 2007, 7/17/10


Aroma: The nose has caramel malts, lots of ripe fruits, a bit of spice, earth, and yeast

Appearance: A rather cloudy orange-amber colored pour with a small off-white head 

Flavor: The taste is rather sweet up-front, a lot of sweet malts, and a bit of spicy yeast

Palate: The body is medium, with that spicy yeast feel to it, and almost no burn

Overall Impression: 
I found this beer to be rather nice, even if it is a touch sweet.  The age probably helped round this one out, as I thought it felt very well-rounded.  It has a pretty decent complexity to it.  The super sweetness does take a way from my enjoyment a bit, but I like what they were trying to do here.

{thoughts} A sweet n hot American "Belgian" with biting acidity and meager carbonation.

{elements} Light mahogany hue, clear; scant off-white foam. Big malt nose of crusty bread and caramel, cool menthol, sweet and spicy figs and plums; moderately high sweetness, moderately high acidity (prickly) and moderate bitterness --cloying. Medium-full body, surprisingly medium-low carbonation, oily texture, moderate alcohol warmth. 12 oz bottle, bottled on 10/05/09.

2010 vintage.  Enjoyed from a 12oz bottle in a pub glass.  The bee pours a dark amber to slightly light brown color, with a faint head that disappears quickly.  A slightly thin nose comes at first, followed by more inviting notes that come alive, as the sample warms.  A beautiful note of candied sugar, and perhaps just the slightest note of grassy hop.  The palate is richly malty, without being over-the-top, nor out-of-style.  Special B, rich, burnt sugar, and molasses come through, along with a subtle yeast ester profile.  Carbonation suits the flavor profile, acting in a complimentary fashion, rather than working as a detriment.  The finish is slightly sweet.  Overall, a nicely crafted beer that, while not quite competing with the best from across the Atlantic, makes a fine showing, indeed.
Bottle 2008 vintage. Copper brown, almost no head. Dark fruit, yeast, some alcohol

Bottle.  Pours a deep copper-brown, with a thin head with large bubbles, and a bit of yeast sediment.  Aroma is yeast, spices, and dark fruits.  The flavor is sweet, fruity, and malty, with a hint of a metallic off-taste in the yeasty finish.  Not bad - it grew on me as the bottle went on.
Had in bottle at Perrys in Adams Morgan. I thought it was a very good belgian strong ale with a nice nose, head and mouthfeel. Enjoyable with a great meal.

12 oz bottle. Copper pour, almost no head.  Aroma has ripe dark fruit. Full bodied.  Sweet and yeasty, some alcohol. Long finish, fuity and malty.  Not bad, would have been better with some more carbonation.

22oz bottle of the 2010 vintage poured into a Trappist glass at 41°.  Color is a deep amber with light carbonation and a thin fizzy head.  Aroma is rich and sweet with a wine like scent of raisins and caramel.  Medium body that goes down with a crisp feel.  Flavor is sweet but not to rich with mellow dried fruits and yeast, then a very mild bitterness.  After taste lets the bitterness build with a bite of alcohol on the end.  This is a very well done light drinking brew with bright flavors.

2010 bomber form bevmo drank 4/28/2010.

rich hazy copper color with a head reminiscent of untoasted almonds. 

big banana nose?... clove-like esters, tingly cinnamon spice, orange, yeasty, earthy, caramel grain, raisins and florals. banana smell disappears after a bit but is certainly a shock to discover...

only to end back up in the flavor. wtf? thats weird, it tastes like a cinnamon sugar dusted banana in the aftertaste. prior to that are notes of yeast, raisins, brown sugar and spiciness with a bitterness on the edge. it is quite sweet. alcohol shows up to the party to try and contain the sugars but he done got his ass beat.

i wish this were in a smaller bottle... 6/3/5/2.5/13/3.0

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2010 2010 vintage, from a 4-pack at The Perfect Pour in MD.  Id like to age this one 5 years to revisit it in 2015.  Nonetheless, pours a slightly hazy, reddish amber liquor with little head and little lacing.  Not surprising for a brew of this gravity.  The bouquet is not intense, but is discernibly sweet and fruity, though it finishes with a balancing hint of sour.  The taste is wonderfully balanced and malty; toffee come through loud and clear supported by a pleasing background of alcohol reminiscent of the more etherial qualities of cognac.  I will be back for more of this.

2007 Bottle. Pours a murky brown with lots of chunky, tan sediment (shouldve poured more carefully), and a frothy light tan head that drops to a thin skin at the surface. The nose is of full, round, sweet, brown sugar-like malt, raisins, grapes and light pepper. Medium to full-bodied and silky-soft with a vinous and slightly resinous (almost woody) finish; nice palate. The flavor is a deeper, richer version of the nose with big, fruity, sugary malt up-front, followed by lesser notes of sweet spice and light pepper along with slightly woody and spicy/resinous hops. Leaning a bit too much toward the sweet side of the spectrum for me to "love" it, its still quite good. This would pair well with a steak or wild game; certainly worth trying for anyone that enjoys dubbels and/or dark Belgian strong ales.
Bottle: Just had Sofie (THE BEER), it reads Belgian Ale on the label, we should respect the brewer. Full, complex, fruity, malty, potent. Food Pairing: Sweet and Sour Pork.

Pours deep garnet color with the faintest remnants of a white head and no lacing.  sweet plum and raspberry aroma with some yeast.  Very sexy mouthfeel.  carbonation is light but sensual.  Taste is mildly tart with some coriander, plum, citrus and licorice.  finish is long, subtle and warming.  Lovely Beer!

From a bottle poured in glassware.  Pours burnt copper color, with an offwhite head and plenty of carbonated activity in the glass.  Aroma is a slightly burnt marshmellow.  Taste is medium sweet, palate has a medium body with a thin texture and alocholic undertones.

Bottle.  Aroma has notes of dark dried fruits, butterscotch, vanilla and wood.  Medium brown hue with a small off-white head that mostly diminished and left no lace.  Flavor is malty sweet with a very mild bitterness.  Palate is medium bodied and oily soft.  Overall a good malty Belgian but nothing to write home about.
A little hot to start. Raisins and candy sugar. Syrupy. Nice balance between sweetness, bitter and hops. Has weird astringent carbonation taste but the aftertaste is good. Reminds me of a barleywine.

Bottle (2010 vintage).

Head is initially small, frothy, light brown, mostly diminishing.
Body is dark amber.

Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (caramel, toasted nuts/grain), with light notes of brown sugar and orange peel.

Flavor is heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter.

Medium to full body, syrupy texture, lively carbonation, moderately alcoholic.

Very simple and ordinary, but ok.  Meek aroma, not much going on. Too sweet, but just enough bitterness in the finish to keep it reasonably sippable.  Bit of a yawner.
Bottled 03/26/2010.Murky brown pour with small quickly receding head. Aroma is candi sugars, cereals, bread, raisins. Flavor is caramel, candi sugars, dark fruits, and a smooth alcohol finish.
Pours a dark brown color.  Aroma is of malts, dark fruit, and brown sugar.  Flavor is of sweeter malts, dark fruit, brown sugar, and raisin.

Bouteille de 12 oz achetée chez Half Time (Poughkeepsie, NY). Arôme: Odeur de caramel et de petits fruits foncés. Apparence: La couleur est ambré voilé. Présence dun mince col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de caramel et de petits fruits foncés avec une pointe dépices. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement minérale. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Légère présence de caramel en arrière goût. (Rating #3083)

UPDATED: DEC 11, 2014 [2855-20100426] 12floz bottle. Toasted raisin malt aroma, but very lightly toasted. Slightly hazy, brown amber body with a medium-lasting foamy off-white head. Old earthy raisin malt flavour with a long bitter aftertaste. Medium-full body. Average.
(w/ DuctTape, Geoff, jerc)

[6102B-20130214] Tap. Cherry bourbon booze aroma. Slightly hazy, dark red brown body with a medium-lasting foamy off-white head. Sweet roasted fruit mash flavour has a barrel aftertaste. Medium-full body. Good but a little sweet. (7/4/8/3/15) 3.7
(@ Abraxas, Miami, FL)

UPDATED: OCT 9, 2012 Re-review July of 2012: nose is brown sugar, caramel, sweet malt profile, light yeast character, faint spice and banana notes. Taste is well integrated with heavy sweet malt profile, candied and brown sugars with a touch of caramel and banana notes behind. The spice is faint and the yeast is present but light in back. Solid body, assertive carbonation, clean and crisp finish 

***

A-dark ruby red, mostly clear with some particles floatiing around in it. the head is very light tan, dense and creamy, leaving a nice lace on the glass.

S-the nose is quite sweet, the caramel malts and candied sugar is right up front. banana, notes of wheat, dark plums and a touch of raisin towards the back with a hint of pepper at the very end.

T-lots of sweetness, candied sugar, very faint caramel, lots of plums behind, a touch of black cherry, hint of booze, light bitterness to the finish.

M-full bodied and syrupy, quite thick and chewy, low carbonation and would have liked to see a little more to balance out the huge body.

D-very tasty beer, lots of dark fruity sweetness. hints of hop bitterness to balance the big sweet malts and a huge syrupy feel.

Pours a lighter amber brown color with a thin off white soapy head.  Has an aroma of dark fruit and caramel with hints of citrus.  Perhaps some pine from the hops.    Has a brown sugar sweet taste.  The biitters and carbonation give it the Belgian Ale feel.  But this has some barleywine features as well.  My bottle go dough-ier as it warmed.  But not overly yeasty.

355 ml bottle (2009). Slightly hazy coppery colour, thin light beige head. Sweet aroma of raisins, dates and toffee-like malts. The flavour is caramel-malty, with dark fruits, spices and even a hint of cherries. Very tasty.

Goose Island
Pere Jacques
Pours medium red/ brown with a thinner cream colored head and not a ton of retention. Minimal lacing. Nice aroma of sweet cloves and caramel with a slight yeasty funk and some alcohol on the finish. Flavor is sweet and boozy with a nice spiciness and a slightly bitter finish. Good brew, and since this is my first Goose island beer, I will be compelled to try more(damn!)
2010 bottle. Brilliant copper color/ viscous tan head. Nice sharp caramel, spicy sweet toffee aromas. medium bodied. Sharp caramel flavor with mild booze, spices, and a too sweet, cloying finish.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Pours a relatively clear medium golden-brown.  The head is off which and made up of smallish bubbles.  The aroma is a bit malty and has hints of banana bread.  The flavor is malty with a bit of citrus and dark fruit.  This beer has a fair amount of body and the flavors are complex.  This doesnt have the distinct flavor of a traditional belgium ale, but thats not to say this isnt a very tasty beer.

Pours a medium tawny brown .. low foam ring, very light lacing .. . abv is well done, has hints of molasses and dark honey, ..bitterness is quite subtle .. . 2009 bottle .. . had my second glass with a nice cigar, pairs beautifully but on the whole, for a GI product, could be fuller .. . "When I give the order abandon ship, it doesnt matter what time I leave. Abandon is for everybody. If some people want to stay, they can stay."

UPDATED: JUN 18, 2010 Bottle from Alko (brewed 05/2009). Color is a slightly murky amber, little head. Aroma has nuts, yeast and a slight touch of soy sauce in it. Great body as well, probably due to the alcohol. This also provides the beer some sweetness, although at first some salty tones dominate. A rather complex brew, all in all very good.

Starts off with a mild Belgian beer aroma of malt and a little wood.  Head is almost non-existant, with a beautiful bright, clear light brown color.  Nice caramel sweetness starts it off with a slightly sour flavor that seems to have some wood aging.  Theres good balancing of bitterness with a warming alcohol follow through.  Very good interpretation of a strong Belgian brown ale.

(22 oz bottle).  Pours orange-red color with thin white head.  Aroma of candied sugar, caramel, raisin.  Taste is sweet with some bitter/sour notes mixed in.  Fizzy on the tongue. Finish is medium bodied and sweet.  Very smooth.  Alcohol warms the chest and becomes noticeable.

Bottle.  Pours a medium amber with a short-lived white head.  Nose is sweet and quite fruity.  Some dark cherries, green apple, blackberry.  Hints of caramel and some floral stuff going on.  Taste is similarly fruity, a bit of raisins in addition to whats in the nose.  The alcohol just barely makes its presence known.  Finishes with more dark cherry fruitiness.

UPDATED: JAN 28, 2011 Sampled on BQ2010. Bottle. Pours reddish brown body with nice head. Aroma is dominated by brown sugar and dark fruits. Mouthfeel is medium with similar notes as the aroma showcased. Bready and almost like cinnamon graham crackers.

This beer was very fruity and had a good balance to it. Seeing that it is a 2007 vintage, the aging probably made alcohol calm down a bit. While 8.00% really isnt that high, with a beer that is a fruity as this it would stand out. I personally got a lot of dark cherry, raisins, and caramel from the flavor of the beer. I personally would like to try a current bottle and compare a vintage bottle to see how they mature. Good Beer.

Clear copper pour with a small white head. The aroma is loaded with dark fruit, coffee, toffee, smokey peat, caramel and vinous deliciousness. The flavor is loaded with caramel and dark fruit sugars. Lots of biscuit-caramel as well. The palate is thick,supple, rich, and quite drinkable.

Dark amber, copper, with an offwhite white head.  dark sugar aroms, dark fruit, sark sugars, burnt malt.  flavor is burnt sugar, brown sugar, some yeast, serious sugars going on and Excellent yeast, fucking yummy

2010 vintage.  12oz bottle from Andersons in Toledo.  Murky mahogany pour with a small light tan head.  Aroma of sweet malts, brown sugar, pears and cloves.  Tastes of dried fruits, bready malts, caramel, bubble gum and apple.  Nice warmth to it.  Slick light to medium texture.  Good.  Would get again.

pours a clear brown with a red tint, a small beige head, and some lacing.

smell is of malt, a touch of caramel, some floral, and a little sweetness.

taste is thick, hops, butter, malt, and a little toffee, end is on the dry side.
Bomber.  Pours clear amber with a one finger beige head.  The nose is sweet malt and spiced fruit.  The taste is caramel, spiked fruit and spice.  Medium bodied.  Strange brew.

Pours a fairly clear, dark, warm brown, with a very frothy beige head.  Aroma is yeasty and a bit wine-like, and as I drink, I think I can also detect some of the alcohol scent.  Medium-bodied, and the taste is great: at first it offers full and well-rounded yeast and malt flavors.  These quickly melt into very satisfying, caramel-backed fruit flavors, especially of orange (maybe a little pear also?).  This beer is delicious; I cant wait to try it again.

Bottle pour to Trappist glass gives dark amber with minimal off-white head.  Aroma faint, a bit like stale fruit.  Taste is well balanced but there really isnt much of it,.  I dont really taste Belgian yeasts at all.  Some dark fruits, a little citrus.  Finish a little bitter.  Medium bodied.  

Almost like it tried so hard to be inoffensive it ended up being uninteresting.  Not bad but wouldnt buy again.

From 12 oz bottle. Aroma deep red fruit, toasty, caramel. Appears deep red; no head until swirling creates a frothy, tan head. Deep malt taste, toasty, caramel, vanilla; slightly alcohol warmth. Body medium-thick, moderately sticky, silky, and all-around nice. Really good beer becomes a great beer as it warms. Very good.
very balanced brew - spicy yet sweet and fruity - would enjoy again but will not go out of my way to find it.

Bottled. Pours hazy brown with sparse to no head and has a very loose sediment. Taste is slightly sweetnsour. Palate is medium to full bodied, creamy, thick feel. Aromas have herbs, orange zest, hint of cheese.

Bottle. 2010 Vintage. Mahogony beer with a cream colored head. Toffee and light roast aroma with spice. Toffee and dried fruit flavor with light spice and light yeast. Medium bodied. Toffee and light yeast lingers with light roastiness and dried fruit.

12oz bottle, 2009 vintage.  Pours a cloudy dark amber with less than a finger of head.  Aroma has sweet fruit, molasses, some herbal notes, and a bit of alcohol.  Flavor is dominated by caramel and molasses sweetness, with herbal notes, malt, alcohol, raisins, and chocolate.  The sweetness overwhelms everything though.

2009 Vintage tasted from a 22oz bottle.  Pours amber with a thin off-white head.  Nose of caramel malt, raisins, brown sugar, and some cherry.  The flavors are a little more reserved than expected, but similar to the nose with the addition of some banana.  The palate is full bodied with medium carbonation, and a medium finish that is sweet.  The alcohol is a little hotter and out of balance than I would like, but this is a solid beer.

Bottle thanks to Rando7. Pours dark red cherry in the glass with no retaining head. Nose is slight molasses and brown sugar. Taste is the same with some spice and Belgian wheats and a dry slight alcohol finish. 2010 vintage would have benefited from some aging. Still, good though.

Pour a ruby-amber color with a small, tan head which fades to some lacing on the edges.  aroma is of candied sugar, carmel malt, yeast, and belgian spices.  flavor is of belgian candied sugar, carmel malt, yeast, spices, and some banana bread.  has a full body with a sweet, slightly syrupy mouthfeel.  overall, a good belgian strong ale.

Pours a deep caramel color with a fluffy tan head. Aroma is belgian candi sugars, belgian yeasts, spices, nuts, toffee, chocolate, dark fruits. Flavor is rasins, spices, belgian yeasts, candi sugar, caramel, spices, some choco-hop-oak-spice in the finish.
Bottled sample.  This a beer to be reckoned with.  I absolutely loved this one.  A bit sweeter than I expetcted, but was fantastic.
Poured dark reddish amber, beautiful maple nose, smooth, rich caramel malt, spice, little dark fruit, little yeast, slight hops.

2010 release in the 22oz bottle.  Flavor is malty sweet but lacks some body.  Its a clean dark abbey style ale but I really wanted to add a bit of sour flemish to it.  So I cracked open a bottle of LEnfant Terrible and mixed the two together.  Turned into a tasty, sour funkapodamus!

22oz bottle 2009 edition $7. This was a weird beer. I could not tell if it was a dubbel or just a weird belgian strong ale. It smelled yeasty but the flavor had citrus and spice like a tripel but then also raisin like flavors that I get from dubbels and belgian strong dark ales. It was easy to drink but overall I just found it to be a bit strange for my tastes.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-08-2010 17:56:17
Belgian candy sugar, banana, light hop spice.  Unfortunate aftertaste.  Clingy, dry, bitter.  Not a fav.

2010 release in the 22oz bottle. A rusty amber colored beer that had little carbonation showing and no head. The aroma was sweet with some dark fruit and malt. Kept thinking of yellow cake as i nosed this. The taste was again sweet but with some medium level malt to offset it. The palate is at first crisp but goes out very gentle with a mostly clean finish just leaving a bit of malt flavor behind.

Pere Jacques Belgian Style Ale--2005 12 oz.  9.00% ABV.  26 IBUs.  (4.25 / 5.0)  Belgian Ale--Golden.  Mild lacy head.  Cloudy sediment flecked rich amber red color.  Mild coriander fruit front.  Sweet malty dry crisp Belgian caramel ester body.  Hot smooth malty mild hop Belgian spice end.  Malty Mellow Belgian.  Sampled 7/17/2005.

Clear, beautiful pour ruby orange with a thick but quickly dissipating off-white head.  Sweet, inviting aroma with notes of candy, dark fruit, and malt.  Very smooth, oily texture with low carbonation.  Like the aroma, the brew tastes pretty sweet.  Candied fruit and brown sugar fades to a nice alcohol warming.  Very fine beer.

Courtesy of Blazer06. Pours clear amber with copper hues and thin off white head. The aroma is malts, roast, caramel and lots of dark fruity sweetness. The taste is smooth and sweet with a pleasing mix of ripe dark fruitiness, malts and caramel. This is smooth and light on the tongue.

Bottled 02-10.  The pour is a nice, mostly clear, rusty-ruby color with an average, creamy, fizzy beige head which settles quickly to next to nothing and leaves minimal lace; typical abbey dubbel appearance.  The nose is a bit Delerium beers with a simple, but pleasant, sugary malt; light candi sugar and toffee, mild raisin and cake notes are beginning to emerge, some spicy phenols, and alcohol warmth.  The flavor is similar but subtle darker (bitter) notes to separate from the sugary sweetness; certainly cake-like notes are prominent with hints of dark chocolate, still light candi sugar, light raisin, light phenols, and still some clove-like spicing.  The palate is a bit light but seemed to work well with this one; medium, nearly lively, silky, warm, and coating.  The finish is long and lingering with cake, dark chocolate, clove, and some light sugar.  A bit hard for me to rate because it is not what I usually look for in a BSDA; the malt richness is lacking, the malt depth is lacking, the palate is thin for the style, and the yeasty notes are fairly insignificant.  However, the simple subtleties, the way the palate supported those subtleties, and the way the different sweeter notes worked well together to minimize how sugary it was.  The more I had, the more I really enjoyed it.  Still a beer that is very young but something that I would try again an definitely try to hold on to for a while to allow the malts to develop.  From such a great brewery, this is an upgrade from the Belgians I have tried from them.  Looking forward to Sophie in my cellar.

2010.  22oz in Goose Island stem at Toad in the Hole.  Enticingly bright red and clear, but the head shrinks to wisps.  Woody maple and sarsaparilla nose.  Neatly arranged sweetness falls in line with delicious cookie spices, but the result comes across as a little less than beery.  Finish profits from the Islands yeast strain, affording a pleasantly benign phenol profile -- all the action happens in the front three quarters of my palate.

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2014 2013-12-14. Hazy brown body, medium foamy beige head. 3+ Aroma is sweet, with an almost marshmallow like sugar touch to it. Flavour is sweet, lightly fruity with mild alcohol in the finish. Smooth medium bodied palate, soft carbonation. Better than I remember, nice stuff. 7/4/7/4/15-16 On tap at Abraxas, Miami
2010-04-26. Lightly hazy orange amber, nice beige head. 3+ Mild aroma, light spice, malt and alcohol. 6+ Flavour is similar, light spice, mild malts. 6+ Average palate. Enjoyable but a bit mild overall. Alcohol is not particularly noticeable. 7/3/7/3/14 2009 Bottle from Liquor Stop, Indiana

Presentation: It was poured from a brown 12oz bottle into a tulip glass. The bottle reads Pere Jacques 2009 and it also has a "bottled on" date of 10/05/09.

Appearance: The pour only produces a small off white head which fades out quickly leaving a rich reddish amber liquid naked and exposed. Only a thing ring of lace remains around the edge of the glass. This lacing is slick and sides down the glass as I drink leaving nothing behind.

Smell: Its aroma is very sweet, estery and malty. It is a touch phenolic and boozy as well with nice notes of caramel malt, over ripe fruit, sweet bready yeast and raw sugar.

Taste/Palate: To start there is a very sweet rich malty and boozy brandy-like base full of caramel, brown sugar or Belgian candied sugar like notes. From there each sip reveals a different estery, fruity, or phenolic flavor note like sweet red apples, peach, apricot, and pear. On to the finish, and now I get leafy hop spice and mild bitterness moving in. Overall though, it remains well on the sweet boozy side in the finish. On the palate it has a medium to full body with a slick sticky texture.

Notes: This is a very interesting and complex beer which I think was still a bit young and could use some time to age.

I agree with the recent review that called this overrated. aroma reminded me of a raisiny barleywine, giving me high expectations that were not met. it does not taste bad, in fact it tastes pretty good, but it is bland, bland, bland. like they forgot to add the flavor, or else they tried to take the bud-miller-coors approach and be as inoffensive as possible. rich texture and nice alcoholic character, but no estery, no sweet, no hoppy, no malty. nothing. the only flavor that came out was at the end of the bottle, when the yeast sediment started to get into the glass and gave it a yeasty flavor.

22oz bomber into a goblet. Pours a dark ruby with a small to no white head. Smells of dark fruits and sweet malts. Mouthfeel is medium with moderate carbonation levels. Tastes of sweet fruits upfront leading to rich molasses and brown sugars and leaves a lingering sweet finish.

Amber body with a white medium head. Malty and bit sugary aroma with notes of caramel, yeast and spices. Flavor is sweet malty, light alcoholic, dark fruity, bit sugary and yeasty on the aftertaste. Medium/heavy bodied. This would be a desert beer I could not drink more than one at a time.

Way overrated. This is a good strong ale but not a 98 by any means. Sweet and a bit dirty with a rather status quo disposition. I drank it. I got through it. Im still here. The finish is also.  No head. Smells sweet. Full body with very little bittering. Pretty basic. LOL, I brought it down a point. Nice!

hazy brown, thin white head.

aroma: lots of sweet dark fruit, lots of sweet chocolate malt, slight belgian dubbel funkiness, rich and pleasant.

taste:
T1= lots of sweet dark fruit.
T2= lots of sweet chocolate malt, slight belgian dubbel funkiness, stale hops.
T3= slightly dusty, slight metallic dubbel, fairly clean.
Tf= slightly sour (like oud bruin).

very sweet, very belgian, slightly complex, and quite good.  only think off to me was a bit too much co2.

Tap at Goose Island Clybourn. Rich vanilla-like complex flavor. Fairly heavy but not overbearing. Fairly mild acidity which I think is a good thing as it lets the rest of the flavors get out. Hop aroma is present but the taste is much more complex and I really liked that about this beer.

Bottle. Creamy off-white excellent mostly lasting head. Amber colour. Heavy malty and moderate hoppy and nice yeasty aroma. Moderate bitter flavor. Strong nutty notes. Long powerfull nice finish. Creamy palate.

Ok im definately going to have to revisit this one in the future.  I somehow decided that it would be a good idea to open this after drinking Avery Moloch and Meph Addict all night.  My tastebuds were so overwhelmed with coffee and bourbon by this point that there was no justice.  It would be one thing if I was visiting another aggressive Amercian beer, but unable to appreciate the subtle nuiances of the Belgian style at the time of tasting.

Bottle; poured a cola brownish color with a smallish off white head.  Aroma of sweet malt, caramel, fruit, yeast, sugar, and alcohol.  Flavor was pretty solid, although I liked it less over time.  Pretty heavy on the alcohol and fruit esters, with some caramel, cocoa and brown sugar.

First beer Ive ever rated.  2010 bottle in a pint glass.  Aroma is of hops, fruit, and a bit of whiskey, maybe rum.  Had a rather small head, maybe 3/4-1 inch, which dissipated over several minutes.  Color is inviting.  Taste is complex, rich and sweet, hints of fruits I cant identify, taste of the liquor that I detected in the aroma, with quite a bit of alcohol.  Overall, this is a VERY good beer, worthy of my first-ever rating.  I dont think its one I want to drink very many of, but its a great beer to have one or two of an evening or maybe to start off with this one and then switch to a lesser beer if you want to keep drinking.  This beer is 8% ABV and packs a pretty good wallop.  I am 61" and about 270 lbs, had 3 fajitas for dinner, and had a buzz after one beer.  I drank a 6 pack of various beers yesterday over a couple hours and had half the buzz this one gave me.  Its a good beer and will become a staple in my fridge.  I like this one better than their Matilda, which is also a pretty good beer.

Bottle, pours a syrupy brandy w/ a slight rimy head, aroma is candy, caramel, and some bready yeast, velvety body. flavor is burnt sugar, rum, and some caramel, lingering alcohol burn on finish, could benefit from some aging

Pours a dark ruby with loads of floaters and a small thin head.  Smells of raisins, figs, and maybe some cherry.  This has definite aromas of rich sweet malts.  Tastes of sweet fruits upfront leading to rich molasses and brown sugars and leaves a lingering sweet finish.

A nice mellow american belgian. Pours a deep copper color, head fades ad no lacing though. Nose is sweet belgian yeast and a bit of candied spice. Taste is sweet but does have balance from the hop. Some good caramel malt flavor too, but not overdoing it. This beer gets good marks for balance. At 9% abv alcohol is not noticable. A nice beer to have with lunch on a Saturday.

Bomber.  Pours a crispy reddish brown, with just a 1/4 inch of porours white foam.  Aroma is nearly imperceptible to me, with perhaps just a touch of bittersweet malts and caramel coming through to me.  First taste is surprisingly bitter, with an oily, viscous mouthfeel.  2nd taste reveals more apple-cider like qualities, with a boozy bourbon taste that is almost offputting?  This beer is REALLY THICK, a heavy contrast to the saison I just tried.  Not bad, but boozy as all get out and a bit hot and heavy-handed for my taste.

Thanks to the Tampa Crew for sharing this one.  Pours caramel apple brown with a white head.  Nose is apple, caramel, some date-like fruit, some smoke, and more vinous fruit.  Flavor is similar with apple throughout as well as caramel and some booze.  Interesting.

UPDATED: APR 13, 2011 22oz bottle from east coast. Ruby-tinted dark amber pour with minimal head. Nose is a touch skunky-sour, wet dog. Cherry and apricot, quite tart and acidic on the tongue. Fairly dry fruity finish. Overall quite balanced and sweet, a bit coating and sticky with some alcohol. Much better as it warms.

update 4/13/10: had a cellared 07 bottle of PJ courtesy a goose island employee friend. very cidery, like a wine cellar. overripe plum. Dark, great brown pour with off-brown head. finishes nicely hoppy-honey, sticky and rich. body is port-like and heavy. wonderful treat

22oz bottle from 2009.  Pours a mostly clear rusty amber color with a frothy beige head that left some great lacing.  Nose of candied apples, baking spices and some brown sugar.  Perfect balance on the palate, very tasty stuff!!

Holy crap this is really good.  Smells like dates or figs, alcohol and some hard butter candy.  Really rich and sumptuous all the way through the aromas, flavors and mouthfeel.  The taste is mellow whiskey and yeast spice that finishes with a raw woodsy grain flavor.  Sugar pops sweet lip smacking at the end of each swig.  Big, rich and flavorful; like an english barleywine/ belgian ale hybrid.  Thank You Goose Island.  2009 12oz.

courtesy of Blazer06.
pours cloudy amber, off-white head.
aroma and flavors, caramel malts, mild chocolate, toffee, with a mild bitter hops finish. Palate retained some warming alcohol with a lingering nice caramel finish.

Darker pour than I expected, a dark brown. Aroma of ripe fruit, lots of sweet caramel yeaty esters and quite a bit of alcohol. Medium bitterswet flavor with more fruit and yeastiness. A nice ape but would benefit from some age.

2010 12oz. bottle. Pours a nearly clear amber-orange with almost no head at all. Small carbonation bubbles creep to the top one by one. Light aroma of dark fruit, caramelized sugar, Belgian yeast. Sweet flavor with figs, candied sugar, and some light alcohol. Warm finish, medium to thick mouthfeel, and soft carbonation. Kind of a let down.

Bottled. Pours hazy amber with an off-white head. Nose of malt and caramel. Sweet flavour with riped, dark fruits, caramel, malt and notes of spice. Mediumto full bodied. More dry finish with alohol notes. Enjoyable.

2009 bottle from a trade with phaleslu. Pours hazy amber color with off white head. Aromas of dark fruits and molasses. Flavors of raisins, figs, caramel and bread dough. Moderately sweet. Medium body with mild carbonation. Thanks Peter.
light Belgian yeast aroma. pours a garnet color.  small but appreciable bit of carbonation.  slight alcohol warmth.  strong and easy to drink at the same time.

The nose is very sweet, malty, fruit, light alcohol.  The appearance is a cloudy brown, off-white head.  The flavor is less sweet than the aroma, and a tad dry, fruity, boozy.  The finish is tangy, dry, some boozy warming.  Full body.  Decent.

Bottle. Cloudy brown with orange notes and a huge foamy off white head with great retention.  Aroma is belgian malt, herbal and floral hops, fruity notes with apples and plums, yeast honey and alcohol.  Flavor is sweet malt with a lot of fruits, apples, plums, raisins, honey, herbal and floral hops and a long sweet finish. Alcohol is very present. Full body with a liquorous mouthfeel.

2010 bottle. Pours a hazy golden brown with a red tint in the light. The head is thick initially but fades to a thin film. The nose is of sweet raspbery, black current and candi sugar. There are a lot of hops in the nose. As you sip on it there is a lot of hop flavor blended with malt and candi sweetness. It leaves a bitter tang on your tongue. The after taste has a lot of citric acid with a dry feeling on the palate. Overall it is a great brew, with good carbonation. Nice blend of spice, hops and malt.

Amber color, no head; heavy sweet aroma with notes of fruits, caramel and alcohol; quite full-bodied and smoothly carbonated, but a bit sticky on the other hand; flavor gives some pear fruit notes, but they are soon covered by honeyed caramel sweetness; alcohol is there, evident, not quite bothering on its own, but it mixing with this much sweetness makes this just a bit too fat stuff, lacking the subtlety of its belgian cousins. I honestly cant give this more points.
En Bouteille.  2009. Pours dark dark dark, lots of head.  Lots of malt, dark fruit, some caramel and such.  Pretty good.

Bottle, Deveneys, Dublin. Very hazy dark amber colour with a fair amount of sediment.  Head vanished to nowt. Sweet, prickly spice booze aroma. Started out very cloying and never really recovered. Caramel malty, yeast, blah...Not a wholly enjoyable experience. Thats 2 average beers from gi in 1 day, had come to expect a bit more....

2008 12 oz. bottle I have stored until today, 

has a hazy, cloudy red-ruby pour with yeast particles swirling in the mix, initially made a small off-white and light caramel colored head, 
there is a little slow bubbling flowing from the bottom of the glass that gives an impression that this is a viscous brew, bottle had a thin layer of light brown opaque colored sediment on the bottom,

aromas of raisin, faint alcohol esters, toasted malt, caramel and bread with caramel and candy sweetness, there is a touch of flowers on the nose to, 

flavors of dark bread, light flavor of raisin, faint pine and citrus from hops, 
has a touch of pepper, spice and alcohol bitterness at the finish, there is a little alcohol heat and fine bitterness on the throat after the finish that ends dry on the palate, I can taste the alcohol but it does not get in the way or becomes obnoxious as the beer warms, 

mouth feel is thick, almost syrupy, 

this is a nice Winter sipping beer, not bad.

A: The pour is a clear light, golden brown with a nice fluffy head on top.

S: A very sweet nose on this one. A lot of sugar and not very much malt, some pears, and perhaps a bit of raisin as well. Not exactly "Dubbel-like".

T: Like the nose, the amount of sugar in this beer is a bit too much. Very, very sweet with some pear and a noticeable alcohol heat and taste.

M: The body is medium with fairly light carbonation. There is a definite dryness to the finish (probably from all the candi sugar).

D: This one was just far too sweet for me. It had some nice fruit notes both in the aroma and flavor, but the overwhelming presence of the sugar sort of drowned them out.

12 oz bottle.  Pours hazy pale amber with an off-white head.  Sweet aroma with dark fruits and caramel.  Flavor leads with raisin backed up with notes of biscuit and caramel, with a crisp palate and a little alcohol.  Rather nice.

Dont get me wrong, this is not a bad beer; its just perhaps a bit too intense for my taste.  Really rich flavors that border on harsh, to me; it seems more like a quad than anything.  I definitely felt like this stuff was awfully boozy for something that weighs in under 10% ABV.  Perhaps some bottle aging would help?  Young, I couldnt possibly do more than one or two pints of this stuff.  Perhaps this is an example of my own personal preferences coming into play.  Im sure this is a fine beer, as many other reviewers seem to suggest.  It just simply is not for me.
Drank from the tap at the Bronx Ale House in the Bronx, NY.  Has a tart, grape like flavor that I enjoyed but may be to much for the normal beer drinker.
bread, citrus, dough, vanilla, orange, cloudy, frothy, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, medium sourness, medium body, sticky, lively, astringent,

12 oz bottle from liquor barn in lexington, ky. Pour is a reddish orange with an off-white head. The aroma is a mix of malts and dried fruits, especially raisins and plums. This is another great from goose.

Pours deep red/brown with tan head, aroma is full of dark fruit.  Taste up front is sweet with molasses and leads into the dark fruits and finishes slightly bitter from alcohol.  Nice belgian style brew.

Dark amber colored pour with a thick light tan head.  The aroma is apple, plum, pear, and clove.  The flavors are bread, fruit, spice, and a touch of alcohol.  Very smooth rich and creamy palate.  The beer is well balanced with nothing too overbearing, an excellent sessionable Belgian ale.

Bottle.

Cloudy copper color with a small white foam that disappeared quickly.

Sweet aroma with notes of alcohol, dried fruit, syrup and raisins. Malty sweet taste. Slightly acidic with hints of apples and dried fruit. Medium body. Not bad.
Deep copper color with a thin white head that settles quickly.  Aroma of anise and peanuts.  Flavor starts nutty and progresses to a slight sourness with a bitter edge.  Decent enough.

Pours a dark, cloudy copper-red with a small white head that quickly dissipates. Smells sweet, with a nutty, alcoholic nose. Oozy, coating mouthfeel. Malty, toffee and brown sugar taste. Finishes boozy. A good, solid strong ale, but not my favorite GI offering...
355 ml bottle from 2009. Dark hazy copper body with small off-white head.  Flavour is malt, sweet, caramel, yeast and fruit.
Bottle.  Pours cloudy amber.  Belgian yeast, malt, and fruit aromas.  Spicy fruit, clove, and bread flavors.

Bottle from 2009.  Bottled on:  10/05/09.  Different label than that in the picture.  Mine says 8% ABV.  A slightly murky amber pour with a decent-sized sandy head on top.  A sweet smell of plums, candied sugar, caramel, red apples, and pears.  Tart qualities in the aroma become more apparent as it warms up a bit.  Goes down thin to medium-bodied with a fair amount of carbonation.  Almost sparkling-like.  There is some caramel and candied sugar upfront along with some plums.  Tart apples, cherries, and pears follow.  A tangy yeastiness is definitely present as well.  A wheaty finish that features plenty of citrusy qualities.  A bit drying at the end.  Nice balance.  A solid brew.

Vintage 2008
Appearance: Pours an iced tea brown with a thin film of white froth atop.

Aroma:  Banana creme pie, vanilla, bubble gum.

Taste:  Bready malt, chewy caramel, pear, spicy hops and a small touch of booze.

Mouthfeel: Medium bodied with moderate carbonation.

Overall: A real treat to all the senses. Reminded me of a hybrid Abbey Dubbel and an English Old Ale. Just fantastic!
tap: pours dark red/brown. Arouma is weak brown sugar and prunes. Chewy toffee, prunes and cherry flavored cough medicine. Finishes boozy and bitter. Not bad if youre into that sort of thing.

Bottle courtesy of a generous RB at tpd97s throwdown in December, 2009. Pours a dark golden to amber with orange highlights. Aroma is sweet and malty with notes of candy sugar, grain, yeast, caramel, some floral esters. Flavor is sweet and malty with notes of fruit, caramel, candy sugar, light floral hoppiness. Medium body with a pleasing sweet finish.

22 oz bomber-amber/orange pour w/a slight off white head. Slightly sweet aroma. Flavors of candied sugar & w/some bread dough, yeast & dark fruit. Had some overtones of alcohol, not a flavor powerhouse; kind of bland really. I expected more from a brewer w/this kind of buildup-certainly wasnt worth what I paid for it. Short finish of alcohol. Not bad...just blah!

Tasted this beer while on Beer Quest 2010 with the guys. This was beer number 85 and the final beer I officially tasted on the trip. 85 beers in 6 days isnt bad though. Pours a dark brown. Aroma of graham crackers. Flavor is alcohol, wheat, and yeast.

Pours a dark orange, small amount of dense tan/yellow foam. Aroma of bread, yeast, a bit of fruit. Taste is sweet fruity, maybe some apple, with a bit of bitterness too, but a bit weaker than I would expect for a Belgian strong ale. Pretty good stuff, though.

[bottle @ RBESG 2009, Grand Tasting]
Sour herbal toffee aroma. Clear orange under bubbly white. Bitter toffee flavour with brown sugar. Weak and boring. Medium body, low carbonation, sweet finish.

2009. Pours bright mahogany into a trappist glass. Off-white head quickly dissipates to hug rim. Pit fruit and sweet toasty caramel aromas. Crisp with sweet dark alcohol-soaked fruit upfront turning to a lasting chocolate finish.

Thanks to luttonm for a taste of this one. Pours like a DIPA - a honey-orange with a smallish head. Some caramel malts and citrus hops underlie a note I cant stop thinking about when I smell this brew: wet dog. It might be the golden retriever we have in the house, but this actually does have that classic wet dog smell. Not what I want to smell in a brew. That note turns to a more generic skunky beer note as this one warms. The flavor is more interesting, with grassy, herbal hops. It doesnt taste too bitter, but the aftertaste is extremely dry and almost acerbic. Interesting, for sure - glad I tried it... but this one needs a bit of work.
Pours an amber gold with a nice thin head.  Not much depth to the taste, but can taste the 9% ABV.  Not the best of this genre.  Was hoping for more.
Hazy orange amber pour with very little head. Aroma is apple and butter with some alcohol. Medium thin body and sweet syrupy texture.
POurs red/brown. Nose is sweet malts, cherry, bread and yeast. Flavor is sweet sugars, sweet malt with mild toast, yeast, bread and fruit esters.

2008 vintage, 12 oz bottle from Happy Harrys in Grand Forks, ND.   Dark brown pour with chunks of yeast floating in the beer.  Guess I should have shouldnt have poured quite so vigorously.  Two finger, eggshell colored head.  Fruity, yeasty aroma.  Flavor is sweet, dark fruit and a bit malty.  Finish is tangy and slightly hoppy.

12oz bottle poured into a tulip glass.  GIPJ pours light brown in color and murky.  The head is large and creamy looking.  The aroma, while sweet, isnt as fruity as most beers of the style.  I can detect peach, alcohol and figs or dates.  The body is medium in thickness with a lively carbonation that balances the weight well.  The taste is heavy-handed on alcohol, reminding me of a barley wine.  The other flavors are light but include butterscotch, vanilla, and traces of a saison-like grassiness.  This is a nice beer and worth drinking but overall I dont think it is as good as some of its competition.  The finish is dry and brings to mind beans.

@Tampa Wkly Gathering @tpd975s-12oz bottle-pours a tan head and hazy brown color.  Aroma is medium malt-caramel, medium/dark fruit, yeast, some alcohol.  Taste is sweet medium/dark malt-caramel/molasses, bready, medium/dark fruit-plum/raisin, spice hops, yeast.  Good carbonation.

Draft at wrigleyville. Pours clear orange little head, decent lacing. Rich caramel aroma with some vanilla and raisin. Incredibly sweet but balanced well. Somewhat funky caramel finish that I cant place. A little bit of roastiness lingers on the tongue as well. Doesnt seem like Belgian yeast but more like an American strong. Solid beer with abv hidden well.
22oz - Nose was sweet like a raisin with some yeast.  Plate reminded me of a sherry, with some alcohol heat on the end.  Nicely done but unremarkable.

Bottle sample at a tasting. Thanks zvikar. 09 bottle. Reddish-amber color. Caramelly and fruity aroma with some flowery notes and wood hints. Very sweet alcoholic flavor, malty and fruity. Finishes dry with some spiciness. Medium to full-bodied. Feels one-dimensional.

From bottle shared with awiseman and brother Eric.  Aroma is very light and sweet with perhaps a nutty component.  Reminds me of sweet potato casserole (perhaps because its thanksgiving and i just had some). In any case, pours dark orange, especially for a belgian, with minimal tan head.  Taste is creamy caramel with some citrus and a fair amount of carbonation.  Havent had too many belgians, but this is definitely my favorite.

Shared bomber thanks to Brother Eric. Pours very cloudy dark burnt orange. Nose is very sweet and caramely with belgian notes. Flavor is clean, smooth caramel malt, some sugar and slight citrus notes. Almost creamy, very pleasing.

Sample at the Goose Island tasting at Blacklick Wine & Spirits on 11/19/09. Cloudy brown pour with a medium tan head. Syrupy sweet aroma of caramel and candi sugar with Belgian yeast. Sweet caramel and chocolate flavor with a nice roasty finish.

Quickly descending head that leaves lacing in the center of the glass. Cloudy mud brown color. Raspberry and other fruits are all over the aroma. Also smells a little like cake. Taste is kind of yeasty and tons of fruit. Alcohol is well covered. There is a slight hoppiness. Sweet, but not too much for it to be cloying. Quite good.
bottle, orange color with slight wisp foam, aroma of belgian sugar and bubblegum, flavors of bananas, bubblegum, caramelized sugar, sesame oil

Bottle poured into snifter. Pours a clear deep strawberry with a thick, creamy, off-white head that has great retention and leaves some okay lacing. Aroma is boozy, strawberry syrup, medicinal. Taste is super cloying, boozy, spicy, medicinal. Meh. Glad I wasnt the one who paid an arm and a leg for the four-pack.

On tap at the Clybourn location.  Pours amber in color with a beige head.  Notable amounts of yeast and cherry in the aroma.  Tastes of cherry Sucrets, wood, yeast, mild orange zest, and spiced pear.   Odd, but certainly not bad.

At a tasting, Thanks Zvikar, no head, clear light red colour, aromas of honey, dried fruits, caramel, hay and oxidative traces, flavours of soap and dried fruits, with a strong overpowering alcoholic presence. A bit dissapointing.

@ a tasting, pours orange to red with a medium head,  aroma of marmalade, toffee, vanilla, cherry liquor and notes of soy sauce, flavors of pine, vanilla, noticable alcohol and some saltiness, medium bodied. Fine
Bottle: dried fruits, malty, caramel, the alcohol is noticable, honey, pretty rich but something is missing, the flavors are not coming together too well but nice overall.

Bottle. Pours a pale amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity spicy aroma with some hints of caramel. Fruity malty spicy yeasty flavor with some hints of alcohol. Has a fruity malty spicy yeasty finish.

Looks like weak coffee or maybe strong tea. A slightly murky brown with some red tinting. Minimal head that has excellent retention and lacing.

Smells amazing! Sweet malty goodness with some yeast scents thrown in. Sugary caramel/toffee notes. Raisins and brown sugar and figs.

Sweetness of raisins on the tongue with caramel and roasted malts. Light splash of cherries and figs. A nice touch of spiciness.

This feels good in the mouth, though its a little bit light, for my taste. Nice and smooth.

Relatively easy to drink this one, though the 9% alcohol will keep you from pounding em down too quickly.

From the Bottle at RBESG Harlequin, Sheffield 19/07/2009
Hoppy aroma. White head. Amber coloured hoppy and malty with a crisp and slightly dry finish.

Label would make you think its wine (mine doesnt match the RB pic). Bottled Jun 10, so only 5 mos. old. Also, I drank this at 50+ degrees rather than the recommended 40.  Clear amber/red body with okay head. Prominent aroma. Brewer claims its a dubbel, but I dont get tat at all. Some fruit and toffee, and lotsa booze. Not as deep as the best Belgians. More barleywine than dubbel, but maybe it needs age and chill. A little disappointing.

Bottle - Light copper pour with a creamy white head. Smells sour and fruity with some light spice. Taste is nice and smooth with some spicy yeast. Finishes with more spice and hops, along with some sharp booze. The spice kind of clings to your mouth on the finish, which ruins it a bit for me. Overall its pretty one-note and bland--I just never really got into this one.

Bottle 12fl.oz. @ RBESG 09 Grand Tasting @ [ The Harlequin, Sheffield, England. ]Clear medium orange amber color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, light to moderate hoppy. Flavor is moderate sweet and light to moderate bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20090719]

UPDATED: SEP 6, 2011 Poured from bomber into Snifter.

Hazy brownish-red that seems to glow from within. Small white head that leaves spotty lacing.

Aroma of dark fruit, raisins, toffee, banana, spice and a hint of alcohol - surprisingly, a little mild.

Fruit (both the mysterious "dark fruit" I often taste and banana) and toffee predominately. Also notice some nuttiness and spiciness. The spiciness builds at the end and almost turns a little bit bitter. Turns a little more earthy as it warms.

The body seems both syrupy and watery at the same time. Moderately high carbonation and almost has a dry spicy finish but the "syrupiness" prevents that.

Nice sipping Dubbel that is pretty good for being made in the US. There are better ones out there but this one is certainly worth a shot.
Hazy orange-red with no head.  Smells of dry fruits.  Cherry, sweet, and a Belgian yeast complexity with a nice alcohol touch. (2007 Bottle)

2009 bottle. Orange brown with a tiny off white veil. Some herbs and sweet caramel on the nose. Medium to full body, sweet palate without being sticky, traces of basil not very complex, with a medium aftertaste of light caramel with again an herbal note. It defenitely lacks a little carbonation, but nevertheless a pleasing beer to have on a cold weather night.
Draft. Pours red brown with a thin head. Sweet caramel malty aroma with some dark fruit notes. The flavor has sweet and toasty malts, caramel, fruit and a bit of spice. Very good.

Bottle at the Bloomington Beer Festival. Poured a slightly hazy brown with a thin eggshell head.  Aroma had a combination of sweet fruits and malts. Flavor was sweet from the malts with a hint of dark fruits. Nice and light on the tongue.

(draft @ Tap and Mallet - Rochester, NY) Copper color with a thin cream colored head. Lots of sweet malts and dark fruits in the aroma. Some wooden and spice notes as well. Flavor is very complex with lots of sweetness and fruits through the middle. Lots of caramel and mild spice follow it up at the end. Alcohol is a bit prevalent. Would probably mellow with age.

It poured a clear reddish liquid with a big light brown foam that left allot of lacing. It had a smell of caramell, malt, yeast, spices, wood and pepper. Very nice. It had a similar taste of sweet malt, caramell, nuts, spices and a hint cognac or similar at the end. Very smooth and nice mouthfeel. Very enjoyable, I liked this one.

bomber: Pours dark copper/amber with a thin off white head.
Aroma is a bit subdued. some belgian candy sweetness and dried fruit tones. Some fruitiness.
Flavour is woody oak tones over a mix of raisiny fruitiness and alc stickiness. slightly spice towards the finish.

12 oz. bottle - 2005 vintage; wow, thanks tom!!  expectations were low, but this was super tasty; clear dark amber with soapy thin white head; killer nose of bourbon, candy malt, oak, vanilla and fruit; super dank with notes of sherry, apple and yeasty spice; super sweet and yummy; kind of a combo of a grand cru and braleywine
Pours a hazy copper with almost no head. Aroma is dark, sticky dried fruit. Nice nose on this one - notes of apricot, plum and peach. Finishes clean.

Bottle - 2008 version. From Ølbutikken, Copenhagen. Appears with a screw-off cap??
 To make an belgian abbey style for others than belgians in their right enviroment should be met by a big sign saying: "Dont Go There" And normally it shows that the attemps is not very interesting - and surely not worth to be called belgian abbey - But then again, it should keep inovative brewers to keep trying to wrestle this type of beer around. This Goose Island named after an belgian Abbot, is another american try: Here goes..The pour is dark kobber golden with noteable yeast-leftovers moshing around. The head is small and tanned that tends to fade out. The nose is nice and intense. It has a perfumic dominans that reminds me of sweet marzipan, chocolate and sweet oranges. In the taste you can tell the influence and you can almost see the belgian idols somewhere in the distance. Its sweet with a slight spicyness. Caramel, vanilla and malts with a sharp alcohol feeling in the very back of your mouth in the end. I find it a bit to sweet to be well balanced - but maybe its just me. Nice creamy low carbonated mouthfeel. This one didnt convince me of the fact that belgians does the best belgians - but its not bad.

(Bottled, 2008 vintage) Hazy dark red-amber with a very small head. Aroma of orange marmalade, dried fruit, some spices. Flavor is also sweetish fruit marmalade with orange peel, some anise and other spices, moderate alcohol presence, touch of cardboard. Medium body with quite low carbonation. Reminds me of Regal (Bocq) and Corsendonk Christmas, but feels thinner in body. Not a bad effort, but it just doesnt quite feel Belgian.

Pours a bright amber color with a medium off-white head which leaves a few streaks of lacing.  Aroma is thick; caramel apple and rum-soaked raisins.  Taste is much the same - a lot thicker than I expected.  Caramel apple, dark fruit, apple rind, and maybe a bit of bleu cheese.  I expected better.

From the bottle, pours a dark amber with a thin white head.  Belgian-y aroma, taste is malty with notes of caramel, plums, alcohol, oranges? Easy to drink, though quaffing will exaggerate the alcohol flavors.  Good-un
Bottle at RBESG 09 Sheffield.  Amber/copper with lasting beige head.  I like orange/tangerine flavours, a bit like tripel I suppose.  Sweetish American malt, but a win for me.
Pours a dark amber with a white head.  Aroma has notes of spice, caramel, and fruit.  Flavor is malty, with spice and dark fruit.
Tap at Clybourn brewpub, Chicago. Great Belgian aroma. Nice sweet, malty, spice, caramel, rich fruit. I really enjoyed this on tap.

Bottle 2009 from ty. Nice red color, not much head.... Nose is sugar and some dark fruits... Taste is a nice belgian. Texture is on the thicker side. Nice raison, oak, slightly roasted malt, brown sugar (how come you taste so good)... Alcohol is hidden well. Overall a nice sipping beer. Thanks again Ty!
Pretty sweet in flavor - malty, surprisingly hoppy, light and pretty easy to drink, alcohol is covered well, but the flavor is too straightforward. The Belgian flavors are restrained.
Solid Dubbel. Bit of malts and some plumb. Not a heavy beer. I would like more of the intensity and richness that a Dubbel delivers...but it is a fine beer.

Very good beer and a bit of surprise to me. It has the flavor and aroma of candied fruits. The beer is a dusky amber with red-gold highlights. A gentle head caps it off. It doesnt quite fulfill my notion of a Dubbel, but its been awhile since my last. The beer is very sweet with a malt flavor that could almost work in a barleywine. It packs a lot of fruit flavors, including plums, grapes and overripe peaches. Its a very nice Belgian yeast strain for an American brewery with good phenols. The beer is right on the edge of booziness, but the balanced sweetness keeps it from going too far. Before tasting the beer, I was trying to maintain some skepticism in spite of my great enjoyment of the BCS. While Pere Jacques might not be quite as perfectly executed as that fantastic beer, it is still quite good in its own right.
Sweet malt aroma and taste. Belgian yeast flavor missing for me. Dark amber color, with modest head.

2009 bottle from Utobeer, ABV is 8 %. Clear reddish copper with a tan head. Malty caramel aroma with noticeable alcohol. Rich caramel and cookies flavours, some spiciness and dark fruits. A good attempt at a Belgian abbey beer (whatever that is).

Dark red brown colored with vanishing yellow head. Cookie-spicy aroma with some vinous note. Medium bodied. Flavor is sweeter with caramel dominating, lemon and spiciness also here. Aftertaste is sugary still with some perfumy hopped touch and exotic fruit, alcohol covered well.

On tap at the Dayton Ale Fest.  Pours a clear amber with a fluffy white head.  Aroma is sweet malts with hints of dark fruit, toasted malts, vanilla, and a bit of caramel.  On the palate, is is rather smooth, but a nice warm alcohol burn is there as well.  The flavor pulls out the sweet malts and finishes a bit dry.  Very enjoyable beer.

12 oz. bottle, 2008 from Buffalohead. Clear amber with a healthy light tan head. Caramel and dark fruit, hints of vanilla and a bit of earthiness. Alcohol is quite evident. Smooth and creamy, rich medium/full palate and light carbonation. Lots of malty sweetness, peppery bite comes through at the finish, which ends up softly dry. Enjoyable, smooth, nice balance.

( 12oz 2007 bottle thanks to zdk9) Pours a clearish amber with oily bubbles. Nose is fruity, sweet corn (in a good way), and alcohol. The taste is sweet caramel malt, with a light creaminess and a great oily body.

Hazy orange/brown with hardly any head. Rich malty flavor of bread, toffee and caramel, with a good amount of suger and alchohol. The fruity esters are noticed as the beer heats up in your mouth, along with bourbun and spicey pepper. Warming finish!

UPDATED: SEP 25, 2009 22 oz. bottle from Ludlow Wines, Cincinnati.  Pours lovely clear copper/amber with small off white head.  Aroma of caramel mixed fruits, yeast, clove, spice, alcohol.  Flavor of caramel, fruit (citrus, banana), sugar, malt, yeast, and pepper.  Smooth, complex, balanced.  Warming alcohol.  Medium length finish, bitter and sweet.  I prefer this one to the Matilda, but not by a lot.

Full amber color with a brownish hue. Fizzy eggshell head. Tart aroma of green apples and grape juice. Some yeast, caramel, and malt qualities as well. Flavor has lots of caramel. Secondary flavors of toffee, bourbon.  Nothing tart like the aroma would suggest, but the yeast/caramel/malt qualities are present, prominent, and rich. This ones on the sweet side. The finish is caramel with only the slightest hint of bourbon. Very smooth and well balanced. I thoroughly enjoyed this. One of the most well-balanced strong ales Ive had to date.
Bottle @ RBESG Grand Tasting 2009... copper ... light toffee nose ... sweet toffee ... little pine ... big hop in linger ... light bitter,
2007 bottle thanks to thirdeye11.  amber with a cream head.  nose is dried fruits, flowers and yeast.  quite easy on the palate with a smooth flavor of dried fruits and light yeast.
Bottle.Deep amber colour with no head.Aroma is bready and tosted has caremel flavor and note of brown sugar and malt,warming and fruity.
12oz bottle into an abbey glass.  There we go!  Much better Belgian style than the Matilda!  One of my GI favorites.

Deep ruby-amber colored pour with a big, fluffy, off-white head.  The aroma is dark fruit, clove, bubblegum, pepper, tobacco, licorice, and caramelized brown sugar with a hint of alcohol.  The flavor is heavy on the licorice with some ripe banana, clove, lots of peppery phenols, and brown sugar.  Finishes a little metallic.  Creamy medium body with lots of carbonation and a hit of alcohol.

Pours a deep burnt orange color with a small khaki head. Nose is dark brown sugar, caramel, bubblegum, spice, and a whiff of earthy hops. Taste is the same with additional notes of toffee and metal. Solid. Medium mouthfeel and medium long finish. Very drinkable at 9%.
Pours a bright orange color. Rally smooth beer with great fruity notes and sweet but not too sweet. Finishes clean with a slight bitterness. Great beer! Brought back from Chicago a month ago.
Bottle. Red/orange with a beige head. Fruity aroma with yeast, malt, brown sugar and a little anis. Sweet flavour of caramel and malt with yeast, fruit and anis. Some bitterness in the end.

Bottle. Pours deep amber coloured with a creamy and lacing light brown head. Aromas of caramel, syrup, sweet malt, roasted, spice and cookis. Rich and malty flavour with notes of toffee, warming alcohol, dried fruit and roasted malt.
Pours slightly hazy amber with an off white head.  Aroma is rich caramel and dark fruits.  Flavor is big caramel and dark fruits as well as a big bit of candy sugar.  Very good.

bourbon color, medium off-white head, a bit of lace.  airy nose (and my notes say, if i am reading them correctly, FISH! but i was possibly drunk then, and i am definitely drunk now, so who knows? maybe my glass wasn;t clean enough), hints of fruit.  flavor is fruity and belgian yeasty.  medium bodied, dry finish.  a bit too sweet but not bad.  on tap @ maple tree inn.

UPDATED: AUG 4, 2009 Bottle 355ml, 2009. Pours translucent russet, with attractive off-white head, and lacing. Sumptuous aroma of dark fruits, yeast and mellow hops. Extremely smooth on the palate, with fruity caramel to the fore, with very few hints of the high alcohol content. A very decent ale, and a worthy tribute to the Belgian ale tradition.

Bottle at the RBESG09, Grand tasting, sheffield. Alround rating: Another failed attempt at a belgian by an american brewer for me. Sweet honey malts, bit of toffee spice is subtle. Its fairly boring stuff.

2009 version, 22 oz bottle. Pours a deep caramel color with red tinges and a very dense, creamy tan head. First note that comes through in the aroma is apples followed by a cherry note, toffee, yeasty and a strong sweet caramel aroma. Flavors blend together perfectly. The caramel sweet comes through first, a very yeasty flavor comes in toward the middle, lots of dark fruit and cherry notes carry through the flavor and ends with a light biscuit note. Very fine carbonation and a moderately heavy feeling make for a fantastic mouth feel. Overall a great brew and one that I will pick up again for some aging.
Aroma of yeast, toasted malt with notes of apple, cherry and caramel. Sweet with a little hop and toffee. Lingering finish and creamy texture. Pleasant drinking this evening.
A bottle tasted at Olutkellari Helsinki. Pale thin head. Bright coppery colour. Soft nose.Soft slightly sweet taste with some hints of caramel. Alcohol well hidden. Mild hoppiness.

355 ml bottle. Finland.
Dark copper colour with small off-white head. Dark yeasty aroma. Slight alcohol and weak hops in flavour. Very much Belgian Dark Ale.

A Mes rate. Bottle at the White Horse.A rather spectacular deep amber colour with a slight off white collar but there is plenty of carbonation. Yeasty aroma with plenty of depth. Some rich chewy malt, lots of dark fruit and a good lick of burnt sugar. The flavour is equally powerful and complex. Big fruit and yeast, interesting malt, lots of caramel and a big warming finish without even being close to hot. Surprisingly full bodied. Good length. Very satisfying indeed. Reminds me of a slightly lighter Lees Harvest in a lot of ways. Good beer.

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2011 355ml bottle (Kaisla, Helsinki) (6:4:6:3:12=3.1)
Rich sweet malty aroma. Sweet sugary body. Quite alcoholic. Some burnt caramel in the aroma later. Plain sweet malty body, very dull. No features at all. Unless you count just plain sugar as a feature, I dont. Dull dull dull.
Rerate: 355ml bottle - shared by Jari
6 very sweet aroma, toffee and caramel very rich, but alas a touch gluey or acetoney.
4 Rich red brief head settles to a ring.
6+ Full malty taste, fairly roasted corners, some sweet nuttiness, vanilla woodiness, and even a ruby-portwine take on raisins.
4 Smooth sweet palate, a little slick, and carbonation low.
13- Aging worked well, the sugars have oxidized pleasantly, with the vanilla woodiness really making this quite mellow, and way more drinkable. More character too. I believe this would continue to improve for another year or so.
Bottle @ RBESG Grand Tasting 2009. Orange blonde color. Tangerine and a hint of powdery hops in the aroma. Alcoholic flavor with tangerine and powdery and medecinal hops.

RBESG Sheffield 2009 Grand Tasting at the Harlequin. 2008 vintage, ABV 8%. Clear amber colour, thin beige head. Aroma of caramel, lots of malts, a bit like cognac. Flavour is sweet, fruity, caramel, cognac. Bland. Medium bodied.
UPDATED: DEC 29, 2009 Great malty creaminess. Beautiful dark brown coloration. exceptionally smooth, very rich, dark fruit flavors are apparent. absolute joy to drink.

12oz bottle, 2009 vintage.  Pours a hazy reddish-brown with a thin light brown head.  Aroma is sweet, with dark fruit and caramel along with some roasted malt, bready yeastiness, and maybe a slight bit of syrupy hops.  Taste is fairly full, with an initial flavor of syrupy hops and caramel ending on a lingeringly sweet and tart finish of plums, raisins, warming alcohol, and a slight woodiness.  Reminds me a lot of the vintage ales, though not quite as rich in flavor and aroma.

12 oz. bottle (vintage 2009) at Vihreä Haltiatar, Jyväskylä. Dark amber color. Perfumed, orangey, toffeish, raisiny and malty aroma. Malty, caramelly, toffeish, nutty and raisiny flavor with restrained spiciness. Well made beer with somewhat restrained Belgian character.

UPDATED: JUL 19, 2009 Bottled, alc. 8% (Beer Hunters, bottled 03/2009). 
Deep amber-copper brown color, small beige head, small floating yeast. Very yeasty, berryish, a bit tart nose. Tart, yeasty, red currant, raw gooseberries, long alcoholic and tart aftertaste. Probably infected, needs rerating, although it is not so bad like this. (7/4/7/3/13 3.4).
Re-rated this from same batch. Same numbers! Interesting. this bottle has no yeast, no floating particles or yeast in the bottom whatsoever. Silky, low carbonation - mouthfeel. Sweet toffeish flavor, some kind of light grassy notes. Close to Belgium abbey dubbels, not very American.

(Bottle at Olutkellari Helsinki on 2009-07-11) Amber and lightly hazy. Small white head. Caramell, toffee and malts in aroma. Medium bodied and slightly dry palate with medium carbonation. Sweetness, syrup, malts and light bitterness in taste. Malts and sweetness in aftertaste.

2007 bottle.  Hazy amber/brown with light tan head which dissipates pretty quickly but forms nice lacing as it is consumed. Sweet malty aroma of caramel and dark fruits. Taste is well balanced and not as sweet as the aroma might suggest. Alcohol is well hidden. Glad that I have more in the cellar.
UPDATED: JAN 1, 2014 TAP: murky amber pour, off-white head. Brown sugar, fruit, and caramel on the nose. Complex fruit, spice, and malt on taste. This is really good stuff.

355 ml bottle. Dark reddish copper colour. Medium-sized light beige head that clings to the glass. Wonderfull sweet caramel malt aroma. Then the Belgian yeast hit you. Reminds me a little of North Coast Brother Thelonious, but this one packs quite a bit more caramel. Spicy with a focus on black pepper and thyme. High carbonation level. Hints hide well in the horizon, and I feel that the finish is a little watery. Much more caramel upfront than in the finish.

Pours a hazy amber brown with a nice off-white head. Aroma is pleasant with notes of banana, apples, and malt. Flavor is complex and fruity. Medium mouth feel and is well balanced. Once of the nicer dubbels Ive tried, and a credit to Goose Island. Im glad to see recent raters put this one higher as I think it is deserving.

UPDATED: NOV 22, 2010 Bottle shared with the guys at the Barrios 500th Swallow Tasting.  Thanks maniac.  Applebutter aroma with some alcohol. Big brown sugar and syrup with dark cherries.  Grapes. Cinnamin. Very enjoyable.

pere jacques - 2010 - Sweet malty, syrupy, lavendar, dopplebock?, Big malty presence, 7 4 8 4 14

Pours an almost non-existent beige head with an amber body.  Smells of brown sugar and a little fruity.  Flavor is dried apple, dates, brown sugar, some yeast...apple butter.  Finish is sweet.  Sweet, delicious elixir.

Bottle  Thanks to my Buddy Jeremiah.  2007 vintage.  Pours a murky amber with a thin tan head.  The head leaves quickly but makes for some good lacing.  Has a good sweet aroma of fruits, caramel, and yeast.  Has a good carbonation.  The mouthfeel is real good.  Flavors are awesome.  I thought the aroma meant this would be very sweet.
