But I was inncorrect.  The balance is terrific.  Has a good spiciness.  Very palateable.  Has a syrupy texture.  the finish is good with a nice aftertaste.  This is an awesome beer.

12 oz bottle from Ryan. Pours a fairly clear reddish copper. Nose is candied malts, some light honey and yeast, some light fruit esters and heavy caramel. Flavor is up front carmelized brown sugar and lots of it. Quite nice. No real hops but the malt is layered enough that the sweetness doesnt become cloying. Vanilla and tofee on the backend with some cherry pit notes. Very tasty.
Botella. Hazy red-brown colour. Sweet and malty caramel aroma. Sweet flavour of roasty caramel and roasty malt with dark fruits. Bitter sweet pleasant finish. Takk fyri Pinball.

It is very beautiful, dark red amber with a creamy head. The aroma has sweetness and notes of roasted malt, caramel and fruit. The flavour has sweetness and notes of roasted malt, caramel, fruit, raisin, spice, yeast and it has some citrus in the finish. Its harmonic and nice.

bottle.
cloudy brown, thick lighrt brown head.
aroma is sweet, caramel, dark fruits.
flaovr is malty, sweet, faint hoppy. dry.

Tasting at DØE, Aarhus Syd, DK.
Bottled, 170609.
Brown with white head. Aroma of ripe fruit and spices. Flavor is malt, fruit and sweet raisins.

I shared this with BeerBaron617, and its a bottle we picked up as part of a pick six...Its a 2008 vintage.  I really enjoy everything about this beer.  It poured a nice hazy light brown color with a caramel colored head.  The aroma was very nice - rather malty and sweet smelling.  At first taste, I only think malt...then I gradually go into a caramel raisin sort of flavor.  Very tasty.  Only my second from Goose Island ever, first rating, and I really enjoy it a lot.

2008 vintage. I shared this 12 oz. with MereLikesBeer. It poured a darker reddish brown. The aroma is pleasantly sweet, with a touch of vanilla on the finish. The flavor was of raisins and caramel. Very finely crafted brew from a favorite neighbor state.Cheers!

12 oz. bottle. Vintage 2008. Bottled 11/07/2008. Pours a thin lasting, tan head with attractive lacing, over a clear (SRM 15-17) body....nose of mild dried fruit (raisin, cherry, plum), toffee.....taste initially slightly sweet, with a bit of bitterness, finishing with more raisin, cherry....mouth feel is light to medium, carbonation medium, rather dry acidic finish. This has most, if not all, the elements of a Belgian Strong, it is just a little lighter than the better/best. However it is very young and should  improve with age.
Flaske: Mørk gennemsigtig øl, uden gærrester. Duft af sukker og krydderi. Behagelig smag til at starte med, men en lidt for fremtrædende alkohol trækker lidt ned

2007 vintage.
Appearance  Pours a medium brown color with a dark yellowish tan head about half a finger in size. The head dissipates quickly and leaves a small cap and ring. When held up to light, it turns into a beautiful amber orange color.

Smell  There is that Belgian yeast smell! On top of the bready yeast (that lingers more toward crackers really) there is a lot of sweet fruits and malt. This smells like white grapes, in a very wine-ish way. 

Taste  The Belgian yeast doesnt overpower the other flavors of this beer like so many other Belgian style beers I have had, which is a very welcome addition! Lots of white grapes, spices, and a little bit of bready-ness. This seems to have smoothed out and become a very mellow, well balanced beer.

Mouthfeel  A little thicker than I wanted, but it is by no means thicker than what is expected. Has a medium mouthfeel that is in no way watery.

Drinkability  This is a pretty solid brew. A year and a half has done this beer well. Definitely a great sipping beer.

Several bottles thanks to belgiumtripel. Bottle is a 008 with an 11/7/2008 and batch 0755. Pours with a small, off0white head over a clearish, pretty ruby-amber body. Aroma of Belgian yeast, wheat, alcohol, chocolate, dark fruits. Taste is wheat, chocolate, cinnamon, some alcohol, tootsie roll, bread, alcohol, estery and tons more. Got another four pack thanks to this trade; I feel that age will help this a lot. Medium carbonation with a dry finish.

very minimal nose, hard to pick up much at all. maybe lightly phenolic. appearance is burnt rust. flavor is of straightforward malt, lightly toffee-ish notes but closer to syrup then crunch. strong caramel character, and lightly hops and/or spice to balance it out. very unlike what i expected, and an entirely different direction then matlida or most belgians that im aware of.

good aroma with fruity esters showing through, could use more intesnse aroma. Appearance is the only flaw in this beer, dark for the style, about 15 srm or possibly a little light for a dark strong.Yeast stays in solution and does not settle out very well. Great mouthfeel with just the right amount of thickness. Very warm finish but not dry. Delicious belgian beer.

Poured from bottle into tumbler.  Very pretty copper color with a very slight pink/tan 3/4 inch head that quickly diminished 1/4 inch.  Sweet understated malt notes in aroma with the alcohol content coming through second.  A nice alcoholic banana pancake aroma comes from these two original scents.  Lots of bits floating throughout the body and a slow but steady steam of carbonation.  Very light sweetness (like warm cotton candy) in the taste and an incredibly smooth mouthfeel with a slight alcohol kick at the back of the throat.  Pretty decent lacing too.  I agree with dutch23mp about aging this beer, hopefully to encourage that 9% abv out of hiding and subdue the over-sweetness.  A nice beer but dont want more than one.

Bottle. Amber body with a white medium head. Malty and bit sugary aroma with notes of caramel, yeast and spices. Flavour is sweet malty, light alcoholic, dark fruity, bit sugary and yeasty. Medium bodied.

Peculiar Pub: Great color during the pour, however the head was lacking... small and quickly dissapating.  Clearly not heavily carbonated.  Inital taste yields dark, sugary, cooked fruits.  Overall mild taste, good beer.

22 oz bottle given as present. pours red with a small cream head.  sweet tasting with some taste of caramel or honey. Simple and not bad. I would like to age this and see if it would have more character.

22oz. Bottle:  Faint aroma of candi-sugar, light caramel, and slight grains.  Poured orange/deep amber in color with a tiny tan head that disappeared immediately.  Clear.  Sparkling.  Flavor is slightly sweet.  Tastes of slight honey, grains, and a hint of alcohol.  Medium body.  Slick, oily texture.  Soft to average carbonation.  I clearly do not see what other do in this beer.

Bottle pours red amber color with off white head.  Aroma is cinnamon, dark fruit, sweet malt, and some brown sugar yeast.  Medium mouthfeel.  Flavor follows the nose exaclty with a hot cinnamon spice finish.  There is a bit of sweetness at the end, too.  Still a nice brew.

2008 bottle @ Liva, Kolding. Pours a deep amber with a red hew and a tremendous creamy head and lacings. Nose is sweet of dark fruits, sugar and yeast. Vinous & inviting. Smooth palate and a  taste of caramel, figs, prunes and raisins. Not as complex , perhaps, as the good Belgiums, but damm tasty, simple and well made.

Bottle thanks to kryptic! Hazy amber, almost no head--beige ring. Sweet nose of caramel, yeast, and spice, perhaps a little banana. Flavor has more malt, some fruit bread, brown sugar, touches of alcohol. A little fizzy in the contrast of carbonation and sticky weight, but without that carbonation, this would be a sickly sweet malt fest.
Pours a hazy amber witn an off-white head. Smells of alcohol and flowers. Sweet with some yeast aromas. Also some flowers. Dry. Some abricots. Medium body. Medium carbonation.

2007 Bottle. Pours hazy burnt amber with a 1 finger creamy tan head. Aroma is rich carmel, almond nougate, toffee, candied fruits, white raisins, sweet apple bread, peppery yeast and more incredibly rich caramel. Flavor is lighter caramel over red delicious apple, vanilla, toasted nuts, candi sugar, light roast coffee, maple sugar, a multitude of sweet breads, molasses, honeycomb, a touch of nectarine and a burnt sugar, bread dough finish. Palate is medium thin thickness with a moderate effervescence that is just ehough to keep things stirred up on the palate without being in the way. This stuff is really, really good. Would make a fantastic pairing for roast duck.

Pours a deep reddish orange color with a thin white head with. Dark sweet fruits, that I cant quite identify, candy and sugar combod with a bready yeasty aroma with spices comes across nicely.  The flavor is similar with the dark sweet fruits and candy sugar dominating with some spices and floral hops in the background. A little bit of alcohol sweetness show up as well. Medium almost full body that is very sweet and smooth that leads to a sweet, clean finish with a touch of alcohol burn. This one is nice with a good sweet flavor...

Bottle. Pours a clear light brown with orange-red hues nice beige head. Strong nose of malts, some nice fruit yeast aromas also, apricot, bananas, green grapes. Medium body, a bit of alcohol, some spice, toasted malts. Decent.

Nice ruby amber with floaties. Small, but lasting off-white head. Spicy aroma, with dried fruit, alcohol, caramel and bubblegum. Pepper-y spicy flavour with caramel notes. Alcohol is clearly noticed. Decent quadruple with an obvious American character.

Pours thick and a bit syrup-like. No real head to speak of. A gorgeous brown color. Not as thick on the palate as it pours. Caramel, vanilla. Not a very big malt kick. A tasty beverage that is put together well. But it isnt something youll tell all your friends about.

Bottle. High fluffy but long lasting off-white head leaving nice lacings. Clear amber body. Alcohol dominated aroma with fruit and caramel. Alcohol also at the front of the flavor, otherwise roasted malt with caramel and apple pear notes. Low carbonation. Long bitter aftertaste.

Bottle.A nearly opaque dark murky brown color body with a medium off-white lasting head . Aroma is bready,yeasty, apples and dateswith some faint clove and bananna esters. Flavor is earthy,malty and spicy/sweet with some apples.rasins,caramel,with just a bit of the alcohol coming through. Medium to heavy carbonation,medium body with a dry finish and mouthfeel. Quite sessionable despite the 9% ABV. Another fine brew from Goose Island.

2007 bottle.  The pour was dark amber, light brown.  The head was slightly off-white.  The aroma was rich caramelly malts, light yeast and cinnamon.  The flavor was caramel, brown sugar, cinnamon, yeast and a bit of granny smith apple and raisin.  Some alcohol too, but it wasnt out of place.  The mouthfeel was warming, medium bodied and enjoyable.
fruity, floral aroma, orangish-red hue, off-white head, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, fizzy, thin feel, medium body, abrupt finish.
Bottle at a Club-Tasting. Clear chocolate brown - white head. Yeasty, berries, fruity, wet dog, caramel, nutty, high phenols, toasted, light hoppy, licorice yeasty. Far too much.

UPDATED: APR 24, 2009 12oz Bottle, year 2007 batch @ Peculiar Pub April 22, 2009.  Pours gorgeous red/brown pour w/ two finger head.  Large nose of brown sugar, dark fruits.  Taste is similair.  Medium/Full bodied, very good Winter Style Belgian Strong.  Also, very cool story of the brew and Pere Jacques on the label.  3.95
Poured into tulip glass, 1/4" head.  Smells very fruity. Slightly sweet, medium bitterness.  Good level of carbonation.  Nice beer.

12 oz bottle poured into a tulip glass.  Color is cloudy deep brown, with small tan frothy head.  Aroma is of caramel apple, yeast, and tart fruit.  Taste is slightly tart, with a caramel apple flavor, and a bit of an alcohol burn, though it is mostly hidden.  Pretty nice Belgian ale from Goose Island!

Pours a caramel opaque color with medium frothy khaki head. Nose is vinous, caramel, dark fruits, light spice. Initial taste of plum, light apple, belgian candi sugar, caramel, yeast. Mid palate some figgy tones become more apparent, still remaining sweet and sugar through the finish. 9% is hidden very well. Hood head retention and some spot lacing of the glass. Medium body. Great palate duration. Overall a sweet beer but attempted be balanced by some hidden tart/citrus.

12 fl oz bottle. Pours deep amber, almost clear and golden with a small, light yellowish and lasting head. Aroma is mild spiced, wooden hoppy and light fruity. Flavour has a distinct hops presence. Caramel, light spiced and fruity. Liqourice note too. Somewhat undefineable chemical touch too. Ends dry, roasted and bitter with a persisting chemical note.

Bottle from LIVA, Kolding. [thank you, Feldthaus]
Pours dark amber with a fine, creamy, off-white head. Fine lacings. Aroma is lightly vinious, caramel, toffee, plums, raisins, coriander. Medium carbonation, good creamy mouthfeel. Great flavour, lots of fat caramel, good dried fruits, biscuits, yeast, a touch of dark chocolate. Good vinousness, wonderful elegance.

Bottle at bager.
Clear orange coloured with a small white head.
Fruity aroma dominated by spices and caramel with notes of yeast.
Sweet flavour of spices, caramel, yeast, liquorice and hops.
Hoppy finish.
Bottle. Semi clear and amber coloured with a medium sized head. Somewhat malty with notes of nuts, dust, caramel and raisins.
12 oz bottle.  sweet.  spices, toffee.  some dark fruits.  easy drinkin.  slightly too sweet for my liking.
Malty and sweet. Not complex. Ok but not great. Sweet and caramel. Slight belgian spice. This one may have been older, need to get a fresh bottle.

Clear filtered body with small off-white head. The aroma is caramel, toffee, dark pitted fruits and light spice. The flavor is moderately sweet, bananas, spice, light pepper, lots of toffee and figs. Medium body is soft and thin with light carbonation.

Bottle - another thx to BZ via Chi-town. Orange/amber color with a slight cloudiness. Slightly sweet with flavors of caramel, apple, and malt. Not to heavy, and very drinkable. Enjoyable, but possibly a little too sweet.

33 cl bottle, Fargo, ND, USA. Opaque mahogany colour, faint head clinging to glas side. Banana, other fruit, raisin & yeast. Full bodied, sweet and almost syrupy. Warming and lingering finish, smooth for the strength.
Pours an dark amber-orange hue with medium white head. Sweet taste with hints of fruit, raisin, malts, and caramel. Good texture and excellent brew.

UPDATED: OCT 11, 2014 I really love these Goose Island specialty beers and this one is no exception. $2.99 for a single and worth every penny although I wish theyd sell them for considerably cheaper. Regardless, when the rest of the humanity is a letdown, at least you can enjoy one of its better creations with this one and forget all about it.

Pours a golden-orange beer with small beige head. Slightly oxidized on the nose, sweetish, with dried fruits, mostly raisins, apples, and some alcohol. Mildly sweet on the palate, with raisins, and some alcohol. Lingering finish with sweetness, and some dried fruits.

From a trade in 2006, but I cant remember who with - thanks, tough! Clear brownish orane, with a sizey white head. Really nice aroma - very sweet, with a lot of pear and apple and a touch of caramel. Very sweet and heavy. Nicely boozy flavor at first, with some shiskey notes and syrpuy fig - like flavor. Very nice.
12 oz. bottle. Very malty beer! The flavor is well balanced considering the maltyness. This beer also has a very cloudy haze.

Amber orange hue and a white head that had great lacing.  Very sweet mostly caramel notes, but there was some sugar cane notes.  Mild bread notes but not enough to balance out the sweet malt notes.  Alcohol was well hidden and the carbonation was pleasant.

A amber ale with a thin white head. In aroma, a pleasant caramel and sweet candy, with notes of cinnamon and alcohol warmth. In mouth, a nice sweet candy malt with notes of licorice and coriander. Medium bodied. Tasted at Mondiale 2007.
Pretty dark and VERY malty. The taste of malt is powerful in this beer.  Very malty.
Bottle. Amber color, medium white head. Aroma of fruit, raisin, plum and fig. Tastes similar but with some caramel and malts. Good beer.

12 oz 2008 bottle.  Fairly rich, heavy malt takes up a lot of the aroma on this one, with notes of rich toffee, almond cookie, minor alcohol, some roasted nuts, and sweet fruit.  Not as much billowing head on the pour as i would like from a rich Belgian style ale, but some soft white cream head that doesnt stick around too long, caramel orange in color, with a mid-opaque body and minor particulate.   Quite heavy sweetness/richness, not cloying but very slightly to balanced on that side of things.  More fig and raisin notes and less nutty notes than i was expecting. Also, a good amount of chewy cookie, some sugar crystals and sweet malt.  Minor earthy hop bitterness finally makes its presence known right in the finish alongside a good amount of rich malts.  A good, not overly heavy feel throughout and very little alcoholic bite. This is a good, well-crafted beer, but theres nothing here too special or unique to really getting me that excited.
Poured from bottle [03/10/08 1855]. Copper in color with tiny head. Smells of malt, dried fruits, and yeast. Tastes the same, but for some reason tastes close to a wine. Very unique brew.
Golden brown pour with dark fruit and chocolate notes.  Yeasty and malty character blends quite well with brown sugar and a full body.  Well blended brew.

Bottle. A hazy, golden-orange beer with a small, beige head. Slightly oxidized on the nose, sweetish, with dried fruits, mostly raisins, chocolate notes, some alcohol and a touch of beef-stock. Sugar-sweet on the palate, slightly warming and full-bodied, with raisins, some alcohol and a little oxidation. Lasting finish with sweetness, some dried fruits and alchol warmth. A quite nice one, but sort of strange.  Cant really pin it. (081215)
12oz botle. Dark amber pour with a large pillowy head. Aroma of fruits with some sugar and malts. Flavor is sweet with a full-bodied malt backing. Alcohol is amazingly well hidden. Nice.

12-oz. 05. Thanks, Doug! What a score. I wonder if that little place in Yakima took care of it, or if its been boiling evry summer for the last four years.
Age has definitely improved this beer--its a tawny, oxidized miracle with four years in the bottle. Dark brown with ultra-slim gray rim. Gargantuan port/sherry nose with heaps of red apples. Creamy body on the high side of medium. Apples, tawny port, figs & raisins, caramel, cream, and butterscotch. Absolutely delicious.
Bottle. Cloudy orange/amber color with a tall creamy head. Aroma: Fruity, hints of malt and sugar. Flavor: fruit, light toffee, dark candi, hint of maple and honey. Alcohol well hidden .

12 ounce bottle (12/28/07) in Westmalle glass.  NIce bright amber red with ring head.  Very toasty caramel  wood aroma with mild sweet syrupy fruit and a hint of alcohol.  Toasted caramel flavor with wood and fruity syrup balanced just enough with tobacco bitterness to stop short of tasting like cough syrup.  Fairly clean finish.  Medium-full body and medium-low carbo.  Pretty good mouthfeel.  Fairly complex.

12 ounce bottle courtesy of dankman. Thanks! Bottled 3/10/08. Pours a brown color with a medium head. Average head retention and lacing. Aroma of toffee, caramel, dark fruits. Taste is brown sugar, candi sugar, green apple, raisin. Full bodied. Nice beer.

Bottle marked 2007 on neck.  Dark fruit, candi sugar in the nose.  Pours dark amber, almost opaque, thin white head.  Dark fruits and sugars continue over the palate.  Finishes nice, lingers nicely.  Good stuff.

Their Matilda blew me away so I was very happy to come across another Belgian offering from Goose Island. More of a Dubbel per style, but safe to just call it a Belgian Strong I was real impressed from the two I sampled and enjoyed this beer thoroughly. Rich, dark, fermented fruit aromas. Mildly spiced and musty. Burnt sienna in color, the pour produced a frothy beige head and spotty lacing. Sweet and malty on the palate, minor alcohol presence, and medium bodied. Faint bitter aftertaste. Plums, cherries, raisins oh my...the dark sugary fruits are bountiful in a nice robust flavor. Balanced somewhat by a noble hop presence providing a slight bitterness. Dank and musty with the trademark earthy qualities. Hints of vanilla and clove. Straightforward goodness, I am impressed time and time again of the wonders that Goose Island produces, and I am surely content with this brew.
Bottle. Beautiful dark amber color. Really sweet and fruity. Another great beer from Goose Island.

Pours a nice hazy orange-mahogany color.  Aroma is extremely sweet and fruity, with notes of molasses, cola, citrus, cherry, honey, coriander, and other spices.  Flavor is extremely sweet, and the beer is extremely drinkable.  Ive been aging this one for about a year, and the flavors have come together really well- cola, honey, citrus, plum, raisin, coriander, and pineapple.  Also has a slight dill pickle flavor, which sounds strange, but actually goes really well with the rest of the palate.  This would be a great one if the sweetness was a bit more subdued, but its a very good beer as it stands.  Semi-creamy mouthfeel, slight stickiness.

This beer is very sweet, with some nice strong concentrated citrus aromas.  It is also very tart, matching to the sweetness like a nice late harvest wine.  The flavor is pineapple, honey, raisin, and it has a nice creamy texture.  The finish lasts 30+ seconds!

12oz bottle.  Glowing dark amber color, looks filtered.  Smooth, big, and malty.  Has a sweet Cognac flavor in the aftertaste, lots of dark fruit.  Wonderfully drinkable, medium bodied at most, not overly thick.  Definitely above par for an American-Belgian Ale.

Bottle, 355 ml - Dark brown beer with a nice brown head. Aroma is very malty and sweet with strong notes of fruits and actually medicinal herbs. Flavor is very sweet again with strong notes of ripe fruits. Not really any sign of hops or any bitterness. A really good and full bodied beer, might be slightly unbalanced, but Im not complaining!

12oz bottle, 2008 vintage. Served in a Duvel tulip. Poured a hazy copper with a finger of off white head. Plenty of carbonation. Lots of sweet malt, fruit and a little spice in the aroma. Flavor is dominated by malt sweetness. Dark sugar flavor. Carbonation cuts the sweetness a little. This did not really do a whole lot for me. My least favorite of the Reserve series that I have tried so far.

By courtesy of Yngwie. Hazy dark amber in body appearance. One-finger, light brownish head. Aroma of dried fruits. Sweet taste of caramel malts and dark fruits, with emphasis on apricot, and a notch of marmalade. Dry ending with a spicy touch. Foamy in the mouth. Pretty good, but not great [bottle shared at a drinking session in Oslo 15.12.2008].
Clear burgundy brown with a lacy tan head, nice sweet aroma, with a bit of fruit on the tongue. A very pleasant plum finish.  A real fine ale.

Bottle, thanks yngwie.
Lots of sugar in the aroma.
Vinous, candy sugar, warming alcohol. The sweetness is too overpowering for me, it lacks other dimensions.

Pours a reddish brown with a vigorous but rapidly deflating off white head.  Wine like esters come off at the nose.  Ample cherry and plum and a very effervescent medium body lead into a soft finish with an almost wood like note.  A nice warming develops nearly 20-30 seconds later.  Subtle, but very long finish.

After really enjoying Matilda from Goose Island, I found this one disappointing.  It was a bit like drinking a Matilda while keeping my mouth full of raisins.  I’m sure it’s me, and not ale, but I won’t go back to Pere Jacques as long as there is Matilda in the cooler.

Huge aroma of bananas and yeast.  A little swirling gives you a big hit of booze.  Deep red color with a yellow head.  Flavor is banana and bready yeast, with some caramel.  This is a very unique beer, and an interesting take on a Belgian ale.  I really enjoyed it, even the alcohol burn, but some might disagree.  I have yet to be disappointed with a Goose Island special edition.
A murky reddish/brown pour.  No head.  Aroma is full of malt, apples, spices, and honey.  Flavor is sweet with notes of honey, stone fruits, and spices.  This reminds me of a barleywine in many ways.

This is a very nice strong ale. A mild yeasty aroma, copper colored with a thin white head.  The flavor is all malts with just a touch of yeast and hops. Clean, dry finish.  Not the traditional yeast or spice flavor of a strong ale, but I quite enjoyed it.

From bottle.  Part of November Dayton Beer Tasting event.  Pours copper with decent white head.  Spices, sugar and earth comprise the taste with a funky finish. Decent mouthfeel - better than the Matilda.
Pours copper with a nice white head.  Smells of sweet malt, bubblegum, spice, dark fruit.  Tastes fruity and sweet with a nice spicy finish.
Pleasant beer with some complexity, but nothing too outrageous. Easy to drink, alchohol is exceptionally well hidden. Worth a try and easy to go back to.

Pours a mostly clear deep mahogany with a mild head that goes away. Lots of things going on in the aroma, including malty sweetness, a lot of dried fruit, plums and raisins. There is a light whiskey aroma with some good alcoholic presence. The taste follows suit pretty much, the flavor is big and well rounded with some definite fruity notes, a little brown sugar, some prunes, and a strong alcohol presence, not so strong that it makes this hard to drink though.
12 oz bottle.  Another favorite of the night.  Lots of caramel and other sweet malty flavors and aromas.  Sweet through out with a finish that was just a touch fruity.  Good stuff.
12 oz bottle thanks to fordest. I thought this was fantastic. Lots of caramel, thick and sweet. Very good.
Unclear golden color.  You can tell this one is not from Belgium but it is good in its own right.  Sweet with a medium body.  Alchol hits you almost immediately.

UPDATED: APR 13, 2010 12 oz bottle courtesy of fordest. Poured a copper color with no head. The aroma was loaded with caramel and mellow oranges. The flavor was caramel malts forward with some sweet winey fruits filling in the sides. The mouthfeel was malty bordering on syrupy. The finish was short and sweet. Overall; Too sweet and syrupy for me, but others seem to enjoy it immensely. Rerate--Bumping this up a couple of notches I like it better now.

Clear copper, no head. Evident caramelly nose. Sweet with medium-full bodied. Fairly soft with with some apricot, caramelized sugar and glue. Intense, but a bit assaulting with a minty black currant finish.

Bottled@SBWF2008. Amber colour, mediumsized beige head. Aroma is caramel malts, mild nuts and some notes of alcohol. Flavour is much the same with some plum and raisins added. Alcohol also stays in the aftertaste, but isn’t offending at all. Pleasant.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2009 Summary: Heavily spiced fruitcake in a glass. And I like fruitcake. Aroma: Fruity, raisins with some yeasty funk.  Appearance: Orange pour, clear ruby in the glass, essentially no head.  Flavor: Heavily spiced sweet fruits: raisins with lots of candi sugar, cinnamon foremost in the spices, followed by nutmeg and allspice.  Earthy funk in the finish.  Palate: Only the lightest sparkle of carbonation, a dry finish offsets the sweetness nicely.
Clear deep amber with medium off white head. Sweet aroma wit  yeast, ripe fruits and caramel notes. Sweet flavour with ripe fruits, caramel and yeasty notes. Ends sweet.
Bottle pours a cloudy dark amber with no head. Spicy, raisins, plums, some sweet malts. Not bad, but I had hoped for better.

Aromas of spicy yeast, some darker fruits, caramel, sweet fruit cake maybe. Pours a moderately murky amber with a thin head. Flavors of sweet and tart fruits, spices, caramel, nuts. Finishes smooth with a moderate carbonation and little alcohol for 9%. I enjoyed this one.

aroma is overwhelmingly fig and raisin.  pours amber in color with a small white head, not quite the typical belgian head.  flavor was really figgy with lots of raisins, not quite as subtle and layered as a true belgian strong, however,  It does do a good job of drying out on the finish.  Not a bad beer, but decent.

2007 Bottle. This isn’t my style of beer. However, this is a decent beer being as it isn’t my style. Pours an amber color with a long lasting white head. This beer does leave some lacing on the side of the glass. Smell is of fruit. Raisin, plum and fig. It does smell like some caramel also. Taste is almost the same fruity and not that bad. The alcohol is hidden very well and is almost non apperent. Again not my style but a decent beer.

Pleasant yeasty aroma, slightly sweet and quite unique. Taste is all Belgium, sour yeasty goodness, sweet twain towards the finish. I was a little indifferent after my first Pere, the second was very impressive and left me wanting more. Well done, Goose.

12oz bottle. Pours a deep clear copper with a small buttery head that lingers a little while leaving a ring and little lacing.  The smell is all candied sugar and sweet caramel malts with hints of dark fruits.  The taste follows the aroma but is pretty mild in general.  The candied sugar and malts are there with some spices in the finish.  The mouthfeel is medium bodied with good carbonation and sticky sweet.  This dubbel was nothing exciting but pretty drinkable.

Bottled at Monk’s Café Stockholm.  Clear copper, no head. Evident caramelly nose. Sweet with medium-full bodied. Fairly soft with with some apricot, caramelized sugar and glue. Intense, but a bit assaulting with a minty black currant finish.

Bottle, 2006 version...don’t know why I waited so long to finally getting around to this one.  Probably should have had it earlier since it didn’t seem to age that well.  Pours a cloudy light brown, with a never thin head.  Fruit and malt nose, dark fruit, raisins, a little citrus.  Fairly sweet.  Overall decent.

Pours a cloudy mahogany colour with a large creamy head. Off white colour medium sized, great retention. Lots of sediment floating around. Aroma is semi-sweet, caramel, cherries and ripe apples. Taste is sweet, black cherries, licorice raspberries and possibly current. Tastey beer all around.

(Bottle, Monks Café, Stockholm) Reddish anber colour with foamy, beige head. Fruity, malty nose with dried fruit, apricots, orange peel and black-currant. Malty taste with notes of dark fruit, dried apricots, raisins, prunes, nuts, wild berries and a balanced, spicy bitterness in the finish. Medium to full body, fairly sweet. Complex beer with lots of flavours mingling together in harmony. Very nice one.

reddish with a thin white head
banana clove light apple and bubblegum prominent
more bubblegum with a watered down sour apple note
ok finish drops it down some.

Draft at Goose Island Clybourn brewpub.  A clear dark gold, little head or carbonation.  Sweet aroma.  Flavour is quite sweet, balanced with decent maltiness.  The sweetness dominates the tip of the tongue, but I keep waiting for a rich fullness in the mouth that doesnt arrive.
very buttery and caramel lends to a smooth moutfeel and taste.  slight belgain funkiness to it, but lacks overall flavor

Bottled at Monk’s Café, Stockholm. Pours out in a hazy reddish amber colour with a low white foam. Malty sweet aroma of nuts, raisins, yeast and fudge. medium to full-bodied with notes of whipped chocolate cream, raisins, fudge, nuts and almonds. Smooth carbonation with a clean mouthfeel. Long malty and hearty finish of fudge and raisin.

I agree about kopher’s statement that this is really a barely wine with Belgian yeast. My first impression was that this was too sweet for an abbey ale. Very sweet, but not exactly cloying. Surprisingly drinkable and enjoyable, with a long spicey dark fruit finish.

UPDATED: SEP 2, 2009 almost clear orange-copper with whispy off-white head.
heavy aroma -- almost like a barley wine -- with a deep candy peach sweetness. also some papaya and light pine.
similar heavy flavor, not cloying but fairly sweet with a long alcohol burn. also some tropical fruit and mild bitterness.
nice medium body and light carbonation.

On tap at Clybourn location.  Amber color.  Big white head.  Nice lacing.  Fruity/Spicy aroma.  Tastes of raisin & caramel with plenty of malt and hints of alcohol.  Very full bodied beer.  Nice warming mouthfeel.

2007 Vintage.  12 oz. bottle.  Pours a hazy coppery red with a moderate-thin off-white head that lasted until mid-glass and left partial lace.  Very pleasant aroma of malt, caramel, apples, yeast, and just a bit of spice.  The flavor is rich and malty with some nice caramel smoothness, followed up with some apples, light spice, and yeast.  No hint of the 9% alcohol, even as the beer warms.  Nicely done.

Pours a copper/dark amber with a one finger creamy yellow head. The nose was very spicy, like a winter warmer. Holy crap, this smells loaded with tons of nutmeg, allspice, clove, caramel. The flavor is very similar, sweet and spicy, nutmeg and clove especially. Wild.

Dark, smooth, sweet, with not too much carbonation.  Aroma was candy sugar and Belgian yeast, however the appearance was surprisingly not as cloudy as one would expect.  Very drinkable, however lacks some of the depth and complexity of the Trappistes.  That being said, GI has done a great job of capturing and representing the style, another great beer from the wizards at Goose Island.

Bottle shared with emacgee and aubreya.  Deep golden brown pour, smallish head.  This was a very spicy beer... definitely a winter warmer.  Malty, perhaps a bit more fruity than many winter beers.  Some vanilla and caramel.  More sweet and spicy than I typically like, but good if spicy winter beers are your thing.

The color was golden brass.  The head was very thin, fizzy, and off-white.  The aroma was sweet honey and spice.  The flavor was sweet, spicy, alcohol, and light citris.  The palate was medium-bodied.  The finish was warm and sweet.

2007 Bottle.  Poured a rich mahogany with a small, off-white head.  Aroma was dark fruits and yeast, maybe a touch of spiciness. Flavor had brandied cherries, raisin, roasted malt and caramel sweetness. Long lasting dry finish with little trace of alcohol despite the formidable ABV.  Velvety smooth  mouthfeel appropriate to the style. Could use something to balance the borderline cloying sweetness, but otherwise an excellent version of a Belgian Strong.
2005 bottle from Peculier Pub. Lots of raisin! Thick, syrupy raisin. No complexity or finesse, just a load of raisin. Meh. Best thing about it is the commercial description.

2005 bottle.  Pours a dark brown with a small head.  Aroma of sweet raisin, dark fruits.  Flavor strongly of raisin, some molasses.  This beer is very sweet, strong, heavy, and cloying.  It was too hard to drink and it doesn’t help that I don’t like a strong raisin presence in a beer.  I’m surprised this gets such high ratings because I found it nearly undrinkable.  A slightly weaker version of DFH Raison D’Extra.  Yuck.

Tasted at the Carolina Crew gathering, Greenville - thanks to Mr. Facto for this pre- bottling wax dipped hand-bottle.  Vintage 2000?  This beer really held up well given its age.  Amber pour with thin tan head. Creamy mouth-feel Sweet toasted carmel malts, and some earthy spice.  Slightly oxidized, but barely noticeable

12 oz bottle from Binny’s.
Aroma: Malty and fruity. Small amount of hops. Very aromatic and a defined Belgian smell.
Appearance: Amber tinted with a light tan head that fades quickly. Slightly red in color.
Flavor: Initially hoppy, but quickly to a malt finish. A little fruity. Definite Belgian yeast strain. Not a lot of aftertaste.
Palate: Initial carbonation, but not too much. Light and creamy, but thick as it finishes. Very smooth for a strong ale.
Overall: Easy, kind of lost interest as I went on. I like the take on the Belgian Strong, but GI has better.

Pours a clear dark orange with a thin off-white fine head.  Smells sticky and sweet, rich caramel, goose yeast for sure, and kinda spicy.  Sweet and toasty, spicy flavor, one dimensional for what it is.  Extremely rich candied finish.  Airy, bubbly mouthful that is pretty glassy and slightly syrupy.  This is no Rochefort 10 as it was molded after.
Poured anice red color with an off white head. Aroma is somewhat spicey with hints of dark fruits in it. Flavor is pretty dry but with small notes of malts and hops and alcohol.

I dont think there should be anything wrong with this bottle but perhaps there was because this thoroughly unappealing. It tastes like Keystone and PBR collaborated to mass produce a BSA. (20some minutes pass). Its gotten much better now that it has warmed. Still not great, but the water mixed with hay flavor that was occurring at the beginning of the finish has significantly diminished. Still has an unpleasant spiciness. Sweet. Makes you want to press your tongue against the roof of your mouth and back of your teeth. A bit vomity.

Poured into a trappist glass.  Pours a medium ruby with a thin soapy head.  Smell of caramel and sweet fruits.  Has a soft mouthfeel that expands into a nice sweetness of sweet fruits, sugar, and molasses that masks the alcohol.  One of my favorite goose islands.
Pours light brown with nice head. Smells of caramel, yeast, and fruit. Tastes of caramel and fruitiness. Really liked it.

Clear red-brown pour.  Thick fluffy head.  Very sweet and fruity aroma.  Maybe some maple syrup or molasses and some spice as well.  Very sweet with bitter malt, though the sweetness is a bit overpowering.  Chocolaty and and a bit syrupy.  Hides the alcohol well.  Not bad, but a bit too sweet.
Clearish brown with semi-thick head. Sweet malty flavor with strong aroma. Goose Island seems to be hit or miss, but this is a hit.

2007. Pours a clear carmel color.  Aroma of dark fruits and molasses bread and some holiday spice.  Sweet, fairly thick liquid, flavors of over ripe fruit with brown sugar, and dark malt.  Light carbonation and a hint of alcohol.  Simple sweet, medicine finish.  Happy to have tried, dont need another.

2007 bottle. Poures a reddish orange color with a big foamy white head with good retention. Dark sweet fruits, candy sugar, bready yeast and spices come through in the aroma. The flavor is similar with the dark sweet fruits and candy sugar dominating with some spices and floral hops in the background. A little bit of alcohol sweetness show up as well. Medium almost full body that is very sweet and smooth that leads to a sweet, clean finish with a touch of alcohol burn. This one is nice with a good sweet flavor.

I actually enjoyed this one...no where near the real thing but its tasty.  Mississippi muddled brown/orange with a head that recedes into nothing.  Aroma is brown sugar, toffee, caramel, dark fruit, and cherry skin.  Can definitely feel the alcohol but tasting it takes better observation skills.  Good, but not outstanding like the other GI Ive tried.
Pours dark orange.Almost no head.Smells fruity, and bitter. Taste is much the same as the aroma except very well spiced aswell.

UPDATED: APR 11, 2009 Bottled, 2006. Poured dark brown, with a tan head. Needed to pur quickly, as both bottles I tried foamed up at cellar temperature. Nose was hoarhound, toffee, and dark fruit (black cherry). Flavor was black cherry, sweet malt, and toffee. Finish was slightly hoppy with a pleasant alcohol warmth. Mouthfeel was nicely carbonated, with a bit of an oily feel to the finish but without any buttery notes.
Rich golden with sweet muscatty aroma with a rich acidic brown sugar blend.  Taste is sweet, but phenolic and spicy with a slightly tart grape skin finish.  Semi-vinous in this regard. $4/12oz

dark amber body with just a hint of quickly fleeting head.  There is an appley, yeasty aroma with a hint of bubblegum.  The flavor is nice.  It has a bit of spice to it with the yeasty flavor carrying over.  There is also just a hint of a metallic flavor.

Pours a cloudy orange with little to no head.  Filled with particles (beer pulp). Ha ha.  Smells fruity.  First its sweet and pleasantly simple, then in the next second harsh and spicy.  Really spicy, but in a good way.  Im just getting into Belgian SAs so I plan on revisiting this one later.

UPDATED: AUG 15, 2008 Appearance is a dark brownish-red color, but not too dark. Aroma is lots of hops, mixed with some fruit. Flavor is fruity. The palate is harsh though, reminds me of an IPA bite, despite it being a BSA. Decent beer, nothing special though.
Draft.  Amber in color.  Sweet fruity aroma.  Very tasty Belgian style ale.

UPDATED: MAY 22, 2008 Bottle,  Taste of roasted molasses.  With a tinge of perfume.  Virtually no head.  Brown/amber color.  Sour flavor.  Syrupy texture / medium body with very little carbonation.  Matilda is much better from Goose island.

Bottle first sampled at the peculiar pub.  Pours dark brown liquid and a thin head.  Belgian yeast, caramel,  slighly sour but still good presence of sweet malt everywhere.  Etoh comes through in the nose and the flavor a solid GI offering.

2006 bottle.  Pours a beautiful caramel with a 1 finger tan head.  On the nose sweet cider and other fruit.  Taste is sweet but with a rough finish where the alcohol really comes through.  Ill break another one open in a few months and see where that one takes me.

Bonus bottle from kryptic today.  Bottled on 040307.  Lots of melanodin aroma when popped.  Fades to a nice caramel aroma.  Darkish amber color.  Small wispy and foamy head.  Nice flavor, a little sweet, but also a little sour, which I suspect is from the 1 year of age and detracts from the flavor.

12oz from a store in Lawrence, KS, whose name I cant remember. 2006 bottle, and its aged just wonderfully. A nice dark brown pour, crisp and lively carbonation and a whole universe of floaties in there. The aroma is really fresh and fruity, with some malts evident too, giving it a sweetness that befits a Belgian strong. Very drinkable too, not overly sticky. Fine stuff, particularly with some miles on it.

On tap at hopleaf
Pours amber with a lot of lacing left.  Smell is sticky malt and light belgium character.  Taste is boring, and bland overall with light belgian yeast and malt.  I dont understand the good ratings, as it is so incredibly mildly flavored...  Mild like the matilda, and just unexciting, but not offensive.
Shared a bottle ar DLD 08. Pours amber with a tan head. Sweet tating and refreshing. Pleasently surprised as usually dont care for belgain strong ales
Shared at DLD 2008.  A nice sweet tasting light beer that, ...what....its 9%?  Yeah right.  Never would have guessed it.  Thanks to whoever brought it yesterday.

2004 vintage

A- Pours a dark peach with an ample head which fades to lacing.

S- Smell is sweet, cider, dark fruits, boozy.

T- Taste is very smooth, raisins, more dark fruit as in the nose, no boozy flavor to speak of that was so prominent in the nose. Sweet caramely.

M- Semi viscous with quite a bit of carbonation.

D- For 9 percent alcohol this is damn drinkable. Very smooth. I was going to hold onto this one longer but I acidentally droped the bottle and cracked the neck, didnt seem to damage the flavor and there was still ample carbonation.

12oz bottle courtesy of pepsican. Aroma of fruits somewhat cheey bready yeast are good on the nose. Dark golden body with creamy off white head that settles to a foam on top of body and leaves some good lacing. Sweet fruity candy flavor with a medium to full bodied thickness for texture. Sticky fruit rollup candy aftertaste and alcohol not much a factor. Good brew thanks Andy.

12oz bottle. Poured a deep brown with a nice thin head.Definitely a sweet fruity nose. Nice complex belgian  flavors . I liked the overall flavor, as it has a certain depth to it that many american belgians lack. The finish had a nice sweetness, although started to get a bit syrupy, so might not be a great session beer.

Poured a dark amber with a light brown head.  Malty, sweet aroma with the sweetness coming out in the forefront of the taste followed by the fruits and belgian yeast.  Mouthfeel is solid with good body.  I enjoyed 2 but the the other 2 are to be cellared.  Ill check back in a couple of years.

2007 vintage.  Pours a very hazy orange-caramel color.  A large, foamy, tan head settles slowly to a thin layer, leaving clumpy patches and lines of lacing behind.  The nose is sweet and bready up front, with a good amount of candy sugar, whipped cream, yeast, flowers, and various spices following.  Flavors basically follow suit, again showing quite sweet, yeasty and spicy.  Soft floral notes blend with cinnamon, tons of pale malts, and mild floral hops.  Medium-full, smooth, sugary body.  Hides the 9% very well.  Finishes clean and sweet.  Overall, a nice, Imperial Golden/Blonde Ale of sorts.  Very similar to GIs Matilda.  Nice brew.
Bottle.  amber color and a genuine Belgium style...i can see why people like this beer, however, Belgian just isnt my favorite.  good but not for me
A deep cloudy amber with small light tan head.  Sweet candy sugar, fruity esters, biscuit, spice, clove, and a hint of caramel.  A very decent belgian style ale, that I would recommend trying.

Pour a dark amber with chunks of yeast floating around.  Aroma is strong:  Fruity, sweet malty with alcohol and caramel.  Mouthfeel is oily and carbonated.  Not bad but just a little strong maybe this would be better if it mellowed for a couple of years.  Taste of dark fruits and yeast with alcohol flavor and warming in the finish.

From a 12oz Bottle.  Courtesy of valpoaj.  Transparent, ruddy amber colored pour with a thin head of cream. 

 The aroma is a pleasant bouquet of yeast and sweet malts, bringing out notes of brown sugar, nutty maple, flakey 

toasted coconut, and mild peppery phenols.  Light bodied, crisply carbonated mouthfee with a dry finish and 

cleansing carbonic bite.  Flavors of toasted caramels, doughy yeast, and almond biscotti.  Some fruity prune 

esters and dry leather come out toward the finish, along with gentle warming alcohols.  Very respectable beer.  

Thanks, AJ!

pours a nice brown with a little ruby when held up to light. strong aroma of candi sugar. it also tastes exactly like dark candi sugar rocks. not enough spicy yeast profile. a little too sweet for my tastes. matilda was awesome, but if i want a strong dark ill go for some chimay blue.
Thick cloudy amber/ brown color with a tan head-minimal.  Yeast, malt, molasses aroma.  Taste of molasses, yeast, malts, and fruit.  Super beer!  Best from Goose Island!

12oz bottle, courtesy of Boboski. Bottled 01/23/06, cellared for over 2 years

Dark bruised plum color with a 2 finger thick light tan head. Incredible retention and sheets of lacing. Very densely packed as well. Nose of grape juice, red wine, white pepper, phenol heat, Belgian funky yeast, biscuit dough, raisins, rum soaked bread and other dark fruity esters. Wow, this smells good. Fore is dark fruits, yeast, dough, caramel, toffee, rum cake and some astringency. These flavors continue throughout the finish of the beer, with the fruit sweetness and dough elements picking up in intensity. Smooth and medium bodied, very easy to sip on and savor. Finish is lengthy, astringent, fruity and with an end kick of yeast and toffee. ABV is only apparent as a warming sensation throughout the beer. Caramelized sugars bring up the very end of the flavor profile. Great beer.

Oh WOW!! I smelled it as soon as I popped off the cap. This is by FAR the best Goose Island Ive tried. Intense, radiant, uplifting flavor. Drinks like runny syrup and my God is it ever smooth! This is coming from a guy that loves hoppy, bitter beers. This is not hoppy at all, even though there is minimal amount of bittering hops that was used for this. Fantastic job all around, need to keep this year around!! Thanks Goose Island!

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2009 pours brownish orange with lots of floaters,smells of citrus and spices taste of oranges,lemons, corrander and raisen bread very sweet gets sweter and dryer towards end. overall i like this very nice interpation of an abbey by a great american brewer

Thanks to Acknud for the 2006 bottle. Pours cloudy brown with a thick off white head. Caramel malt, molasses, slightly fruity, yeast aroma. Thick body with lots of candi sugar and malt taste. Sneaky strong. Very interesting version of a  belgian.

Thanks to acknud for the bottle. Cloudy orange with a small head. Aroma of caramel, brown sugar, plums and oranges. Fruity sweet taste with some tanginess at the end. Alcohol was well hidden. Heavier mouthfeel, but no banana yeast. Very strong brew IMO.

12 oz bottle, 2006 vintage courtesey WeeHeavySD. Thanks Jon! Opened 2/8/2008 and poured into my duvel tulip,  hazy medium brown with and off white head wihich quickly disapated into so scum.  Yeasty aroma. flavor was spicy with a nice amount of bready malt rasin and carmel with clove.  balenced and drinakble. some alcohol warming but no burn. a deccent belgian form the midwest.

Poured from a 12oz bottle (2007 vintage) and served in a tulip.  This beer poured a hazy amber/brown with a one-finger thick head of beige foam that quickly settled into a thin, lasting layer.  Some nice lace was left behind.  The aroma of the beer was made up of spicy and bready yeast esthers, caramel, fruit, candi sugar, and clove.  The flavor included rasins, apple, candi sugar, caramel, spicy yeast, and a mild alcoholic burn.  The mouthfeel was full-bodied and moderately carbonated.  Not overly complex, but a solid represention of the style.  A well made Belgian from Goose.

12oz bottle, 2007 from mdm46410. Another surprise. Better than expected. Sweet and spicy aroma. Caramel, toffee, white chocolate, dry tree bark, spicy yeast and a tiny hint of alcohol. Pours unclear copper/ruby with a thin and fizzy white head. Slight sweetness balanced nicely by some spicy and dry yeast on the tongue. Caramel, candy sugar, honey and dusty yeast. Medium to full bodied with  a good amount of carbonation. Fairly well balanced  but nothing stands out particularly well.

Pours a murky brown that shows heavy ruby tints when held to light. Crème head that is minimal at first and doesnt stay around. Nose is strong raisins, sugar, and yeast. Flavor is even and smooth. Nothing wild. Minor sweet tone. Little bit of wood. Typical dubbel kind of stuff really. Feel has a good carbonation to it and the liquid is good as well. Overall this is a very smooth and well made Belgian ale. Nothing extremely unusual about it, as American produced Belgian styled beers tend to be.
Pours brown with a slight haze.  Bottled on 12/30/06, opened and drank on 2/2/08.  Smells of toffee, caramel, and slight licorice.  Taste is strong alcohol, but with a caramel back.
Hazy brown color and scents of caramel and spices.   Taste is very strong with alcohol, but balanced by a caramel malt.

Bottle courtesy of moejuck. The pour reveals a murky brown color with a thin offwhite head. Good aroma of nutmeg, licorice and sweetness. Good flavor of licorice, nutmeg and lingering sweetness. The body is medium with a liquorous texture and soft carbonation.
Bottle. pours a mid orange color. lots of fruits and even some vegatables.  Was very drink when I tried this.  Will have to try it again

Pours a heavily particulated amber colour with a creamy off-white head that leaves good lacing and fades to a micro-bubble film. The nose is estery, with notes of pear concentrate dominating over mild vegatable tones, apple, boooze, and burnt caramel. The flavour has an equal pear presence, candied sugar, caramel and bubblegum yeast moving into apricot.The finish is dry and the body is medium bodied with a airy, yet somehow oily mouthfeel.

Pours a deep hazy copper color with just a little bit of head that dissipates to a bit of lacing. It is definitely sweet but more balanced with hops than other more sweet beers I have had. The aroma isnt too strong in this beer but there are hints of apple/fruit. Taste is definite notes of apple cider with caramel undertones and bit of yeast. Very light carbonation and a medium body.  I really like this beer. delicious. I want to go to the brewery and try all their taps!

smells a bit like applecider. light applecider taste in this medium bodied and slick belgian number. oversweet but balanced with a nice hop finish that is N-I-C-E. good yeast quality and genuine abbey type spice to this brew. light and tight carbonation and good malt follow through. this brew could show the Belgians a thing or two! alcohol just right.

(Bottle 35,5 cl) Courtesy of fiulijn/boboski. Vintage 2007. Hazy, warm, amber golden with an off-white head. Sweetish fruity, but also somewhat medicinal aroma. Quite full-bodied with very sweet fruit notes, some caramel and an underlying yeasty note. Basically no bitterness. Unbalanced and cloyingly sweet. 271207

Sampled Batch 0 via single 12-oz bottle during Cheesehead YeHA in Brookfield, Wisconsin and shared by MrFacto. Pours an opaque dark brown brew with a fast dissolving light tan head that leaves behind a fine film and tan ring. Aroma of sweetened caramel malt, some yeast, earthy spices and a touch of fruit character. Taste is medium bodied, very light carbonation with flavors of Belgian yeast, roasted caramel malt and some white pepper. Finish is semi-sweet with a yeast and caramel aftertaste.

12 oz bottle from 2005. Pours a hazy brown with a light ivory head. Spicy nose with hints of dark candi sugar. Plum, banana, coriander and fig are the major taste contributors. The palate is good with a tendency to linger pleasantly. This is a good beer but not the best from Goose Island.

12 oz. single bottle from Johns Grocery (Iowa City, IA). 2006 Edition. Poured into a tulip glass. Poured an almost opaque brown with a decent tan head that begins to dissipate a little. I can smell this bad boy the second I pour it. Caramel malt and some fruit elements. First taste is very sweet malts and hops that arent to be outdone. A belgian yeastiness / spice is evident as well. Wonderful biscuit/cookie-esque/bready flavorings with vague, although noticeable fruitiness (Did I taste apple? I think I did.). A nice thick full mouthfeel that could even be chewy. Tart and malty on the finish. A beer I enjoyed that I did not expect to.

12 oz bottle.  Poured cold with a cloudy brown color.  No head. Nose is alcoholy and sweet. Taste is sweet, too much for my palate. Alcohol was very evident.  Nothing subtle in this beer. I"ve had much better dubbles.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: 12 oz. bottle from a friend.  Nice amber pour with a slight white head.  Was in a smoky room, but I picked up an estery, malty aroma with some yeasty, bready character as well.  Flavor was similar with plenty of fruity notes up front, some spice coming through towards the end, as well as some sugary sweet malty characteristics.  Alcohol was well hidden and this was dangerously easy to drink.

From bottle courtesy of valpoaj : Pours a dark hazy copper color with a beautiful white two finger foamy head that has great staying power.  A nice fruity, malty nose, that is sweet and complex.  Flavor is very good, Strong fruits on the begininning, and it finishes with a strong caramel malt backbone.  Goes down smooth, with a medium body.  No trace of alcohol in the flavor for me, wonderfully hidin in the flavor.

Bottle (2007).  Pours a nice coppery, amber color with a med-sized white head.  Aroma of fruity sweetness, wheat, yeast and some caramel.  Flavor is also on the sweet side, with definitely some fruity qualities, some tartness, some honey and some of the caramel malt flavors.  Rather tasty.  Surprised at the 9% abv - very well hidden.
Dark amber pour with light ivory head. Floral notes with hints of honey. A little too sweet for my taste.

tap at clybourn....pours an amber brown with fluffy ivory head....aromas of doughy yeast, sweet candy sugar, and caramel malt.  lots going on here....flavors follow suit.  candied sugar, caramel malt, honey that makes a bit too cloyingly sweet for my liking.

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2008 Vintage 2006 as reviewed on 11/20/07

Pours reddish brown with a beige head of a half-inch. Small particulates in suspension. The foam receded to a partial skim coat on the surface, leaving a few scarce traces of lacework.
Aromatics are fruity and vineous, with a hint of cocoa.
A large strawberry-cherry note leads off, followed by shades of red wine and faint bakers chocolate.
Plenty of phenols follow through, with lingering clove and bubblegum.
The mouthfeel is creamy and luscious. Carbonation is on the light side for style, but lends some nice drinkability.
The dubble profile is a bit off on the pallet. Drinks more like an strong dark. Light chocolate with lots of fruit and jammy. 
Strawberry marmalade barely dusted with cocoa powder.
Alcohol steps foward with some nice warmth and each sip finishes fairly quick. 
Finishes with a nod of red wine, cherry blossom honey, and a hint of hazelnut.

Not spot on in the realm of Dubble, but damn tasty and fairly complex. Looks like the aging has helped Pere along.

Vintage 2006 revisited on 6/30/08

Quite murky in appearance, with a half-inch head of dense tan. 

Dark rum, raisins, toffee, caramel, and tobacco in the nose. Cocoa-spiked bubblegum and dark fruits.

Creamy mouthfeel and slightly chewy.

Caramel, raisins, and chewy malt lead off the pallet. Mild alcohol notes pull through. Shades of nougat, vanilla, toffee, and bannana follow along. 

Finishes with some light residuals. Chewy malt and brown sugar. Dryer than I remember though.

After having a fresh one on draught at GI Clybourn, I would say that this beer improves with age up to about 1.5-2 years. This one is a bit faded compared to the one reviewed just six months ago, and the one on tap was pretty mediocre.

UPDATED: NOV 21, 2007 Pours amber with a large white head that goes quickly.  The aroma was very malty with a hint of green apples.  Tasted sweet but had a dash of tart fruit to help keep it from being overpowering.  I get a wonderful cantaloupe as well,  interesting!  Nicely carbonated and finished without much notice of the higher ABV%.  Im glad I have 3 left.

Tap at Barcade: Pours a hazy deep amber with an off-white film for head. Sweet aroma, mainly dates, honey and sweet Belgian malts. Creamy body with a sweet flavor of candied fruits (dates mainly), candy sugar, sweet apple cider and some Belgian yeast undertones. Too sweet overall, but still somewhat tasty.

On tap at Coles 
Appearance :Amber with hint of brown , fizzy creamy top.Nose :Wheat like front , some citric fruity midlle-nose , somewhat greenish at end.
Flavour/Palate : Some tartness , some sharp crispness with cured chewy zesty hop merged by alcohol. Overly harsh with raw drying alcohol . Fuller front and balance a bit more as Unibroue does.

12oz btl. An amber pour with almost no head. A nose of dried fruit. A very pronounced flavor of dried fruit and a very pleasant abv warmth. Smooth full palate but he carbonation takes off a bit much. A damn good beer for me that carbonation really kept from being a most excellent beer.

Bottle sampled. Pours a dark copper color with a small beigh head. Aroma of caramel, toffee, sweet malts, and some light spices. Flavor is well balanced and smooth with dark fruits,molasses, yeast,raisins,alcohol and some mild hops. AWESOME

Pours a copper color with an off-white head.  Aroma is of candied sugar, lemon, sweet malts, yeast, and a little alcohol.  Flavor is the same with a slight alcohol warming. One of Goose Islands better Belgian style ales.

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2007 Bottled 9.22.06.  Over 1 year old.  Who knows how this was stored.  In any case, Im not a fan.  I drank it all, it wasnt horrible.  But, it was quite sweet, and rather boring.  Really, I found this to be bland overall.  Hazy amber, almost no head developed, aroma was hardly there, but I did get some candy like sweetness.  The flavor is also, rather sweet, and malty, and there is a hint of yeast down there somewhere.  The finish disappears almost instantly, but remains somewhat cloying.  The alcohol is rather subdued, which is the only thing that saves this from being a real drain pour.  It this was very hot from ABV Id dump it.  Again, bland and boring, and sweet....  and sweet.

Hey, this is a really great beer! Pours a very hazy brown with some bronze tones. Great nose featuring some estery, fruity, malty aromas. A touch thin in body, but certainly good. Flavor is very good and typical of the classic belgians. This one is served a bit warmer than proly most places would do it, but still, could be warmer. Lovely finish. Only hints of the alcohol. Having this one at Bodega Brew Pub downtown La Crosse, Wi.

Thanks to a Santa from last July....or December. Pours out a mahogany color with a thin lacing head. Sweet fruits, yeast, and slight earth notes. Flavor is up front sweet with dark fruit, candi sugar and some yeasty/alcohol notes.

06 12ozer via road trip purchase from my friend Liz, thank you Liz.  Sampled after enjoying Matilda.  Pours dark amber orange with a 2 finger creamy tan head.  Nose is okay, got some off putting notes taht I cant describe.  Taste however is sweet, silky and overall pretty good wtih a residue of the inexplicable thing in some belgian styled and belgian ales that turns me off, but overall nice cant say its bad because it tastes pretty nice overall.

On tap at Clybourn.  I am not a huge fan of sweet Belgian styles, but the darker the better and this one works for me as a dessert beer.  Not the best looking, but I love the GI glass it comes in.  Plus it smells good.  Only bad thing is that is is $7 for 10 or so oz, and i have seen it for $9 as well!
On tap @ Coles Buffalo NY. Pretty good offering. Lots of dried fruit, sweet deep reddish brown color. Molasses, slightly boozy. enjoyable
I had this at the brewery.  There was a candy sweet aroma and was deep red in pour.  Dark fruity in flavor.

12 oz bottle purchased at Johns Grocery. 2006 vintage, bottled 9/22/06. Poured an attractive ruby red-orange color. Head was one finger high and off white. It reduced over a few minutes to a thin film. Aroma was of salty biscuits, pear, raisin, molasses, alcohol, and brown sugar. Lots of smells. Sweet and fruity on the tongue. Full bodied with plenty of alcohol, plum, and malty molasses. There was also a hint of clove. Decent beer.

12 oz bottle.  Deep copper in color with a no head. Malty caramel candy sweet aroma. Malty fruity flavor. Dark fruity notes. Plum, raisins, and alcohol notes. Well balanced. Full bodied. Finish  is sweet.  Too sweet. Drinkable.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2012 Pours a translucent, muddy deep copper with no head whatsoever.  Aroma is quite mild, candy, malt and a touch of yeast.  Flavor is similar, sugar, candy, malt, toffee, grain, also touches of fruit like white grapes.  Finish is soft and a little watery with a touch of heat on the tongue.  Had better Abbey beers, and this certainly didnt hold up next to the other Goose Island beers I had.  ***** re-rate from a 750ml 2009 vintage pours a hazy, light caramel brown with some thin creamy white head.  Nose is plums, candy sugar, apples, cloves, banana, cotton candy.  Flavor is sweet, candy sugar, a little boozy, rum, coconut, plums, raisins.  Lightly chalky, dry finish.
nice red mahogany color, some biege head not much lacing. Nose is very fruity, pear, clove, some dark malts and alcohol, flavor is very similar but so well balanced some raisins coffee great beer!!!

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2009 September 2007 - Pours dark orange with a fully receding light tan head. This beer has protein precipitation, due to either age or poor storage. Aroma of phenol, plums, spice, toffee. Taste is sweet and phenolic, notes of sticky fruit and spicy apple, toffee, and plums. Mouthfeel is full bodied and somewhat dry with soft, supple carbonation. Drinkable and interesting, but this pales in comparison to the esteemed Rochefort. Much too sweet for an accurate Belgian, needs to be alot drier.
Ar 6 Ap 2 Fl 6 Pa 3 Ov 13

2009 Bottle - Pours amber/ruby with a mostly receding tan head. Notes of pepper, phenol, clove, toffee, caramel, oak and spice. Medium to full bodied with lush carbonation.
Ar 6 Ap 4 Ta 7 Mf 4 Ov 14
On tap at Goose Island Clybourne. This brown ale pouerd with a modest beige head, eliciting a pleasant malty fruit aroma. The flavor is fruity and spicy with a carbonated, slightly bitter finish.
Cloudy amber, caramel color.  Very little head.  Aroma was fruity and sharp.  Flavors of caramel, maple syrup with a slight alcohol tinge in the end.  tasty.

Date: 06/03/2006
Mode: Bottle
Source: Roadtrip

clear dark amber, nice fine beige head, touch of lace, sweet spicy aroma with fruity essence, hint of alcohol, thick sweet body, lots of sweet malt flavor, great sweet fruity character, lots of apricot, touch of spices, a sweet fruit beer without being a fruit beer, tons of character, 
-------- />
Date: 04/28/2007
Mode: growler
Source: tasting
Words: pj

lots of earthy spicey aroma and flavor, touch of caramel sweetness, is this the right beer

Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 8/10; Palate: 8/10; Overall: 16/20
Rating: 3.9/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: **4
350 ml bottle mail order from archer liquors.  Slightly orange copper brown with a fizzy white head.  Floral dark fruit aroma.  Sweet raisin and brown sugar taste.

bottle.  deep cranberry/brown pour with small frothy off white head.  nice malty aroma with dark fruits, yeast and mild spice.  caramel malts are the backbone.  cinammon, sugar, alcohol warmth.  light/medium body.  easy drinking.  a bit sweet.

Bottle Mondial.

 Wow!  A big malty, caramel, butterscotch aroma. Copper, pours a small tan head. Huge caramel flavour, lots of malt, and theres that butterscotch again. Medium bodied,very well balanced. Great offering!
ohh so good! Dark amber color, very balanced flavors. Goes down like gold! So shocked at how good this was, stumbled over it at a bar and fell in love. My top local beer!
Just too sweet for me.  Aroma of alcohol and cinnamon.  Toffee, corn syrup, and alcohol on the palette, finished wet.
Very nice.  Dark amber with a small off white head.  A little sweet but overall nice balance between  sweet and spicy.

poured into tulip.  pours a dark clear amber with moderate off white head.  light malty citrus aroma.  smooth and light not very aggressive.  sweet candy, light hops and malts.  not too complex in the initial.  almost a sessionable quality.  light belgian yeasty presence suddenly presents itself after the first few drinks, a maltiness.  gets great because of its subtleness that hides the alchohol.  it is complex in such a subtle way, very light and smooth yet no hint of the ABV, only improvement could come from bottle conditioning,  was a relatively flat palate for the style, and not much head...

2005 bottle.  Pours a mildly yeasty dark copper color, with a small, quickly evaporating off white head.  Big caramel aroma, some dark fruits, and big sweet malts as well.  The taste was much the same, just huge caramel flavor with a good dose of some alcohol.  The fruits come really secondary here, as the malty caramel masks much of everything else.  You could tell its got a little age to it.  I liked it though, seems to have aged quite gracefully.  Sweet in the finish and lingering in the aftertaste.  Quite enjoyable and full flavored.

Finally entering all my "Better Know a Style: Belgian Strong Ale" tasting 07 results.  Aroma is moderate malt and spicy with a little sweat.  Flavor all the way through is moderate sweet with an average finish.  Body is medium and dry.  A pretty good brew.

Surprisingly spicy.  The spiciness however, seems to be trying to make up for the lack of carbonation.  Without the characteristic high carbonation, this Belgian style ends up a wee bit flabby tasting.  Its still a pretty good beer, but with a few more bubbles, it could be great.

2007 Bottle, it travled 1000 miles to make it to my fridge and it was worth the entire trip.  Not sure of the color, its either a dark amber or a deep copper, Ill keep drinking to make sure.  The aroma hits you with malts and fruits.  The taste is sweet with malts and a light touch of caramel and spice.  No detection of hops at any time, with a sweet fruity finish.

Distinctiveness is one of the most important criteria for me, and theres nothing else quite like Pere Jacques (at least, nothing fresh, i.e., brewed in the U.S.)  It pours a deep amber with more than a little gold tinge.  Not much head (not a problem for a sipping beer, in my opinion).  The aroma is molasses-y malt, with the alcohol coming through nicely.  It has a big sweet fruity malt taste, complex and bordering on decadent.  Its reminiscent of a cross between a Belgian Golden Ale and an old ale or some other malty style.  It has an almost perfect degree of alcohol warming.  It finishes just a little sticky, with little evidence of hops.  Incredibly satisfying without being filling.

(Bottle) Pours a rich reddish amber color with almost  no head. Low carbonation. Sweet aroma, with caramel and alcoholic notes. Apple (cider) and other dried fruit notes in here as well. A decent beer overall, but a little too sweet for my liking.
Nice beer with a smooth taste remenesent of a belgian abbey beer without the traditional esters (since not real belgian wild yeast used).

bottle 07 vintage. mt 100th rating! wanted to do something real special (not that wasnt good) but thought this would be great with the pork chops i was planning on having (and it was) plus ive never tried the high end GI stuff. no real head forms on the pour. its color is brilliant ruby red brown, and it has no haze to it at all. bit of a boozy nose with some yeasty aromas and light hop character. smooth and evenly balanced with lots of malt sweetness. apricots and cloves come through in this lively zesty spicy  and estery ale. good example of belgian style.

Sample @ Belgian Beer Fest, 10/2006.  Pours brown with a small, lacy head.  Aroma is heavily malty with some fruit and candy sugar characteristics as well.  Flavor is pretty sweet, with caramel, candy sugar, and malt up front vying with spices and fruits in the back.   Not my favorite offering from Goose Island, but a solid beer.

2006 Bottle.  Big aroma of dark malt and overripe fruit.  Dusty, sedimented amber gradient under a lacing light brown, ephemeral head.  Taste is sweet and lightly bitter, loads of malt with clove/coriander hints, caramel with that big red fruitiness, fainter brown sugar and spicy yeast, and a touch of alcohol.  Could use a dose of hops in the end.  Creamy smooth mf, medium body, finished dry and fruity with spicy yeast and molasses.  Pleasing!

12oz bottle.  Pours nearly brown with minimal head.  Has a very sweet, fruity taste which almost becomes too much toward the end.  Good mouthfeel, very smooth malty flavor.  Overall, a very fine brew.
2006 vintage.  Hazy dark amber pour, almost brown.  Sweet aroma with spices and dried fruit and yeast.  Sweet malt flavor doesnt hide the alcohols bite.

Cloudy amber with thin tan head.  Aroma of dark fruits, yeast and alcohol.  Taste of sweet dark fruits, some spice, and alcohol.

One of the better American attempts at a Belgian.  Definiitely not as good as a Rochefort, the brewery  at the monastery of which Pere Jacques is the Abbot.

2007 bottle.  Hazed ruddy amber with no head at all from the get go.  Very faint but not unpleasant aroma.  Very faint malty sweetness.  A hint of cinnamon, strawberry?  A bit of DMS knocks this down a point.  Very nearly flat, somehow a bit of fizz, a bit thin too.  Still okay.  A bit sweet with a forward fruity not so funkiness.  Acidic, some dark malt character.  Alcohol comes up.  Not hops to speak of.  Some diacetyl and DMS.  Dry finish.

Bottle sampled with Mad_indian, from a trade with Ohiodad. Pours murky orange/bronze with a small off-white head. Aroma of fruit, spices, caramel, and sweetness. The flavor is exceptionally smooth, caramel, sweet, spices, fruit. Excellent!!!

Bottle sampled with Stegosaurus, courtesy of an ohio dad trade. Hazy orange pour with fluffy head. Bread, fruit and spice aromas. Banana , yeast and alcohol taste. This was really blended well. I was quite shocked how smooth this one was. Nice job !!
draft: a nicely done belgian. yeasty for sure, with bannanas, other fruits present. Well done.

Bottle:  Poured a clear amber with a smaller beige head and no lacing.  Nose is yeast and fruity.  Wine notes and lots of plum.  Taste is fruity and winelike with a smooth malty presence.  Sweet caramel tones soften the fruity and yesty notes.  Not bad at all.  Thanks Eithcubes.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2010 2010-08-06, bottle, vintage 2009, 1 year old, 6-4-7-3-14=34Beautiful red-amber color; good-sized frothy head. Aroma of caramel, quite mature, and a bit metallic too. Medium body strength; it has a strong caramel flavor, sugary, a tad metallic, with tones of liquorice; the alcohol is too evident. Confused.2007-09-29, draught at the brewpub, Clybourn location, 7-4-8-4-16=39Hazy dark amber color. The aroma is quite fruity, malty, sweet. Very good body, good malt flavor, with a nice fruitness from the yeast. A classic strong Belgian Ale, more powerful than the Matilda, but less characteristic; warming in the end. Very good.2007-06-23, bottled on 2006-01-23, 1 and half years old, 8-4-8-4-17=41Hazy chestnut color; thin creamy head. Strong malty aroma; the yeast leaves fruity notes; a touch of sweet wood, maybe of Bourbon vanilla, leather, very light phenol. Full mouthfeel, full malty flavor, very sweet (but not cloying). Warming final; not bitter enough, but nice and strong malt, vanilla, sweet wood.Sweeter than a traditional Belgian Ale, not enough hop to be a Barley Wine.The complexity of the aroma, and the epicurean luscious malt, for a great beer.
2007 from the bottle.  Pours absolute copperwith a brief head.  Spice and citrus fruit on the nose with the sweet malt flavors on the mouthfeel.  The finish is dense with a nice crispness to it.

UPDATED: MAR 12, 2008 Delicious beer, Not as strong as i expected. Dark copper, light minimal head, nice lacing. A bit syrupy, malty, plum, dry fruits. I would buy this again, well carbinated. Great belgian considering its a goose. Well balanced.

2007.  Form bottle acquired at Liquor store in suburban Minneapolis.  Pours a reddish amber/copper color.  Small head that dissipates quickly.  Some clove, phenolic, caramel, alcohol and cardboard in the nose.  The cardboard worried me - not that the brew was bad necessarily, but that it had sat on the shelves too long.  None of that in the taste, however.  Nice phenolic flavors from the yeast strain, and a tasty sweet malt flavor.  Very good brew all around, although I would like this one a little drier and with a bit more carbonation.

Opaque copper-brown body with very little head.  Loads of brown sugar and a overall brown cake taste.  Rather yeasty with distant fruity notes.  Pleasant silky/chewy body.  The hops are about as present as a stoner dude in geometry classes.  No problems, just very much forgettable.  Very basic Belgian inspired beer.
06 bottle: Pours a murky brown color with little to no head.  Very tart aroma with some malt hints and some candy.  Very woodsy, malty and some caramel to boot.  Decent mouth feel.  Good brew

I had this on tap at Romans.

Many beers have a great aroma but disappoint when you taste them (smell better than they taste).  This beer was the first one I can remember that was the reverse of that - it smelled not so good but tasted terrific!

The aroma was a bit sour, woody/cardboard-ish, and a bit like good-beer-gone-bad.  However, undaunted, I took a sip and was quite surprised.  The beer is quite spicy up front, with a warm mouthfeel with lots of stickiness and alcohol esters up front.  This beer was served in a long-stemmed glass (looked like a wine or martini glass), and it definitely drank more like a really nice spirit than a beer.  Mouthfeel was quite smooth, like a beer that has been secondary fermented (dont know if it has or not).  To me, Goose Island beers are a bit hit&miss, but I definitely enjoyed this one.
Nose is bubble gum and cardomon, you can smell the alcohol. Nice caramel flavour, with earthy figs.  Attack is quite sweet and lasting.
Bottle. Poured a very hazy red color. Aroma is sweet and wheaty. Taste is so good vice well balanced.
Robe brune claire surmontée dune mousse qui sestompe. Arômes de caramel, dépices et de levures. Saveurs de caramel, dépices, de pain et de céréales.

Dan Journal #3.  Tasted 4/11/2006.  12oz bottle.  Hazy with a caramel brown hue.  Doughy and bready aromas.  Slight raisins in the nose.  Initially a sweet bready malty flavor.  Cola-ish middle.  Cloying finish.

Clear filtered body with small off-white head. The aroma is caramel, toffee, dark pitted fruits and light spice. The flavor is moderately sweet, bananas, spice, light pepper, lots of toffee and figs. Medium body is soft and thin with light carbonation.

A muddy amber appearance with no head.  The aroma is a very subtle sweetness with a hint of raisins.  There is a little carbonation on the tongue with a sweet aftertaste.  This beer is slightly different than anything else but still an enjoyable brew.

2006 bottle - Pours murky amber with a thin head.  The aroma has yeast, sweet malt with a hint of molasses, and dark fruit.  The sweet flavor includes that dark fruit and some nice spice notes.  Its medium to full bodied with a dry finish.  Very good brew.

[4 year old bottle (Early 2003 bottle, sampled April 2007), pre-production bottle saved from the Michael Jackson Beer tasting at Sheffields in Chicago]: tightly bubbled foam quickly rises out of the top of the barely labeled bottlepours clear bronze-red and at a distance, dark brown.  Carbonation is thick, full and taupe coloured.  Rich raisiny, chocolate aroma, seemingly thick with molasses & peppery spice.  Smokey, earthy flavours  slightly thinner palate than I was expecting, but soft and lively no less.  Light bitterness ensues at the end and through the finish.  Very nicely developed after 4 years8/4/8/4/17
[April 2004 production bottling, sampled April 2007]: Pours just as clear as the 4 year old, pre-production bottle, but the head is noticeably weaker and the body is not quite as red.  Softer, fruiter aroma with blueberries and strawberries instead of raisins and yeasty spiceFlavour continues the fruitiness & brings out some yeast and orange-bitter qualities.  Finish is sweet with touches of caramel and oak.  Darn good unless compared directly to the pre-production and slightly more aged bottle8/4/7/4/16
[Previous Rating, July 2003]: Saaz hops mixed with sweet green apples and ripe pears - the hops are faint and seem like they should be pronounced. . . Sweet sugary apples offer a nice front end, but need some time to ripen and fill out. . . not quite enough palate.  I would love to have a bottle of this to hang on to for a few years.  More flavour comes after some time with the glass. . . this is on the way to greatness. . .6/3/8/4/15

Bottled 4/30/07 Poured a deep amber look with a bit of haze (sediment) and a hint of a white head.
