Initially very malty aroma with some fruity overtones that carries also in the taste with subtle hint of alcohol and yeast with a smooth finish.  It will be interesting ito see if the brew will age well (label says flavor will continue to develop over 5 years).  A good effort for Goose Island.
maybe its the style, but I hated this beer. It smelt like dung to me. And taste was similar. It was 1.5 years old.

Murky brown appearance with a diminutive off-white head.  At first all I could taste was a fairly generic maltyness but as it warmed a bit more candied fruit sweetness became more evident.  Nothing incredible for the style but still a very enjoyable beer.

Poured a dark golden color.  taste was slightly floral, banana, brown sugar, honey, quite sweet and smooth.  Hid the alcohol pretty well, and was enjoyable.  Nothing that really seperated it as being fantastic though.

Pours a lightly hazy amber with golden highlights and a smaller bubbly white head.  Aroma was lots of fruity esters, banana, dark fruit, honey and malty sweetness.  Flavor of Belgian yeast and spices very fruity with lots of banana.
Bottle:  Pours a murky brown color with a thin white head, bready aroma with brown sugar and rich dark fruits, starts and ends lightly sweet with a mellow aftertaste.  Alcohol is well hidden.

Cold 12oz bottle:  Pours a clear amber color with micro-sediment throughout.  Rich malts, earthy hops, dark fruits and alcohol notes.  Medium bodied, smooth and well carbonated.  Ending is malty and sweet with caramel notes.

Bottle (101505). Strong floral aroma accompanied by noticeable malt and hints of ripe, perhaps dark, fruit. Translucent dark ripe apricot color with a minimal head that minimally attempts to lace. Medium mouthfeel. Starts with ripe stone fruit, a touch of raisin, the effect of alcohol in the nose, and a finish that is surprisingly dry with a slight touch of bitter. Forgot to mention the caramel malt that rises after the start, which is why the dryish finish was surprising.

great malty start to finish, and i love malt.  sweet caramel dominates the nose and taste with a nice almost somber presence of yeast, that lies low yet has something to say.  nice and heavy and active in the mouth.  really well done

Bottle from OhiDad consumed at the Beerinator gathering.  Thanks Scott! Golden amber with small off-white head.  Very well carbonated like ever Goose Island brew Ive had. Aromas and flavors of banana, sweet malts, belgian yeast.  Alcohol hardly noticaeble. Fruity and rather delicious.

Pours a three finger, off-white head that fades to a thin layer leaving some lace. Cloudy amber color. Medium carbonation and medium bodied. Raisiny nose.  Flavor sweet raisins, fruity, excellent dubbel. Alcohol is hidden, smooth finish.  Better than Matilda. Bottled on Jan 23, 2006, keeps good, $2.99 for a 12oz bottle from Johns Grocery Iowa City, IA.

UPDATED: APR 8, 2010 Bottle. Hazy deep amber, copper pour. Frothy, mostly diminishing off-white head. Heavy aroma of caramel and pear with hints of dough, earthiness, toasted grain, raisin, plum and prune. Some industrial, plasticy notes. The flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly acidic and lightly bitter. It finishes moderately sweet, lightly to moderately bitter and lightly to moderately acidic. Mild tartness and lots of alcohol. Medium body, creamy texture, soft carbonation. The combination of alcohol, intense sweetness, fruits and leathery mustiness leave a slight medicinal aftertaste. Not bad, but better to buy a real Abbey beer than this.

Bottle.  Deep brown color with a thin white head.  Tame aroma - caramel, malt, metallic, slightly nutty.  Flavor is a little better.  Alcohol is very well hidden, reminds of seltzer with brown sugar in it.  Flavor is nice, like a baby quadruple.  A nice beer thats on the edge of being excellent.

While not listed as such I think of this as attempt at Midnight Suns La Mâitresse du Moine for an American trappist style.  Has the dark fruit aroma and taste but I found the traits to decrease over time in the glass.  The body became weaker and the overall effect suffered as it sat in the glass.  A shame as it started off very nice.

UPDATED: MAY 29, 2008 12 oz bottle sampled at "Better Know a Style: Belgian Strong Ale" Blind Tasting 07.  Pours clear amber, with an off white head and fair lacing.  Nose of grain, carmel, grape, raisin, pear, wood, and a bit of alcohol.  Initially sweet and lightly acidic moving to brown sugar, cherries, malt, balanced well, though a light body.  Creamy texture and fizzy with a lightly alcoholic finish.   Pretty tasty overall. 7/4/8/3/14 = 3.6

Sampled at Delilahs Vintage Strong Ale fest April 08. 03 vintage.  Pours a hazy brown with an off white head.  Yeast, brown sugar, and dried fruit in the nose.  Dried fruits, caramels, raisins, sweet red apples, and sour notes.  Lightly charred in the finish.  Decent, but maybe past its prime.  7/3/7/3/14  

5/22/08 2004 vintage thanks to drewbeerme.  Pours an orange amber with a beige head.  Sweet and aged malts.  Flavor seems to have fallen apart though.  Watery and sugarry, or sugar water.  Touch of tartness and brown sugar.  Hardly drinkable.  7/3/5/2/10 = 2.7

Pours deep red. Aroma is berry, cherry. Flavor is fruity with hints of apples and bananas with a dash of spices. Mouthfeel is smooth and a touch syrupy. Finish is mainly berries. This beer is very well balanced but almost too much so - it lacks a certain flare because of it.

UPDATED: MAR 28, 2007 Poured from a 12 ounce bottle into a snifter, cloudy rusty brown with no head. The aroma was light and of sweet fruit. The flavor was sweet and fruity with a touch of apple and honey. Very smooth, no bitterness or alcohol bite.
aroma of thai food, with a sweet, ginger quality. Light taste of maple syrup as well. medium body, spicy qualities.

UPDATED: JUL 2, 2008 This is one of the BEST AMERICAN micro brewed  Belgain Strong Dark Ales.  Very similar to Collaboration not Litigation from Avery, and similar to the Belgian brew Chimay Blue or Grand reserve.  This is an EXCELLENT perfectly balance brew with a tint of sweet malty goodness with a slight hint of hops!

NorCal tasting Feb 07 - To sound like a broken record, this is another nice beer from GI. A sweet honey-like aroma, with fruity esters and a bit spiced. Appearance is deep brown in color with a nice head. Flavor is light fruit, honey and more spices with a light hop profile to keep things interesting. A nice beer!

Lots of sweet malt in the aroma. Slightly hazy copper color reveals a medium palate.  Nice sweet malt flavor with some vanilla scents.  Very smooth and easy to drink.  No hop presence to speak of, but the toffee-like sweetness is done nicely.

UPDATED: APR 25, 2009 Cloudy amber appearance with a whitish medium head.  Somewhat sweet sugary-candy taste with a bit of malt. finish also malty sweetness. A  nice beer but using Duval as the standard it lacks in frutyness and sweetness

Bottle.   Pours a cloudy dark amber color with a thinnish off white head.   Aroma is brown sugar, toffee, yeast, alcohol.   Flavor is sweet caramel, yeast, honey, dates, slight alcohol.   Palate is medium-full, medium carbonation, slightly sweet, sticky, malty finish.   One of the best from the GI reserve series, imo.   Love it.

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2007 Orange amber with good, foamy tan head / Complex nose of banana, apricot, and spice / Creamy, full, malty body with long finish /  Complex flavors of spice, banana, apricot, caramel, and raisins / Special.

Bottle at Wriggleyville.  Pours clear dark amber with a small fizzy light brown head, mostly diminishing, spare lacing.  Aroma is average malt (cookie, nutty), average hops (flowers), average yeast (dough) with notes of bubble gum, dates and coriander.  Medium bodied, oily texture, soft carbonation and a bitter finish.  Average duration, moderate sweetness and bitterness, light acidity.

Good stuff, nice malty butter toffee aromas, silky smooth mouth, fruity and malty but with just the right amount of the belgian hoppy crispness to leave nice and clean.   Pours like dark amber with a bit of haze.

Poured a bubbly brown color with almost non-existent head...almost resembled a coke!  Pleasant, somewhat fruity and sugary, nose, and very smooth on the palate with some lasting alcohol flavor.  This was a very enjoyable beer with a nice sweetness that I enjoy in a beer...will seek this beer again in the future!

Courtesy boboski.  Slightly cloudy dark brown color with thin white head.  Fruity Belgain malt, mild pit-fruit aromas, not a whole lot of yeast character on the nose.  Thin sweet fruity flavor with a slight tang at the finish.  Wouldve liked some more yeastiness in the smell, but overall a good American take on a Belgian style.

The pour is a burnt-rusty shade of orange.  Altogether this brew is almost seamlessly woven together.  Aromas are toffee, earth, and cinammon, leading into a carrot-cake dry sweetness in the flavor.  Hints of peat, musty yeast, and spice.  A quietly rich rendition.

Pours a cloudy, deep copper/rust color.  Looks great.  Aroma is pretty enticing as well.  Theres some sugar and toffee to it, a slight cotton candy-ness, but also plenty of funky, almost cheesy yeast aromas.  Taste is full on caramel at first, lots of caramel sweetness.  The dryness from the yeast helps cut through and had some earthy and funky notes.  This continues through the finish, which is just strong enough to cut the sweetness, but not enough to dry out the mouthfeel.  Im really enjoying the balance of a dessert-like sweetness with the funky, almost cheeselike yeast qualities.  Could have been messy but this is very well made and hold itself together inredibly well.  Great mouthfeel.  A superb US-made Belgian strong.

Bottle.  092206.  Pours dark red with a thin beige head.  Butterscotch, honey, yeasty aroma.  Good mouthfeel.  Well balanced, slight alcohol burn.  I must say im very impressed with all the Goose Island Reserve beers, not one has let me down yet!  Very good belgian strong.

Pale brown with a pale tan head; honey, grapefruit, pine, nuts and dates aroma; very sweet with cream, citrus, toffee and honey aromas; bitterish finish with bread, toffee, caramel and dates aromas;.
Quite a pleasant beer, if a little sugary in the mouth. Its a very well put together beer with the hops melding seemlessly into the malt flavours. Though it tastes nothing like any Belgian beer Ive had. (74/100)

12oz bottle.  Dark orange-brown with some large particulates.  Small light brown head.  Heavy ester aromatics, pineapple, citrus, and clovey spice.  These along with raisiny alefruit and caramel sugar.  Candied fruit up front, followed by slightly ruddy caramel and raisinbread.  A dominant spicy component then manifests with a surprising hoppiness.  Residual fruity and spicy esters in the finish, with a lingering sweet plummy maltiness.  Mouthfeel is a heavy medium, somewhat chewy and hot.

UPDATED: JAN 21, 2007 Pours a medium brown color with medium off-white head.  Aroma is of caramel malt, belgian spices, and fruit.  Taste is of caramel, toffee, light fruitiness, and also a bit of peppery spice.  This beer seemed like it was trying too hard to be Rochefort 8 but came up short.  Enjoyable?  Yes.  Would I willingly buy it again?  Maybe.

Pours a hazy chestnut brown, briefly topped by some soft light tan sudsy foam. Good lacing. Very sweet aroma - brown sugar, caramel malt, and a little bit of fig.

More variety of flavor than the aroma suggests - toffee malt, fig, bittersweet chocolate, and mild rum. It dries out somewhat towards the finish with a fresh blast of spice and hops in the aftertaste. Nice blend of flavors, nice balance and contrast while intentionally remaining on the sweet side. Medium to full body, gentle carbonation. If I didnt know this was made in Chicago, Id swear it was made in Belgium.

UPDATED: MAY 22, 2008 12oz, dated 9/22/06. a poor pour allowed quite a bit of sediment in the glass. poured into a GI reserve glass. will have to re-rate. pours a very murky brown with small head. aroma has some dark belgian candy sugar, belgian yeast, and dark fruits. flavor has candied dark fruits, sweet malts, caramel, and alcohol in the finish. perhaps some light spice notes. overall a pretty nice flavor. mouthfeel is fizzy and watery. beer improved when paired with a sharp dry cheddar. theres things about this beer i like but the fizzy mouthfeel quickly followed by an alcohol bite just kills it for me. perhaps some age might help.3.3 

2/25/07, sampled at blind "Better Know a Style: Belgian Strong Ale" tasting 07. gave it the same total score blind! 3.4.

2/23/08, 2003 vintage (aged 4-5 years), past its prime, a bit sourish and the body has fallen off too much. id say it peaks at 1-3 years if it improves at all.3.1.

5/22/08, 2006 vintage, 28 months aged. pours hazy amber with small head. aroma perfumy, cinnamon. flavors are sugary dates, cherry, a bit sour, extremely watery. like watery cough medicine. this is pretty gross. okay! this beer does not age well. 5/3/5/2/12=2.7.

Rating # 850 Bottle from TPaliga; Thanks! Nose is fruity and caramelly with notes of apples, pears, spices,  and brown sugar. Rusty red with a small tan head; Medium body with the flavor of caramel and fig newtons, along with a slight amount of alcohol. the finish shows the tiniest bit of hops mixed with some slight alcohol.

Pours reddish brown with minimal head. The aroma is not stong of rye bread and fruitiness. Flavor is sweet candi sugar, light caramel, spicy and raisins. The beer has very minimal carbonation with a dry finish.

Bottle. a Hazy amber beer with a beige head. The aroma is light oxidized with heavy dark fruit nots and rye bread. The taste is sweet dark fruits and rye bread, light spicy. Medium to full body with a sweet old, fruity finish.

12oz bottle from my secret santa.  Aroma:  Lots of frutiy esthers with a strong dose of pears and green grapes.  Sweet maltiness and candi sugar with some good caramel notes.  Some light spiciness and yeastiness.  A noticeable alcohol note as it warms.  Appearance:   Orange/amber in color and hazy.  Light beige head was full and creamy with good retention.  Good lacing.    Flavor:  Medium-strong malt/candi sweetness with a toffee/caramel character.  Pear and grape fruit flavors.  Bready yeastiness, earthiness, and a light pepperiness.  Alcohol is noticeable but not unpleasant.  Fairly dry finish.  Palate:   Medium-full bodied.  Medium carbonation.  Alcohol warming in back and roof of mouth.   Overall:  A nice belgian style ale.  Really enjoyed the fruitiness in this beer.  Good stuff.

An unclear brown beer with a brown head. The aroma is of over ripe fruit and oxydized, as well as with light notes of alcohol. The flavor is sweet malty with notes of caramel and over ripe fruits, as well as light spicy notes, especially cloves and coriander. The end is dry.
Cloudy, reddish brown color, short, fast, dissipating head. Smells of alcohol and malts. Very malty taste with hints of apple, raisins, and caramel. Sweet finish.
user_location: Hastings on Hudson, New York, USA

text: Bottle.  A hazed amber color with a diminished white head.  A strong alcohol infused, medicinal, raisin and banana aroma.   Warming, sweet, caramel coating, oily malt fruity flavors.

Dark amber body, medium head. Deep fruity  yeasty aromas with hints of toffee and brown sugar. Initially very malty with caramel and toffee along with strong fruity notes of prune and plantain which follow and dominate. The beer suffers as it warms, becoming overly sugary and sweet, but still smooth and malty. Very little hops, fairly alcoholic finish.

Bottle dated Jan 06.  Dark and hazy mahogany color with an moderate tan head.  Spots of lacing.  Aroma of molasses, dark fruit (raisin, prune, dried berries) with some earthy notes and alcohol.  Tangy brown sugar flavor mostly, maybe with some orange zest. Finish is syrupy, with a slight bitterness, but still oversweet.  Medium to full bodied palate with fine carbonation.  Nice, but Id like some more of a bitter element  to balance out the sweetness.  Reminds me of barleywine

UPDATED: APR 10, 2009 Original Rating Dec 16, 2006: 3.8...Fun beer- a tad sweet, but in a good way.  Very malty, high alcohol.  Smooth finish.  I really liked! 

Re-rate April 10, 2009: 4.1....Cellared this bottle for over a year.  Wondering if itll be any different.  Aroma in this one was much stronger than I remembered in the original - very estery and fruity.  Taste has intensified nicely- taking on a sour note, with deep malt flavor bordering on almost a barleywine intensity.  Wish I had another one I could keep for yet another year.  This has aged just beautifully.  Very good.

12 oz. bottle via trade with 11026 - Pours a slightly hazy deep amber color with a one finger off white head.  Some floaties present.  Aroma is brown sugar and lots of esters.  Flavor is sweet and fruity.  Smooth mouthfeel.  Medium body.  Nice beer.  Thanks Steve.

Bottle.  Sweet malty and yeasty thick aroma with a light dried frutiness.  Amber brown color with quickly diminishing tan head.  Flavor is sweet and full of dried fruity notes. Bitterness of orange peel throughout the middle.  Creamy mouthfeel and good carbonation.  Good overall.

Bottle from Santa. Danm Im drinkin all my Santa beers with the quickness. Anyway, Beautful slighty hazy amber color. Sweet, malty fruity aroma. The taste was the same with smooth body and mild alcohol finish. Candy sugar and yeast are also detected but not over powering. Very good beer.
This one fits in the Belgian category well.  It had the minimal tan head, with the yeasty smell and candy malt taste I associate with a Belgian.  Not fancy, but good.
user_location: Lake in the Hills, Illinois, USA

text: Bottle - Brown beer with a tan head.  Sweet aroma with a big malt blast.  The taste masks the alcohol very well.  A bit sweet but overall very good.
Aroma of yeast and candy sugar.Pours dark with a hint of red.Very little white head.Very sweet malty taste.Medium body with a swet alcohol finish.

slightly hazy brown body with a nice tan head that disappears quickly. aroma bread caramel apples and hints of spice. flavor bittersweet caramel and tart green apples with a hint of spice. tart caramelized apple finish. medium to full body. lively carbonation. nothing amazing but its nice.

Bottle courtesy of Tpaliga: Poured a cloudy deep brown color ale with a medium dirty white foamy head with average retention. Aroma of candi sugar, big strong malt and subtle yeast characteristic can be detected. Taste is quite sweet with lots of candi sugar and some dry figs characteristics. Body was definitely fuller then average with some well concealed alcohol. Very reminiscent of Gouden Carolus Keizer though probably not as complex.

Medium brown in color and a small head that does not last this is a nice looking beer as it pours.  The  carbonation mixes with the body to form a nice visual.  Alcohol comes through prominently in the flavor and also gives a nice warming.  There is plenty of sweet malt in the flavor.  Sweetness is the most noticeable aspect of the beer.  Some dark fruit can be found as well as caramel.  This makes for a nice cold weather drinking beer because of the warming effect.  Might be great after a ski outing.
Suprisingly good to me since I do not favor malt headvy brews. It is impressive but too sweet for me

12oz - 2006 - Aroma is cherry, raisin, yeast and a touch of chocolate.  Pours brown-red with a small head and good lacing.  Flavor is much stronger and better than aroma.  Sweet raisins, malt, alcohol, and chocolate covered cherries.  Creamy palate gives it an excellent finish.  Let it warm up and get ready for a treat.

Pours a clear deep rouge with a lacy off-white head. Aromas are mild, pruney, sweet candy, liqour. The body is med. but OH MY GOD sweet!. Flavors are completely dominated by this cloying sweetness. The 9% is hidden well under a blanket of sugar. Needs some dextrose or a higher attenuating yeast to dry this out and make it more pallatable.

One of my first beers that Im actually trying to rate.  Goes down smooth, alcohol is noticable.   Doesnt smell too appealing.  I do like the taste though and thats what saves this beer for me and why I would recommend it to others.

Play-do, fruit cake , sweat, fusels, and sweet breads and earthy clay make up the confusing aroma. Murky oranage/red brown in color with a pretender of a belgian head that is a finger thick, tan and lasting. Fore is lightly spiced caramel and rum cake and followed by stewed dates and syrup laced sweet bread. has some positive notes and some less than stellar asspects. The carbonation is low and that makes it feel syrupy. Some of the flavor notes are there, but it lacks the nuance of a many belgians which tease you with a parade of intermingling flavors. This is fairly concnetrated (good) but narrow and predicatble (bad) though in the end what is there tastes good so it cant be disliked.
12oz Bottle pours out a dark amber topped with a very small head. A very nice and sweat aroma. I can pick-up the Alcohol but not to strong. A very good tast.

[Bottle - Johns market]
Deep rich brown color with a light brown head.  The beer has been sitting for over a year in my beer cellar.  Has a deep carmel and fruity nose and the flavor was also as rich.  This was a truly nice belgian to drink.
brewtopia 10/21/06.  Aroma is caramel, bread, and fruits.  Taste is caramel, bread, dark fruits, with some spices in the finish.  good belgian strong ale.
Hazy amber with an off white head.  Sweet malt, spice and fruit aroma.  Flavor is sweet and bready with a spcy finish.  Nice.
Auburn cloudy appearance. Tastes like a belgian red with malty overtone. Tastes  more like a belgian red than almost any other american "belgian style" beer Ive had.

Found this one bottled at Binnys Oktoberfest in St. Charles, Illinois.  A nice taste treat.  Light copper pour with a light tan head, nose of caramel candies and cherry, lots of baked bread, plum, apple and orange with a strong alcoholic finish.  Pretty good.

Bottle. Pours copper with an off white head. Aroma of sugary raisens and a whiff of alchohol. Nice mouthfeel and carbonation., but lacks the earthy texture that the imported belgians have. Flavor is sweet, with notes of raisens, hazelnut, cherry, and maple. Some peat and complimentary alcohol comes out on the finish, which is a tad sticky. Overall, very enjoyable. Glad I bought 4. From the first place I always hit when I go back to visit my old stomping grounds in Chicago.

Bottle.  Pours a medium copper with a 1 inch head that dissipated slowly.  The aroma was sweet.  Cherries, chocolate, sweet fruits, and belgian yeasts.  The flavor was very complex.  Many different malts, and flavors come bursting through this one.  Intense fruits, yeast, and a little of the alcohol come through.  Not much left on the palate, as it had a very clean finish. Excellent rendition.

Sample from a bottle at Binnys "Fall Festival of BEERS." Mild coppery color, sweet nose and flavor. Very complex, the malts hit you withy a mix of bready and baked flavors, but not overpowering. Its a different beer, and despite the price, is worth it once in a while.

Muddy brownish red color, with some carmel highlights.  I had a good sized head on mine, carmel in color.  The flavor was so complex, it almost caught me off guard.  There was some hints of orange peel, sweet tart apples, chocolate, strawberry, baking cherries, some wheat, and some heavy yeast.  SOme carmel, malt, and hazelnut as well.  Definitely worth trying.  If it werent so damn expensive, Id always have this on hand.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a rather murky looking brown colored body with alot of very fine floaties.  Head was fairly small, off-white, fizzy, and faded quickly.  Aroma is very sweet and loaded with fruity esters.  A combo of banana, macintosh apples, chocolate, figs, light alcohol, yeast, and overripe cherries.  Flavor is intense fruitiness, yeast, and alcohol most prominantly.  Finishes slightly sweet with some yeast and a good dose of bananas.  Mouthfeel is classicly Belgian in nature.  Medium to full bodied with a slightly sticky texture and fizzy active carbonation.  A nice fruity yeasty Belgian.  Comes off as more of a Dubbel more than a Belgian Strong to me.
Pours a copper color with a mild aroma. Fruity and plum-like, with enough complexity to keep me interested. Overall a fairly mild Belgian strong, but well-made and well-rounded.

Bottle at the brewpub.  Pours an amber copper with a thick off-white head.  A decent fruit overtone and a background of cavelike musts that for some reason finishes flat.  Not a carbonation thing but more of a complexity issue.

Red-brown color with minimal head in the pour and sweet autumn aromas. Someone definitely put a lot of consideration into making this brew. The flavor has good yeast and malt flavors that mellow out into a pleasant finish. Well rounded. I thoroughly enjoyed drinking this beer.

Poured a dark brown with not that big of a head. Aroma of maltiness, breadiness, brown sugar, very similar to a barleywine. Very sweet aroma. Flavor was sweet, had a little tartness, brown sugar. Palate was very thin almost as this as water. This kinda sucked. If this was a little thicker this would be great. Tastes like it could be a american barleywine with just a belgian yeast.

Trade courtesy of Monger!  Pours a fluffy, khaki, big-bubbled head; attractive clear brown with a reddish tinge; good retention.  Plenty of malty / brown sugar in the nose, maple syrup, banana, and caramel notes.  Medium mouthfeel; unadulterated, almost tea-like malt presence (tastes like homebrewing!), little balancing bitterness; some fruity, banana-like components; mouth-drying, almost approximating a red ale.  Medium, sugary finish.

Dark amber body with a thin off white head.  Aroma is yeasty with lots of caramel malt.  Some cherry and spices on the nose as well.  Flavour starts sweet with notes of dark cherry before turning spicey.  Finishes bready with a slight alcohol backdrop.

A nice looking beer with pleasantly sweet, appley aroma.  Somewhat reminiscent of Hair of the Dog Adam in look and aroma and somewhat in taste.  Numerous sweet flavors from cane sugar to cherry to dark apple and beyond.  Very sweet taste that is true to the style.  Well done!

12 oz bottle shared with malachi

Shared this with malachi on a Friday night.  It was pleasing and easy to
   drink but did not rock my world.  Still, Goose Island has turned in a solid
   effort with this one.
Aroma / Appearance - Bananas, rum, candy sugar, caramel, cherries,
   pear and malt play against each other to see which one can dominate.  They
   end up forming a nice inviting balance.  The body was a cloudy amber color
   with a thin bubbly head.  Based on the visual and olfactory feedback, this
   was lining up to be a nice beer.
Flavor / Palate - The amount of flavors relative to the nose was a
   little disappointing.  Despite that, there was still plenty going on here.
   Among the key players were caramel, honey, apples, peaches, peanut butter,
   malts and cherries.  A slightly yeastiness underlined everything giving it
   a dry feel.  The finish was pleasing, being smooth and sweet.  This was
   enjoyable and easy to drink but it did not rock my world.  Still, it is a
   well done beer I would have no problems sharing with others.
Thanks to Monger for this one.  From bottle pours a dirty brown with off whtie head.  Nose has caramel, candy sugar and hints of dark fruits.  Flavor follows.  Pretty good.

12 oz. bottle picked up at Corral for $2.32.  copper in color with a short lived tan head.  sweet spiced aroma and flavor of spiced apples, caramel and brown sugar.  an OK brew but Belgian Strongs are not my favorite, especially when the alcohol is evident as it was in this one.

12 oz bottle courtesy of and shared with gputty. My favorite of the 3 sampled today. Copper pour with an off white, almost yellowy head. Caramel and brown sugar nose. Sweet brown sugar flavor over a subtle fruitiness. Even, mildly dry finish. Very good!

Bottle.  Pours a rich amber with a nice head and lacing.  Aroma is nutty raisin.  Flavor is a sour-sweet raisin, with plum and peach in the background.  Full and coating on the tongue.  A nice effort.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Served on tap.  Pours reddish brown with a sizable tan head.  Smells like apple, caramel, brown sugar and port.  Taste was the same but had a medicine quality in the mix.  Palate was pretty nice but again the medicine taste was there.  Hints of vanilla and cherry came in towards the end.  This started bitter but smoothed out nicely.  Nice brew.
Pours a reddish brown with a thin head. Light sweet candy yeast aroma. Sweet flavor, very rich.

Very nice dark amber color with average head that initially dimishes but a thin layer remains throughout the glass. A little too yeasty for me, but will be a favorite among fans. Good beer nonetheless!

(BOTTLED 3/18/05 THANKS TO KEVIN OR KRAMER FOR THE HOOK UP)murky brown body with an off-white head.caramel malts,hard candy,and figs made the aroma.flavor mixed up the same with a little brown sugar,and honey.only complaint was it lacked carbonation.

Bottled 012306 #1105. Pours a rich mahogany color with a small off white head. Aroma was of fresh dough and honeysuckle. Nice crisp taste of sweet hops and malts. Kind of a medium bodied beer that has all sorts of flavors dancinng around on the taste buds. This is a outstanding brew!

On tap at Brouwers Cafe.  Pours a darker amber with a hint of brown.  Larger frothy tannish white head that definitely stick around for most of the glass.  Aroma has hints of dark fruit and Belgian sweet malts that are quite thick.  Flavor brings a Belgian sweet yeast and malt taste while also hinting on vanilla, cherries, darker sugars, and caramel.  Palate lingers with the sugar and malts for the most part.  9% ABV is hidden well.  Id definitely drink this many times again!

From Immys Tasting, courtesy of Secret Santa Eve!  So much good stuff was going around at the point this came out that Im not sure how many people got the chance to try it.  Too bad, as it was excellent.  Medium towards dark amber color.  Rich aroma of dark cherry, with a hint of molasses, quite rich.  Flavor matched, with a bit of a vanilla note as well.  Very, very nice, great way to finish off a great tasting event.

UPDATED: MAR 2, 2011 Bottle on 10/22/2010. Clear golden body with a small white head. Sweet fruit and caramel aroma. Sweet caramel and fruit flavor. Medium body with moderate carbonation.
7/3/7/4/15 - 3.6
Rating on 7/22/2006. From Immys Tasting. Clear dark amber color with a thin light brown head. Aroma of dark and chocolate malt. Flavor of sweet malt and caramel.
7/4/8/3/15 - 3.7
Deep bronze with thin head, full fruity aroma, layers of sweet malt and yeast, dried fruit and toffee.  Really delicious and warming.

A dark colour and some white head. Lovely yeasty and malty aroma, with bourbon in background. Complex taste,sugar or the like added. It did not hurt to hold it to about 4 months after being bottled. Satisfying and like a wine with dinner as every food prompted a different taste stimulus.Tad sour aftertaste. thanks HogtownHarry.

Thanks to Secret Santa for another great one.  Pours turbid deep coppery/brown/ruby edged with 1-finger, creamy off-white head.  Also, as I poured I noticed ribbons of dark brownish sediment.  Aroma of big fruit, some rauchy malts, some hopcitrus, and some brown sugar.  Nice intense, complex aroma.  The flavor is very fruity, with some figs, berries, pear, apple, and plum notes, plus a solid hops and citrus back end.  The whole thing stays on the sweet and fruity side throughout, at times approaching a barleywine profile but then seemingly backing off a bit and becoming more of a slightly tart, heavily fruity IPAish beer holistically.  Whatever you want to call it, it is a damned fine brew.

Bottle.  Pours a ruddy brown that is barely luminescent with little head and a faint effervescence.  A thick doughy aroma with a fruity background and some perceptible hops.  Very tasty, rich and sweet with an array of candy fruits before leaving you with a lingering bitter-sweetness.  The palate, like the beer is rich and thick and feels creamy in the  mouth.  Quite good!

12 oz bottle: poured reddish amber with a small tan head. Aroma is of wet tobacco, iced tea, light caramel. Sweet flavor with dark fruits and caramel. Light bitterness in the finish. I cant tell if I like this or not. Flavors seem to be all over the place.

Aroma is slight, with only a touch of sweetness and sucrose. Palate is very sticky and sweet as it enters the mouth, with lots of candi sugar, brown sugar, sweet cherries. I notice none of the brett they mention. A rich and filling beer, that could do with reducing sugars and bringing out the brett.

Dark mahogany with a foamy white head and some lace. Aroma is very sweet with caramel. Dark fruits are in the mix as well. Slight yeast and/or bread smells, too. The flavor is much the same as the aroma but bittering hops come in to the equation. A touch more in the spice department as well. The end is a bit bitter and some heat shows up. Thick and chewy body leaves a coat in the mouth.

Thanks to Dough77 for ths.
Reddish-hued, medium-brown body that makes a small, but persistent, creamy tan head of tight bubbles.
Sweet, fruity, complex aroma. Fresh yeast.
Smoothly delivered flavor that follows the aroma. Just enough bittering in the finish to balance the sweetness. Not bad.

"Poured a brown color with almost no head. Aroma was of spices and bananas. Flavor was of spices dark fruits, not sure where the banana aroma came from cause didnt really get that in the flavor. Had an alcohol bit to it that i didnt enjoy."
Amber color slight haze no head Nice aromas of fruit and dark fruit. Flavor is very sweet not much dark fruit flavor but some nice yeasty and spice flavor. lightly carbonated

Hazy deep amber body with a very small head. Fruity aroma with yeast and light spices. Some caramel and sugar. Flavor has a more pronounced fruity taste. Got cherries and raisins, hint of berries. I found the flavor and mouthfeel to be more appealing than the nose. Medium bodied. Still, something feels off or messed up. Not bad, but could be a lot better.

I saw this in a liquor store in Lawrence Kansas and just thought Id give it a try. 12 oz. Bottle.  It pours murky light red with a quickly dissipating head and no lacing. The nose consists of raisin, plum and brown sugar.  It has robust brown sugar, fruit, and raisin flavors. A little on the flat side but otherwise it is nice beer.

Dark multi brown. Frothy, off white head. Rich and roasty caramel malt, doughy yeast, dark fruits, candi sugar, cocoa powder, and subtle anise and alcohol. Full, smooth palate. Great brew after dinner with a mild cigar.

UPDATED: JUN 15, 2007 Original Rating: Was expecting a dubbel for some reason up through the pour. Poured the standard red-brown of a dubbel but with an unimpressive head. The aroma shocked me, as bananas jumped out with spices and yeast (Im not used to bananas in dark malted Belgian beers and was wondering where the dark fruits were). Flavor was rich and spicey with dark fruits and candi sugar coming through. Bananas only in the background of the flavor and the alcohol came through a bit sharp. Ill bet this one is a fine aged beer to drink after a few years (this sampling was only 7 mos old from bottling). I shoulda stored it away for a little while. Impatient me. Re-rate, 6/07, courtesy beerded_one at SL: Amber orangey bornw color pour, good head and lacing. The aroma/flavor was caramel, toasty nuts, sweet malts, light spices, fruity concoction. A decent brew. Thanks, Paul, for this re-rate!

UPDATED: DEC 15, 2008 Poured medium amber with a small white head. Malty, fruity aroma and subtle fruit taste. Stronger than it tastes. A bit pricey, but cheaper than a flight to Belgium, and right up there in taste.

Bottle (12oz).  Poured hazy deep mahogany-copper with an average lasting foamy straw-coloured head.  Sweet and spicy aroma, alcohol, apricot and  and dusty dry butterscotch and light floral hops.  Taste is mild, sweet, fruity, softly spicy, yeasty, a bit dry but sweet, the alcohol is sneaky, the finish is fast and wispy.  Lightly sticky, slightly thin mouthfeel, not much carbonation.  A pleasing attempt at BSA - a little sweet, needs to be livelier but strong and full of character.

12oz bottle acquired in trade with iwantalambic (thanks!). Bottled on date of 4/16/04. Poured a deep orange color with a small sized off white head. Lots of small floaters. Aromas of yeast, caramel, oak/wood, and nutty. Tastes of caramel, lighter yeast, toffee, and nuts. Very light alcohol finish.

Thanks to hopdog for breaking this open...
Appears a dark amber with a small off white cap and small amounts of lacing around the glass.
Smell is of caramel, nuts, wood, raisins, and plum.
Taste is of the mentioned aromas with caramel being the standout of the bunch.
Mouthfeel is smooth, medium bodied, slightly sweet, and hiding that 9% nicely.

Pours a cloudy pale brown, has a nice off white head with good lacing.  Sweet maltly fruity aroma.  Very sweet roasted malt flavor with hints of prunes and raisins.  Mild hop bitterness as well.  Some alcohol warmth after the swallow, but not overly assertive.  Looks more like a dubbel than a triple, but it has the ABV of a triple.  Very good effort.

From a twisted cap long neck brown bottle with a blurb about the dubbel on the front label and a bottled on date on the back label, 02/16/05.

Made a very good appearance, poured a cloudy dark orange hued amber with a fluffy, foamy pale tannish head that settled into a thin, foamy, creamy-like lacing, small amount of sticking, good carbonation.

Had a caramelize sugar, toffee, fruity and dry Belgian yeasty nose with whiffs of spicy rum-like alcohol.

A crisp, creamy, carbonated smooth fullish bodied mouth feel, good drinkability.

Toffee and caramelized malts taste, plum fruity, yeasty, a good crispiness from the malts, a nice spicy alcohol warmth in the palate and a fruity and caramelized malty finish, with a yeasty and spicy alcohol warmth lingering in the palate.

Tasty and balanced Dubbel from Goose Island, another quaffable beer from a consistently good brewer.
this was a pretty good beer.  Had it at the LI beerfest.  I wish I could have bought a bottle,  the small taste was a real teaser.

Bottled 2/16/05  Yeast-laden nose with a nice round oaky character; some sweet maple and just a touch of dried fruit. The first thing that hits the tongue is the carbonation - an acidity that gives the immediate impression this beer will make you pucker, but that quickly subsides and the warmth of the malt takes over. The carbonation may be a bit sharp due to its aging, but it has let the body really settle out nicely. The high ABV is not readily apparent behind the very present yeast and malt. Slightly chewy, very sticky. The aroma is perhaps a bit more intruiging than the flavor proves to be, but nonetheless this beer holds up very well.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2007 Draught Goose Island Wrigleyville-A hazy red with a constant head ring. Aroma of malt and yeast. A little sweet and it seems to cover up  fruit tase. Overall a good tasting Belgium. 
12oz bottled on 1/21/05-Body with a deep amber color and an off white head. Aroma of toffee, yeast, alcohol, and malt. Taste of alcohol, yeast, caramel, and toffee. I liked it better aged a bit. 7/4/7/4/15

Rating #200.  Poured into a Goose Island goblet.  Color is dark brown but translucent, cannot see through the beer.  The aroma is Belgian sweet.  The taste however is lighter than expected, thinner body.  That belgian sweetness is less present.  The aftertaste lingers for a while, again that sweet belgian-y aftertaste.  A good stab at an abbey dubbel.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: Bottle. Pours a hazy ruby-brown with an average size somewhat-lasting foamy off-white head. Mild aroma of caramel malt, yeast, a little sourness, dark fruit (moslty cherries), brown sugar, spices and alcohol -- theres lots going on there. Very nice sweet flavour of caramel malt, yeast, fruit (cherries again and more), spices and alcohol. Medium bodied. If I had to complain Id say I found it a touch too sweet at first but that seemed to pass as it warmed slightly. I was quite impressed with this, its a very good Belgian style beer.

Murky red with a small ring of head which is long lasting.  Aroma is of cherry, brown sugar, spices, very sweet.  Sweet flavor follows.  Lots of malt and yeast used in this brew.  Refreshing and decent.  Maybe just a touch too sweet.  The one thing the belgians may do better is that their beers are more carbonated to dampen the sweetness.  Still a very good effort for Goose Island.

Bottled 2/16/05, 12oz.  Pours a cloudy brownish red with almost no head.  Very malty--aroma of dark fruits, brown sugar and molasses.  A little bit of spicy hops noted as well.  Very sweet, with molasses and raisins coming through fairly strong, alcohol present, a little bit of spicy hops, into a bittersweet finish.  Low carbonation.  Medium to full bodied.  Good stuff.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: had this once a couple years ago and didnt like it.  then had it again and didnt like it.  then had it on TAP last night and it was so awesome.  definitely the best BSA ive ever had.  candyish, but milder.  warming alcohol, certainly, but neither distractingly nor detractingly so.  a very balanced creation that lacked the earlier woody notes that took away from it in the past

12oz bottle via trade with Dough77 - Thanks Tim!  - Pours cloudy dark amber with a big tall fluffy tan head that stayed very well and laced the sides of the tulip well.  Aromas of candy sugar, raisins and yeast.  Flavor is full of candy sugar, raisins, yeast, also some caramel there and toasted malt behind the sweetness.  Soft mouthfeel and very light on the palate for a sizable beer.  The palate is what sets this apart from other domestic made belgians, reminds me of Rochefort in mouthfeel.  Very good stuff..
Slightly cloudy gold - lots of floaties.  No head.  Nose or orange, lemon, alcohol, spice.  Lots of orange, corriander, some clove, yeast, fruit.  Decent malt presence.  Fruity malt finish.

Pours a tawny reddish brown with a quickly disappearing head.  Aroma is of dark fruits, cereal and yeast - very rich and sweet aroma.  Taste is very rich and full bodied - medium to light carbonation.  Taste is very malty with Belgium signatures.  Enjoyable  earthy mustiness, some dark fruits mixed in and a bit of molasses.  Candy sugar seems to be in the mix as well.  Slight astingency on the finish, but still mainly the malts.  As the beer warms the sweetness starts becoming more cloying.  After having Demolition that Goose Island calls a Belgium Ale I didnt expect this to be very authentic, but I was pleasantly mistaken.  This is a very nice beer.

Pours a tobacco color.  Thin head, hurricane swirl on top.  Wow, this is brewed in Chicago?!  This definetly fits the belgium style.  Doesnt have the complexity of a Chimay and some of the other Belgiums I have had.  This is overubundant with maltiness.  On the sweeter side which masks some of the subtle fruit taste.  I was hoping for a bit more complexity, but its enjoyable.

Orange to brown colored pour with some floaties in the bottom.  Taste is rich, possibly too sweet, and yeasty.  When compared to other beers in this style, this one does not stand a chance, but if you just base it on its own merits, its a damn fine easy to drink smooth belgian strong.  Good beer, wish I could buy it more often.

Cloudy orange-to-brown with no head.  Sweet yeast in the nose.  Sweet caramel or candy sugar, bready Belgian yeast, sweet dried fruit, and toasted malt, with a little more explicit alcohol than I would prefer.  Some sweet spice as well.  I would prefer a little more bitterness in a beer this sweet, although that might be less authentically Belgian.  Nice, buit I prefer Trois Pistoles from this side of the Pond and several true Belgians to this beer.  I think that with less alcohol burn I would be happier with this beer.
Cloudy Ice Tea brown in color. Sweet yeasty aroma with fruit and spice notes. Sweet toasted malt flavor that finishes very smooth. A very pleasant brew.
Brown color with small white head. Malty, sweet, and very drinkable. Smooth finish.

Bottle 2004 vintage poured a hazy copper brown with a lasting amber head. Aromas of raisins, brown sugar, and some vinous notes. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of dark fruit, molasses, vinous and a hint of spice with a lingering sweet finish.

Big sweet nose. Candi sugar and raisins. Malty, vinuous sweet with fruity esters. Bit of soy sauce. Belgian strong ale aromas, yeasty and musky. True to style. Vaporous, and really reminds me of Rochefort 8. Cloudy dark amber brown with off-white lacing head. I poured in the lees. Silky heavy body with medium carbonation and alcohol warming. Mellow sweet quaff, for sure. Rife with candi sugar and estery Belgian yeasties. Reminiscent of Rochefort or Chimay. Huge malt sweetness and fruity ester. Just enough bitter to round out the finish. This is probably the best domestic Belgian strong Ive had to date.
Pours a darkish red/brown.  Aromas of spice, coriander, yeast, and alcohol.  Flavor has an alcohol taste to it, mixed with a nice smokey dark fruit.  Also has strong hints of spice.

Mine is opaque brown, but I make a point to get the sediment into the glass.  The head does start very big but never completely fades, staying at maybe 1/4 inch of foam ringing the edge of the glass.   They nailed the aroma, with malt and light fruit, but it is a little light in that regard.  Good flavor.  Loads of sweet malt and lighter fruit.   Lightly spiced. Yeast shows up in the aftertaste along with some alcohol, which is hidden fairly well by the substantial malt body.  Very smooth and easy to drink.  Should age well.  Well done.  But a screw off cap?

Light brown, big puffy head that faded fast.  Smell sugary-sweet, some breadiness.  Flavor is soft fruitiness, light malts, decent yeasts.  Bit of an unfinished chemical sense to it at the end, not a great finish.  Its a bit like a Unibroue beer thats not quite ready to go, something in the yeast leads me that way.

12 oz. bottle.  Cloudy brown body with a 2 inch off-white head that dissipated quickly.  Aroma was malt sweet smelling a bit like cotton candy and rum.  I also detected a not entirely pleasant acidic odor.  Flavor is very smooth and very sweet, almost like drinking brown sugar.  I tasted no hop presence, and the alcohol was well masked.  Palate is very smooth.  Quite tasty, and with 9% ABV dangerously drinkable.

(02.18.06) Sampled at FebFest 06, Libertyville, IL.  Poured from a 12 oz brown bottle (bottled 1/15/06).  Hazy light brown Belgian strong ale having a small off-white head.  Soft carbonation.  Caramel/sweet malt aroma.  Full bodied ale that starts with light malt sweetness and caramel/toffee/toasty malt flavors.  Finishes with a pleasant malt fade. No discernable hop flavor.  Smooth, rich, and delicious.  A wonderful malty Brewmaster reserve beer.  Another excellent offering from Goose Island.

Moderate pour puts a mirky chestnut colored ale with modest carbonation and ruby highlights in my Corsendonk Tulip. Smallish cap goes to a glass-lacing ring. Aroma is one of the most pleasant of any North American craft Belgian I have sampled...a lovely grape aroma spiked with rum soaked bread smells. 

Silky smooth delivery up front of vinous tastes; red grapes in abundance, ripe red plums and sweet muscat grapes...then the malts and yeast take over the palate creating a musty, rum soaked Christmas pudding decernment...finish is surprisingly drying with the hopping showing up to bitter the fruity malt tastes.

The underlying asset of this brew is its sinister but extraordinary drinkability. One of the few Belgian craft beers I wanted to poke back 3 or or more of in a sitting...Hear that Unibroue? D-R-I-N-K-A-B-I-L-I-T-Y

Pours a brownish,sandy red color with a thick beige creamy head.  Unfiltered.  Tons of hops floating around.  Aroma is of pears,banana,nutmeg, brown sugar, molasses and fresh yeast.  Taste is a combination of nutmeg,pear,banana, spiced wafer, raisins and caramel.  Excellent !!!

From the bottle
Pours a cloudy ruby brown with beautiful highlights and the expected sediment, and with a very subdued head. This is a sweet belgian-style ale (think Rochefort 8); both the aroma and flavor bring out brown sugar/molassas, raisins, belgian yeast, a touch of pineapple and pear, and hint of alcohol but nothing near the 9% actuallypresent. Pleasingly, the flavor does not stay sweet throughout; the tail end of each sip turns softly bitter with finely balanced hops. 

This one is enjoyable throughout, and quite a nice (the best Ive had to date?) domestic alternative to some of the sweeter, darker Belgian ales. That said, I didnt sense in this beer the full complexity that I enjoy in some of the similar imports.
Hazy deep amber, lasting beige head.Light alcohol, spicy yeast nose. Taste is sweet, malt/molasses, medium alcohol heat.Chewy

Bottled. Pours a reddish/brown sort of color. Some sediment is floating about. Appears to be fairly carbonated. Aroma is sweet and fruity. Some candy aromas are present. Flavor is sweet right off the bat. followed by a deeper dark fruity/roasted malty flavor. Slight tartness to balance out the sweet. Alcohol is very well hidden.

A fast yet creamy head over a caramel/ruby body with a thick haze... and a flawless presentation from our bartender. A veritable "fruit cocktail" of aromas with sourish cherry, pineapple and citrus that is not overdone but rather linear and delicate. Additional light funk and wheat. Flavor finds sweet malts exploding in a caramel-candy fluff-bomb (as asinine as that may sound, each time I took a drink I re-read that line and it was perfect.) Caramel is light and airy... very much "brittle". Vanilla and lemon arrive in creamy waves to follow. Sweetness can be a little harsh, but this was fantastic.


<font size=-4>Via bottle at <a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Island Beer Company (Clybourn), Chicago, IL 60614<font size=-1>

This beer says hello with a mild aroma of hops and fruit that has wheat undertones.  It is a cloudy copper liquid with no head.  A moderately thick, mildly sweet, mildly bitter beer that that has a sweet date taste that gabs the tongue with the sensation of alcohol.  This alcohol taste lingers on the tongue after swallowing.

Muddy orange with a beige head and yeast sediment floating around. Aroma is sweet, yeast, fruit, and spices. First thing I noticed was the silky smooth mouthfeel. Sweet but not cloying, pears, banana, orange, a hint of strawberry, and a hint of pineapple. Has a good malty body that is so sleek. Reminds me of a Dole flavored juice in ways, but has belgian yeast. Not a big fan of belgian strongs in general, but this is a very nice brew. Again the silky smooth palate rivals that of the Westy 12.

From a 12Oz bottle. Enjoyed this puppy while wrapping the Xmas gifts. Call it a tribute to Rochefort or whatver, I call it a very enjoyable abby style ale. Wonderful fruity aroma on the pour. Very nice ruby/brown color. Classic abby mouthfeel, and tastes like its been it came all the way from Belgium. This one will win you over quickly.

Pours a deep cloudy mohogany color with a one finger head that fades to a solid ring with a spotty cap. Leaves a decent amount of lacing on the glass.

Smell; theres lots of raisins, some maltiness, oranges, candied sugar, and has just an overall spiciness to it. I really like the way this smells.

Taste; sweet raisins, some orange peel, definite candied sugar, molasses, has a bit of warming alcohol, although I dont get any of it in the taste. Mouthfeel is medium bodied, and a litlle sticky, probably due to the candied sugar. I bought a four pack several months ago and tried one at that time. I liked this at then, but it seems to have gotten much better since I let it sit for about 5 months. I found this to be very enjoyable.
user_location: Where the hell am I?, Nebraska, USA

text: Poured from bottle into shaker glass as I dont have any wide-mouthed glasses.   This beer was a cloudy orange/ amber with a minimal off-white head that almost completely diminished.  It was carbonated enough that I could see little gass bubbles frequently rising from the sides.  Now about the aroma...it was smooth and sweet with just a hint of alcohol.  It also had some sort of fruit that I could not place.  The taste was enticing!  Once again, just a hint of alcohol, but covered well by a host of other flavors.  I taste the fruit that I smelled earlier but I still cant decide what it is.  This beer is teasing me, taunting even.  Its driving me MAD!!!  But before that happens, Ill have another.

A bit over-carbonated appearance for a Belgian Strong Ale.  Cidery brown body with a thick foamy head. Gentle, sweet yeasty nose with a slighty cough syrupy flavor and smooth on the palate.  Taste profile was midway between a belgian ale and a dubbel.

12 oz. bottle with thanks to Eyedrinkale for the trade!  Pours a beautiful dark reddish mahogany color, hazy with a moderate beige head that diminished mostly.  Aroma is full and fruity, prune, ripe pear, molasses, nutmeg and clove.  Flavor is also rich and sweet, prune juice, more molasses, raisins, mild coffee and sweet brown, spice bread.  Full body and creamy carbonation.  Very good.

The aroma was light w/ fermented fruit, coriander, slight citrus and honey notes.  The flavor was coriander, light fermented fruit, flowers, and a candy sweetness.  The beer poured a cloudy brown color w/ thin lasting head and lacing.  The mouthfeel was light bodied and creamy.

Cloud sediment auburn, bubbly and foamy head, sticky lacing. Nose of sweet caramel malts, plum, light hops and yeast. Light chocolate taste and a large body and balanced sweetness. Finishes lightly tart, a bit sweeter and a little acidulous for my taste. Typical Ameribelgian.

Very cloudy deep amber color with smallish tan head and faint lacing. Aroma is full of caramel, dates, cinamon, cherry, hints of oak and burbon. Flavor is malty, slightly sweet, with caramel, vanilla, notes of alcohol in the finish and a faint bitterness. A very nice brew.
Dark amber color with small chunks floating.  Rich sweet malt aroma. The mild spice aroma becomes fuller and almost overwhelming in the flavor when it mixes with the high alcohol.

This is by-far the best tasting Strong Belgian-Style Ale by an American brewery Ive had.  It has a sweet fruity aroma, with a hint of alcohol.  The head leaves quickly, but the smooth texture of the beer is very enjoyable.  As close to a copy of Rochefort 8 or Westmalle Dubbel as you can get from an American brewery.

Pours a nice slightly murky deep amber with a nice creamy head but fades.  Aroma is very fruity, caramael malts and some yeast.  Flavor is mostly sweet with lots of candi sugar, caramel malts, and some fruitiness.  Moderately yeasty, but not complex enough.

The bottle poured a dark amber beverage with a small fizzy white head that only lasted 5 minutes before disappearing entirely. The aroma of sweet ripe fruit including banana and apricot was pungent. The presence of malt was barely discernable.  The body was thick and the texture smooth, almost oily. There was little carbonation. The flavor started off very sweet almost like rock candy. As it matured on the pallet, it brought out an alcohol warmth and became quite smooth. The alcohol warmth continued to build for a while and the finish was very long and mellow with no hop bitterness detectable.

Medium brown pour with a large creamy white head... looked rather majestic in the snifter.  Grapes, pears, raisins, spices, and alcohol complemented a very nice bready aroma.  Sweet and bready flavor picked up substantially all of the aroma... however became surprisingly muddled as it warmed.  The alcohol and the sweetness made it almost cloying toward the end.  This was a decent effort, but I prefer G.I.s other reserve ales (Matilda and Demolition).

This one never lets you forget that its a "big" beer.   Alcohol fumes making my eyes water along with an intensely syrupy-sweet raisin smell.  Flavors likewise are over the top...alcohol, caramel, dried fruits, raisins, and weird citrus? spices....  This has some wine-like characteristics.  Unusual and interesting sipping beer.

Wow!  I like this one.  Very rich, sweet, suculent, its really nice.  I think this was a pretty new bottle and was good just like that.  Its got a great sweet malty nose, and so much fruity character in the taste and finish.  Very well done.

Really quite different from most other things Ive drank.  Very fruity, malty, sweet, and almost mead-y.  The mouthfeel does a good job of keeping all of these flavors in check, it is mellow and smooth and only slightly coating.  Not a session beer, but a welcome change of pace.

Lots of odd tastes here.  Orange, grape, maple syrup, molasses, bread dough, and spice.  An amalgam of exotic tasting malt and yeast.  The stickiness of the feel conflicts with the fruity taste.  Im torn between a thumbs up and a thumbs down.

Thanks to goldtwins for this beer.

Poured a murky mahogany with a small off-white head.  Smells sweet and vinous with a touch of spiciness.  Taste is cream, cinnamon, grapes, cocoa, and a touch of alcoholic dryness.  Very rich and tasty, as well as drinkable.  Nicely done.

Beautiful aroma is best part of the pour.  Really murky brown color with floaties and a fair head that dissipates and leaves a little bit of lacing.  Aromas is complex and bold... sweet with mild fruit (raisins seem like a good description, maybe plum or prune, too) over a little bit of a grain that is really subtle.  Flavor is blessed with a great mix of the fruit/sweet remnants of the aroma that is followed up by a sweetness that recalls toffee.  All of this has a mild alcoholic bite to it that provides a little warmth and compliments flavors nicely.  Smoothly and masterfully blended.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Picked this up at Johns Grocery in Iowa City.  The color is a bold red amber with a creamy custard colored head.  Somehow it has a thick look to it.  Aroma is a nice and complex.  Raisin, plum, and spice along with a yeast character, really fits nicely for its style.  The flavor is yeasty with a greay roasted malt.  The second wave is very sweet, and that sweetness settles very cleanly. It is about at this time that I notice the head stays sizable for a long time and produces a great lace.   Raisin and plum provide a nice extra character and brings a bit of a tangy alcohol.  It rounds out very nicely with carmel and a mixture of the aforementioned dark fruits providing a very full and sweet character.  Nice beer.

Nice-looking, very cloudy,  reddish-brown body.  The aroma has bananas, fruits, prunes and syrupy sweet malts/sugar.  The flavor is also very sugary, a little bit thin.  It is indeed rich, and dessert-like.  Malty and only slightly spicy.  Nice, smooth and chewy finish.  Perfect carbonation.

Brownish-red tint with thin ring of lace - high, fizzy carbonation - this carbonation is soft on the palate, however - somewhat musty aroma, with notes of raisin, plum, apple, caramel, nutmeg - lightly spicy and fruity up front (mostly raisin and cherry) - sweet caramel and toffee show up late - long, sweet, belgian sugar finish - quite a solid ale that hides it abv well - the abbot it is named after should be proud.

Bottle: This copper brown colored beer makes its high alcohol presence known.  It is there in the aroma and in the taste, making it resemble what I imagine raisin cough syrup to taste like.  Too sweet and strong for me.

Thanks to Secret Santa for this beer.
Dark brown color with a thin white head, this is a tasty brew. Lots of candy sugar flavor and stickiness. Very enjoyable

12oz bottle. Dark brown color. Medium sized white foamy head. Aroma is banana, clove and citrus. A medium bodied Belgian Strong Ale. Malts are fruity and sweet, banana and clove, candi sugar and a touch of caramel. Not a lot of spices mainly fruit and sweet malts, but definitely Belgian yeasts. Smooth taste. Hides the 9% alcohol very well. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.

Another thanks goes out to beerguy101 for allowing me to sample this beer. This pours a ruby red color with a thin white head and mild amounts of lacing. The aroma is ALL bananas and clove at first. It does eventually give way to some alcohol, citrus, malt and sweet fruits as well, but when in doubt, its ALL banana. The flavor is medium to full bodied with heavy banana fruityness. Very tart and acetic finish...crisp in all senses of the word and very VERY dry in the finish! Mildly carbonated and generally sticky in mouthfeel. Some candy sugar flavors in the finish, but once again, another portion of the beer dominated by banana. Perhaps a hint of ginger in here too? Not bad at all, but Id probably have loved it more had I been a fan of bananas.

Bottle.  Pours orangy cloudy brown, little nto no head.  Big dark fruit and candied fruit aroma.  Nice caramel malty flavor upfront, with loads of darker fruit, some yeast flavors, and some spices.  Finishes with a bit or a corriander bite.  Light but crisp carbonation, combined with a fairly thick mouthfeel.  Alcohol was present, but no burn.  Very enjoyable.

Picked this up on my way thru Kentucky (near Cincinnati).  Poured a hazy amber, light lace, no head.  The aroma was sweet  malt, cotton candy, molasses and other fruity sweetness.  I also thought there was some spicy cinnamon in there.  Relatively complex and nice overall.  The body was very thick, coating and creamy.  Very nice flavor.  Big caramel/molasses malts and fruit ranging form dark and dried (like raison) to pear.  Very interesting and good.  There is some spice as it warms and includes ever increasing hints of clove and banana and cinnamon.  Did not know exactly what this was when I tried it but Belgian strong makes sense.  I actaully liked it colder as opposed to warmer.

Pours dark red/brown/ruby with a big tan head.  Definite dark fruits and maltiness in aroma.  Thick and viscous on palate.  Starts sweet, malty, with dark fruits and finishes with a slight amount of tartness.  Very nice beer.

Pours a deep copper/red color body with a huge, fizzy head that fizzles down to a smal layer on top.  Aroma is spicy with dark fruits and berries with a little alcohol.  Very nice flavor.  Rasberries, raisins, and plums with a little alcohol in the finish.  A bit smoother than it looked at first.   Great ale!
This definitely has a bit of an alcohol nip to it, which is perfect as it is a winter seasonal.  Sweet and spicey, but at the right level.  Too much of either is never good.

Thanks Chuck!  Pours to a thick creamy but mostly disapating beige head.  EXCELLENT lacing.  The body is mahogany and has some particles in the body.  The aroma is candi sugar, spicy sour green apples, toffee.  The flavor is spicy, nutmeg, allspice, cinnamon, sugar,  sweet alcohol, creme brulee, oak.  The palate is medium bodied and very rich and creamy.  This is a good beer.  I dont get much alcohol at all...

a bit of an off orange copper cloudy color w/ a small white head.  Smells sweetly of plums and carmelized sugarz along w/ a light fruit mostly apples.  Palate is warm well coated smooth and creamy.  Flavor is like a sweeter barley wine.  Big sweet carmel malt flavor full of plums and apples lightly spicy cinnamon and nutmeg not much bitter and a noticable alcohol.  Good stuff.

Nice frothy head atop a mahogney base. Good lacing.  Dried fruit, sugars, a nice blend of spices in the nose.  Alcohol is still very up front though.  Some burnt sugar, cinnamon, nutmeg, pepper, and light bitterness across my tongue.  Medium body.  Lingering burn
Bottle. Light amber w/ off white head. Sweet, sour like green apples nose. Taste is alcohol, sweet malts and caramel.

12 oz. Bottle:  Poured a nice cloudy orange/amber, well carbonated, with a mostly sustaining tan head.  Aroma was of spicy fruits/tart fruits (green apples, sour citrus), chocolate/toffee type background provided a sweetness to offset the tart aromas up front.  Flavor was more sweet than tart, with lots of caramel dark sugars, raisens, and other fruit.  I felt the alcohol was well hidden and did nothing more than provide a nice belly warming.

2004 bottle : Dirty brown with some fluffy white head. The bottle itself had a whole lot of funk at the bottom. Alcohol is very present in the nose, as are sweet malts and a fruity sweetness, although I am not too sure on which fruit. Maybe some buttery toffee as well. Huge and complex flavor. Spicy sweet to start. Sour apple and some raisins come through with the malt. Finishes warm and spicy sour. This beer really knocked me back. Only complaint is that it seemed a bit flat for the style, needed some more bubbles. Great brew. Could be a session brew, albeit a short session with the amount of alcohol in this thing.
Hazy dark amber.  Alcoholic, slightly yeasty aroma with caramel undertones.  Straightforward palate with caramel and alcohol, and lightly spicy yeast.

12 oz bottle.  Cloudy, deep copper coloured beer with a thin white head.  Sweet malty aroma, beautiful light yeasty spice, some herbal character (dill and oregano).  Light oaky character as well.  Flavour is sweet, malty, vineious, a bit of marshmallow, dusty yeast flavour, herbal/spicy with a light toasted malt finish.  Vanilla retronasal.  Woody and oaky finish.  Soft creamy texture... just beautiful.
hazy brown color, little head. smells of yeast, and a bit of fruit. flavor is yeasty, fruity-banana, etc,  with a bit of a spicy finish. medium bodied. very tasty

Cloudy, medium brown appearance with a small head that faded so fast I couldnt tell the color.  Yeasty aroma with a nose that resembled mildly spiced banana bread.  Well carbonated, medium-bodied mouthfeel.  Malty, with an over the top sweetness and an underpinning of ripe fruit that lingers through to the finish.  At 9%,  the alcohol is well hidden.

Murky reddish brown body with a thin off white head.  Apples and pears in the aroma, with some banana carmels, and bread.  Banana is most evident in the taste, but alcohol is there too.  Malts, and apples make an apperance too.  Tasty.

Opaque muddy orange-brown with a bouncy foamy head.  Blowtorch of a cooked sugary aroma ... this is intimidating!  Pow ... bigtime alcohol is clearly evident ... cooked,  um ... banana!  Yes, thats it (thanks, previous rater).  At first, this is overpowering, but as it breathes a bit and warms up, it settles into a beautiful concoction ... smooth and sweet and not as overpowering as the first impression wants to indicate.  Decent.

Bottle: Cloudy amber/brown body with a small creamy, thick tan head.  Aroma caramel, bread, yeast, chocolate cake, banana, a hint of alcohol and fruity/citrus hops towards the finish.  Medium bodied, medium spritzy carbonation - enough that the tiny bubbles can be felt, but never dominates your palate.  Taste is chocolate-covered bananas (though not very sweet), honey, malt, bread, toffee, slight bubble gum/candi sugar flavor, and a bit of spicy/grassy hops as it warms.

Cloudy orange - brown color with floating bits.  The aroma is a mix of sweet caramel, alcohol, and hops.  Smooth with a mild creaminess.  Light to medium bodied.  A nice balance of sweet caramel, malt, and hop flavors that are unfortunately overwhelmed by a strong prescence of alcolhol.

Hazy orange / brown in color.  Some sediment floating around.  Head is tan and small, about the size of a quarter, floating in the center of the trappist glass.  Aroma is damn delicious - chocolatey, bananas, ginger, spice cake and some wafts of alcohol.  Flavor is chocolatey, sweet, ripe bananas and a dash of coffee.  Toffee, caramel and black licorice characteristics evolve from the choice of malts.  Body seemed initially thin, but it grew on me.  Leaves a margarine-like coating on the palate.  High carbonation up front, but its succinct and well thought out.  Finishes like a midnight snack.  Very good beer.

UPDATED: JUL 26, 2011 This is the first beer that I have tried from this brewer. Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured a cloudy chestnut color with a medium sized soapy tan head that left a bit of lacing. The aroma is sweet caramel, date and  plum. The flavor is very sweet with sugary caramel, molasses, date, raisin and wood. Long finish with lingering date and caramel. Fairly full bodied. Excellent.

Turbid rusty brown, thin off white creamy head.  Complex nose of spiced dried plum and cherry, some caramel, with hints of brown sugar sprinkled throughout.  The flavor was well balanced, spicy, with lots of Belgian yeasty fruity overtones.  9% was well hidden.  Full bodied, lively carbonation, bittersweet, drying, spiced dark fruit finish.  I hope this is an indication of what Ill be drinking at the Clybourn location on May 20th.  Great representation of the Abbey style and highly recommended...

Pours with an amber body topped by a thin to medium thick head with some lacing.  The aroma and flavor are sweet and flowery wtih a slight citrus note and some candy sugar.  Medium bodied and smooth yet slightly tingly.
Pours a hazy orangish brown color with a small off white head.  Aroma of brown sugar sweetness, apple, and alcohol.  Sweet flavor, yeast with  and spicy finish.    Medium body.

Fromt the 12oz bottle this pours copper with a small white head. Sweetness and spice throughout the aroma and flavor with a very balanced bitterness in the finish.  Fruity esters showed up as it warms mixing well with a light spicing. A small amout of alcohol showed in the finish, but i cant blame them with 9%.
Wonderful malty spices and apple aroma,sugar banana aple taste,with hints of currant and date in the blend,sweet and smooth, as well made as many from Belgian. A very pleasant surprise

Poursa golden orange  hue with a halo of a tan head.   Aromas of bananas, yeasty esters and a hint of citrus.  Flavors(full bodied) oaky honey, a little banana, some other fruits and a light sweetness.

what a wonderful brew from goose island....orangish brown hazy appearance with minimal white head...aroma of spices, sugars, and light fruits, as well as a touch of caramel...flavor was of sugars and spices, with a great aftertaste of plum and a touch of white grape...i will be drinking these much more often

This is totally delicious - I really had no expectations, good or bad, when I bought this 4pack.  "Strong, rich Belgain" - OK, what does that mean?  Poured an interesting cloudy brown with a large frothy tan head, great lacing.  Aroma is sweet spicy malts, fruits.  Tasted at a nice warmer temperature, this is full of milk chocolate covered cherries and even bananas, peaches and apricots.  Hints of vanilla and alcohol give it a nice kick.  Very enjoyable - Ill probably try to get more of this before it disappears.

Bottle:  Very nice malty aroma.  Lots of fruit, caramel, and sugar.   Very dark transparent dark reddish-orange with a somewhat large bubbled head that sticks around for a minute or so.  Very malty.  Fruity, caramel, sugary, and raisin.  Pepper, light apple, and light yeast in the finish with some light alcohol and a slight burn as it goes down.

Split a four pack with Pailhead. Been nursing this thing for two hours this morning. Pours medium brown with decent tan head that fades to a ring of bubbles rather quick. Aroma is very strong overipe bananas with a spice background. Flavor much the same with a smoky, woody dry finish, with some strange spice, maybe the coriander mentioned. Very well done.

Eyecatching hazy brown orange color with a nice medium fluffy rocky head on top. Rhasberries, yeast and candy sugar nose. Doughy, vanilla taste, kind of onedimensional- with a peppery finish. Nice one. Thanks csbosox for this nice treat.

Hazy orange with floaters and a decent off white head. Light and fruity aroma with caramel and peach. Lively mouthfeel with a clean fruity dry finish. Flavors of plum and fig with some yeast and spiciness. Overall not a bad offering.

12 oz bottle: Hazy deep amber w/a  lasting, thick, creamy, cream colored head.  A little flat and lifeless @ first in the aroma.  Sugary sweet, some bready malt, hints of peppery yeast & woody aromas.  Alcohol; minor notes of raisins deep within.  Very heavy dried peach fruit flavor at first.  Well balanced w/ a lightly bitter finish that tastes like bready malts.  Caramel and brown sugar as well.  Finish is semi sweet w/ a short lived aftertaste that is lighlty herbal hop and dries out fairly quickly.  Medium carbonation, dry m/f, fuller body.  Im not a big fan of this one.  Its very bland and boring with most of the characteristics, except the peach flavor at the beginning.  Aromas and most flavors are light and average at best.

Wow,this sonofabitch is marvelous.I can close my eyes and think that I have an Abbey under my nose.Strong notes of exotic spice and fruit,clove,coriander and bananas:overipe.Very nice but will I be let down after I taste it.NO.Heavy and thick.The spices and ripe bananas
mingle with each other and boy this is a great brew.

Sweet vinegar and raspberry nose - like a raspberry vinagret - and some alcohol. Murky brown-orange color with a low tight head. Sugary sweet malt body, yeast tastes and some orange flavor. Missing a bitter or spicy balance to the sweet body. Heavy, thick and sweet overall. Good, but this isnt my style....

Bottle.  Rich opaque brown color.  Off-white head dissipates quickly to ring the edge of the glass leaving scant lacing.  Aroma is decently malty, bits of sugar and fruit make its way out.  Flavor is initially candy sweet and then transitioning into a dark fruit realm.  Adequate hopping provides some bitterness in the finish.  Overall very well done.

Bottle:  This pours an earthy brown color with a thin cream colored head.  The aroma is alcohol, very sweet malts, dried fruits, and some undetermined spices.  This is quite wine-like, an alcohol burn with plums, raisins, candy, and a sprinkle of hop bitterness.  Its got a dry, sweet-sour alcohol finish.  Nice warmer.

In the bottle at the Crescent Moon Alehouse. Served to me in a matching Goose Island tall stem goblet. Pours a cloudy yeast-filled amber with a beige head. Superb aroma of raisins, fruity sweetness and 18th century patent medicines. I spent a long time just smelling this ale. The head is full oif body and kept jumping up each time the goblet was swirled. The flavor was candy sweet with a subdued tartness. The body is strong, but I would have expected something even heavier from the aroma. Its a delightful thing when a macro-micro like this still puts out the goodies for us.

Sweet, floral, fruity and malty aroma, redolent of fresh banana bread along with lighter notes of apple, clove and berry.  Medium-dark reddish orange color, hazy with a fine, lasting head and delicate lace.  Flavor is comprised predominantly of abundantly sweet, sugary malt and yeast esters, lending a certain vinous fruitiness that lasts throughout and finishing with a mild alcohol note and lingering sweetness.  Smooth and lusciously creamy palate with a full body.  Simple yet tasty.

cloudy amber color with a nice beige head.  Nice dark fruit aroma with a sweet taste of candied sugar, plums, raisins and some mild spice.  probably a bit sweeter than most belgians, but this did not detract for me. A most enjoyable brew from the goose island folks.

12oz bottle  bottled on: 021605...pretty fresh bottle...picked up the 4-pack in early March...pours a murky ruddy brown color with no head formation...swirling the glass produces a slight tan foam...smells first off of burning toast, then a little raisin and plum also come through the light phenol/medicine like aroma...yeast again makes its presence known in the flavor, but this full bodied sweet beer has plenty of malt and honey-like flavor in it as well.  Finish is laced with the earthy spice of the yeast and sweetness, with an underbelly of rough hop bitterness and alcohol.  I dont normally look to american brewpubs/micros when I want a fabulous Belgian ale(with a couple of exceptions), and this is no exception...it proves to be decent, but not special in the least...it is young and a little rough around the edges...maybe some of that distracting yeast character will turn into something more intriguing with some time...Ill grab another 4-8 bottles to test it over time...I am glad to see something like this being brought into Nebraska.

Pours cloudy brown, like apple cider. Aromas of dark fruit, yeast, brown sugar, and malt. Flavors are sweet malt, brown sugar, yeast, honey, and fruit. A little on the sweet side, but Im loving it none the less. Thanks to EddieG for including this as an extra in our recent trade.

from the bottle.poured a muddy amber. with a tan head.aroma a fruity yeasty, honey, grapefruit, malts, hops, alcohol, sugar, grapes, floral, musty. flavor, hops, malts, and mild sourness, than some honey comes in along with some apples and dark fruits. not to bad of a beer glad I got a 4 pack going let this cellar for a couple of years.
Bottle. Cloudy brown color with a large rocky tan head. Aroma was very complex of malt and fruit. Flavor was as complex with malt, yeast and sweet long finish. Very good brew.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2006 


Re-rate after aging a bottle for 1 year:
The spiciness toward the end seems to have mellowed out quite a bit. This beer now comes across as very soft on the palate. Seems to have lost alot of the vinuous spicy fruit flavors that were very noticable when fresh. Caramel and bread notes are now at the forefront. Seems to have aged very well. Going to leave the rating as is.

Bottle. Thanks to joeybgood for this one.  Pours deep bronze with a tall frothy tan head. Nose is sweet and fruity with light yeast notes. Raisins, hint of banana, candy sugar, sweet malts, light wheat and yeast, and wafts of alcohol. Taste is also very sweet and fruity with light bitterness.  More raisins and dark fruits with sweet malts, candy sugar, grains, light spice and flowers.  Body has big carbonation, light bitterness, but not as full as expected.  Finish is dark fruit and light spice with flowers, light cookies, yeast, and light alcohol notes. Very good!

UPDATED: MAR 12, 2008 12 oz bottle. Tasted at 57° from a NB worthy glass. Poured reddish brown with a long lasting off white/nearly tan head.  Small sediment rests on the bottom. When the foam dies down, it coats the side of the glass.   Nice aroma of malt, prunes, raisins, and over ripe dark fruits.  The first impression is of the full mouthfeel due to the malts and the carbonation. The flavor is bready, malty, and sweet at first then shifts to chocolate?, dark fruits, earthy hops character, estery notes, with some dark brown sugar.  The finish tries to be balanced, but the hops lose out in the end to the malt and it comes of slightly sweet, but certainly not cloying.
