I just had a Rochefort 10, and although this is certainly not as good as that, it is one of the best domestic beers of its style.  The alcohol is barely noticeable. This is a very, very good beer and I just heard today that it is being sold in Kansas, this is great news.  
12oz bottle dated 01/31/2005, making  this 3+ years old  Served in a Chimay chalice @ 41° just a minute or two from the beer fridge. Aroma is dark fruits, dark caramel, toffee, with hints of leather and tobacco. A slight sourness lurks in the background. Silky mouthfeel with a little alcohol heat in the finish. Taste is woodsy, dark caramel, dark fruits galore,  toffee, soft alcohol at the front and warming at the end. The beer has dropped a good amount of sediment in the last 3 years and  it coats the bottom of the bottle. Scores all stay the same.

(12 oz bottle)  Pours rather deep red amber with less than a finger of head.  No lacing present.  Smells of very ripe fruits and a touch of alcohol.  Taste is no different except for some "clean" fruit or citrus flavors.  This is my favorite type of beer(from what little I have tried) and, I like this best.

Pours dark but transparent rusty brown with a huge white head that stays. Aroma is of hay and some mild fruit. Flavor is an interesting mix of light fruits, dark fruits, a slight spice, ans a mild maltiness. Finish is a little water if you do not get a signifigant portion of the head to add creaminess. The light fruit addition to the traditional dark fruit/malt/spice belgian is what makes this beer different and interesting and quite good flavor wise.

Having tried this when it was fresh and after it has aged awhile I prefer the fresh.  The aged seems to lack any hop bite it might of had making this a little too sweet for me.  Nicely malty, sort of like a sweet plum coffee-cake with raisins.  Good lacing.  I prefered this to their Demolition, their other winter special.
Very Belgian like in the yeast.

Thin yellow head. Very dark amber and copper coloring. No light penetrating. Aroma of bananas and pears.  Also some bubblegum and bread.  The taste falls short after the strong aroma. It has pears and maybe  a hint of clove. Not a whole lot going on. The mouthfeel is soft and velvety. As smooth as anything I have encountered. So I suppose that complements the gentle flavors.

UPDATED: FEB 15, 2005 Holy smokes!  Im not sure which trappist they were shooting for here, hints at Roch 10 but I understand this is really a Chimay Blue clone, but IMO its better! And while they didnt quite give us a sublime, amazingly complex little creatur like Roch 10, theyve perhaps made the very best Belgian style Ive ever had from an American brewery.  So very soft, juicy, rounded, caramelly fruity malts, perhaps a teeny bit of chocolate, a little coconut, touch of banana and phenol, sweet alcohol finish.  Did I say this was soft?  Wow!  Nice amber-red color, full head gave way quickly, no lacing.  Oh, and the mouthfeel was just soft and juicy.  Luscious.
Thanks for this brew Santa!  Caramel, fruit, and a bit of salt compose this aroma.  Body is a foggy amber with a frothy cream head.  Pretty sweet, but not overly.

What a damn cool story on the label.  It made my heart warm up.  Dark Amber.  Large, frothy, lasting head of foam.  Aroma of cocunut, bourbon, caramel, chocolate amd dark fruits.  Notes of pit fruit, blackberries, cocunut flakes, chocolate, caramel, dark fruits and banana are present in the flavor.  A very good beer overall.

Thin head with a nice cloudy brown color. Estery sweet cadided aroma. Apples. Malty palate, taste of yeast and fruit. Nice bittering in the finish. Very balanced. Alcohol is apparent but fits in well.

Doughy, nutty, sweet aroma with plenty of candy sugar. Amber-copper coloured body with dense, though thin, off-white/tan head that recedes to lasting cover. Extremely sweet flavour (though not unpleasant) with doughy, yeasty character and some hints of alcohol. Fine bubbled carbonation and very soft mouthfeel with medium-full body. Bottle enjoyed with MartinT, muzzlehatch and Rastacouere.

UPDATED: JUN 11, 2007 The Lure:Faint apricot sweetness and bready chocolate are met by solitary alcohol. All is subdued and not that appealing.

The Festivities:Sweet malt fruitiness gives depth to the resting light yeast. Earthy chocolate and French toast dabble with the added sugars. Weak oranges in a thick but quiet body are not prone to waking up the vibe in the glass.

Transcendence:A flat puddle is an exhausted remnant of something once vivacious up high.

Bottle-conditioned. Clear orange body wearing an off-white cover. Very yeasty nose though its not necessarily the most appealing yeast strain. Thick fruitiness (banana, mango, watermelon, peach etc). Big alcohol suggestions through the baked breakfast pastries yeastiness and donut like sweetness. Big fruity flavor bathing in alcohol, doughy, desserty sweet, perhaps too much so. Medium bodied, tropical juice texture, medium carbonation. Average for the style, lacking finesse.
Hazy caramel color, Sweet malt aroma with hints of yeast. flavor is sweet malt, Flavor is caramel, sweet malt, hints of dark fruit.

Thanks to Darkover for the trade. I didnt know Goose Island had it in em! Dark brown color with ruby tones. Thick and fluffy beige head and nice lacing. The aroma is full with malt, dark fruits and spices. Rich body with a smooth array of flavors, from sweet malt, plum, and banana to spices and hops. The finish is flavorful with yeast, and a bit of spicy alcohol. This is probably the best Goose Island beer out there.

I think this in one of the better American versions of a Belgian beer out there.  Classic Belgian aroma - earthy yeast, pepper, clove, plum, cherries, toffee, caramel.  Hazy ruby brown color, tan head.  Flavor isnt quite as complex as the aroma, but still very good.  The malt, toffee, and caramel combine with pepper and clove, while the fruitiness is much more subdued than in the aroma.  Sweet, but not cloying.  Medium body, medium-high carbonation, fluffy mouthfeel, slight warming.  Based on the 4-pack I bought, I think this beer is definitely underrated.

A delicious, sweet, candyish aroma seeps out and pervades the atmosphere the moment I uncap this ale, and now anticipation is high, and the race is on to get this taste down the throat and into the stomach...but first...
Appearance: hazy auburn hue, thick and caramelly, under a prodigious head of creamy, almost pudding-esque foam...looks great...smells? 
Divine! Toffee meets spices, nuts, vanilla, cocoa, ...weve got dessert on the way, here! Rather light, but not shy with flavor, big sweetness, in just the right doses. 
Taste: the same and then some. Rich, thick, lush texture, big, rewarding mouthfeel...this is some nice stuff! Flavor spends its time washing all over the senses, playing here and there, leaving traces and drops of deliciousness wherever it may. 
As a frequent fan of dubbels, I find no fault at all here, and in fact see this among the higher stratum. Ive enjoying many good brews from the Goose, and Im finally ecstatic to know that they can crank out something truly stellar! Thats what this is, to me, a big, malty, sweet, tasty, nearly decadent creation. Citric notes intervene near the end, and they play well with the other flavors. 9%? Didnt feel it at all, until...now...goodnight, ...

Bottle. Thanks to my Secret Santa for this. Cloudy amber color with a big head. Nice sweet malt aroma. Aroma is candy sugars, apple and some dried fruit. Taste is a lot of the same with some toffee. Nicely done.

Beer pours deep dark reddish amber with a dissipating tan colored head.  Aroma is deep and layered if not overly complex consisting of sweet malt, candied apples, alcohol.  Flavor is likewise malty with lots of candy sugar and a bit of alcohol burn.  Good, but doesnt rival any of the great Belgians.

Hazy brown/amber coloured body with a nice sized tan head. Aroma of pit fruit, caramel, toffee and malt-very nice and strong. Medium-bodied; Alcoholic kick up front-fig & pit fruit tastes with some spices noticeable. Aftertaste a bit better-not bad-just not great. Overall, a nice beer-definitely a good one to try if you can get your hands on it. Thanks to Mike (BBB63) for the trade on this one! I sampled this 12 ounce bottle on 29-May-2004 at the Eastern Shore in Virginia.

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2005 Bottle pours a deep murky caramel, medium off-white fizzly head, super strong carbonation, with attractive brewers lace.   Sweet malts, loads of caramel, yeasty/bready, with subtle hints of alcohol on the nose.   Forwardly sweet,  a bit malty, but the caramel aroma doesnt emerge in the flavor form.   In fact, it seems a bit hollow.   Body is okay, mouthfeel is lively and airy.   Warming finish, slightly grassy, slightly sweet, some apple skin.   Enjoyable aroma, but the flavor doesnt really follow suit.   Good nonetheless.   Thanks goes out to TChrome for the trade!

GABF 2004. Cloudy brown body and a tight velvety off-white head. Sweet and nutty brown sugar nose. More sweet brown sugar in the flavor. Highly carbonated palate. Little to hold my interest beside sugar and alcohol. Fair, but considerably less depth than expected.

Deep rust color.  almost real apple cider color.   excellent carbonation.  effervesent.   the taste is of apple, banana and caramel with a nice alcohol ending.   Very enjoyable.  Much more goes into this beer than most of their others.

9/14/04:  Bottle.  Belgian-candy-alcohol to the nose.  Peach-brown body with an off-white head (very minimal in size).  Slightly hazy.  Sweet candy sugar taste with other evidence of plum, caramel and alcohol.  Crisp finish.

The dark brown takes on a gorgeous ruby tone when held to the light. The head is a little small for style and is the faintest of khakis. The aroma is full of candy sugar and plums. Some toffee and a little tiny bit of banana. The flavor is pretty much the same with just a slight pepperiness from the alcohol. Really not a bad American-made Belgian strong, but the candy sugar flavor seems a little strong.
Thick Brick Red Coloring. Small Head.  Badgerben mentioned banana which is evident at the end.  Malts..Yeast.. Alcohol Fairly Hidden.. Very Decent Belgian.

Pours flacid and brown with a ruby hint. Apple spice in the aroma like apple butter and champagne yeasts. Carbonation is high but not as high as the sugar content. This baby is SWEET as can be. The flavor has toffee notes and hazelnut essence. All in all, a nice beverage and simple rendition of the style.

09.11.04  12oz bottle thanks to Bunkypop.  Thickly hazed, rusty orange color with spartan head (even when swirled).  Deep and rich aromas of fruity, bready malts, ripe apple and pear, and Bananas Foster still on fire - yes, the alcohol is very present on the nose, and very welcome.  This beer absolutely melts in the mouth - with each sip a fine effervescence spreads across the palate evolving into a velvety cream.  Flavors are soft and delicate, bubblegum and banana, slight pie spice, dried fig.  A cacophany of flavor subtlties keeps this brew from being supremely balanced, but it is still quite good.  Nice alcohol warmth makes me forget about the imperfections real quick-like.  Good stuff, thanks Steve!

Deep milky amber/brown with thick whip cream like head. Cherry, malt, cream, toffee,chocolate and light spice on the nose. Light prickle with creamy feel and lingering finish. Toffee, carmel, cherry, malt, tootsie roll, and cinnamon flavors. The finish lingers while the alcohol is well hidden. A great brew!

UPDATED: JUN 23, 2005 Pours a cloudy brown with a huge creamy tan head.  Nice story on the bottle as well.  Aroma is very malty. Flavor is very bready and fruity. Makes me think of banana bread.  There is some alcohol in the finish but not its mostly hidden quite well.  Fair to good but its missing some spice to it.

aroma of fruit and bread.  very fruity, malty, sweet and a little bit of a bitter, spicy finish.  i became aware of the alcohol about half way through, but this was still quite easy drinking for 9%.  i think i liked this better than the other belgian strong ive had from goose island, but that one was good as well.

UPDATED: AUG 24, 2009 Original Rating, September 10, 2004:  Pours a hazy and dark red color with a thin head.  Aroma of malt mixed with bread.  The taste is pretty run of the mill for this style: bread, yeast, malt.  There was a little hit of banana I found interesting.  Not bad. 7/3/7/3/14  Re-rating; Bottled April 4, 2009; Tasted August 24, 2009:  Dark murky brown color with a very thin head.  Strong malty aroma.  Lots of bread, caramel, and a little fruit.  Thick and chewy malt flavor.  More and more bread, grains.  Yeasty and fruity.  A hint of spice.  Not cloyingly sweet, but definitely finishes on that end of the spectrum.  Wonderful, and my prior rating is criminally low.

Cloudy ruby colored body, off-white fizzy/thin head that turns into a nice creamy ring. Aroma has a cherry-wine or port-like front, along with some apple and liquor. Fizzy yet sticky palate that brings some overripe and sugary apple, cherry, figs, and wood. Tis a bit sweet, but not obnoxiously so.

Big, fizzy, off-white lingering head.  Nice aroma of licorice, brandy, or raisins with an alcohol wash.  A bit cloudy red-brown. Initial metallic taste detracted (poor storage?), but luckily departed.  Hot taste of alcohol followed by cinnamon, cherries and other spices.  Feels like a party goin on in my mouth.  A really lively, conversation-filled party with well-to-do Alslatians and French snobs.  Finishes smooth and large.  Ripe plums and conac.
Orange in color. Decent head. Apple candy nose. Very sugary- hints if bananas. Slightly wheaty.

Fruity aroma, some banana.  Golden yellow with rainbows of color.  Good solid flavor--again fruity.  A quality palate with a frothing quality.  Very very enjoyable.  Id like a few more bottles of this.

UPDATED: DEC 14, 2004 Ruby body, numerous tendrils of bubles maintain a light tan head.  The aroma has mocha, oxidized apple and yeast.  The big sweet, yeasty flavor has a yeasty bready start with light strawberry and apple.  The flavor finishes on a dry note, featuring wood with honey sweetness.  The beers lightness reminds me of a Westy 8.  Fig and mocha elements at the start of the flavor as in the aroma.  Still, the beer seems "light and dry" as far as this style can be.  Alcohol notes in the finish.
(Bottle)  Pours a slightly cloudy light brown with a small off-white head.  Aroma of banana, caramel, alcohol, and yeast.  Complex balance of dried fruits, sweet malt, apple, and spices.
Bottle. Nose is straight bubblegum, alcohol, and banana. Sweet. Taste is yeast, bubblegum, banana, and CO2. Good, but too sweet. This looses overall points due to its sweetness.
Poured cloudy hazy amber with rich head...smelled fruity, bubble gum, bananas...very yeasty tasting...I think I detected artificial sweetner of some kind...cloying in the finish...

sweet yeasty sugary aroma of wood and earth. light brown color. expected belgian  taste, sweet chewy alcohol and apple flavor. finish is a touch hoppy that melds well with this beer but is still a little too sweet.

Pours a cloudy ruby brown color with a huge light brown head that sticks to the sides of my glass. Fruity sweet and spicy aromas, sugary plum and grape flavors, medium to full bodied with a crisp and carbonated mouthfeel, finishes with some brown sugar sweetness.

Dark brown color with a tint or red.  The head on top is a soft cream which holds a small size to it.  The aroma has a note of candy sugar, fig and molasses.  Flavor is a quite parallel to the nose.  Which you can equate to very pleasing.  Palate is rather viscous at first but ends with a small sting from the 9%.

Bottle: Good nose, fruity, apple cider, plum, butterscotch, rum. Hazy brownish orange color. Small to no head.  Sweet flavors  Brown sugar, rum, lite spice,banana, apple. Sticky sweet bubbly mouth feel. Warming. Fruity sweet dryish finish. ABV hits on the finish.Tasty Im starting to like this style more and more. Very enjoyable. Thanks Marinaro500
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: Bottle pours a dark hazy amber red with a small head.  The aroma is quite malty and of dark fruits.  The flavor is malt, dark fruits, and a minor hop blip.  The palate is rich, but also cleansing.  Overall, a pretty good effort.
UPDATED: SEP 5, 2004 Dark cloudy red color with a big beige head. Aroma of yeast and dark fruits. Flavor is pretty rich and sweet, with raisons and figs.

color is a virtually opaque deep amber. head is THICK beige and lasting. aroma is slight alcohol, lots of caramel malts, raisin. flavor is loaded with raisin, caramel malts, slight hoppy presence. this beer reminds me slightly of the hardys vintage ales.

Wow now this is something special to come from the folks at Goose Island. It remeinds me a lot of Bornems Dubble.  Really malty and rich with chocolate/cherry flavor.  Carbontaion is good, but could be bit more?  Opaque like a good scotch ale with all kinds of flavors that dance through the palat. I found this quite nice and the alcohol was present, but now where near obtrusive.

This beer defies category, as it is dark and yeasty - like a belgian brune, but without the dark fruit flavors of a dubbel or quad.  The flavor is predominately honey and pineapple - with some roasted chestnut.  Light fruits dont make this beer light, however, as there is a smokiness and weight of the malt that is evident in the best belgians.

12 oz bottle.  Hazy, muddy molasses-copper shade, lasting smallish head.  Sourdough, grapefruit, bitter orange and baked fruits in the aroma, banana-creme texture at the front of the flavor, very smooth and rich...cherry-port seems appropriate for the sweet-rich-alcoholic finish.  This is fairly close to an ABT, flavor-wise, and a good one at that.  I love it.

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2010 Bottle.  Nice copper color, wth a good off-white head.     Flavors and odors of ripe fruits.  Apple?  Banana?  Full body  and the carbonation was about right.  This is a very good Belgian Ale.

Pours a bit on the hazy side, and it is an amber color.  It is fairly well carbonated, and shows a tan head when roused.  I get aromas of alcohol, cherries, and malt.  As I smell deeper the dominant alcohol in the nose begins to die down and more of the fruitiness (raisin and fig, but the cherries certainly dominate) is able to peek out.  The taste is fruity up front and finishes with a  slight bit of spiciness.  There is quite a bit of sweetness left in this beer, it adds to the richness and picks up the fruit notes that are found in this beer.  This is pretty enjoyable and would probably age quite well.

Really a very nice offering from GI.  Im not sure how many stabs theyve taken at Belgian styles, but this one does pretty well.  A nice color, but the nose is fairly weak and lacks fullness.  Flavor is slightly bitter, but good.  Needs a few more elements to be top notch.
Hazy copper with a full, foamy beige head.  Pleasant aroma of sweet fruit, malt.  Oily feel in the mouth.  Full bodied.  Smooth.  Flavor was sweet and fruity and pleasant and rewarding.  Quite good.

UPDATED: SEP 19, 2004 Well not too bad if you like your Belgian strongs with only mild sweetness and a bitter aftertaste. It is a good beer similer to say Chimay blue but my taste run more to Duvel or Chimay red. Nice packageing and a good job. Not worth the price unless you cannot get real Belgian stongs by you. Aroma a little weak

This is the first bottled "premium" beer from Goose Island Ive seen in my area.  Pere Jacques poured ruddy orange-brown.  Medium light tan head persisted until the beer was gone and clumped in a manner suggestive of the presence of wheat malts.   Rich aroma of banana, apple peel (slight), earthy fruits and a twinge of wet socks.  Flavor began with sweet, lightly caramely candi (brown?) sugar, toast, and bready yeast flavors.  As the beer warmed a sweet, fruity (cherry) aspect developed as did peeks of banana.  Ethanol permeated the toasty finish.  Not the most complex Belgian Strong Ale but classy, rich, and interesting nonetheless.

this was a wild brew from goose island!  not what i would ever expect from them, and very tasty indeed.  very malty, slightly fruity and alcohol was somewhat noticable.   not a bad out from the big goose but not my favorite either.   leave belgian strong ales to well...belguim.  but nice try!

Malty aroma (like a doppelbock), dark amber color with a thin white head that diminishes quickly.  The malt flavor is rich, but is quickly overpowered by the heavy alcohol taste.  The finish has a slight sourness that is hard to get rid of.    It kind of reminds me of the aftertaste of a cough syrup.  This beer could be a bit smoother as well.  Typically Im a big fan of Goose Island, but this one is definitely not up to par.

UPDATED: DEC 23, 2005 Rerate.  I saved this beer for about 2 years, waiting until I graduated from college.  While this was originally the first belgian strong ale I ever had, Ive seen had a good deal.  On the second try, it is quite good.  Im not sure if it is because Ive had more of the style or the aging made it better but its good.

this is the first "belgian strong ale" ive ever had and i thought it was kinda gross.  it was kind of sophisticated because it changed flavors like 4 times over the course of the bottle.  the aroma was bad, like alcohol but it might have been my half indian friends old glass.

Nearly opaque dark brown, slight mahogany glow towards the bottom, a whipped and frothy smooth, dusty tan cap grows to about a half inch, poofs down slowly to a thin haze and sufficient collar. Lace is drippy, some big globs stick, but also drip back in after a while.

Aroma is a bit restrained at first, but pleasant with a nice fruity display of banana and raisin, bits of bready yeast, caramel, and a light interplay of alcohol proceeds within. Warmth brings it up a notch better which is accompanied by medicinal phenolic heat.

Taste is eager yet yielding of some inobtrusive raisin, dark grapes, banana, and plum. A bit vinuos in tang and alcohol, dark caramel seeps from underneath with a moderate chocolate sweeping just before the finish which gathers in slight dry leafy hops and alcohol spice with smaller hints of leftover fruits. Subtle, warm, with a classy flare of fruityness. Nice.

Feel is quite warm, well-rounded, firm, creamy fullish body, but theres a trustworthy fluffy texture that insues within the carbonation thats really nice. A well heated, covetous, complex body and character that kept me inticed the whole glass through.

 It was around mid-glass where it truly blossomed into its own and became quite nice. From there on in, this was a real treat. Not overly complex, but has a real nice relaxing quailty to it.

stem glass / dated 041604: hazy red brown body with peach highlight that lays under a big, tight, and lingering off-white head. it smells fruity, sweet, and spicy. it tastes fruity, sweet, and spicy. its very nice. it's mostly sweet and malty... a bit syrupy, but not cloying; a bit evident of alcohol, but not offensively so... medicinal? nearly. hmm, indeed... after having some IPAs a good pere jacques and steak hasnt tasted any better! it's fairly straightforward and very good! ("flavor will continue to develop over five years" !!!) perhaps i need to save a bottle for some years later...

Draught somewhere in Chicago:
This is a nice version of an Belgian ale. More sweet and malty than most Belgians and more fruity. Very nice and a pleasure as a substitution after 6 pints of IPA.

The beer after departing the 12 ounce brown bottle sets in the glass a hazy burnished copper with the head portly in size and a winsome light tan color, frothy in texture an as it dissolves the lace forms a thin sheet to cling to the glass. The aroma of banana, sweet malt seem to dominate with a slight hint of fusel alcohol to round it out, start is sweet and thick in malt, the top middling in its feel to the palate. Finish has an authoritarian acidic bite, the hops mild with the aftertaste vinous and extremely dry, the high ABV gives a warming to the tummy, a drinkable tis true.

Small little floatie colonies cavort about in the copper body. The head is a small tan ring around the edge of the glass. The aroma is sweet cherry, a lot like a cherry cough drops without the medicine smell. Not much else. Maybe a wee bit of some roasted malt. Sweet and fruity. I can not get my mind of the cough drop analogy. Quite sweet and one dimensional.  Syrupy and alcoholic. Especially the finish.

Tiny beige head atop a tiny-floatie-filled, otherwise clear copper body.  Aroma is syrup sweet, maraschino cherry.  Taste is quite sweet, cherry, alcohol, finishing moderate alcohol warming/burn.  Full body.

Bottle. Cloudy orange amber color with a tall creamy ecru head. Fruity acetic aroma. Hints of malt and sugar. sweetness overflows. Light toffee, dark candi, hint of maple and honey. Alcohol well hidden but too sweet. Granted it is not cloying, its just  sweet.. .

Bottle. Dark amber color with a thick tan head. Nose is full of fruit and yeast. As it warms, hints of banana come through. Flavor is dark fruit with some barnyard flavors. Alcohol is noticeable but not overpowering. Thick palate and wet finish.

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2005 Keith-Amber color with a thin white head that stays throughout the entire drink.  Rich and hearty belgian that is full of taste and begs to be sipped.  May be a winter beer, but I can drink this any time.
Eric-Bottle given to me by keith-april 2004 (almost a year old)  pours a deep amber hue with nice smooth off-white head.  aroma of candy sugar, spice, banana, brown sugar, like a rich double.  flavors are much like the aroma-big candy sugars, clove and even hops.  The hops are present, but never detract from belgian flavors.  finish is malty with slight burnt notes and lingering spices.  palate is firm and solid.  alcohol well hidden!  I guess this was veryhot when young.  cookie like finish-very nice!

A truly top-notch Belgian style, on par with even some of the Trappists. Nice, deep mahogany color. Big, creamy, off-white head formed of large bubbles. Darkly fruity nose with hint of winter spice and gentle whiff of alcohol. Creamy mouthfeel accented by very gentle carbonation. Rich and full flavored yet delicately complex. Tasty.

UPDATED: NOV 13, 2004 Color somewhere between honey and strong apple cider. Not much in the nose except some faint malt and fleshy fruit. dry and a hint of sweetness at the same time but more on the dry side.Aside frome the actual mouthfeel,the only thing I can taste is a hint of malt and mild fleshy fruits. Could be this was in its infant stage as the bottle was only 6 weeks old. Perhaps a sleeper to try again come the winter holidays.
UPDATE-Tried this again almost 6 mos later. No change,still subtle and boring. Glad I didnt stock up on this.

UPDATED: SEP 11, 2004 Pours a reddish-brown, about the color of apple cider, thin head, but thats expected. Yeast, bread, dark fruits? The yeast smell is heaviest.Taste is interesting complex. Lots of malt load with a balanced hop finish. Tastes like some sugar candy, soft fruits, some grape, banana, plum. Very tasty. Feels great in the mouth too! Excellent brew. Managed to find this at the Binnys in the Loop...

Bottle @ Goose Island Clybourne:  This wasn't on the menu, but after talking with the waitress she had some other beer options and this was one of them.  It was served in a wine goblet.  The beer pours a cloudy reddish-brown.  There was some head from a fast pour, but it was gone fairly rapidly.  There was a big, sweet nose:  yeasty, bread, some floral, some fruits with plums and raisins being most evident.  The taste was initially sweet, with a slightly sour aftertaste.  Some fruits and caramel to the taste. This made the traffic jam that I sat in to get there worthwhile!

Hazy copper color with a small off white head.  Very complex aroma of figs, nuts, honey, currant, yeast, chocolate and vanilla.  Taste was very dubbelish including dark fruits, cherries, and a slight alcohol burn.  This was very nice, thanks Floydicus!

Beautiful deep bright cherry red with some dark ambers, golds and oranges.  Bottle conditioned, VERY Hazy, but not muddy looking.  Small head, light tan, good amount of lacing.  Aroma is divine.  Fruity (bananas, nowhere as strong as some others noticed), lightly hopped and quite caramelly.
Begins medium sweet, lightly carbonated, smooth and lush.  Belgian candied sugars, light floral hops (interesting take for this style) and some moderately sweet caramel flavors.  Light orange curacao flavors on the finish mix with a touch of dry woodiness (from the hops) and some good clean yeastiness that lingers on a bit.  Consistency is way too thin for the style, but the flavor is simply amazing.  I actually found this to be relatively under-malted for a belgian strong, with a firm bitter hops presence and a good balanced yeast flavor.  Alcohol immensely well concealed.

One of the most attractive beers I have ever seen.  Reddish brown, dark and translusent.  Aroma of yeast and belgium candi.  That is it, not much flavor, pretty much sucks wind once you drink it.  Never had a beer like it, and I don't care to have another.

UPDATED: JAN 19, 2009 Pre-release bottle given away at the tasting below, Feb. 04, Tasted 4/19/05. Okay, the big banana taste has really settled down now. Its still pretty prominent, but I had to get pretty far down in the glass to be reminded of it. Instead there a big pile omalt here. Toasty and caramelly, with a fruity bubble-gummy aspect. Sticky, and with a fine alcoholic mouthfeel. Much better than my first impression.
Original rating, 2/8/04 from sampler at the breweryJacques, Jacques, Bo Baques, Banana, Fanna, Foe, Faques, Fee, Fie, Moe, Maques--Jacques
In other words, banana. Hits you in the nose as soon as your pour. Overwhelms everything else. Pours dark yellow under a thin head. Likeable, but a bit overdone.
UPDATED: JAN 22, 2004 Fruity, sticky, malt aroma. Straightforward bready, fruity, caramel flavor. Almost cloying sweetness and one-dimensional. Malted heavily, some fruit extract added?

Cloudy watermelon. Broken foam in the middle with a thick, light tan ring. Huge aromatic wall of richly sweet, fruity, earthy malts, plums, and pleasantly piney hops. Fruity esters are replaced by the phenols. Touches of rubbery, medicinal alcohol and black cherry. Soft, round body. Sandy, tiny-bubbled carbonation. Big cakey malt flavors coupled with a touch of medicine and mild acidity. Leathery malts, rubbery alcohol, and subdued esters mix with the dark fruit from the malts. Finishes medicinal, sharply alcoholic, and everlastingly chewy and malty with some underlying dark fruity esters. Lingers with leathery, plummy malts and medicine. This ones all about the malt. Solid effort, but far from awe-inspiring. Serve at cellar temperature in order to suppress the massive sweetness.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Bottle at Brewpub: They seem to keep this in bottles hidden under the counter and only reveal that they have it if you nag the daylights out of them.  A rather sweet, malty Belgian Ale effort that exceeded my expectations.  The alcohol is quite well-hidden and I found it sweeter than many Belgian brews.  Good.

UPDATED: JAN 15, 2004 Mahoganey color with a creamy light brown head. Aroma is of plums, rasins, caramel and toasted malts. Flavors of plum and some touches or roasted malts up front. Some hops come through and there a caramel like taste that lingers on through the finish. Some more hops come through in the finish as well as a dry toasty feel. Quite nice. Thanks to Jokes for this one.

FOAM series and available in bottle at brewery only while supplies last: Ruby hue with small white head and some lace. The aroma hints of earthy Belgian yeast esters, sweet bread, applesauce, plumcake, and toffee. The taste is very sweet and fruity. A minor sourness and those yeasty characteristics  provide the undertones for the flavors. A well place dash of spices are detected towards the finish. The alcohol was well hidden until the very end. The mouthfeel is soft and well rounded. The beer has now been aging for 6 months and appears to have started to become quite smooth and yummy.

Darker bronze with fluffy off-white head.  Nose is very estery with strong notes of biscuit and flour.  Very appley and fruity, as well as biscuity, somewhat dry on the tongue. Alcohol is well masked.  Not as complex as the also sugary Chimay Blue, but still a very nice gift from Goose Island...but is this the Goose Island Blue????  I don't remember that one well...

Thanks again to BBB63 for this bottle fine brew.  It poured a large head of finely sized foamy mostly diminishing light brown colored bubbles that left behind a good lace and a carbonated hazy brown colored body.  It was interesting to not that the bubbles from the carbonation appeared to be suspended within the thick body of this brew.  It had a very nice caramel malt aroma and flavor.  The mouthfeel was smooth, vinuous and slightly tingly with a slight afterbite.

Thanks to BBB63 for giving thedm and I a bottle of this fine Belgian Strong Ale, which by the way, is one of my favorite beer styles and it is one that definitely did not disappoint me. It poured a medium sized tan head with fine-small bubbles that completely dissipated during my rating. The body had fizzy carbonation, cloudy and the hue was amber/copper. The nose consisted of caramel, fruitiness and alcohol. The flavor was sweet, fruity, caramel and alcohol from start to finish. The mouthfeel was pleasantly smooth and light-medium bodied. There was a fair amount of lacing on the sides of my glass. I would recommend this Belgian to anyone who enjoys drinking Belgian Strong Ales.
Thanks to Jokes for sending me this bottle. Very good beer. NIce robust stong flavor to it.
Medium to dark amber.  Sweet banana aroma.  Big alcohol up front and through the nose.  Nice and robust, sweet banana and coriander flavors, and very rich.

Sampled at Great Taste of the Midwest. Yellowish reddish color. Huge thick, off-white head. Very attractive. Faint molasses aroma, similar to a doppelbock. Very rich flavor, good, sweet, hints of cherry. Reasonably smooth for a high alcohol beer.
Deep ruby color.  Strongly estery aroma, fair bit of hops as well.  Thick on the tongue, a bit cloying.  Very estery flavor, a bit of hot alcohol.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2007 Bottle... RBSG2003... Goose Islands tribute to Chimay Bleu, I believe.
Cloudy, ruby/copper/mahogany hue. Mid-sized, khaki-colored, fizzy head.
The nose is of caramel and rock candy, various fruits and alcohol.
The flavor is of sweet caramel and fruit (apple and pear). Well-balanced and grassy.
Full-bodied with an oily mouthfeel and fizzy carbonation. Short, astringent, lightly sweet finish.

I saw a comparison of this beer to Chimay written in a local paper.  The best I can do is compare this beer to the Chimay that I know; the Chimay of the past year and a half.  Say, you Chimay nay-sayers, that Chimay were to deteriorate from it's previous state in a fashion that represents the recent demise of the beer.  That is the best comparison I can make for this beer.  Pours a nice amber, copper color with little head.  The aroma is simply amazing.  Sweet and delectable, the fruits dominate the nose.  Simply a hint of what is to come.  The flavor, however, does live up to the nose.  Sharp to the point of being harsh, the flavor is unrefined.  Strong apples and sweet candi sugar seem to dominate throughout.  I think a little time would provide this beer the opportunity to mature and mellow and become really incredible.  Darker fruits and a "ripeness" would let itself well to this concoction.  Give it the opportunity and time will heal all wounds.
A very good attempt at Chimay Blue. One of my favorite beers from the recent brewpub visit. Had one of these and a dopplebock and had trouble walking to the train stop.
Dark plum, ruby color.  Has a really dark plum, raisin flavor with some sugar.  Warm alcohol in the finish.

dark petrified wood color, bubbles floating to the top and making neat tan designs..malty & yeasty aroma with hints of sugary port wine..Big bubble-gum yeastiness in the flavor with some grassy bitterness and maybe hints of alcohol molested nectarines..

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2004 Growler:Well,this sure didn't let me down. Dark brown with a creamy,short lived,tan head. Aroma is slightly,hoppy,malty but intensely spicy/fruity from the yeast.Thick,rich,beer with a soft,smooth,palate. Sweet,bready,malts,hefe-like fruitness and spice from yeast with a light acidity to it.The finish is spicy from the yeast and moderately hopped(herbal).The beer is somewhat hoppy but doesn't seem overdone. I like it.

This beer just strikes me a little funny. If you're going to make a Chimay knock-off, why hop the shit out of it? It's not bad stuff--has a decent, slightly spicy, rather fruity ester profile that is reminiscent of its inspiration, but the hop profile is way off.

UPDATED: SEP 11, 2005 Hop Jacques: On tap at the 2005 Great Taste of the Midwest, dry-hopped version of Pere Jacques:  Pours a hazy copper bronze with a thin, off-white head.  Citrusy hoppy, bready aroma has a well balanced tart, complex Belgian yeastiness.  Starts sweet, hoppy, and malty with lightly tart, citrusy finish.  Slightly metallic, but well-balanced and interesting.  I wish they would bottle this one.

Bottled on 04/16/04, sampled on 8/7/05: Pours a rich dark copper brown with a thin cream-colored head.  Richly sweet Belgian caramel malty aroma has some bready yeasty character.  Body starts with a nice, sticky sweetness and lots of dark fruity raisiny complexity.  Very well-balanced and enjoyable, an authentic Belgian clone. 

On tap at Clybourn as "Blue" on  2/9/2003: Dark brown color with small creamy head.  Bready, yeast aroma with a complex fruity and sweet palate.  Alcohol is somewhat evident.  Syrupy mouthfeel, but still well balanced.  Not quite Chimay, but close.

Yeasty and spicy aroma, typical for style.  Wonderful clone of Chimay, once it warms up this comes remarkably close.  CLoves, spice, banana, nice balance!  Alcohol present at the end.  Very enjoyable.
